I have mixed feelings about EA and The Sims 3, honestly I consider The Sims 3 a much better game than the Sims 4, though the Sims 4 has a lot more polish (coming from that game, you should know what you're getting into with this one) when it comes to bug fixes and overall quality. The Sims 3 is a buggy fucking mess that barely works half the time, but I have to admit, the few hours that it does, I have such a fun time. It's why I'm so angry when it inevitably crashes, because I've had more fun playing this game on both my computer and god forbid my ps3 than I ever did on the hundreds of hours I slaved over in Sims 4. I have been playing Sims since Sims 1, and Sims 3 is my favorite.  You get a lot more out of the EP and Stuff packs.  
Plus, every now and then Steam runs some specials on the game so you can get it cheaper.  The building and Create a Sim is great too.  I feel like Sims 4 is better at building, but for gameplay Sims 3 is better.  Which you can still build great, amazing items in the Sims 3, others and I have done it.   I am happy that they now offer Sims 4 on Steam, it's about time.  But I personally like Sims 3 best.  But with all things, if you want more gameplay you will have to buy some of the EP and Stuff packs.  I personally have about 11, including base game.  But I am more story based in my games and want packs based on how I tell stories.   

Also, make sure your computer can handle it.  I have always upgraded my graphic's card on any computer that I played on.
If your computer is slower, than the game will lag.  And it depends on how many EPs and Stuff packs you add.  I personally have a lot of CC too, and play in a lot of CC worlds.  
I started playing this game on my older computer in 2009.   But since about 2014, I have added some extra gameplay into my Sims by adding CC.  
However, you don't have to add CC, custom content, to play.  
The Sims worlds/ neighborhoods are nice, and even right now, I have a game going in Sunset Valley, and I am playing with pre-made game characters who live in the town.  Right now, on my newer computer, I have 8 neighborhoods I'm playing in.
Just remember the more you add to your game the more the computer uses, think Graphic's Card.  I know for Me, upgrading my Graphic's Card helped.  But it's really up to your computer and how it will play.  I'm not computer savvy and I couldn't tell you the best Graphic Card to get.  I would normally tell my guy that I want my game to run good/great with the game, and he would find the graphic's card for me to help with game play.  I do know I have it maxed on my 2018 computer. 
 
Another nice feature to Sims 3 is the color wheel, which allows you to color your sims, furniture, buildings, and anything else to any color you want.   I love the color wheel.
But again, remember the more you add the more you use.   Like any game, it has its good and bad aspects.  What game doesn't?
There is just so much to do in Sims 3.  I spend hours just building a sim or house alone.  But that's what I like.  I spend hours creating stories about my sims, but that is what I like, and Sims 3 allows me to do all of that.   
And that is why Sims 3 is still my favorite.

I love the sims 3. I grew up watching the game and never had my hands on it until now, after being so disappointed by years of the Sims 4. The game runs smoothly on my PC with just the base game. The Sims has always been one of my favorite games of all time. The Sims 3 is by far my favorite version!

Pros: The Sims 3 is definitely an improvement from the Sims 2 and is, in my opinion, the best of all 4 games. The lore is deep and families from the Sims 2 are back. There is so much customization when it comes to building lots and adding clothes to your sims. The game also has music from real artists translated into Simlish for the simmer's pleasure. There are a ton of personality traits, aspirations, and I love the biography option. The player has so much creative choice and there are quite a few unique features that other sims games don't have. Sims react more realistically to life events than in the Sims 4 and it's an open-world, so you're not staring at a loading screen every time your sim leaves the house. The build and buy modes have a wider variety of textures with more customization, angling, and furniture. The settings menu itself has a lot of customization and preferences to offer, including changing your sims' lifespans. If you have the pets expansion, you can actually play as your pets, unlike in the Sims 4 where pets are NPCs. The game offers a tutorial for new players to help them navigate it's many features and also provides a small guidebook. You can also look up tips online. There is a social feature where you can message, friend, and like the posts of other simmers as well as post your own content. As a writer, I sometimes use this game to act out my stories and bring them to life.

Cons: The game isn't complete without buying expansion packs. This has always been a problem with the sims games as players have been urged from the very beginning to spend money on additional content. The game is also very glitchy and hasn't been updated in years due to the fact that EA is instead focusing on more recent projects (like the Sims 4.) The base game itself doesn't have a wide variety of clothes and hair styles and can get boring after a while. I've had to reinstall the game more than once due to bugs. The quality of the game is typical of it's time, but is considered outdated and low now. The interaction between the sims and objects could also use some improvement, especially since sims have a larger space bubble and therefore can't walk as freely, unlike in the Sims 4 where they can pretty much go wherever they want. The game also uses sliders instead of clicking and dragging, but this is mostly because that kind of feature hadn't really been introduced in video games yet and was a very new concept when this game was released. If you're a fan of sliders, this may be a good thing, but if you prefer clicking and dragging, you won't see any of that here. The sims' fears from the Sims 2 don't exist in this game. The game stores memories and life events, but the sims can't talk about them and are not as affected by them as they are in the Sims 2. It's also harder to play without using a mouse.

Tips and side-notes: Although this game is available on console, I recommend downloading it on PC as the controls are a lot easier and it'll be easier to type commands as well as other texts. When installing mods, test them out as sometimes files can conflict and become corrupted. You can view your downloaded content in the launcher under "Downloads." If you need technical support, since EA no longer provides it for this game, I recommend diving into the sims forums. Often times you'll find people experiencing a similar problem and there are experts who can help you out. I also recommend getting expansion packs while they're on sale. If you like the game, there are a number of Discord servers you can join that also provide technical support.

Overall, this is a good game and I love it. Cheers-

While I haven't actually put 500 hours of playtime on this account, I'v probably put 2,000+ hours into it over all the different accounts and computers I've played it on over the years. Leaving the launcher open racks up playtime for some reason.

I'm pretty sure this is one of my favorite games. It's the sims, so you already know if you're going to love it or hate it. I'm going to focus on a few key points though, since I believe it is best played in a certain way.

-DLC and prices
Yes, there is a lot of DLC and it is expensive. A lot of people are disgusted at the idea of spending hundreds on a game to get the full experience. I will tell you, as someone with a lot of history with this game, owning all the expansions is not advisable. The game becomes unstable, bugs multiply, sims become borderline bipolar in their actions and there's so much happening and so much to keep track of that you'd have to play a VERY long game to see it all in one sim's lifetime.
Pick and choose what DLC is interesting to you. Otherwise, just play the base game; it's very playable without any additional content and you're able to download tools to create custom neighborhoods and clothing for sims with little effort.

-Mods
The modding support is cool and can help the game, but I prefer playing without mods. For quite a while I used mods simply to enhance game stability and longevity. After a while though, I found that game actually ran worse and was less stable when using them. They prevented a lot of prevalent bugs and issues, but I've personally experienced a lot fewer serious issues on a vanilla setup. Your millage may vary is all I'm trying to say.

-"The best" setup
As I said, pick and chose your DLC and mods carefully, but I've found the game shines the most with the following:
No mods
Generations, Ambitions, Pets, University and Seasons
Full autonomy for sims and pets and a long lifespan with default values
Graphics to max and I prefer to run in windowed at 1280x720 so I can watch videos or peruse reddit while playing

Currently on a save of 20 hours and haven't had a crash or major issue beyond some stray horses clipping into my sim's house one time. moveobjects on fixes that in an instant and beyond that I'm bug free.
Every expansion I listed all synergize well together and really have a sim-focus to them. 
Generations expands each life state so they're detailed and interesting and have obstacles depending on the specific sim. 
Ambitions expands job and career opportunities allowing your sim's career to be as in-depth and micromanaged or as simple as you like, along with proper self-employment.
University allows sims to attend university whilst not aging, giving them a big head-start in careers as well as just a fun time for certain sims. Also, smart phones.
Pets adds in the furry creatures we all know and love. They're a burden in real life and they're a burden here too, but you love them for it.
Seasons adds in weathers and holidays and festivals and aliens, (for some reason,) adding great variety to each day and year in a sim's life.

All of this allows the game to run very smoothly with the fewest bugs and issues. So long as you save often, you could find yourself playing in a single town for potentially years. As nice as the rest of the games in the series are, this one still shines the brightest to me.

[h1]If you plan on getting it I recommend the following:[/h1]

[b][list]
    [*]Buy it on a sale [i](Especially if you get it with DLC's..)[/i]
    [*]Speaking of DLC's, i'd say you grab a few because they increase the playability a lot, but not too many because there are some that are quite insignificant and may increase lag, as the game is poorly optimized
[/list][/b]

[h1]What DLC's to get then?[/h1]

I personally recommend these five as the absolute best, and pretty much essential (in order from most to least important):
[b][list]
    [*]Seasons
    [*]Generations
    [*]Ambitions
    [*]Pets
    [*]Late Night
[/list][/b]

*I would also throw [b]Supernatural[/b] in there but only if you're into the whole paranormal aspect of it. I think its super fun.

Already reviewed but time to update it, 

Cons - Price, this game is too bloody expensive for such an old title that never gets an update, last update was 12th November 2015. and yet the expansions and Stuff Packs are about $30 au each with 21 packs in total including the Base Game, makes this probably the most expensive decade old game in the history of games. they should have these listed at half the retail price they are now at least. I honestly cannot think a single player game out there of the same age that costs anywhere near the same price as.

BUT

Pro's  - Gameplay, honestly as a game this is still well worth playing, this steam sourced version works better on my old PC than the Origin Client setup. I have a dated 1st Gen i5 a 2nd Gen i5 and a i3 laptop and the game runs fine on all three with 8GB/16GB and 4GB ram, all of these are DD3, and running Windows 10 on Graphics below the Nvidia 7 series GPU's. 
I strongly recommend using this game on a system with a good Hard Disk that is no more than half full, I find performance issues appear once the Hard Drive it is on starts to struggle with all the data its handling and storing, I use an old spare HDD in my PC just for the Sims 3 and 4, and this works perfect for me, with all my expansions and CC Mods installed. 


So in the end, Recommend the game, and I recommend buying it when on sale. it does tend to go down to a rather nice price when on sale here.

I would like to preface this review by pointing out that obviously, this review is based merely on my opinion.

Pros:
- Great graphics
- Open world
- Easily moddable (although not as easily moddable as sims 2)
- Enjoyable even with CC or mods (Unlike its successor)
- Fun
- Colour wheel
- Story progression (even for inactive households)
- WAY better than sims 4
- Cheaper than Sims 4 (especially when you consider the fact that Sims 3, even in its base game is a complete game, while sims 4 after 700+ is still not a complete game)
- Traits (which adds more personability to your characters)
- Booby slider

Cons:
- Can get laggy (especially in Isla Paradiso, which unfortunately also happens to be the most aesthetically pleasing out of all the worlds)
- When you sum up the cost, it's quite a hefty price (so I'd probably recommend you buying it while on sale, or perhaps skipping on buying possibly unnecessary DLCs)
- Characters can look both pretty and odd at the same time (if that makes sense)
- I personally, don't feel like I can attach myself to sims 3 sims as much as I attached myself to sims in sims 2. I feel like things like the cutscenes, made sims 2 a little bit more fun, but that's just me.

The Sims 3 takes a fresh approach on it's classic simulation. Adding an open world concept that really brings the game to life. Customization is endless and the game play provides an interactive experience to players leading to hours of fun. 

My only complaint is the game is laggy, this is a known issue of the Sims 3 and is highly dependent on how many DLC and packs you add along with custom content. Certain packs such as Island Paradise are know to crash easily.

I wish there was a middle option between 'Recommended' and 'Not Recommended' because that's where I would put TS3. I've played The Sims series since the original game as a kid. I've done around 1000 hours of TS3, and it's a great game for sure. I haven't played TS4 and I don't want to, because I know it has all of the same issues that frustrate me about every instalment of The Sims.

Firstly, it is not worth the price. I bought the game and all DLCs when they were discounted at 65% off. At full price I believe it would have been over AU$450. It's currently AU$600 at full price, so the price has gone up by 33% since I bought it all those years ago, and the game is over 10 years old. There are far better games out there for that much money.

The other problem I have with The Sims in general is game performance (i.e., lagging and bugs). Lagging in long-term games has been an issue since TS2 and it's worse in TS3 (and just as bad in TS4 from what I hear). Every one of my playthroughs has become unplayable after a certain point due to lag. It doesn't matter if your machine smashes the (ten-year-old) spec requirements. There are fixes you can make, mods you can install to "manage" it, but like a terminal illness it will eventually get to a point that is unbearable. And why should you have to do routine maintenance on your games or install mods to keep them working properly anyway? (Sidenote of gratitude, though: If it weren't for the legends at NRaas, my playthroughs would have been much shorter.)

Overall, it's a great game and I don't know of any other life-simulation game like it (more than happy to hear about any). But it has only gotten LESS great as time has gone on when you consider all the other games out there with fewer performance issues and available for a fraction of the price.

The Sims 3 is a pretty alright sandbox game to screw around in. If you were to ask my preteen self, I would have told you it was complete trash before playing it for another fifteen hours or so -- so, basically, it was one of my favorite games at the time. With the power of hindsight, I can accurately judge its best and worst merits.

[b]The Good:[/b]
+ A first (and, unfortunately, only at this time) for the series, each map in The Sims 3 is a small Open World, which complements the Sandbox nature of the series while adding new twists on its own. The majority of my time with The Sims 3 as a preteen was spent with the Showtime expansion which, while not very good, has a decent enough map that makes good use of the new mechanics that were added to the game. Because of that, I can't really say what my favorite maps are, but there are a few good ones in there
+ The amount of possibilities provided by the sandbox nature of The Sims cannot be ignored and it's no different in 3. Become the president of the world, have over 100 babies, or die in a Macaroni and Cheese induced house fire. The choice is yours, and it never disappoints.
+ The ability to customize each article of clothing, furniture, and otherwise purchasable items -- also a first and only for the series -- gives more options for customization in an already customizable experience.
+ Ten years later, The Sims 3 mostly holds up on a graphical level. Obviously, some things are dated by today's standards (texturework, every time a Sim is in bed), but a lot of it still looks really pleasant.
+ Mods are supported right out of the box. While mod support isn't as great as it is in 4 (oddly enough, one of the only saving graces for that game), there are still a ton of mods that add a lot to the experience. Add in a gun, allow your Sims to have casual sex with complete strangers consequence free, or do what my 13 year old self did and--

[i]Note to self: when accessible memory wipes become a thing, have more than one.[/i]

[b]The Bad:[/b]
- There isn't a whole lot of content in the base game. There's not enough to say this is a major issue, but you'd be a fool to not snag an additional expansion pack with your purchase.
- While each map being an Open World is cool, the sacrifices needed to make it a possibility are disappointingly understandable. Things like work and school are just buildings that your Sim disappears into and cannot be explored by the player. This leaves a lot up to the imagination -- great for a 13 year old, but boring to anyone older.
- Performance can be more on the iffy side at times. Especially if you have a lot of mods installed, expect some hefty lag every now and then.

[b]The 'So Bad TikTok's Algorithms Would Hide It And Get In Trouble' Ugly:[/b]
[i]Sorry if that comes off as circlejerk-y[/i]
-- Some expansion packs are nice, but seven years after the very last expansion packs were released, I can say: they are not worth $379.81. Holy shit, if you want to talk about excessive monetization in Video Games, The Sims is the perfect series to center that discussion around. The best I can say about 3 is that there are no loot boxes as those weren't the hot topic for greedy publishers at the time, but there are still microtransactions via SimBucks (at least I think that's what they were called. I can't be bothered to actually look it up because I just don't care). These are a little excusable, in that they also gave players the opportunity to buy new maps with additional content that wouldn't have been big enough for a full blown expansion pack. But, even then, those maps aren't sold on the Steam page or anywhere else outside of the in-game currency. Once EA stops allowing people to spend on these things (more than ten years after the game came out and three years off of being ten years since the last expansion packs), the only way these bits of newer content will become accessible is through piracy. Thankfully, the system is so thanklessly thrown in that if one chooses to go down that path, all they need is an official file that interfaces with the game's launcher to install the content. I don't know if calling that lazy scratches the surface of how embarrassing that is. Disregarding that, the actual expansion packs are split into three camps across a spectrum: solid, solid But Unnecessary, Stuff Packs, and Whatever The Fuck That Katy Perry Thing Was. Solid packs (Late Night, Supernatural, University Life, Into the Future) alter the gameplay in either drastic or noticeable ways. They could have been included in the base game, but knowing that not every game can be super content rich at launch, are understandable exclusions. Solid But Unnecessary packs are ones that alter the gameplay in ways that would have been great to see in the base game and not a separate expansion pack. The two biggest examples I can think of for this are Pets and Seasons. Then you have Stuff Packs. Recall that one of the most hilarious and deadpan game reviews ever written comes from a piece on a Sims 2 Stuff Pack and, really, you shouldn't need much more to go off of. All they really add is cosmetic stuff, which wouldn't be so bad if they were downloadable only packs for five to ten bucks a pop and not currently $20 and released as retail products at launch. Then you have the Katy Perry incident. I do not wish to speak about this, other than that it's not available to buy on Steam and things should stay that way.

All in all, I would recommend picking up The Sims 3 on a sale. It's less refined than 4 is in some areas, but don't mistake that as me extolling one over the other. In terms of content, there's no contest between the two games. That said, if you would like to spend [b][u]700 FUCKING DOLLARS[/u][/b] on DLC alone, go ahead and try out 4.

TL;DR If you like casual games and love being able to customize things (maybe you often spend 1hr+ in character create screens, like me?), stop wasting time and just get this game already. It's what you're looking for and, definitely buy this one, over 4. The graphics aren't as nice, sure but a lot of what is overpriced dlc in 4 are just base game features in The Sims 3. 

If you're brand new to The Sims as a series, it's basically just playing house. You make a Sim, choose the house they live in, have them look for a job, go downtown and make friends, hang out with said friends, etc. What I personally find incredibly engaging about the series is the designer aspect of it. I love being able to design my Sims clothes, what they wear when going somewhere formal, casual, etc.. Not only that, but being able to design a house, from the ground up that other sims can move into or even my own Sim, someday. There's just so much in these games that can be customized.

This is the best Sims game in the series, but it's not great. The game itself is pretty good, but the way it's programmed forces me to give it a negative review. Maxis is known for making broken games. There's issues with it recognizing quad-core systems, overloading and causing error code 12, and the way it renders objects makes the game literally eat itself the longer you play.

It's an unoptimized, unstable mess, and it's been ripped to SHREDS with DLC.

But hey, at least it isn't Sims 4.

The sims 3 is the best out of the series and the high point before the downhill trend.

With a few choice DLC's that let you piecemeal what addons you want and some fixes to keep it running well its both feature rich and fun to play for hours and hours, The lack of loading screens and seamless transitions keeps you popping to different areas of town or home to plan things to do or just to check up on your household.Your Sims themselves will constantly keep a smile on your face as you see them go about their daily lives.

The DLC's are clearly overpriced but are worth picking up on a steam sale and know you're going to need to look up some fixes and a mod or two so the game doesn't break down on you over time.

I'd recommend to pick up University Life, Seasons, Pets, Generations to go with the base game.ALSO IMPORTANT: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1131162350 This guide to help you get the game working and keep it working.

Overall it's the must have of the series and plays better than it's newer counterpart (The Sims 4) which i'd say avoid unless you absolutely love this kind of gameplay.

The game itself is great.
There is allot of content to play around with, and the ~ $10/dlc was reasonable on release for the volume of content added.
Then EA fucked their own release of sims 4, upped the price by 3X on a 10 year old game, and to this day refuse to allow it to go on sale.

Two wrongs here seem to balance the chequebook, and therefore make a right in the eyes of EA execs.
I am not an executive, and see the price of the sims 3 + DLC (~$550 at time of writing) as outrageously and prohibitively expensive.
LET ME BE CLEAR: it has been - 11 YEARS since release - the whole package is worth maybe $50.

My recommendation is to buy the base game to support the developers at a reasonable price tag, but pirate the DLC.
Its been cracked and readily available for over half a decade, there is no reason whatsoever to pay $27 for "outdoor living stuff"

Your Sim can travel from house to middle of city, anywhere without loading screen [unlike Sims4, where just going from one small area in the park to 20meters away will require loading screen and wait time] Sims3 also has the rest of the townies doing their own business at the same time, so you can just view another building and watch other sims doing interesting things including demonstrations, live bands, reading in park, and countless more. I recommend  these expansions too : Seasons, Late Night, Supernaturals, and University Life.

Sims 3 should be the start of your Sims collection... if you don't already have one. You can totally get a feel for the game and the add-on DLCs are a good value when they are on sale. This is definitely a worthy game to have in your collection because once you master this one, you can always move on to the next Sims in the series. Either way, this Sims is one of those iconic games for a generation of people. It's worth to get.

The Sims 3 is a great game.   Though it has aged a bit, a lot of issues can be fixed with a few mods if you are okay with it.  Also, I recommend you wait for a sale, as everytime one happens with any of these items, it's always 75% off.

I wouldn't recommend any expansion in particular, as each of them adds content in a pretty specific area, but each one is very thorough with the amount of additions in that area.  Like fantasy/horror?  Try Supernatural.   Enjoy Sci-Fi?  Look for Into the Future.   You want your Sim to rise to fame?  Late Night and Showtime have you covered.  However, there is one exception to my "I wouldn't recommend any expansion in particular" rule.  If you can buy one, I highly recommend Generations, as it basically adds loads of content for any playstyle, whether you want to make as many Generations as possible, or live as your one and only Sim forever.  Whether magical or technological, Generations can support any playstyle.

Whatever expansion you buy, above all this game is good... but it might need some assembly with mods.  Nraas Overwatch and Nraas ErrorTrap are a must download.

Even in 2019 -- ten years after release -- and despite having the backing of Electronic Arts, the second largest game studio in the world, this game is an unplayable, buggy mess. 

My computer (Intel i7-8086K plus NVIDIA 1080Ti) is more than capable of handling GTA V with all of the settings maxed out. But somehow The Sims 3 from 2009 has brought my computer to its knees?

Let's quickly list all of the issues:[list]
[*]Whenever I launch the game, it also launches an Electronic Arts / The Sims 3 game launcher that runs hidden in the background, and the launcher continues to run even if I quit The Sims 3, and somehow the launcher uses ~20% of CPU even if The Sims 3 is no longer running, and the launcher prevents me from turning off my computer, and the only way to exit the launcher is to kill the process via Task Manager
[*]Game performance degrades over the course of a session; eventually the performance slows down so much that it doesn't matter whether I have the game set to 1x speed or 3x speed, because time will pass at 1x speed either way
[*]Weird in-game bugs show up; the most memorable was when my sim cooked waffles and set them down on the counter and somehow the game registered the waffles as a book about logic, and when I clicked on the waffles I only could see a grayed-out option to read the logic book, and eventually I had rotting waffles on the kitchen counter that I couldn't do anything about
[*]On maybe 10% of work days, my sim's carpool for work doesn't show up (but I still get in trouble for missing work)
[*]Sometimes, other sims invite my sim to their house, or to their party, but when I look around the neighborhood I don't see any house with the sim who invited me over living in it
[*]It takes about 60 seconds to save the game
[*]It takes anywhere from 60 seconds to ten minutes to load the game
[*]My most recent save will not load -- the game crashes every time I try -- so I guess my save file is corrupted and all of my progress is gone
[*]All of the aforementioned issues persist whether I run the game in compatibility mode (Windows XP SP3) or run it natively on Windows 10[/list]

So anyway.

Electronic Arts is asking you to pay four hundred dollars in total to buy The Sims 3 and all of the DLCs. And yet, since 2013, Electronic Arts has not invested one dollar in fixing bugs or patching The Sims 3 to ensure consistent performance on newer versions of Windows and on newer PC hardware. 

Please don't buy this game -- please don't reward Electronic Arts for selling a broken game for $400. Honestly, Steam should consider pulling The Sims 3 from their store if nobody is on deck to make sure that this game still runs on modern hardware. A brief glance at the Steam discussions page will reveal just how many people like me are unable to get the game to run acceptably. Numerous people on the discussions page insist that you need to install unofficial fan-made patches before the game will run well. Steam should not be selling a game where you need to install unofficial fan-made patches to un-break the otherwise broken game.

This is a classic, and in my opinion better than The Sims 4. I will say this and the expansions are still very pricey (especially considering how OLD this game is), but I've got extremely low expectations of EA and the things that they are willing to do to their customers. I will never ever ever buy a sims game and then pay $40 an expansion for ~$10 worth of content.

Anyways.

I've been playing this since the year it came out (I was in 7th grade), and I feel like it has aged extremely well. Sure, there are obvious signs of its age, but the main thing that keeps me playing this over The Sims 4 is its open-world feel. You don't have to load every single time you shift from one lot to another.  The entire map operates regardless of whether you are looking at it or not, and it's cool to be able to shift over and stalk people who are working out in the gym, just because you can. 

ALSO, the ability to put custom textures on everything is amazing and I can't believe they removed it. Instead of being limited to literally three colors when you buy something (clothes, furniture, ect), you have literally unlimited creative freedom because you control the texture that is being applied to the surface. Want your couches to be made out of metal? Sure. Want a plastic suit? Why not.

This is much cheaper than The Sims 4 and still a very good game. I especially recommend this if you are planning on buying expansions, because you can get these at a much more reasonable price (when they are on sale) than The Sims 4 expansions.

As you can see, I put a lot of time in here, and let me give my 2 cents worth.

When I bought this game, I got it in a bundle that includes Base game, Generations, Pets, and Seasons. On sale it was about 12 dollars CDN I think? Regular prices were 20 dollars base game or a DLC, but on sale, they dropped it to 5 dollars each. Pretty reasonable deals, I bought a couple DLCs, Late Night and University Life, and have been considering others. 

But sometime in the last year, not sure when, someone decided it was a good idea to raise the prices 7 dollars each, and get rid of the bundle that was a REALLY good way to get someone into the game. I would NEVER have bought this game without that bundle's existence, and frankly I don't think it's worth paying out the kind of prices that they're demanding. I also haven't seen any sales since the price hike.

My thoughts are that maybe they made the prices so horrific here in order to make the also expensive Sims 4 more attractive and maybe get more sales there. Kind of a scummy thing to do if that's the case.

Thoughts on the Game:
The combo of generations, seasons, and pets really made the game a great experience out of the gate for me, and you don't even really need much more to have a lot of fun with the game. There's some pretty decent autonomy by the sims, and that's without mods. With mods you could probably improve your experience, although I never experimented much in that regard (even with that playtime). Also, the world is one big open sandbox which is great. The one major downside is the extremely long loading times, when you start up and load your save or start a new city. It's not too bad once you're actually playing, except if have University dlc and you go to university, in which case you'll have an even longer loading screen until you get there. You'll also have some glitched sims at times, but if you use the in game command menu there's a command to reset a particular sim and that fixes the problem most of the time. Doesn't fix wild horses stuck in your walls though.

Custom sims are great, there's a lot of freedom with what you could do with it, and some of the personality traits can help flesh out your characters. The first sims (besides my personal one) I created were Wario and Waluigi, first interaction with them Waluigi chose to bore me to death. I also would often give characters the Inappropriate trait because it's one of the best traits for stirring things up and one of the few ways that could lead sims to get romantically paired without it being off screen or you having to direct them to do it. Insane trait was always a blast as well. I liked to give my sims free will and observe them. Part of why the play time got so high, I'd leave it running in the background at times.

If I were to give them a priority though, for me personally, it would be Generations, then Seasons, then Pets. For some Seasons would maybe be more of a priority, but this wouldn't even matter if they still had the actual decent bundle that made the decision a moot point. For the 2 expansions I have, I liked Late Night a bit more than University Life, mainly because going to university take too dang long. You do get some new buildings and such that you can use to spice up your towns so even if you're not at the university, elements from that expansion can still apply to your town which is good.

Considering that that particular combo of Base Game-Generations-Seasons-Pets would now cost 108 dollars CDN is disgusting. This game's 10 + years old, I just went and got Portal 1 & 2 for 2 dollars to get myself to the 35 dollar mark for the summer sale. This game isn't even on sale at all this summer while Sims 4 is. The only thing to note is the Into the future expansion was 40 dollars before so it's gone down. But on sale, it'd go for 10 so that doesn't matter much.

Final Thoughts:
With what prices have become for this and considering they got rid of the best starting bundle and things may not go in sale, I can't recommend picking up this game at those prices. I may change my mind if I see they have sales, but that jump up in price is gross, and getting rid of the good bundle just kills it for anyone new looking to try the game out. If that starting bundle still existed and went for 20 dollars or less on sale, I'd recommend this game. But with these garbage bundles and even more garbage prices, I can't, even if I really enjoy this game.

The hours Steam has listed here are inaccurate.  I've played Sims for hundreds of hours on other computers.  I learned about how to create mods by editing content in the Sims 2 and experimented with making script mods for TS3.  If EA hadn't hiked the price of stuff packs up like this, I might even have left a positive review.  But I can't do that with a good conscience.

For those of you wondering: Yes, you are being ripped off.  Just one Stuff pack (DLC that simply adds items/clothes to the game) now costs as much as the game itself (these were not always priced this high).  Stuff packs add things like furniture and outfits---some of them are genuinely unique, such as the Katy Perry pack adding items that are shaped like cupcakes and candy, or the Movie Stuff pack introducing superhero-themed content.  But other than that, Stuff packs generally do not add anything exciting.  Your gameplay will not change from these, your Sims will not react any differently to the Sweet Treats furniture than they do any other furniture in the game.
Now, it's understandable that the Expansion packs (DLC that *does* add new features, worlds, interactions, new sims, etc) cost $20---but it's absolutely ridiculous that Stuff packs are that expensive.
And don't look to the Sims 4 as a good alternative to this game.  Base game TS4 starts out with even less features than the base game TS3 and 2 had...and added only *some* of that content back in as expensive DLC.

I do believe developers should be paid fairly for their work so I understand why prices may be high.  However, I also believe consumers shouldn't be exploited for corporate greed.  More specifically, customers shouldn't be exploited for *EA's* corporate greed.  When EA begins respecting it's own developers across the board, when it stops buying smaller game companies just to gut them, and when it stops rushing out incomplete games with $60+ price tags....then we can allow a little wiggle room for greed.  But for now, today....EA only cares about your wallet.  Don't let this company con you into paying them hundreds of dollars for a full game.

I shouldn't have been allowed to play this game. It was extremely fun but terrifying to play God. Some downsides are that even if you have a fast and big computer the frame rate will still continue to drop and the game will slow down, usually its caused by mods.

Some tips to consider when getting the game + mods:

-Downloading mods and custom content into the game is great and all but I recommend getting a software that combines some of the cc and mod files together so the game can run somewhat smoother.

-But don't put everything in one file because that will actually remove some content so when combining files categorise it so you don't lose files and so it just appears more organised.

 -Delete the cache files, they are created every time you open your game and they are there to make your game smoother. But getting mods will definitely make cache files a bother, because they have your previous settings saved so deleting them when installing mods will actually allow you to use the mod in the game.

Those tips are there just so when people get the game they don't get frustrated when it starts to slow down.

I have a YouTube channel for gaming and I have (at the time of this review) 15 videos on The Sims 2. It's still my favourite of the 4 games. This game, however has a lot of great features from The Sims 2 and then some new features like the colour scheme designing tool is WAY better in this game than any of the other three! Very customizable things in this one. And I know we ALL appreciate that kind of freedom. The animations aren't very much different than TS2 and not the overly "cartooniness" of TS4. The graphics are definitely an improvement from TS2 and a lot of the same features return which makes it a very nice balance of a more modern Sims installment without the rediculousness or lack of difficulty in TS4. But there is an issue I've run into many times with this game's performance. trying to record this game for a video is a challenge. The game begins to get a little choppy and quality seems to drop a bit. Another performance issue with the game I've run into is when going to lots (my sim is a ghost hunter for work and travels to houses) the game seems to freeze for a good solid minute (and a half) when arriving to lots sometimes. Very strange issue that seems to persist but is on and off. Overall it's a solid game with a few bugs (as any Sims game has). Would recommend! Also, y'all can uhh go ahead and sub to AngeloTangelo on YouTube ;) I'll wait lol

Rating: 4.7/5

Oh boy, time for a long, juicy review! 

The sims 3... Where do we even begin?
I know! The engine. 

One of the main reasons the Sims 3 is better than the Sims 4 is because of the engine. While Sims 4 has a more optimized engine, it's a heavier game doing more than cancelling out the effects. And, it does a loading thing that is super long (about 30 seconds) when you just wanted to go to your neighbor's house... But the Sims 4 also didn't add Toddlers or cars until a late patch. 

But, the sims 3 is easier to use, has a nicer GUI (Instead of flat stuff that looks weird and confusing, the Sims 3 has a more appealing GUI), and doesn't have that loading thing.

The sims 4 is highly dependent on expansions and gameplay of the sims 4 is bland without expansions.

But the sims 3 is just fine without them.

We're only scratching the surface as to why the Sims 3 is better than it's sequel.

Probably the best EA game ever created.

Grade: A+

Amazingly fun game. The computer I'm using can't handle The Sims 4, so I settled for this game. I really didn't realize how much fun it truly was.

If you're new to the Sims series, this is a wonderful place to start. It has plenty of tutorials throughout it to help you along the way. Even if you've been playing the series a long time, you can skip them, which I love. The customization of your Sims is amazing, you can get incredibly detailed if you enjoy that like I do. You basically never run out of stuff to do in this game. If you somehow do, look up different challenges to do, building challenges, game-play challenges, and more. The community is awesome with all the custom content they've created. The expansion packs could add some more elements to it, however-

If you don't have the money for that like me, the base game will still keep you entertained for hours on end. I have only had it for two days and have 14+ hours of game-play on it already. 110% recommended by me.

So yeah, awesome game, you can spend hundreds of hours on the game and never get bored. there's many ways to play and your choices are almost unlimited when it comes to world building, item coloring and your designing or advancing your Sim's story/life. you also get many DLC to choose from and unlike some games, you can pick and chose what you want! though some DLC can make the game feel almost too easy at times.

Best part is the music IMO, so many good tunes!


The only down sides I've noticed is are as follows

1: the lagg can be really bad at times and it seems to get progressively worse when you add more DLC or try to build huge mansions/buildings with large amounts of items on lots.

2: some of the features from the sims store can't be accessed anymore which kinda stinks since there's 2-3 additional worlds/towns you can build/play with.

3: EA no longer provides support for this game which is bad because some DLC have bugs that will either break your game or disable certain features. so check the reviews first for details before buying a DLC!

4: The price for an 11 year old game originally released in 2009 is a bit high. (current year of this review is 2020)  The main game price is worth $20, but I think the DLC should be $10 for expansions and $5 for stuff packs. luckily the game and DLC goes on sale quite often so if you don't want to pay full price, just add it to your wish list and wait til it goes on sale!

5: space. if you want to own everything, you will need some space on your hard drive for this game.

I've been following the franchise ever singe I was very young, The Sims Complete Collection was my first game ever. So The Sims itself means a lot to me, it's very near and dear to my heart. This game right here is one of my favourite Sims games. With all that said, I highly suggest buying this on sale. If you include all the DLC (which you should!) it is far too expensive to buy at full price. Thankfully Steam does sales quite often. 

The only thing that I am mildly peeved with, after all these years, is The Sims 3 Store in itself. Having to buy a special currency to use on a website for extra content is just. Not something I really agree with, especially when the base game + expansions are as expensive as they are. But it is a well known fact that EA is greedy, so it's not really surprising. Sadly. 

But even with the nickel-and-diming, I still think it's a solid game. But that might just be the nostalgia talking. Who knows?

This is a good game with some solid intrigue. I didn't grow up with The Sims, but when I first got this I have to say I played for nearly 12 hours the night of. While I do love this game, I'm going to have to parrot what everyone else is saying, that the expansions are way too expensive, and given that they are not all equal should not all be priced identically. There are some annoying glitches, and the graphics are a little outdated, if not a little poorly put together. While I'd recommend the base game, I wouldn't recommend the expansions just for the sake that they are way overpriced for what they are. The expansion packs don't add more than the base game, though they change up the experience, and thus shouldn't cost over $300-$400 just to add to the original game. Especially when the packs are left as-is and have a high chance of corrupting your game if you use them (I'm specifically talking about University Life, my game would get corrupted once my Sim would come home from graduation). And given there is no longer support from this game, it just detracts from the fun of the whole game in general.

I played the original "Sims" back when it very first came out, and spent many hours on my old Compaq computer giving my little army recruiter a good life (and occasionally forcing him to wet himself....hey, ye who have never locked your sim in a room without a toilet, or removed the ladder from a swimming pool, cast the first stone lol).   Later I bought a version for the Playstation 2 but it just wasn't the same and then I just kind of forgot about the game in general and moved on in real life.   But now in 2020, during this whole Covid-19 era, I was reading an article about how people who are tired of being shut-in their homes were turning to simulator games like "The Sims" to escape real life and have fun in a virtual world.  It made me nostalgic so I found a free trial of Sims 4. I played it, and it was fun, but something was just....different.  I just wasn't having the instant addictive fun that I had the first time I played the Sims.  I watched some YouTube videos and read some other reviews and apparently I wasn't the only one who felt that way.  Sims 4 is more like a reboot of the series, and left a bad impression on a lot of long time Sims fans.  A lot of people are unanimously saying that Sims 3 is the peak of the series so I dropped $20 on it and took a chance.  And I don't regret it.  Instantly fell in love with the game all over again, and was taken back to when I first played "The Sims" all those years ago.     If you're like me and you haven't played The Sims in several years, I highly recommend "The Sims 3".   I haven't had any technical glitches or computer issues with the game at all, and I didn't feel like I had to "learn how" to play the game.  Its just intuitive, I think.   You just start playing and then you're addicted!   If you can click and point, you can play The Sims 3!

Nice Soundtrack
Great Expansions
So Much Content
High Replayability Value

Disclaimer: I have over 5000 hours on this game on Origin, and possibly thousands more elsewhere. I don't own it on Steam

This is hands-down the most ambitious a life simulation game has ever been. And it shows, for better or for worse. You get dynamic, lively open worlds with a high degree of creative freedom in really every part of making a Sim, a home and a life. It's a very fun and rewarding experience throughout.....except for the performance issues. 

Good god, be wary of the performance issues. You'll need a few mods to minimize them. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT THESE MODS, you will NOT have a good time. EA did nothing whatsoever to optimize this game after the initial release in 2009. It ran just fine at that point, but 20 content packs and countless separate mini-DLCs have come out since then and the engine simply cannot handle them very well. If you have a good PC you may get lucky and have a tolerable experience out of the box......maybe it'll even be smooth once you install those mods. BUT DON'T COUNT ON IT. Expect a brilliant, funny, satisfying, creative game undermined largely by poor performance.

Still, I couldn't recommend this more. It's a hell of a game. I've put 5000 hours into it over the last 9-10 years, and I'm not stopping anytime soon.

Its the sims...again. Over the years I've tried the different sims games, the graphics gets better, the interaction gets more varied but it really just boils down to a simple thing. It's your personal soap opera where you're the director.
The core components are basically the same with each sims version. Aging and other effects create a slightly different dynamic. Would I buy Sims 4? Only if it came in a bundle sale on steam and had smaller game save files. Do I have fun with it? Sure, but then I can have fun with a lot of simpler games. It's cheap to get if you grab the bundle on holidays and hours of play if you like Storytelling. Yes, its basically playing with a digital dollhouse or "action figures." Then again, most games are in the most basic sense the same concept of make believe and playing hero or bad guy.

Sims 3 does have a number of bugs that have never been addressed even now. Sims 4 is reportedly less game breaking. NRAAS has appeared to solve a lot of issues with Sims 3 as a community developed fix. As I understand it, it's a script that cleans up things in the game each day. re-routing stuck characters, removing extras, turning off televisions, etc. 
It's not a bad though it is a broken game if you play it long enough without the community fixes. With the fixes it trudges along and on sale days it's cheaper than sims 4.

I will be frank, growing up me and my friends always thought the sims was a childish game. There is zero 18+ stuff, and everything revolves around being nice to people. Meh i rather play grown up gritty stuff...

You can imagine how at 21 damn years old i had the biggest surprise of my life when i decided to eventually buy the base game and see what the fuss was all about. 

The sims 3 lets you create a character and guide it's life with a maximum degree of freedom (within an utopian society where F UP stuff doesn't happen) through his entire life, then proceed playing if you have raised children. The range of interactions with people around you is Mindblowing. Add to this the fact that this game has better home-building and decoration tools than any program every created for actual arquitects and it gets insane. 

The Sims is not about steppin into a story. Nor is it about a story where things change based on your decisions. It's about creating whatever story you want and choosing how it will unfold thru your actions. You can be anyone and do anything (aside from the BAD stuff). 

I was amazed and played it for a long time, despite having a prejudice with this game for 21 years of my life. I was missing out.

Now about DLCS: The base game is certainly fun, but to have the best experience possible you'll want to grab the major DLCS that you like. Some let you be a wizard or a vampire, Some let you have animals in your house, Some add all 4 major seasons to the game and their beautiful effects. It's up to you but i don't suggest picking them all up even if you have the money, the reason being the more DLC you have installed the more demanding the game will become. So do your research and only buy what you truly want. Also DLC is expensive. Like very expensive. Don't buy dlc if you can't spare the money, it's probably not worth more than having money for essential and outside leasure stuff. 

Pros: You can live an entire different life in a fully interactable Open World with extremely complex and different characters to meet. The game has infinite replayabilty because you can always start as a different person and make different decisions. Also you can create the house of your dreams with the best home designer tool ever created. And with DLC you can have ten times the replayability because of the new Open Worlds to explore and new stuff to do. 

Pros over the sequel (The Sims 4): It's open world and the world feels alive. It also has so much more content that the comparison isn't even funny. And the Art style is miles better than whatever the hell they decided to greenlight for the 4th game. Sims 3 is superior in every single way minus stability. 

Cons: It crashes. Not frequently, but it does. No matter your hardware. The game also gets laggy if you have too much dlc installed. With all dlcs my game is unplayable. But with 3 maxium i can run this well, untill it crashes. Always save every 10 minutes. The autosave is a joke. Also this game lacks any type of 18+ content, which can be boring for people that want more realism. Plus the price of DLC is insane. Much better games are beeing sold for way less than a SIMS 3 expansion.

Takeaway: The Sims 3 is the best simulation game out there. If you like simulations, get it. If you only like games with explosions and gunfights and crime and war and drugs and whatever mature thing you want then it's definetely not a game you'll find interesting. But you should give it a chance because i did an it blew my mind. 

Btw i'd like to make an observation: More games should build around the concept of the sims 3. Customizaiton in this game is TOP NOTCH and it's something that is lacking in 99% of the games out there. The SIMS is the living proof that customization sells.

After 10 years they have now increased the prices of decorations/clothing dlc's. Why? Because they are Electronic Arts! 
So if you want to have a dlc furniture set for a 10 year old game then you now have to pay 20 Euro's for it hahaha.


Sims 3 in itself is a fun relaxing game thanks to Maxis the developer. EA the publisher doesn't deserve your money though. The game doesn't even run well on modern PC's and is quite glitchy. Some dlc's are even outright broken, but they sell them anyway.

Game is soo much fun BUT, I do NOT recommend you to buy most of the DLC's as they are way overpriced. Especially nowadays. I remember back then buying the Sims DLC's for around 3$ or so EACH. By far the best sims made, love the fact that it has so much to do and so much freedom. I love the aspect of the open world like game play, being able to have a whole open world town to interact with that has all sorts of businesses and other buildings is great. My favorite part of sims 3 is the fact you can be a business owner. It's fun to see your weekly check from it roll in, and being able to build your own/buy and edit and upgrade your business is so fun! I had one character who was top of the business career and over time I ended up buying everything in town and was rolling in 1m every week! The city life pack is super fun being able to be a celebrity and gain fame is also really cool. Another big one is having the option to own your own vehicle. Also on the sims 3 website there's an exchange tap where you can download all sorts of cool content people create and upload and that is reaaaally cool. For sure one of my favorite games and still playing in 2020!

The Sims 3, in my humble opinion, is still the best Sims game. It's not hard to bog your game down with stuff to the point where it's sluggish but at least the options are there. It's an excellent open world. It's also the only Sims game (to my knowledge) that has martial arts. That's pretty important to me as martial arts and fighting were a huge part of my life at one point.

One of the chief complaints when this game was new is the load times. Because of the open world nature the game has to load HUGE chunks of data all at once. It can still sometimes take a while but with modern SSD hardware and processors this isn't as much of a problem anymore.

If you've never played The Sims and are looking for where to start. Start here. Oh and, don't pay full price for any of the DLC. It's good content but isn't worth more than $10, if that.

[i]Full Disclosure: Before purchasing The Sims 3 on Steam, I played around 500 hours of the disc version and 300 hours of the Xbox 360 versions (both The Sims 3 and The Sims 3 Pets, which were separate). Additionally, I bought the original The Sims on release in 2000 and have thousands of hours in both it and The Sims 2 and many expansion packs in the two decades since.[/i]

You know what The Sims is. Considering The Sims 4 has been out for a while, perhaps you're here because you wonder if The Sims 3 is still worth it. It is. My review focuses on grading the game for how it stands out in the franchise, not to players new to the franchise in general.

Back when The Sims 3 came out, I heard about all its new features and was put off. It seemed Maxis re-evented the franchise and added so much new stuff that I barely recognized it. It wasn't until my husband (a console gamer only) rented a copy of The Sims 3 for the Xbox 360 that I realized those changes were [i]good[/i] by watching him (a Sims newbie at the time) play the game. I promptly started playing it myself, and it became my favorite of the franchise. Despite the total overhaul, The Sims 3 manages to get most things right and add so many things that, while previously unnecessary, only sweeten the experience.

The aesthetic of The Sims 3 differs from the first two entries; while at first I found it too cartoony, it grew on me and now I prefer it. Colors are crisp, Sims give often over-dramatic yet entertaining expressions, and there are enough options in genetics to make individual Sims look different from one another through the generations. The wish/trait systems is a new addition to this entry that I was suspicious of at first but became the main draw; rather than simply having goals for your Sims mentally stored away as you control them, the game suggests wishes and goals for you to complete for rewards (physical rewards and "upgrades" for your Sim by making them less likely to get hungry, keep friendships for longer, etc.). These wishes are suggested to you for different reasons. For example, if your Sims visits a park, perhaps they wish to go fishing, pick up seeds, or eat hot dogs from a nearby grill. Sims may wish to kiss a friend if fate dictates they find one another attractive (shown as a moodlet), or if your choices steer them in that direction (flirting). Wishes aren't mandatory. You can pick and choose or ignore them completely. In either case, its guiding hand has gotten me to play in ways I never have before, by exploring different career paths or trying self-imposed challenges (The Asylum, Baby-maker, etc.).

The other [i]huuuge[/i] change in this entry are personal traits, which gives each Sim a unique personality that is a game changer for the franchise. If you make a Sim insane, it's likely they'll talk nonsense to others or argue with themselves. Making a Sim a kleptomaniac not only gives them the chance to randomly swipe stuff from locations they visit, but you get to keep the stuff as well, and they'll likely want to join the Criminal career branch. Depending on the traits each Sim has, their lives can become easier or harder, and they'll judge other Sims accordingly. Some traits cause Sims to clash or become easier to befriend, though it's possible to overcome it if they clash. Failure was always failure in The Sims and its sequel; in The Sims 3, making Sims with the worst traits possible isn't only a valid option, it can be downright hilarious.

The Sims 3 has its problems, of course, and most of them stem back to EA, whose grimy hands taint everything they touch. Even the game's store page reeks of pretentious triple-A BS, with them stamping "TM" within the name of the game everywhere. Despite its age, The Sims 3 has so many expansion packs at such outdated expensive prices it's ridiculous. The game also wants you to sign up with an online account through its launcher, but doing so only unlocks more annoyances. There's now a digital currency, and it's nauseating to see they offer real-currency-only items before in-game items in Buy Mode and while choosing outfits. This is the main reason I didn't support The Sims 3 upon release, and it's the main drawback to the game now. The Sims 3 is a wonderful game, and EA's unending greed only sullies its name and legacy. Additionally, The Sims 3 has more glitches, issues, and crashes than is acceptable for a game this old and this full of microtransaction BS. I've put about 150 hours into the Steam version over the last two weeks (it only tracks about a third of my playtime for some unknown reason), and I've had countless freezes, lags, crashes, and many odd bugs. The same happened to me in all versions of the game before it.

The Sims 3 is what happens when developers innovate with such ambition that they end up with an outstanding success. For me to say that means a lot considering EA's filth still floats in every crevasse and the game's buggier than a honey farm. I suggest buying while on sale to limit the cash you hand to EA, though no matter what price you're buying at you'll get your money's worth.

A fun and relaxing game where everything's possible. With DLC's, of course!

Although yes, most things are locked behind a paywall, the basics that you do get are pretty good. 
With a revamped and more simple building style (with the introduction of blueprints if your lazy! :-) ) And the introduction of a explorable world without any loading screens from the previous games (although it'll lag on latency computers) The jobs are pretty fun also, from being a store-clerk to being a goddamn president of united sims of simerica (ignore that pun) Altough you have to grind alot for the skills, which will take time out of your sim's day in order to master them, but in the end it does pay off! In the end, it's a pretty cool and casual game to play when you want to chill out after a day's work. Just, if you want more, get that debit card ready!

I've played this game for years and I finally feel like giving this a rating.

The mechanics in the Sims 3 are convenient when travelling your world and accessing each Sim in a given household whenever you want to switch the controls. The smooth game play along with the casual escape from reality is ironic, given that you have to pay bills. But it's fun to go out and buy food, meet random Sims, and go crazy with creativity. Adding expansion packs makes the Sims 3 all the more enjoyable for someone who wants more options to push the game play experience. Also with the right build on graphics, the world looks so good up close.
With the cost of the DLCs being as much as they were basically 11 years ago, I'd suggest purchasing Sims 4. Then at least when you buy the DLCs they are for a modern game.

Apparently this game cannot cope with being on a modern PC.
If you have a high resolution, the User Interface become so tiny it is impossible to read, even on a 50 inch screen. The game becomes effectively unplayable since you cannot see or read any of the details about your sim.

The Sims 3 is the best of the Sims series so far. There is far more activities to do, it has character customization  more complex then SIms 2 and more meaningful then Sims 4, and it has an open world concept. If you are considering getting a couple of DLC's I would definitely recommend getting SIms 3: Island Paradise and SIms 3: World Adventure. DLC's Ambition, Supernatural, University, and Seasons were pretty good too, but they're not nearly as interesting as Island Paradise and World Adventure. Generations is meh. Also this is the first time I have played the Sims and not had a computer breakdown on me after a month of playing, and it is also the first time I have used an external hard drive.
With Sims 5 being in the works I hope that it will include an open world, and more puzzles like those in World Adventure to help make it less mundane.

I purchased Sims 3 years ago via disks etc. It's an amazing game, the best of the Sims series by far. The only better game was the Sims 2 Open for Business, but there are mods out there to get near enough to the experience with Sims 3. Sims 4 is trash, start to finish - various reasons why and we all know it. 
BUT. 
Sims 3 requires the DLCs to get the proper experience. And like others have said, charging $30AUD per expansion for a game this old is criminal. I re-purchased it and a few expansions through Steam when they were on special for about $5 a piece. Spent about $50AUD and wish I'd bought the lot there and then. 
Seriously, this game is now older than some that are on GOG.com. Do us all a favour while most of us are in lockdown and drop the prices, then I can't recommend it highly enough.

To be honest, the game is fine, fun to mess around with but I can't recommend a game with such abhorrent pricing schemes. More than 400$ worth of DLCs on a game more than a decade old. A lot of the 20$ DLCs are nothing but clothing and furniture, not even worth buying on the very rare occasion they go on sale. Glad I didn't give EA more of my money other than for the base game. If you want something new, I highly suggest you mod it in, could save you hundreds.

This game is a horrendously overpriced cash cow ( like so many others ). Playing without any dlc feels like you are playing a half finished game that EA sloppily rushed out into the market before it was complete, best way to describe it would be simply put empty and lackluster. Buying this DLC however will cost you 150 - 200 (On Sale) - 400 (Regular Price) which is the equivalent of buying the base game 20 times. 

EA's business model is gross ( of course ) and has been for many years now, if EA even slightly cared for their consumers this content would have been in the game at launch 9 years ago or added in after for free, as things like pets just feel like they are missing from the game.



Edit: It's alright if you're really bored during Quarantine. But do yourself a favor and just don't buy it.

I LOVE LOVE LOVE The Sims 3! I also have the large disappointment known as The Sims 4. The ONLY advantages Sims 4 has over Sims 3 is Sims 4 is prettier, has a better CAS (Create a Sim) selection, and has better Build/Buy options. Other than that, The Sims 3 is better in literally every way, I've also heard The Sims 2 is pretty good too. Unlike the Sims 4, The Sims 2 and Sims 3 are much more fun. With Sims 4, you HAVE to have so many mods just to make it actually decently fun. In The Sims 3, you don't need mods for this game to be fun. I have wasted almost $100 on The Sims 4, and I regret it. I would have much rather have spend $100 on this game instead. They recently announced The Sims 5 is in the works (oh boy), they decided to not listen to the majority of players and are trying to add multiplayer, the reason why Sims 4 is a hollow shell of a Sims game. Sims 4 doesn't have multiplayer because they couldn't do it and left the game missing tons of features. Guess what game ISN'T missing ton of features? THE SIMS 3!

The game can even glitch and make your Sim unhappy all the time. This happened to me on my recent playthrough: 5 hours in, nothing I could do could make my Sim happy; he was in such a bad mood all the time that he refused to clean anything as soon as he came near it, even without negative moodlets; this was caused by a bug that has to do with a temporary positive moodlet accidentally applying a permanent negative moodlet of the same value).

Aside from that, it's standard Sims gameplay with some neat things to do and see, and it's still a great time today if you just want to spend a lot of time relaxing improving your Sims' skills.

Nowadays, I recommend it on a good sale with maybe some DLCs if you enjoy it and want more to do.

[h1]The Sims(TM) 3[/h1]

The Sims 3 was one of my favorite games since the release in 2009, I was stoked, I was always into The Sims as a kid, still am. Owning The Sims 1, The Sims 2, and now The Sims 3, I can say the improvement is very noticeable. I'm here to type this review since I had this game for quite some time, I've been addicted to the game recently so I figured to do this now while I'm inspired to do so.

[h1]What is The Sims?[/h1]
If you aren't familiar with The Sims, this is a kind of game with a Life Simulation, sure, playing with virtual dolls in a way, but somehow it's very addicting and quite relaxing. The Sims has a unique playstyle for each individual person. Some like to be architectural and build houses to pass the time. Some want to have their own challenges in creating a family and see how far the generations will go. Some people just want to drown their Sim for enjoyment just for the hell of it. These are just examples of what you can do.

[u]The Concept[/u]
Every Sims game has a "Needs" bar, to bathing, Eating, Entertainment, Social, these are examples. You would simply replenish these bars by cooking, watching tv, etc.

Your Sims are basically humans, they live under a house. You can build your own home and can really unleash your architectural talent, or just practice in general with your imagination. Otherwise, you can simply move your Sim into a pre-made house if you wish to. Living in these homes you can add furniture to whatever you desire to fit the lifestyle of your Sim.

Your Sims have a personality you can give them, do you want them to be romantic? You can do that. Do you want them to live miserable and happy? You can also do that. In The Sims 3, you are given more to give to your Sims compared to the other games, however, the concept stays the same.

You can also edit and dress your Sims to fit their personality as well. Do you want to give them a Tatoo? You can do that. Give them a Cowboy hat? Of course, you can also do that. [i]I'm sure you get the idea...right?[/i]

[h1]EA Game, must be DLC Hell.[/h1]

It is, unfortunately. The Sims is known for their expansions, however, most are indeed worth it. The Sims 3 is fair of $20 in my opinion, however not for most expansions by how old this game is. The Sims 3 does go on sale often to $5 including each of the DLC's often, so I would snag them when they reduce to that price.

In my opinion, I would recommend these Expansions to start out with:

- The Sims University = Enroll your Sims into a University for better jobs.
- The Sims Pets = You can add Cats, Dogs, Horses into your family.
- The Sims Seasons = Add Weather and Holidays in your gameplay.
- The Sims Late Night = Able to use Apartments and enjoy the Night Life
- The Sims Generations = More things to do, extending the Family Tree.
- The Sims Supernatural = Able to have Vampires, Werewolfs, Witches, etc.

The rest of the Expansions are optional, I can recommend them, these are just some I think would work best for most people, however, having all these Expansions will add more to your gameplay. Again, these do go on sale for $5, they are an absolute deal if you get them at that price.

[h1]The Sims 3 or The Sims 4?[/h1]

This section is very opinionated, The Sims 4 is an improvement for sure as your Sims can actually multitask on what they do, especially during socializing. The Sims 3 lacks that of course, it's older. Graphically I like The Sims 3 more than The Sims 4 because the 'Cartoon Graphics' 4 has personally displeased me. The Sims 4 Expansions weren't as fulfilling as The Sims 3 had for new content. The Sims 3 has an Open World where The Sims 4 does not, which does include performance issues that The Sims 3 has for weaker end systems, even stronger ones, I suffer with it sometimes.

Overall, each one has its advantages and disadvantages and just varies on taste. The Sims 4 is only available on Origin, however, at some point, we may see it on Steam since EA has been more open with Steam recently with newer titles.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I hope I provided enough, for people just looking into The Sims or Veterans, I can recommend this, full price at least for the game, though, again, the game does go on sale for $5, same as its expansions.

Modding support is still alive, in fact, I'm using some right now such as Worlds and Clothing for certain Sims. These can be easily accessed from a few websites.

So in conclusion, yes get this game.

http://sims3.thesimscatalog.com/sims3/

Will always love The Sims 3. I love the open map concept where you can have your sim jog to the diner and have lunch, and then head on over to the gym for a workout, and then back home, all without any loading screens. This game is incredibly better than The Sims 4, I absolutely hate what EA games did with the newest game. Being able to have roommates that you don't control, but still contributing to the weekly rent was a great touch. So many jobs to choose from, so many ways to entertain yourself. DLC's and stuff packs that actually made sense and make you feel you are getting your moneys worth. Large amounts of items, lots of customization, the ability to customize your town to your liking! Not to go back on the rant about how everyone likes The Sims 3 much more than The Sims 4.... But everything about this game was so much better done than the newest addition to the franchise.

I generally play the game through Origin, so that playtime does not count here, but suffice to say I am well over 1000 hours

If you want a game that is fun, addictive, and provides a great sense of accomplishment, this is for you. Of course, if you want to buy a game that works as advertised without needing lots of unofficial support, this is not the game for you. The good news is, the community can fix many of the problems with the game. Bad news is that 10 years later, EA couldn't be bothered fixing their mistakes, though they didn't hesitate to raise the price without fixing the game itself. I want to give it thumbs down, because EA deserves that, but the base Sims 3 game deserves thumbs up. Half the expansion packs have bugs that range from severely negatively affecting gameplay to rendering the game entirely unplayable. On the other hand, anyone seeking a Sims experience these days has to choose between 3 and 4, and 3 is the easy winner, by miles and miles

I love the sims but the game can become dry after several weeks when only the base game is purchased. They have many expansion packs which will most certainly add new angles to the game and allow it to become a very well rounded game. The expansion packs can get pretty pricey though as each one costs an average of $20.00 each and The Sims have 20 expansion packs. The ones that add the most to your game in my opinion are Sims 3 Pets, Sims 3 University Life, Sims 3 Supernatural, Sims 3 Ambitions, Sims 3 World Adventures, Sims 3 Seasons, Sims 3 Future, Sims 3 Generation , Sims 3 Showtime , Sims 3 Island Paradise and Sims 3 Late Night. You can add them on whenever you like and they should integrate smoothly into your game. One last thing is if you prefer a more enhanced and realistic experience you can also download MODS free of charge online outside of the steam platform. Do so at your own risk though because some Mods conflict with others and may make for a bad gameplay. Only experienced and knowledgeable gamers should attempt any modifications to the game.

Waited for the whole thing to be available as a bundle, so that it would be as glitch free as possible.
Played 44.8 hours.  Had an okay time.
The launcher stays active in the tray when the game's off, so shutting down my computer required an extra confirmation step every time I was done.
Now the game won't launch at all.
I'm sure there's an easy fix, whereby I do half an hour's research, open up/save/restore files, or maybe uninstall and reinstall the whole thing, and then we're back to square one.
I'm certain I have better things to do.  This game is a lemon.

Later: Okay, not sure why the game stopped launching, but here's a little more to it.  Once you've started the game, the launcher just keeps on trying to pop up ads for DLCs, additional material you might obtain for a modest fee, and generally keeps looking for content that is no longer available to it.  This can actually slice off a chunk of your available computing power while you're playing the game.  So, all you have to do is pause your game, open your save options, re-open your launcher, and then close the launcher.  Then you can play this damned game.  Alternatively, you can save the launcher files to another folder, possibly titled "Annoying Obsolete Backup Crap", and launch the game old school from Sims3.exe in your file search thingy.  See? (bangs head onto desk)  It's so easy! (bangs head onto keyboard) All of this does nothing to fix the grim reality that the people in this game resemble doughy monstrous 3d versions of the NPCs from Elder Scrolls Oblivion.

I love this game

I would say this game is pretty good. I love the open-world gameplay style to it, it's nice to have your sims be free to go where ever they want without having to wait on loading screens. Speaking of loading screens, they are quite long. It takes about 2 minutes per loading screen for the game to load up for me- thankfully, they don't happen often and only do when I start up the game and load up a save. I really enjoyed the free customization. It made home designing unlimited, as I could change the materials and colors of any wall paintings and furniture. I made myself a cyberpunk neon home thanks to iy. The same applies to character creation, it's great to NOT be stuck to the pre-made clothing designs.

I own the Pets expansion pack, I recommend it unless you're the type of player who doesn't like it when your characters are distracted from reaching their goals. (Pets require lots of attention and care, and may slow down whatever goals you're trying to make your sim reach) I love the extra building and clothing items added to the expansion pack as well.

My only issues with this game is the numerous bugs, glitches and freezes. I have a Windows 10 computer, my settings are set low as possible, no mods or creator content yet the game continues to lag. Not to mention that the interactions between sims seems less energetic than those in the Sims 2. I feel like my Sims aren't really into each other when they interact and it bores me at times.

Overall, good game. I would rate it a good 4/5.
