Sims 3 is a monster of a game with the amount of decent DLC it has. Because it's so massive in terms of content, it has many, many issues.  Luckily, there are many passionate people out there for this blessed and cursed game. Mods that will help run your game smoother, and custom content creators to make your characters look refined and attractive.

As told by how many hours I've played this game, I absolutely love it. It was a rough start because of all the problems at hand. But I dived deep into CC and mods which made game play all the more fun. The base game is very boring, but you have mods to thank to make things more interesting.

DLC has my list of complaints (and I have almost all of the ones that add actual content instead of clothes and items) - I don't like the fact that you have to get DLC just so you can have pets in the game. And even then, Pets is usually the culprit that slows down your game because of the excessive amount of animals that run around your town.

Another one is Worlds DLC. Having the option to go to different places is great because it adds more flavor to the vanilla, BUT, once again, these places also have sims running around with pets spawning in there too! 

However, if you can look past all the neglect, bugs, and lag, you can find a very blessed and heavily cursed game. There are a million mods out there to enhance your experience, and CC to build your wardrobe for your Sims. Anyone who is into life simulator games can give this game a try.

The peak of the Sims franchise was The Sims 2.

The Sims 3 is a welcome graphical update, but improves on little else.

EA portions out the bulk of this games content in bite-sized chunks as downloadble content, and in-game micro-transactions, without which, the game feels incomplete.

I bought the game and most of the DLC when they were discounted (almost a decade after release) but I still feel like I didn't get my money's worth.

Still a few bugs, but they're all documented. Not worth the full price,  except the base game, but expansions go on sale fairly often for the patient. Sims 4 has easier character creation, better building methods and a search bar for items, but this game (sims 3) has a wider array of customisation for content, including patterns and colours, that Sims 4 has yet to match. Sims can be made fairly quickly, it's the optional custom detailing that takes so long in SIms 3. Despite owning both games, I find myself returning constantly to Sims 3 over Sims 4 (on Origin) for its content, variety, and complications.

The Sims can be entertaining but requires all of the expansion packs to get the most fun. Unfortunately, despite being pricey, many expansion packs introduce very little new content for the game so I also recommend purchasing them in bundles and sales. I would like to see more time progression as the generations go on (e.g. fashion changes, buildings ageing etc.) and perhaps introduce a more adult version of the game which could include crime, disease and war as genuine threats to your sims; for example, the military career path should not max out as "astronaut" because that isn't realistic and there should be options for evil sims to commit crimes, with the addition of a karma meter so that sims can become good or bad depending on their choices.

Don't get me wrong, the game is good.

But the price is completely unreasonable. $20 for some DLC? I've bought full-fledged games for $20. EA can fuck off with their greed.

Any competitors out there, I will buy your game just so EA loses the monopoly on life simulator games. Fuck them.

Ok, me and the sims go waaaaaaay back to when my computer was probably 15GB of memory...total, back when rosebud ;!;!;! ruled the day, and DLC/expansion packs were a farcry into the future.  The Sims isn't for everyone, you're literally SIMulating living a life/building a house BUT it's a nice escape for those who don't enjoy even simulated killing, being scared out of your mind, solving complex puzzles, looting dungeons etc.  It's great for my OCD, I don't EVER really need to "play" the game (I spend probably about 95% in build/buy mode TBH), and I can just zone out with the soothing music as I create houses no one in their right mind would ever be able to build.  Plus, with tons of add-ons anyone can create their own unique world that they can "control".  Kind of like Black and White, without the awesome deities causing miracles/destruction.  20/10 would recommend, but again I AM biased as this built the base of my childhood gaming on PC along w/ Doom and Neopets.

The Sims 3 is my favorite game. I somehow lost all of my TS3 disks when I moved, then my computer died and I eventually got a new one, but alas, my TS3 game was gone forever. I was so happy to find the digital versions during a major Steam sale. I've been playing this game, plus later expansions, since it first came out. I find it hard to define why I love this game so much, but I think it has something to do with the customization options. You can customize the colors and materials of almost everything, including buildings, furniture, clothing, and the sims themselves. You can also download mods to further customize sims, objects and gameplay. This game is seriously fun and addictive.

I would recommend this game for other people to play because it is a stress free sandbox game that you can do anything with. The DLC for this version of the game is abundant and you are able to play a multitude of different game scenarios. From being a supernatural being, to going to different jobs and working alongside your sim. You can even travel into the future. If you love games that allow you to have free reign and make your own choices this is a wonderful choice, and once you start playing you will be there all day. For me Sims 3 is way better and more complex than Sims 4. I also like that the Sims 3 is available on Steam, instead of Origin. Steam is a much more user friendly game client and is more aesthetically pleasing.

[h1]The Sims 3  (4.5) [/h1]

One of the most addictive games Ive ever played. You can spend some time without playing it, but once you open it again, Ill be the only thing youll play for days.
Although its very superior to The Sims 4 in many aspects (open world, vehicles, graphics, style editor, etc.) it sadly has some serious performance issues, along with game-breaking bugs, crashes and eternal loading screens (all of these get worse with the more DLCs you have installed)

[b]The good: [/b]

Incredibly addictive and fun.
 Huge variety of objects, jobs, places to visit, etc. (more with each DLC)
 Excellent build mode.
 DLCs, though their price is excessive, some of them are really good and add tens of hours to the game.
 Soundtrack, graphics, everything good for its time.
 Style editor (textures), which for some reason this tool is not available on The Sims 4.

[b]The bad: [/b]

 Serious bugs and crashes without reason.
 Very long loading screens (even more with DLC and store items)
 Poor performance with FPS drops. It doesnt use more than 2GB of RAM.
 Very high DLC prices. They are worth the same as the game.

[b]Notes: [/b]

 In my opinion, the following DLCs are essential: Seasons, Pets and possibly Ambitions, the rest are not important.

 The Stuff Packs are basically all useless, I dont recommend any of them if you dont yet have all the expansions (except for Into The Future, Showtime and Supernatural, those are bad)

 Before I could buy it on Steam, I played this game for more than 500 hours (approximately)

 Buy The Sims 4 for better performance and a much more playable game, or buy The Sims 3 for more gameplay options and a better game in general, but be prepared for serious bugs, fps drops and all kinds of problems.

[b] Though it has some serious issues, The Sims 3 is still the best one in the series, and for me the best game of the year 2009. Recommended with or without discount (with all the DLCs you can buy) [/b]

This game is so glitch-prone, it's impossible to play without having the cheats on to fix whatever the glitches cause. I had one game that wouldn't let me leave China in the world adventures expansion. Don't get me wrong- it's a fun game; but I wouldn't Recommend it to someone who's never played it before. It's a worthwhile game, but if you didn't start with Sims 3 at any point before, I would recommend Sims 4 as a batter version of this to start with.

The game, with almost all DLCs, runs really well on my old notebook (Intel HD 4000, 4GB RAM, i5 1.7Ghz). It's the best game of the franchise. The people that say that this game is heavy and runs poorly on their PCs are the reason that EA made a crap game for TS4. Claiming to be light, TS4 is a total crap when compared to TS3, in all possible aspects. Long life to TS3.

Simply not a very good game, Normally, the game is overpriced and the DLC is also very overpriced. When browsing for a new game, I Saw that the sims 3 was on sale and all the DLC was too. So I got a couple of DLCs that looked good, and the base game. My PC is 100% good enough to run the game. I wait for the game to download, and as you can see I played 1.3 hours before closing the game. I didn't play the game again, and also requested a refund.

The game ran very poorly, despite having a computer more than good enough to run it. I experienced frame drops and a couple of crashes in my hour of play. As well as this, it was very confusing to play. There is a launcher which I fail to see the relevance of, which prompted me to log into my EA account. After putting in my login details, I tried 3+ times to log in without any success- they didn't even recognise that my account existed (I made sure everything was correct!)

They also gave me some product keys- one for the base game and one for each of the DLCs that I bought along with it. Again, these were useless to me and I could play the game without them.

Overall: Confusing to run. Doesn't work very well. Simply not fun to play- I would strongly advise purchasing any EA games (specifically the sims) on Origin, even if Steam is your preferred platform, If you still want to buy this game or any DLC for it on steam, I strongly suggest you wait for a sale. It's not even the newest installment of the game, yet it's still quite expensive. (Overpriced, for sure.). Unless you really, really want to: do not buy this game.

Well, yeah. I purchased this game after being recommended this game by a friend. Knowing Maxis games, having purchased some before, I knew that it would either be worthwhile or a heroically ambitious fail. But, cutting to the chase, I must say that this game was just what I expected. A step up from Sims 2, but not quite matching as good as Spore. It loads slowly, and you have to pay for premium features. Also, the texturing sometimes is a bit painful on the eyes and sometimes a bit glitchy. However, it is not to be said I don't like this game. It runs smoothly, and there is a great opportunity to not be 'guided along' on a story line. The world is your canvas, with something for the clean honest guy who works hard for their goal or the dirty hacker who cheats all their cash. Also, with a couple of expansion packs (which I got when they were on sale, trust me, it makes things much better) it makes things much more enjoyable, but get them when they're on sale, it'll save you a lot of money. 
What I do have to say that this game is worth it in general and I would recommend it to everybody.

*.:.   Sims 3   .:.*

[b] My Personal Favorite Aspects [/b]
 * [strike] torture [/strike] creative storytelling
 * design (both houses and sims)

[b] DLC [/b]
 1. Seasons
  a. festivals, aliens, and weather
 2. Pets
  a. Not only cats and dogs, but horse and smaller pets
  b. hey, at least you don't need to buy DLC for your DLC like Sims 4 Pets and My First Pet
 3. Generations
  a. This probably isn't worth it if you don't play with sims aged toddler through teen.
 4. University Life
  a.  the actual gameplay isn't wonderful, but I enjoy the items and clothing provided
 5. Supernatural
  a. Vampires, Witches, Zombies, Fairies, and Ghosts. All of them are pretty well-rounded, expect for the Zombies who just 
   ruin your gardens and make weird noises. Just as zombies normal do.
 6. Showtime
  a. the performance aspect of the pack is ideal. The irl social aspect of the game is useless unless you have friends who 
   play this game still and are on at the same times as you
 7. Late Night
  a. adds vampires (unless you have Supernatural, in which is adds more vampire features) and many nightclubs. If you 
   enjoy clubbing and the nightlife, get this pack
 8. Ambitions
  a. makes some professions interactive
  b. introduces "work-at-home" professions with "create-your-own-hours"
 9. World Adventures
 a. adds a slight puzzle element to the game. This can be avoided if you don't want to, but a good portion of the vacations 
  become null
 10. Into the Future
  a. I'm disappointed in the way this one turned out. I was personally so excited for this geeky pack, but it was a let down 
   due to its lack of substance.

[b] Special Note [/b]
A lot of comments have noted issues with Showtime and Island Paradise. I, personally, have not experienced any issues involving Showtime. Island Paradise does possess an issue involving the Scott Family. All you need to do is just delete them and then the game will work smoothly. I have also seen comments saying that entering the cheat (DiscoverAllUnchartedIslands) in the console command (CTRL + SHIFT + C) helps as well, though that could ruin a part of the exploration and discovery aspect of the game.

Play with Life.

Create the lives you've always wanted!

Ready to live a freer, more creative life? In The Sims 3, you can let your fantasies run wild as you design your ideal world. Start with your Sim, refining each shape, color and personality trait until you get the precise person that pleases you. Design your dream home, but dont let a grid limit you; place, rotate and stack furniture and walls freely and to your hearts content.

Once the hard work is over, its time to be a mentor. Guide your Sims path through life, developing a career, finding love, and pursuing dreams and desires. Spending time with friends and family is just as important as mastering painting or accumulating knowledge.

Take things to the next level and record movies of your Sims adventures and share them with the ever-growing and thriving community. With a huge catalog of expansion packs and fun objects to discover, there is no end to the possibilities awaiting you. It all begins here; your adventure awaits!

We still need to manually paste the product keys, remove the hyphens, copy them again, and register on The Sims 3 website while waiting for the download!  Stuff Pack 6: Katy Perry's Sweet Treats, all of the My Worlds (other than Riverview as a registration reward), are still sold separately. When I had finally tried it out, I found that this game made absolutely no sense - there no consequences in a "simulation" game... and I loved it. Want to steal all of your neighbor's furniture? Go ahead! Tired of being the richest philanthropist in the world? Well, then throw it all away and wait tables instead! Don't feel like working? That's fine, just don't show up to work and then yell at the co-workers you left during lunch rush and watch the trouble ensue. Fun for the whole family!


In all seriousness, I have never had so much fun rearranging furniture in so many different ways and knocking down my infant son's bedroom to renovate my new bathroom - to work my way up from a trailer to my dream house, to where I have enough money to renovate everyone's houses so that everyone has a dream house! 


There is a real joy in taking a step back from the insecurities and responsibilities of your real life to take in a false sense of accomplishment in Sims. 

10/10

Sims seems to only have gotten worse with the years. Personally, I'd much prefer Sims 2: Life Stories on Steam. The menu's are particularly frustrating. Compared to my 200+ other games, this one might just get the reward for worst menu's. It takes forever to find the options you want, or to get to / back to the main menu. Same goes with switching from and to the neighborhood. All the hints in the top right telling you how to play get annoying real fast and why do we even have custom content? If we want that, we'll install mods. Basically, simpler was better when it comes to the Sims. (also, I miss my electric guitar. Didn't care much for the acoustic one. Adding it was fine, but why remove the original guitar?).

Other then that, the Sims is a classic that everyone should have played. I would just recommend getting an earlier version (will be tricky to get your hands on though).

Lots of expanded stuff from other sims games! A lot of creative flexibility too. 
Pros: World feels large. Can edit the appearance of almost anything. Animations are fun. Editing the town is simple. More nuances to people's relationships to each other. Can do fun things with houses like multiple basements, balconies, archways, half-walls, etc. Personality traits are fun to play with.
Cons: Steam version seems to have trouble clicking objects into place when in build/buy mode. Hairstyles are limited. Create-a-Sim heavily leans toward Caucasian features and hair. If you want to read into it, there are some real shallow ideas about materialism and money here- all sims are programmed to want more stuff and more money and they're fulfilled when they get it. Everyone's kind of a caricature of a human being. Up to you if that's benign or not.
University expansion is, weirdly, belittling to its players. An object description, for example, reads: "You're full of revolutionary ideas! You'll forget all about them when you learn about things like mortgage and car insurance! But for now, buy this flag!" Several other moments like this. Sims normally has a cynical-humor kind of tone that I love but it becomes distractingly political here.

Amazing game, especially considering how cheap the game and expansion packs are when on sale. It runs like hot garbage on Windows 10 but the game is very enjoyable and when compared to the lack of polish EA puts on the Sims series you might as well get sims 3 which is cheaper and more fun (imo) than Sims 4; it's also easier to get up and running on Windows 10 than Sims 2. The nostalgia factor help the score for sure in my case. It really is a nightmare when it comes to optimization though, like its genuinely awful to run.

UPDATE: Finally upgraded from a laptop with a i3 and integrated graphics to an actual desktop and my Radeon RX 580 GPU makes the loudest weeeeeeeeeeeeeerrrreeeeeerrrreeee noise and is whining everytime i load Sims 3, I went into the files and changed it to where Sims 3 knows my graphics card but the noise won't stop no matter the settings so I now would not recommend buying this game unless your GPU is from before 2014, if you do buy it make sure to get it when it's on sale for 5 dollars.

UPDATE 2: Finally got it working after downloading a Skyrim FPS limiter mod and just extracting it to the Sims 3 bin folder, I couldn't get AMD Radeon software to limit my FPS in Sims 3 so I'm happy this method worked. Still can't give it a good vote though.

This is a fine game. However, after hitting nearly 50 hours I've seen most it has to offer. Some of the fun mechanics are DLC-exclusive (like opening a Laundromat because the laundy items are locked behind DLC, or opening a store to sell stuff because the mechanics of a functional store are locked behind a DLC). So, it's not possibly to experience this product to its full potential without spending hundreds of dollars at asking price.

Essentially this is a perfect product if all of the DLC were contained in one big bundle.

However, we have content segregation due to the capitalistic nature of AAA company business models that try to house so many employees at the consumers' expense, reflected in high prices of their products. 10 years down the line, the DLC for this product are not worth their asking price, yet the company doesn't seem to care.

If you want to spend $20 to get roughly 50 hours of entertainment, be my guest. I think it's worth it. Some people get more, but I've already seen all the game has to offer. I'll still play it, but the experience is already dying out for me. $20 per DLC is just not worth it when I can get another 50 hour experience from a different (possibly more entertaining) game at that price. I'd say each DLC is worth $2.00 USD if you want to be fair to consumers (and we'd probably buy them all at that price).

Anyway, that's my review. You allowed Capitalism to ruin what could have been an experience to stand the test of time, essentially segregating over 80% of the world's population from being able to afford your product. So, each of you from EA I hope you're enjoying your salary, because a lot of people can't enjoy your content because of it. Even if you have no control over prices, you still benefit at our expense. Go indie like Kojima.

This is still the best Sims game out there. Sims 4 is slowly catching up in some areas and is better in others, but over all, Sims 3 still has the best freedom of play, the most options, the least restrictions, and the best mods available. Unfortunately, Sims 3 can be a bit temperamental/unstable with all the expansions and mods running at full tilt. Normally, Sims 3 also requires you to install everything in very specific orders for them to work together, but Steam's version handles the expansion installation order for you, so... HUGE PLUS for getting it on Steam!

This is my first time playing Sims 3. I remember the original Sims from when I was a kid. It seems like they have made a lot of improvements so you can focus on the story of your characters more than the minutia of their various needs (though, that minutia is still there.) Mood ups and downs adds another colorful variable to their every-day dramas. Being able to interact with the town makes it feel more real, less like that creepy canned feeling of living in a fish-bowl. My Sim can walk right over to their neighbor's house and strike up a convo. If you like Sims, this is probably the best one. If you haven't played Sims before, get ready to get addicted.

The Sims 3 makes me feel right at home, but with a large amount of extra features on top of what i'm used to; the biggest one being the open world without any loading screens (except for going on vacation to other countries). This game is just amazing. I had always wanted this game ever since I started playing The Sims on my iPad. I knew that the PC version was the best version of The Sims 3, and honestly, I was right. The Create-A-Sim is excellent- the slider function provides so much diversity when creating my sims. The loading screen now contains a minigame that rewards you with Lifetime Happiness Points, which give the loading screens at least some importance. The gameplay is great as well- it's very amusing to watch my sims do whatever, and even more fun to control them. I really enjoyed building relationships with sims in the household and out. The Build and Buy Mode is also amazing, as there is a variety of options for customization. The music in this game is also excellent. Overall, The Sims 3 is an amazing game and I would highly recommend it.

I can't say whether I recommend the sims 3 or don't recommend it. This is one of those games where you can't make up your mind. I'll admit it, I've been a big fan of the series, having the complete collection of the first one and its online remake "FreeSo", the sims 2 Ultimate Collection and the Sims 4. Out of all of them, the fourth instalment is the worst one and the second instalment is the best one. The sims 2 is one of those amazing sequels like Team fortress 2, halo 2 or timesplitters 2, a game which expands everything and makes change that kept bringing you back to it.

With the third game, I don't know how to put it, I have good things and bad things to say about it. The good things about this game is that the AI is far smarter than the previous games. The AI in this game isn't stupid and needs don't decay ridiculously quickly. I also like how time now progresses as I play along, it feels like a real interactive story is going on when you play this game, people age and make friends and enemies, an aspect which I adore about this game. Playing the second one you have to play in rotation whether you like it or not which was one of my main issues with the second game but maybe that is what encouraged more interactions with each family you have in your neighbourhood, building more on the story you want to tell. Now that time is always moving, you can sit back and enjoy what happens in your world. Build and buy mode was also vastly improved with the third game, everything clicks into place properly and you're no longer limited to a small grid. The gameplay of the sims 3 is brilliant, its much better than the second, first and fourth games

Now comes the issues with the sims 3. First and foremost this is a game that you have to mod to enjoy whether you like it or not. The story progression, while it is good, is shambolic at times and you have to install Nraas mods to fix up the performance issues as well as the story progression. For instance, default story progression will have your sims buy a horse even if they didn't have a stable for them (if you have the pets expansion that is) so what sense does this make? ontop of that, you need mods, especially clothing and slider mods to make your sims have character. The character creator in this game isn't good but to make it better you have to download slider mods. And when all these issues are fixed, the game shines very well.

But this doesn't stop technical problems from occurring. First off you have the launcher. Any game with a launcher always brings bad luck from my experience and I hate them, why do I have to launch the game twice and overload my disk?  Uplay games have this same problem and games after the 3d universe of GTA have suffered from the same issue to the point that GTA IV was broken at one point and GTA IV EFLC is still to this day, BROKEN because developers aren't doing anything to solve the problem. The sims 3's launcher is clunky with a poor UI designed for it. I especially dislike how some mods are put as "downloads" which can only be added to the game through installing them with the launcher whereas others can easily be put in the mods folder with no issue. Launchers are some serious issue not with just this game but with any game on steam. Another technical problem everyone faces is CAS lag spikes whenever loading everything and this is by far the most annoying, other issues include random lag stuttering for no issue whatsoever.

One final issue I have with the sims 3, is that creating your own world is not user-friendly at all. One of the key reasons I play this series is because I make my own characters and worlds. The second game was really good at this, lots were easy to place and world were also easy to create with the ease of simcity 4 (another brilliant maxis title). With the sims 3, I don't think CAW is supported with windows 10 because it is completely broken and refuses to install on my pc. Luckily, many CC makers have made really good worlds, especially for people with a low amount of expansions. But even then, putting in rabbit holes is an annoying job, why couldn't they just include them in the lots tab? 

Look, I don't hate this game, I like the gameplay, it is a good game. But the stuff you have to do just to make it right is real time consuming. Expansions need to be bought (Seasons is by far the best one), mods need to be installed (Which make the game 10x better) and technical issues need to be fixed. I love the gameplay of it but it depends on what you're up for when it comes to this game. As for the future of the sims series, most people said the game died at 3 which I can agree with. The fourth instalment is a total joke and a cash cow encouraged by annoying YouTubers who love giving EA the spotlight. Hopefully, Paralives can learn from the second and third games and shape up to be the best life simulation game possible
I love that this game has a lot of gameplay and I definitely recommend this game!

If you've ever dreamed about creating your own virtual avatars and living out the lives you desired or want to explore without reaping the consequences in real life, then this is definitley the game for you! Although this game has been out for almost a decade and EA has stopped supporting Sims 3 in favour of Sims 4 for a few years now, I still think it's better for anybody interested in simulation games to purchase this instead. For one this is available on Steam, EA Origin, and retail (DVD) so you don't have to worry about having to sign up for exclusive services just for a single game. Another benefit(s) are the different strengths of this game that have been omitted or weakened in the sequel Sims 4, such as having to see a loading screen each time you visit a different part of the town. Finally, this game has huge mod support much like l4d2 (even to this day) so you can fix issues and expand upon the content. 

Of course, this game is known for having poor optimization due to EA not properly supporting the game on newer systems both soft and hard so anyone with Windows 8 or newer and with graphics cards beyond 2013 will run into problems. The most obvious being low framerate and extremely choppy camera...unless you modify some files to force the game in recognizing your GPU (doesn't seem to work for integrated, sorry) and limiting the framerate through Nvidia Control Panel or AMD Radeon Settings as Vsync isn't an option through in-game settings. Speaking of which, if you don't restart the game upon changing the video settings your computer will crash and force reboot and any progress will be lost; each driver update seems to revert them back to default. Also, playing the game for more than a number of weeks in-game time for any save file causes lower framerate and less stability too (can be fixed with mods).

It may seem bad but if you go through a little optimizing yourself, the game should run fine and there won't be any problems anymore. Sims 3 overall expands upon and improves its predecessors SIms 2 and 1, and is considered by many fans to be the best game in the entire franchise. In addition to controlling virtual avatars known as Sims, you can renovate, upgrade, and customize homes; change the landscape and the residents of the town; explore a wide variety of places like the beach, art gallery, pool, fitness gym, etc. with only one loading screen; complete many oppurtunities, skills, hobbies, career paths, and life goals that intertwine with one another. There aren't really any predefined goals so likg Gmod you have to decide yourself what to do aside from a few objectives that are not mandatory. Be forewarned that your Sims can die and if they all pass away then the save file can no longer be played.

Customization in Sims 3 is not limited to homes, but also to the avatars and the town - features like breast size, voice pitch, tattoos, real estate, business development, eviction, etc are some of the many available. The simplicity of point-and-click along with a HUD that changes depending on the mechanics is a good approach at catering to gamers whether it be casual or veteran. For a "childish" game the music and sound effects are nicely done and don't seem to over the top or the quality of indie/retro games with the former playing under certain conditions like l4d2. Graphics wise, it isn't the best looking game even back in 2009 with many textures being poorly done or just photos compressed on to 2D surfaces, though the lighting and shadows give off a cartoony look. The polygon count and models make Sims 3 contribute to the game looking alright, not the best but not mediocre even after all these years. 

Going to your GPU's settings can let you improve the graphics further with Vsync, AA, and Filtering Mode (a must) while lowering the settings in-game that affect the rendering of trees, households, and objects improves the performance. Due to the lack of support for newer hard and software, avoid playing Sims 3 at 1080p and beyond unless you don't mind the text and HUD being super tiny. EA released about a dozen expansion packs but they're expensive so only buy a few of them during holiday Steam sales as most cater to people with specific preferences or give players extra stuff. I'd recommend getting Seasons, Generations, Late Night, and Pets, while others like World Adventures or Island Paradise are up to you to decide. If you were never interested in simulation games, then don't bother; however, if you buy this please optimize the game and only buy the game and DLC during sales as EA is a greedy company (less so than Valve)?

It truly pains me to say this, because I enjoyed the previous games, but The Sims 3 is a poorly optimized piece of garbage. It has to be.

The game worked like crap when it first came out, so I thought I didn't have the best hardware for it at the time, but it's still lagging like crazy today. Even with a beastly desktop machine on any setting.

Trying ANY so-called solution or "fix" over the years has been a great waste of time. From forcing the game to recognize newer video cards, verifying steam cache, clearing the games cache, resetting all sims, uninstalling custom content, reinstalling the game, lowering the graphics settings, playing offline, etc. etc. ... ad nauseam ...

It's just not worth it. Again, I like "the sims," and I've even put many hours into this particular sims game, but at this point I can no longer recommend The Sims 3. I know nothing of Sims 4, but you might just wanna go for that one instead, or you could just go outside and make some real friends!

How do I put it bluntly to either warn you away from this game or get you into it. Hmm, Oh I know, this game is broke as hell. There are 2 different reasons why this game is broken, one is good, and the other is concerning. First, this game is really addicting, seeing as how you can make your own people (or yourself) and see how they survive in a virtual world. However, this game is pretty boring if you only want to play it without any expansions. I like the different life states, so I constantly use them in my worlds, but this leads into my second point, and this one is a very bad one. These expansions, some are really good and bring many good and fun things and others are just glorified skin packs, are expensive as hell. Yes the old EA microtransactions curse. Each and every one of the expansions are $20, just as much as the game itself. Now ask yourself, am I going to need any of these, absolutely not, but why not have a dog or cat,or be able to become a mermaid by eating a bit of kelp. Take my word for it please, wait for a sale to buy any of these. Its a waste of money for all of these packs. Now for the final verdict. Do you want to have fun playing a game that EA has never patched? Well its your choice, but get this game. Just seeing the many ways they fucked up making this game is always fun to mess around with.

It's good play to kill long periods of time, it does have it's glitches now and then but they are occasional enough to deal with and there are very simple ways of dealing with them such as: 

Whenever a Sim's baby is stuck on a stairwell and cannot be moved, press the options menu and press 'Edit Town', then there should be an option to move your household (including your house) to another lot and the glitch should be reset. The same can be applied for when a Sim will not leave your household. There is also the option of using cheat codes to fix glitches, which can be used by pressing Ctrl + Shift + C at the same time where a bar at the top of the game should show up. This bar can be typed into. Typing 'testingcheatsenabled on' and then opening up the bar again (it will close once a cheat code has been used) and then, 'resetsim insertfirstname insertlastname should reset the glitch and cause the sim to reset to their respected place; for a baby in their cot, for a neighbour their home.

The best The Sims game in the franchise.

Graphics are better than The Sims 4 (cartoony graphics that has nothing to do with real-life) and The Sims 2 (faces are ugly), there are a lot of expansions and mods, it has a real open world with amazing custom towns, memorable soundtrack and a lot of features that didn't make to The Sims 4.

That was a list of advantages. Sadly, it's a game published by Electronic Arts so there are many problems with that.

First of all, if you want to enjoy this game to the fullest you need to buy expansions. In my opinion, they are too expensive considering the fact that most AAA games have their GOTY version with all DLC released that cost even less than The Sims 3 with all expansions after around 10 years (6 if expansions' release dates are counted) of being on the market!

In addition to that, there is "The Sims 3 Store", which works like real-life furniture/clothing/whatever-you-imagine store but virtual. You can buy stuff with your virtual currency bought for real money. The main problem with that is a way too high price for that stuff. For $10 you can add 1000 SimPoints to your account. and for that, you can buy, like, 10 furniture or 10 hair. There are also few worlds that can cost even $50! They even increased the price to be a little higher than the exact few thousand to make you buy more simpoints! For example, Aurora Skies cost 4307 SimPoints. you can't buy 4307 SimPoints so instead of paying $43 you have to pay $50 for remaining points that you might not need at all! Thankfully, they didn't ban mods so you can download even better stuff for free from the Internet. It's not that easy with expansions though because there aren't many mods that are equivalent to features from expansions.

Alright, so what if you are naive and rich enough to buy all/most of these Expansion Packs/DLCs/Stuff Packs/whatever-they-are-called-by-EA? You have a problem then because they couldn't even optimize this game! Yes, they are taking a few hundred (maybe even a few thousand because Sims 3 Store stuff is really expensive) dollars from you and it works like poop. They left this game broken and never cared about fixing it. Roads are broken and cause many performance and scripting bugs, scripts tend to save file corruption, it stutters as hell even on modern pc, memory leaks are common, multithreading is broken, sims get stuck without any reason, if you play longer newly generated sims have the exact same face, new GPUs aren't recognized, v-sync doesn't exist so it's possible to get a lot of FPS and stress your GPU and a lot more. EA doesn't have any plans to fix these issues. There is still a hope that they fix some problems eventually because the 64-bit version has been announced for the macOS. 64-bit port could mean that there should be less CPU and Memory utilization problems so we would be able to enjoy this game with all expansions at least without stuttering and FPS drops.

To sum up everything, The Sims 3 is a really fun game but thanks to greedy and lazy EA it never got treated as it should be. Instead of fixing the most expanded game in the franchise they just threw many main features away, added some new and released it as a new game, of course with more expansion packs that add similar features that sims 3 expansions did for you to buy once again. Owners of the previous game got f**ked twice and EA is happy with that.

For that reason, I don't recommend paying EA for this game. If you really want to play it legally though you can buy just a base game on sale because it's the only thing that works alright. You will miss many features but at least you won't overpay and your game will work ok. If anything changes I will edit my review.

[h1] ThE mOsT hAuNtEd GaMe In ThE wOrLd [/h1]

The Sims 3 is a "real life simulation game" where you play as some loser and do the things that your social anxiety prevents you from doing in real life. You'll start out buying a house and then getting a job until you die. Along the way, you'll decorate your house with various items and furniture, and maybe find a special someone. There's also some "wacky events" to prevent the game from causing existential dread, especially if you have some of the DLCs. The game's fairly simple and is obviously meant for casual players. You don't have to interact with a lot of things and often your character will just "do something" with the meter building up, specifically when it comes to working jobs. The relationship mechanics are fairly standard, where you'll be repeating the same "friendly actions" over and over again until someone likes you enough to sleep with you. Just like in real life. There are "life goals" and each Sim is different in their varying traits. It is fun to watch your Sims grow from children to adults, and move out on their own. Speaking of which, the "living world" is actually fairly decent, where each Sim will do their own thing and also die. Just like you.

It should be apparent that the latest Sims release was criticized due to its lack of an open world, which is fair criticism since in this game you can go wherever in the town without any loading times. Therefore, if you want a Sims game I would recommend this one. Still, when it comes down to it there really isn't a "ton" to do even when you have all the DLC, especially because of that whole "you're not going to interact with anything, the meter's just going to fill and you pretend your Sim is doing something". The most enjoyment you're going to find in the game is building up your house and creating your own little dynasty, maybe making it so everyone in the town is related to you. The "special events" really just cause you to deviate from monotony in order to get some more cash or earn more points in order to get "life time rewards". This game is a "real life" situation, so maybe it's wrong to expect really much more than what it already is, and it does a fine job at what it is. It lets you "simulate" a life that you'd rather have, while also adding jokes and "fantasy" elements to keep it from becoming boring. Overall, if you want a life simulation game, just get this. 

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Towns feel completely lived-in with everyone going throughout their daily lives, making you never feel alone
[*]Relationship mechanics are sweet and lets you have the friends you never could have
[*]Creating your families and watching them grow has a certain satisfaction to it, along with building the homes of your dreams
[*]Huge variety of customization options and the graphics still stand up pretty okay to this day
[*]There are a significant variety of things to do, but most of it is just new settings to interact with people or get your meters up
[*]Fun fantasy and sci-fi elements to keep the game from feeling too bland
[/list]
[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Relationships are super mechanical, if we could make friends by hugging them 30 times without consent then life would be very different
[*]Sometimes you're just going to get bored of doing the same things over and over again and watching your Sims age
[*]While the world is "lived-in", NPCs lives could be a bit more dynamic than they are
[*]Most of the environments and buildings are going to be identical throughout towns
[*]DLC is still overpriced and much of it doesn't add much
[*]Water DLC
[/list]

For anyone having trouble with the Steam version, you can (and should) activate the game, as well as any DLC you buy through Steam, directly in the Origin client with the serial numbers Steam gives you

You can do this by installing the steam version, pressing play, and when presented the serial numbers Steam provides you for the base game and any DLC you bought, copy and paste those into the Origin client directly to activate it in Origin. That way everything is detected and registered with the base game properly in Origin, and you don't have to go through headaches that I imagine are numerous if you try to play it through the launcher included with the Steam version.

Once you have the Origin version activated and installed, you can uninstall the Steam version and just run it directly through Origin.

Also, look for the game and DLC when they're on sale. Normal prices are kind of insane for this game, which is why I held off getting this until they're probably gearing up to release Sims 5.

Originally looking for The Sims 4 in Steam platform, but unfortunately only The Sims 3 is available on Steam.

Although The Sims 3 does not have a better and higher quality graphics like The Sims 4, but who would have thought that I actually enjoy my time in The Sims 3 to the point I get so absorbed that I played it for more than 200+ hours. It is surprisingly way better than what I originally expected from The Sims 3.

The Sims 3 is well-known as a life simulation game, but honestly, it is more surreal than what you are imagining and expecting. As a player, you'll get to choose how your Sims live their lives. You're tasked with making them happy, and seeing them through adulthood and into their senior years. Along the way, you may pursue any number of goals, participating in player-made challenges, or simply attempting to complete their lifetime wish.

Even though there is a lot of strategic depth to explore, yet it is also highly accessible. You don't have to be a 'gamer' to enjoy the Sims games, you just need a computer or laptop and to use a mouse. This game is definitely an "everyone" game - children, teenager, adults or even elderly could even play this. 

The Sims 3 also shows a lot of depth with its socializing system. Based on personality, charisma skill levels, and character traits, Sims will be able to perform a huge array of social interactions. Your Sim will develop relationships over time, and may have friends, enemies and even fall in love to eventually get married and WooHoo to make a baby. The interface for socializing is simple and intuitive, it is very easily to understand even for new players who have never play The Sims before.

Overall, The Sims 3 is truly a very entertaining life stimulation game. If you're a gamer and you like games with a lot of depth, and open-ended gameplay, you'll probably enjoy the Sims 3. Moreover, it is a game which anyone could play regardless of ages. If you have not play The Sims before, I highly recommend you to try play The Sims 3 and you will not regret it. Absolutely worth it!

I've had a love hate relationship with The Sims over the years since the game was first developed. I've had low spec' computers and I've had high spec' computers in that time and I can safely conclude that this wonderful game is sadly very buggy on any system. In fact it's notoriously buggy, it will lag, it will freeze, it will take ages to load, it will crash to desk top.
However, in between those times it really is a compellingly addictive game of architecture, interior design and God-like manipulation of little humans. After a while you start to think of real life as a giant Sims game with all of your social interactions adding or subtracting from your relationship scores and your hunger bar flashing as you miss your lunch hour.
Be prepared to look up forum help and fixes for various bugs, but on the whole this is a game I keep going back to despite its flaws because of how fun it is.

If you've never played a Sims game, grab this one on sale. It's a must-play social phenomenon.

The Sims is still largely in a genre of its own. There is little else like it... Except the other Sims games, which are VERY much like it. Unfortunately the Sims 4 may never come to Steam, but it's so similar it doesn't really matter; the main thing it improves are the graphics and character customization. Sims 3 has larger more open worlds (fewer loading screens!), packs more content into the base game, and generally feels more immersive, interactive and alive to me.

The DLC adds a lot. Into the Future and World Adventures were my faves. Avoid Island Paradise; it's still too buggy to play. And definitely get into modding because there is a whole world of extra content on modthesims.

Sims 3, in my opinion, is way better than Sims 4. I have played a little bit of both, and while Sims 4 offers a bit more customization in how the Sims look, it's still nothing compared to the interactivity in this game. While yes, I bought 20/21 of the expansion packs, there is still much more content in them. If I didn't have them, I'd say I would still enjoy what the game had to offer. From house building, to mastery of skills, to advancement in careers, there's usually always something you can do or try out. 

Personally, the expansion packs add a ton more fun and engaging content. The main must-haves are Into the Future, Supernatural, Pets, Adventure, Island Paradise and Seasons. These packs provide lots of content and hidden secrets that make the game less watch your sims go through life and more engage with my sims. Especially the Adventure and Supernatural. 

Second to those would be University, Showtimes, Ambitions Generations, and Late Night. These are more for adding new skills and events/items to interact with, but I feel I didnt use all the much. Especially university. I havent played any content through that expansion, and the main thing that you get from it is a degree that makes your sim go 3/10 levels in the chosen career. Maybe its more entertaining than I originally thought, but I have yet to try it. The stuff expansion packs are more for interior design. Some items are interactive, but most just provide boosts in mood because its comfy or high-end. I wouldnt recommend buying them unless theyre on sale (thats when I got them). 

But the main thing I enjoy getting (despite some dependence on owning expansion packs or paid items), is the Exchange on the Sims 3 website. Creators make custom content ranging from families to lots to even whole towns. Its like visual mods, but can make the experience goofier or more realistic. And its all free to download.

This game isnt for everyone. Even for me, I play it for about a week or two straight, and then put it down for months. Its a good game to come back to or bring yourself back into gaming when school has kicked your ass. Its as engaging as you make it be.

This game is a [b]classic[/b]. This game really helped me cope with severe boredom and loneliness back in the day. I'm sure some of you once had a point in your life where nobody wanted to visit or hang out for one reason or the other. I've become so engrossed in this game, used to have custom maps, and had some great saves I wish I'd backed up.

The Sims 3 is the best in the series. Some will argue that TS2 is superior, and that's fine. TS2 was fantastic as well (I missed out on this one and played it later) but This one introduces some great features not available in any of the other games. Create-a-Style (CAS) Where you can manipulate in-game textures and materials... in-game! You can customise everything to your heart's content, this includes selecting patterns and even fine-tuning colors! This works on Characters, objects and buildings! This game has near limitless potential for the ones who put in the effort! I've managed to get so much fun-time out of [i]just[/i] the Base-Game alone! Another exceptional feature this game has, that makes it's core is the "Open world" environment. The gameplay takes place all on a large inter-connected map. Lots are separate "plots" which back then, not rendering them made the performance bearable. You can explore the entirety of the map all to your heart's content! Also there are Expansions that append to the experience. 

Also the soundtrack has really grown on me. While I'm a bigger fan of TS1's mix of Jazzy, classical and Piano-tune music, The soundtrack here isn't bad at all! I didn't care much for it at first, but I eventually really began to like it. It's hard to believe it's been 10 years this came out! It's a shame that EA didn't give the core engine the love it needed; namely optimization. The Successor (if you can call it that) actually REGRESSES in many ways.

This game would benefit so well from modern CPUs with all these cores and threads. Even current high-end CPUs will give sub-par performance with this game, not because our PC's suck, but because it all runs on just 1 core, so keep that in mind as 2009 wasn't really on the multi-core train yet, despite quad cores being a thing!

Not to mention, there ARE mods out there that do fix some issues, i.e. stuck sims, adding more life to the town by changing AI behavior, etc etc. 

There also exists "The Sims 3 Ultimate Fix" that can resolve startup issues, but it also behaves like a "NO-CD patch" which bypasses the "Launcher" and can be played offline.

Is this game perfect? No. Long answer: Noooooooooooooooooooooooooo. There are bugs that may still be to this day unresolved. This game unfortunately is one of the ones you [i]need[/i] mods to really get the best experience. 

If you feel lonely, have no one around to spend time with and have some free time to kill? Get this game and enjoy. At least you'll have a much higher frame-rate than I did back in the day, unless your PC is also from 2009. XD

Despite it's age, Sims 3 is a very unique and fun game that I would recommend to more casual players or those who abhor violence and gore and would rather have a more calming game to play. It does contain sexual content, though all nudity is censored. I consider this the superior game to it's successor, Sims 4, as it has more features readily available in the base game and the expansion packs are far cheaper. (That being said, save your money on 'Stuff Packs' as they only add cosmetic items, and buyer beware when buying the 'Island Paradise' expansion, as there are a lot of glaring issues and bugs). 

Pros: 
-Hundreds of hours worth of content, practically endless replayability. 
-Option to have explicitly bisexual, gay, and lesbian sims. (There is no explicit option to have your sim be trans.) 
-Ease of access and simple commands. 
-Sims 3 Exchange offers easy, secure modding for free (maps, custom clothing, etc.) 
-Extremely customizable, allows for great deal of creativity in sim creation and home building. 

Cons: 
-Extra content is locked behind DLC (Pets, Seasons, Adventure, Supernatural...) and there are tons of micro-transactions that only add cosmetic items such as hairstyles, clothing, and furniture. 
-Long loading times, sometimes freezes or crashes. Make sure to save often! I've heard horror stories where people lost hours of progress!

Some dlc's add to your town and some add a whole new town you can visit, move to or do jobs. Yet, all dlc's do add items like furniture, items, hair-styles, clothes and design to your game.
Seasons and Ambitions primarily adds to the town you live in - creating weather, festivals, more careers/jobs to current buildings and new buildings around town.

Pretty much got this because the Sims2 stopped working... Waited until sales hit.  

Sims 2 was better, Sims 3 is basically more or less much of the same as before.  If you have a working copy of the Sims2, you already have a better game.  If your like me and you had to move over to the Sims 3... Eh... I miss the Sims2.  

Off the bat, it feels too easy, not the Sims was ever a franchise with a lot of depth, the issue is its *too* simple.  I created a Vampire and 10 days like it was immortal, as soon joined her 3 days later her husband (also a vampire) and as they grew up, their 3 children. 

With the Sims2 you can say you got a better game over the original, but aside from some graphic updates and tweaks here and there, it doesn't feel like much of a different beast to the Sims2. 

I can't thumb it down because, aside from the in-game coins thing trying to make you spend money on content they don't sell with any packages, its not a bad game.  But no Sims game is truly bad.  Its just that the add-on DLC, as with all past versions makes you wonder what is truly being added to the game.  It gets worst in Sims4, so this is likely the best of both words overall with the Sims3, so take it or leave it because after this game... The future looks grim.

Edit:
Going to add in a few more things... So... An issue I have with this game is its full of needless fluff.  Sims and Sims2 have fluff, but their more streamlined.  Some of the intereactions a Sim can do are needless. 

Adding to the previous comment about Vampires being too easy to make immortal, there is also the Fairy.  Both these beings make the game too easy, you have no reason to play a normal Sim unless you want the challenge.  Within 15 days I had my first immortal fairy when I tried it.  

Other critques include that there are tons of items; you will not use 75% of them.  This was a problem in previous sims yes, but... IT gets worst in Sims3 the more items you own via packs or items from the Sims store. You will never ever use most of the content of the library because the item is either trash, not that useful or useless. Often what happens is for example, you want to buy a telescope.  Well you buy a cheap one to start with.  Then you wait for the money to buy a better one.  Except... The most expensive isn't "better" all the time and often a cheaper one is better. (I've put countless hours into Sims 3 off Steam)

If we were to judge each main Sims game off the base game then Sims 3 is the clear winner as it is the most feature-complete and personally caters to my play style. It also changed the gameplay from that of 1 and 2 and still even from 4 by going true open world, allowing for vehicle transport, neighbourhood strolling and proper rewarding exploration. The Create-A-Sim mode is also the best in this game with the colour swatches AKA Create-A-Style, additional clothing slots and strong customisation features such as the face and personality traits.

The building side of the game also saw many improvements, conveniences, new features and more ways to make the lot of your dreams. Although you can't make your own town from scratch in-game, a world map tool came to be that let you essentially do the same thing.

The SimPoint microtransactions are disgusting, over-priced, unethical and still to this day, but they also meant content that adds new gameplay features to be added in the game. Unlike other Sims games that didn't really allow for this.

The graphics aren't that great but they are better than previous Sims games, the most common complaint being the weird plastic-like art style that make the sims look like dolls and lifeless. Additionally, the performance of the game is really garbage, installing many mods and/or expansions can cause incredible slow downs and extremely long load times. But now in 2019 with a beefy rig, these performance issues are no longer a thing, which lends this game to stand the test of time even moreso.

Sims 3 is my favourite Sims game, even with all expansions installed, but of course Sims 2 and 4 did certain things better or have features not seen in other Sims games. However, I think Sims 3 offers more good things than it did take away bad ones and I highly recommend buying this and the expansions on sale on a decent rig.
Love that this made it to steam, but it can get buggy at times, nevertheless still love it! I hope other sim games can make it to steam as well~

This game is amazing. Much better than Sims 4 in a lot of regards, especially if you like customizing every aspect of your Sims and other creations and the OPEN WORLD which is awesome compared to Sims 4's very segmented pieces. What that means, though, is that Sims 3 is probably harder to run on most PCs than Sims 4 is, funny enough. The NRAAS mods like Master Controller, Story Progression, and Overwatch are imperative because the game is honestly not very well optimized and without those mods you'll run into problems all the time. I would also recommend using the 3booter launcher, because it will cap your FPS to 30FPS so that your CPU isn't working at max speeds to run this game at hundreds of frames per second while the game logic itself still runs at only 30. I played this game for over 200 hours before I found that launcher and it's a godsend. I wish I could still track my playtime but it's a trade I'm willing to make.

Another thing to note is that when you update your GPU drivers ALL of your settings get reset. Your save data will remain but even things like the aging scale are all reset, so make sure you take note of all your settings before you update drivers.

As far as DLC goes, wait for sales because during the Steam Winter/Summer sales they will go down to $5 instead of $20. I haven't bought any Stuff packs but I have most of the EPs and would recommend all of them for the sheer amount of cool content that they add, including entire worlds. For $5 it's absolutely worth it, but $20 is probably not as great. The base game + Generations and Pets also frequently goes on sale for around $20 so that's when I would buy it.

Not recommended unless you buy DLC. Game gets samey, boring, and the game amounts to pressing buttons then watching your Sim do the thing. Game doesn't have achievements and LITERALLY EVERY DLC IS 20 DOLLARS AMOUNTING TO ~400 DOLLAR PRICE TAG. Some of the DLC can cause technical issues and add content of varying quality. Meaning research should be done before buying.

Completely not worth it. The Sims is a fat cash grab by EA and is garbage. If you enjoy the housebuilding mechanic or the management of sims then I'm happy for you and wish I could enjoy these core features. However, for me most of the gameplay loop (Job, piss, poo, whatever other bs you have to deal with your sim) is a chore and keeps me from enjoying building. 

Overall, for me, the sims is a good idea gone completely wrong. Perhaps the fourth game is better, but that's not on Steam at all.

Went into this as my first Sims since the original Sims, so here are some differences and my opinions on them: 

Sims now age and die - not a fan of this, especially with the very short life span on default, though in the menu you can increase lifespans to a point where aging pretty much wont happen

Sims have goals/wishes - these are nice, it gives you something more to do than just focus on making money and advancing your career

Besides regular careers, there are other ways to make money - these are nice additions, you can make a living as a fisherman, street musician, odd jobs from phone calls, etc

Sims have cell phones - nice to be able to use the phone whenever, though I don't know why they still allow you to purchase a land line phone?

Not everything is in build/design mode, you can go to stores and actually shop - this is a very nice addition, gives your daily routine more variety 

Design (or decorate, whatever you call it) mode has very little option - in Sims 1 i recall having so many items to choose from it was very easy to make your house unique, this game (base version, no DLC) honestly has very little; though i know thats part of the ploy to get you to buy the DLCs

A beautiful game filled with many fancy ways to waste your time.
 It's quite honestly a blank canvas that only really blooms once you have a good Expansion pack for it, and it's definitely worth buying DLC for.

It's pretty old, though, so it has some intricacies that need taking care of via third party applications.

Great game overall. It runs fine for me, despite the occasional frame-drop (though it usually lasts only a few seconds), and it has aged decently for its time. Though, it's far from perfect, it's still well worth the money (although I don't recommend getting all the DLC for it)

I decided to try The Sims 3 because I was looking for a building/management game of sorts, but I ended up dropping it after the first hour and a bit. During that short hour, I have already crashed into a billion of paywalls, which is saying something. Oh, you want to start in a nice-looking map, or you want your character to wear this nice costume? Nope, you gotta pay up, buddy. While I'm not completely adverse to micro-transactions, there is a ridiculously minuscule amount of content I can access within the base game, which isn't exactly cheap.

Secondly, this is a personal preference of mine but my god, the character customisation feels so... bad, for the lack of better term. I usually love customising my characters to the point that they have to look exactly how I imagine it in my head. Most games I have played can usually come pretty close if not identical to my mental image, but every character I've made in this game ends up looking like a demented child with every bad genes imaginable.

The last thing that drove me off the edge is that everything takes centuries to load/render despite the fact that I just upgraded my computer earlier this year (most likely due to outdated, inefficient coding structure). While I may not speak for others, I absolutely despise lag while playing games.

0/10 avoid this game unless you enjoy playing a laggy game, bad character models or crashing into paywalls.

You really can't go wrong with any Sims game.. This one in my opinion just happens to be the best one of the four games! Easily one of my greatest and most played childhood games. If so much content from this game wasn't paid dlc, it would easily make its way to one of my top 30 games of all time

While the game itself is fun to play, the game has one major technical issue that breaks the game (and possibly your computer). EA, in all their wisdom, didn't make sure that The Sims 3 stays capped at 60 fps. I have gone through the game options, my graphics card options, and my windows 10 options to try and keep it from surpassing this limit. However, if I go check the fps in-game (ctrl + shift + c, type in "fps on"), the game fluctuates between 200-300 fps when playing and 400-500 fps when loading. This causes the fans on my laptop, which was made 10 years after the game was made and well exceeds game requirements, to run at full power. Even then, my computer is reaching temperatures that can very well ruin the graphics card as well as other components. I only recommend this game to people who can afford to continually replace their laptops or wish to destroy another persons laptop.

The last Sims game I played was Bustin' Out for the Game Cube. I loved that Sims game and many parts of the Sims 3 have given me that old familiar feel from way back when in the days of classic Sims. This game is pretty great so far! There have been a few hiccups where it didn't save properly and I lost some progress but I think that's more my fault than anything else. As far as this game goes, FUN. It's a great game to play if you're not currently working and have days on end to throw into it. I say that too because this game is massive. If you have all $400 worth of all of the DLC content, there is almost nothing you can't actually do with your character. Even after acquiring all of the DLC, which I haven't done yet, there are also things in the game you need Sim Points to buy that aren't part of the DLC packs. The game just goes and goes and offers you a lifestyle for your Sim in every category imaginable whether you want to be inhuman, or a movie star, or a world traveler, or a chainsaw-wielding psychopath, or an organized crook, or pro musician, and so so much more. I can highly recommend this game for anyone who played the Sims back in the 90's and wants to go back to the ole' roots of the game's magic. This game captures it majestically.

This is an adorable and very funny and addictive game.  There's even certain loopholes you can do such as take over another family's house and obtain their large income, or just move in with them and go from there. I love how you can also build crazy houses and community hangout spots. Like I said, this is a very fun and entertaining game.

Pros: Fun to Play
It's fun running your own soap opera
Upgrading your characters through achievements is fun
Upgrading and redesigning your house can be fun when you've earned the money

Cons:
Expansion packs are ridiculously expensive and there's even more micro-transactions for single objects in the game.
Some of the time mechanics make no sense at all (for example you can't socially interact with someone while doing a job that seems to take ten times longer than you would in real life - who the hell spends more than an hour making pancakes?!)
Ridiculously slow to load no matter how powerful your machine is.
The triple speed when people are sleeping or at work is still too slow. Those moments are perpetually boring - if I were to design this, I would add a "dream" activity and a "job" activity because people do not pay this much money for a game to be bored.
It can still be ridiculously buggy, which I'm not impressed with at this stage.

Sims 3 is great! It has hours upon hours of things to do and the game lasts as long as your imagination does. 

Creating Sims and houses are fun and easy thanks to the create a style system, where you can add patterns and colours to any item you want. You can really make your Sim and house unique and different from what someone else has made. 

Gameplay is never a dull moment, you have skills to improve, simoleans to earn and romances to find... among maybe trapping a few people in a pool or lightning a fire in your worst enemies house once in a while.

Performance and graphics can be lacking depending on your system however. Since the game is open world, it is very resource intensive and some expansion packs can easily lag or straight up break the game. A big problem I've been having is lots of screen tearing and there doesn't seem to be a vSync option.

The expansion packs vary in quality, however they are all jam packed with stuff. Stuff packs are really lacking however, with only having furniture and clothing items and no gameplay and you don't get lots for the price you're paying. There is also an in game cash shop that sells even more furniture and clothing, alongside a few gameplay options. I would have prefered these be added into the existing expansion and stuff packs, but with enough patience (and lots of ads) you can get the in game cash items for free.


Other than the performance and the amount of extra content EA tries to tickle your wallet for. The Sims 3 is great and I highly recommend this if you're in the market for a life simulation game.... and I also very highly recommend you buy this instead of Sims 4.

I've only played the first two sims games so I can only speak to those, but I love this game so far! The expansion on creativity is much appreciated compared to The Sims 2 (the ability to rotate objects and add clutter especially). The life simulation portion has been greatly expanded as well, giving you better control on your sim's wants and needs, and the customization for creating the sims is amazingly robust. Being able to individually color clothing pieces is a boon.

Overall from my own personal experiences I can recommend this game if you want a good experience and enjoyed The Sims 1 and 2!

[h1]Buy At a Discount, then Download Free Stuff Online.[/h1]

Over the course of a week, I've played this game 110 hours... It's still great after all these years, but the EPs and SPs are just too frickin expensive. Get them when they're heavily discounted, but keep in mind there are several sites out there that will allow you to mod the absolute hll out of this game, and also some with [b]TONS AND TONS[/b] [i](and I mean TUHHNZZUH)[/i] of FREE content, like:
[list]
[*]New Careers & Social Interactions
[*]Improvements to Relationship Panel
[*]New types of stuff to Build/Buy
[*]Ridiculously swank custom houses
[*]Completely custom made towns inhabited by handmade sims
[*]Custom Create-a-sim features like Cat/Vampire/Supernova Eyes, and realistic skin, and better hairstyles, and better clothes, and Bling.
[*][b][i]New Frickin Vehicles[/i][/b]
[*]Disabling the annoying carpool after you have your own ride
[*]Mods that clean up the junk in your game every night, like radios/tvs that were never turned off, and abandoned cars
[/list]
There's so much stuff is kind of insane actually. I won't post the links to the sites here... I'm always weary of clicking a random link on a forum post. I recommend just Googling [i]Mod The Sims[/i], [i]Nraas[/i], [i]The Sims Resource[/i], and [i]Carls Sims 3 Guide[/i]. So yeah... if you're ready to sink your life into making a life for something that doesn't exist, then yes - you should buy this game.

Honestly, I love the level of control offered in the Sims games.  I've enjoyed them since I was a very young child, and think that different platforms have different great things to offer in the individual games.  Sims 3 in particular is one I keep coming back to.  I adore the default towns and have a lot of fun just exploring and familiarizing myself with the neighborhoods and town lore.  Obviously designing your own original or themed/fan characters is a huge plus, as well as designing and coloring your own homes!  I legit spend hours building my houses alone, and usually base them off of interesting houses I've seen IRL, or nice-looking blueprints for fancy homes online.

This game never feels stale because there's always something different to do.  Play as your own original characters, play as the NPC neighbors, play as your offspring, etc.  The possibilities really are endless in the Sims games, and the towns and custom descriptions for every item in the game really are charming.  I usually find myself snorting or chuckling to myself when I decide to peruse them.  Sims has such a nostalgic, happy feel for me, and it's associated with some of my most peaceful and positive memories growing up.  It's just a nice game to relax with and kill time in a way that's enjoyable.

I have honestly been so immersed in Sims 3 that I haven't even bothered playing Sims 4 yet, though it will come in due time.

An "oldie but goodie," this is arguably the best Sims game, both in animation and gameplay. And with so many expansions that add new items are even better, new features for said gameplay, I'd reccommend this one the most, too. I'm pretty sure everyone has at least heard of Sims, but forget Sims 4, and give into some nostalgia and pick up Sims 3! And even better - get it on Steam, which has frequent sales, unlike Origin, so you're not shelling out another 20 bucks every time you want an expansion pack. 

If you're into simulation games, if you want to make Sims die in a room without doors, if you want to act out a fantasy life or a character's life, or even if you just wanna wonder where all those hours went and how it got to be two in the morning already, then this game is for you.

I can see why this game is still getting some mixed or negative reviews. I just finally decided to buy the whole experience during the 2019 summer sale Prix and even though I am recommending this game (Because the Sims 3 is a great experience and still a better one than Sims 4 ATM) I still want to call out how absolutely greedy EA still is with this game. There are still BS microtrasactions for things that are already in the game that you downloaded (after so many f-ing years after this game's release) and not to mention the advertising for pointless stuff that you can buy from the store occasionally coming up in the notifications during gameplay. Though I still don't see the need for that with this old game, as even with the steep 75% discount on sales it still is a little bit more expensive than fully priced Triple A games by today's standards for the full experience. Luckily you don't need any of these as the Sims 3 has a great modding community and there's already a lot of high quality free custom content that you can download on the internet. 

TLDR
(1) The game is great
(2) EAs pushing of micro-transactions and locking of content already on (and taking up space on)  your system is not.
(3) The Sims community is very welcoming and great. Plus, There's a lot of free content that has been accumulated over the years, that is way better than anything that's on the Sims store. So feel free to go nuts with that :)

But overall, I enjoyed this game. I liked just watching things happen and making a story out of my gameplay experience. Granted, I had to get mods for the interesting parts to happen, But even the vanilla game has quite a few options that I wish the next game in the series did (Clothing customization, Open-ish world, Among others).

Overall, If you can handle the slow loading speeds and occasional lag spikes at points, This game can be pretty enjoyable.

The Sim's 3 has a lot to offer in the base game without needing to add any expansion. The basic premise of the game hasn't changed at all over the years, but they slim down the need requirement for easier flow of the gameplay without making you focus all the time on filling your sim's needs. They add several new skills allowing for a bit more diversity of play. Overall Sim's 3 is like any other game in the sim's series, but is easy enough to pick up and doesn't have to much of a time commitment allowing it to be a great quick play or a more long term game depending on what fits your play style.

The Sims 3 is the third entry in a longtime series of life simulator games. As the second sequel, it should come as no surprise that the graphical fidelity, number of animations, and character interactions are above and  beyond what was previously possible in The Sims 2. The series has always been a riot, but The Sims 3 takes it just that step farther in allowing you to completely customize your character and their world. The game is highly moddable, has one of the easiest cheat modes in any game, and is ripe with tons of downloadable content--paid and free alike. It is truly a game for the ages!

Con's
-Costs too much for a game this old. Buy only on sale.

I got this game because I heard such great things about sims games, how fun they are and such. I got 3 specifically because well I couldn't afford to get sims 4. Unfortunately, I was rather disappointed. You see, the game is very empty and lacking in content, likely just so you will buy the many many expansions. There wasn't much for character customization, and there also wasn't very much in the way of decor and such. I like to try and build rather beautiful homes in games, even if the game isn't meant for you to do so (case and point: 7 days to die) but in this game, where it should have been rather easy, the lack of things available to decorate with was pretty on par with games where the point isn't to do so at all.

Something else I had an issue with was sims just not taking care of themselves unless I watched them. Yes, I know there is an option to enable them to take care of themselves. This option was turned on, and they would take care of themselves, but it seemed if I left the game running while I went to get a drink or something, I would come back to find they totally stopped taking care of themselves. It is of course just a coincidence that occurred several times, but the fact it would happen at all when they are suppose to fulfill their own needs is problematic.

TL;DR
The base game lacks a lot of content and a very important feature doesn't seem to consistently work makes me very much so dislike this game
