Yes its one of EA's big money making schemes. "The Sims" Where they release the title for 60$ and then release mini content packs over time each with the cost ranging from 20 to 60 dollars adding little bits to the game like pets, new places to visit, new actions for your sim, new things for the sim to learn, new furniture and things to add to your home(s) and so on.

While it is a giant scheme to take your money it is a good one, because I find myself returning to my little overhead view of my simulated persons and pets making them do silly and sometimes serious things living out their little simulated lives in their simulated homes with their simulated pets and simulated families, friends and neighbors all the while talking their little nonsense sims language bla bla bleebing about nothing.. ah.. its just like real life.

I will not be surprised when sims 5 comes out with monthy subscription fees just to play it.. because EA needs ALL your money, not just some of it.

If EA isn't building a giant robot to kill us all it would really surprise me.

The Sims 3 was my first Sims game, it is very dear to my heart, and because of that perhaps I am somewhat biased. But I do believe that this is the best Sims game available. The Sims 2 seems like to much a downgrade in comparison, certain things that are improved in The Sims 3 make it hard to go to back to. The Sims 4 is more cleaner, but they have taken out a lot of the details that can micromanage every aspect of your Sim's lives. For example, The Sims 4 removes the ability to make the bed, your Sims automatically make the bed every time they get up, even Sims with the Messy trait. Your town is fully loaded and live in The Sims 3, whereas in The Sims 4 it only loads one specific house/lot at a time. Granted, there are lot of bugs in The Sims 3, but these can be quickly squashed with some fan-made patches easily and readily available online. I had hoped many of the little things that made The Sims 3 great will eventually be introduced into The Sims 4, and some have. Despite this, I still believe The Sims 3 is best way to really take your Sims experience to the next level.

Gotta say, sims 3 will always be my favorite sims game out of the whole franchise.
Sure the sims 4 has better graphics and sims 1&2 have nostalgia and that great old timer game feel to them but sims 3 is just superior overall.

First off the main game is pretty good even without the expansions. Even if it might get a bit boring without the expansions it doesn't mean the base game is bad, imo the base game in sims 3 is the best out of the whole franchise (cause we all know how much sims 4 base game sucks)
the free roaming over world is something i desperately wished would have been added to sims 4 because it just made the game feel that it had more depth. The character customization is not bad but i have to say that the character graphics are.... a little underwhealming and not THE all greatest, but they are not bad, just a little above avarage.

The expansions of sims 3 are maybe one of my favorite ones out of the whole series!
world adventures - bring a lot of exploration and traveling options making everything feel more lively and out of the ordinary for everyday life.
Late night - vampires, parties and alot of fun party options. what more do you need ^_^
supernatural - maybe my favorite expansion out of the whole sims 3 expansions. It's a must have if you love fantasy, cryptic/mythical creatures like vampires, werewolves, faries and witches. Not to mention the potential for creating awesome potions to spice the game up.
Ambitions - is another must have, gives you new jobs, traits and possibilities + they finally gave us laundry :D
Pets - pretty self explainatory, if you love animals then this is a must have.
Seasons - not a must have but defenetly a good expansion if you want to make the sims 3 world more life like and real with the ability for different season.
Generations - another expansion that makes the world feel like more life like and lively. It brings a lot of different ways for your sims to bond with their children and grandchildren. It also makes growing up as a sim much more enjoyable and rewarding.

i recomend the sims 3 game alot if you want a great game with decent/good graphics with enjoyable expansions and replay possibilities. But i would sugest buying the games when they are on sale since usually sims 3 expansions go for good prices especially on summer sales. usually 50% off or more.

[b]The Sims 3[/b] is well.. if you don't know what it is, it's very likely you've been living under a rock for the past 2 decades and are likely still there. But, if you are one of these unfortunate humans [i](Perhaps serendipitous from some perspectives.)[/i] The Sims 3 is the last game in a human/town simulation from Maxis that EA has allowed on other clients. 

I apologize for the gratuitous salt but I do have a slight chip on my shoulder so to speak in regards to EA. (That's Electronic Arts not Early Access, thanks again for that needing to be explained every time. Even [i]within[/i] context.)

[b]The Game:[/b]

The Sims is by in large a town/life sim with the expected uncanny humor that Maxis has a small reputation for. I'm not going to get into any significant detail as this game is well known. But, being as I've not played it since the initial inception and subsequent Livin' Large expansion; I figured I'd give my perspective on the matter. 

The town is a nice feature, which was not present in any meaningful way in the original. The lots  would load separately and going to the store or meeting friends at the park for a picnic was simply unheard of. You could invite people over and they'd spawn in your lot but that was the extent of it. I have fond memories of the simplicity. Owning transportation, BASEMENTS and having specific individual and family inventories just weren't a thing. So, from this, the main base game of Sims 3 I think has dramatically improved upon many features. 

Now, the Sims actually age in this game and have lifetime fulfillment sorts of goals. All for you to dictate, manipulate and direct as you see fit. But, the slowly aging and borderline non-contemporary gamer that is me who is not used to such features, thankfully, you are able to turn off aging without the presence of mods or any DLC. Which is nice. But, the fact your Sims can depart from existence due to old age as well as children actually becoming adults can make things seem more significant. Rather than just simply managing a bunch of needs and meeting requirements for what are very gamey mechanics. 

There is also this very Animal Crossing sort of vibe happening. Wherein you can have your active Sim gallivanting around town looking for minerals, catching bugs and fishing on top of all these other things that lends itself to this almost extinction level of addiction. There are also some quality of life features regarding caught/found records of those things. As well as records of skills obtained. Though, personally, I'd like some way to dig deep into the finances to derive precisely where my income is coming from. 

[b]The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.[/b]
[list]
[*] The base game I think has a decent amount of content for the $20 it is currently listed for at full price. 
[*] The DLC business model of this game is abhorrent. There is no reason to have this many DLCs that are the same price with almost no option for a discounted bundle. Especially so long after being released.
[*] Buying SimPoints is dumb, I'm not going to do it. Take those items out of my buy/build menus if my wallet is empty. (Edit: There is an option to do this. However, SimPoints are still dumb.)
[*] You can download user made content. Homes, objects, Sims, clothing objects, etc for free from the website.
[/list]
[h1] LET ME BE CLEAR[/h1]
The DLC practices behind this game are simply egregious, anti-consumer and downright despicable. If not, duplicitous. I do really enjoy this game and I do recommend it but the DLC stuff is really, really bad. Please take caution regarding the expansions when buying. 

[quote]More here  [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

The SIMS 3, one of my favorite games, and also the worst one. 

It's incredibly demanding on my computer, just shy of a gaming computer. The loading screen game is fun, but lags minutes behind. I can get up and leave, have a coffee, and come back, and sometimes it's still flashing on the last found item somewhere random on the screen.

Saving takes just as long sometimes. But if you don't save, you risk losing some incredibly important life event when the game silent crashes on you. Just, whoops, there you are, desktop, no more pregnant patriarch. Let me tell you, that unexpected weight gain, the surprise of your in-shape father of the family giving birth in the yard when he's supposed to be raking? Gone. All gone.

So yeah, save often, and wait, wait, wait.

As for the game play? Here's a plus, you can actually do well! You can advance in your career and be rich, or you can just forgo traditional methods of employment and create a team of robots to garden and harvest fancy books from your omni-plants for funds (Need the future expansion for the robots, otherwise you have to do it yourself), or you can buy everyone a computer and force them to write novels, articles and short stories until they start doing well at it. Or you can hunt for flowers in spring and sell those (if you have seasons expansion and turn off the other seasons, that works better). Anyway, you can actually advance and do well in the SIM world, unlike in the original SIMS, which I also love but never quite succeeded at with all the pausing to just keep the things alive.

And on that note, the free will option is great, and sometimes results in some surprises. Sometimes in some not so pleasant surprises as I found out when I made my Leader of the Free World quit and try to get a job in another track. He would not leave the house. Me: Go to Work. Him: Make me. Me: Go to Work! Him: I think I'll play video games.

So basically, it's an awesome, winnable game with dynamic game play, interesting scenarios and options, but the price of all that awesomeness is a demand on my machine that's greater than running Everquest on a raid with the particle density turned all the way up, which is to say ridiculous. 

Will I keep playing? Yes, because I love it. But I will also bring along my Kindle, my knitting, or my phone to keep me occupied while it does its thing and tries to function.

I like to create myself and then try to finish a play through where I have no friends.
That way I'm being internally tortured as well as having to suffer the agony and loneliness of the real world.

This game is a great fun classic. While the game itself is extremely fun it has major flaws. Throughout this review i will be comparing sims 3 to sims 4. The reason i rate no is because i believe the negative side of this game out weighs the good

Cons:

 Stability: I can play gta v on ultra setting but yet i cant play this without lagging every minute (with most dlc unlocked). There are several workarounds I've tried but it does not work well on my pc at all. The same problems i have currently with this does not change even after i upgraded my pc. For some people the game works great meanwhile others like myself are stuck like this and cant do anything to fix it. If you do not believe me you can check the many threads on the sims forums with the same issue as myself.

 Crashing: Eventually as you continue playing you will continually crash due to poor implementation of vehicles and stuck sims causing errors. The vehicles are never cleared out of the database so as sims use vehicles its continually saving it to the file to a point it causes several stability issue's. You can fix this by installing some performance enhancing mod's but its kind of sad that ea still has not adressed a lot of these issues in order to favor sims 4.

 No support: This game has been completely abandoned by the most part by ea. if your wanting and or looking for support the best you can get is by joining a forum and seeing if some other user on there can help you. 

 High Priced Dlc: It's been 10 years and they still have not lowered the dlc cost at all. As i said before i recommend waiting for a sale

Pros:

 Lots of customization: You can pretty much create as much styles as you'd like when creating your sim which has been completely abandoned in sims 4. 

 Open World: Yet again another thing completely abandoned by sims 4 is the open world concept introduced in this game, this is one of the most redeeming quality's of this game and is  a large open world in which you  can get lost into.

 Worthwhile Dlc: While i hate how high priced the dlc is, It add's a lot to the game that makes it so unique and fresh. I do recommend everyone waits till a sale before ever thinking about purchasing the dlc.

This game is f*cked up

I've been using the Sims 3 to effectively escape reality (being that my fiancee and I live in >overpopulated suburban wasteland city< USA, you can imagine I have a mighty need for what this game offers. 
Recently having visited another country that's infinitely better imo, I now have a base to go off of when designing my Sims cities, lives, buildings, houses etc.
My experience with the Sims games - excluding the joke that is Sims 4 - (which is playable but greatly lacks content) is great and it's a game I always have and will come back to. 
Even if you play it to all ends one year, if you take a break and come back you can make new sims and pursue new careers and mischief all over again.
It never truly ends. 
I've been playing for years with more hours than this account has on record, and I still haven't done all the jobs and I still have a few DLC that I'd like to get. 
That being said, I've also never even used Mods, which grant even more play-ability and allow you to sink more hours of your life into a life that is most likely better- until your Sim dies in an untimely haunted house accident. 
My Sims kid can't seem to flush a toilet properly to save her life, but she's a B student still so I suppose it's acceptable for now.
Sometimes my Sims cancel their actions to go to work- or use their cars or travel at all- for no apparent reason. But hey, who doesn't cancel their obligatory actions once in a while? At least they show some autonomy to entertain me.

But if you want a list here you go- 
Pros: 
- Amazing customization in all aspects. You can completely change a town or city to your liking and replace all the sims and edit (albeit you have to cheat some) their careers and family status to your hears content. And don't forget unlike Sims 4 you can actually edit your sims color of hair, eyes, clothes, furniture, etc. with tons of options, instead of maybe 5 choices where you have to pick the least of the evils.
- With all main DLC you can experience a full life with or without aging on! Make your sims read some horror novels on a stormy night, let the kids out in the yard and help them make a snowman- then get ambushed by a snowball fight from the neighbors rotten ugly ducklings. Download some mods and do some other things like follow your kids to school and control their daily lives even further! There's so much content you could play till your retirement and have many more fulfilling lives between now and then. 

- Sims 3 is cheaper than Sims 4 by a longshot if you wait for discounts when the DLCs are $5-7 each! 

- The graphics are satisfying for most any computer than can run the game, the point of view never really gets old for me personally. If you want to control your sims directly instead of omnipotantly clicking them to success or failure, i recommend sims 2-3 for the playstation or gamecube consoles. You can control your sims with a controller, though building is a little trickier. (I forget if you can actually control them this way in sims 3 for ps3, but I think it might also just be point and click just with a controller.)

- If you're good at multitasking you can easily lead your Sim to entertain you with their life without any cheat codes at all, but certain cheats DO allow for a more enhanced and immersive experience. See above where I gave the example of cheating to edit non active household sims to have different jobs and careers etc. (though you will need to temporarily have them as your active household to do 
this. I suggest if you do, you do all this editing BEFORE you start to play your main household!)

- you can edit housing much more in Sims 3. In sims 4 if you try to create a loft, good luck, it'll autofill the floor you're trying to leave open on the second story to make it into a >room<. GG Sims 4. There could be a work-around for this but, none that I found in my hours of frustration trying to make a damn loft. Sims 3 is easy sailing. If you have the imagination, and the hours of time to make and remake and remake your starter home or dream mansion, you can do it. and you can have a mote.

- it's the Sims and no other game comes close to replicating what it does so well. 

Cons, some are opinion and personal EXP, but yeah:

- Bugs. Such as the aforementioned Sims cancelling actions for no reason. 

- Glitches when cheating- like elongated Sim extremities, and horrific elongated pets when you edit them with cheats. 

- timing. TIMING. Getting up isn't immediate, no, it'll take approx 10-30 Sim-Minutes for your sim to go from sitting to standing. 

- Trying to throw a party in an apartment with an elevator is insane. Will the guests actually all make it up to your apt? Probably not. 
They'll be too busy all waiting downstairs by the elevator, and will leave from there when your party is over- never having actually arrived. Pity. Don't throw parties in APTs at all OR, don't invite more than maybe 3-5 sims to any you throw. 

- it takes forever to load your game and to save. but this is the price we pay for an open world.

- Island Paradise will lag for most people, no matter your specs, because the Devs never cared to patch it. I suggest only Vacationing there, not living, but that's just me. 

- speaking of Vacations, you cannot take one to another location if you do not have the right DLC- even IF you have the location, such is Island Paradise. Without Generations or World Travel installed, I cannot take my sims to a nice island retreat. Plan your DLC buying accordingly. 

- Lag is a thing that'll happen, best to accept that most people can't afford a top line PC or Laptop to run a game smoothly 100% of the time. 

- my one main opinion that I wish Sims 3 had was something like Get To Work in Sims 4, but unlike Sims 4 I'd want it to be optional. In Sims 4 if you don't go with your sim they can't get promoted. This can get complicated and time consuming if you have 2 or more sims to a household that have Get To Work careers. There is a mod for going to school with your sims, but i dunno if there's one for any of the jobs and such. It'd be cool to have one though. 

That about sums it up. 11/10 will never stop playing this game.

This game isn't a soap opera.

Its a horror movie.

And you're the director.

The true Sims experience is to kill as many people as you can in the cruelest and most sadistic ways possible within the confines of a G-rated family game. Entrap them in elaborate mazes or build cruel human zoos, break their minds, starve them, drown them, incinerate them, there are many tools at your disposal. 

Limitation is the mother of invention and it's time to get creative.

Silly jokes aside Sims 3 is the definitive Sims experience. The open world nature of the game expands it from just a one house Soap Opera to a full on city builder as well.

Want to get to my review? Read below.

The game is fun, fun enough for me to play this game on 3 different consoles over the last 10 years.

The customisation is fun, but most custom items are hidden behind paywalls either through DLC's or through highly-priced Simpoints that you can't get without paying. If you want good clothing items, furniture and other items added to your game without paying, there are some really good Sims 3 modders online that allow you to use their items for free, just check the files and be careful from who you download from (reviews of users are very helpful with this).

Gameplay is very open, you can pretty much do anything and it'll be a new experience every time until you've explored most places on all available free maps. DLC is the only way to get a new experience with new maps, items and clothing and with some DLC, some new areas and interactions.
So you don't waste your money on rubbish DLC's, the DLC's that give you the most gameplay freedom are:
- University Life
- Supernatural
- Pets
- Seasons
- Town Life
- Generations
- World Adventures
- Ambitions
The rest are either rubbish or only add a few items/clothing options into the game. 

Other than that: Good base game but shit (and greedy) publishers. You'll love it, just don't spend +530 for it.

After countless hours, my character has become a ruthless killer, hellbent on manipulating people, making them feel safe and welcome only to brutally torture them and laugh as they cry out and beg for mercy only to be given a painful death. Is it bad that I don't attempt to stop myself from allowing all of this anarchy? Or is it worse that it makes me question if this is the way life is supposed to be? The amount of graves in my yard is overwhelming, when I close my eyes I can hear the screams of the countless mothers, fathers, sons, and daughters I've massacred. There's so much blood on my hands... all my sim can do is look out the window as he eats a bowl of oatmeal and laugh, he has no regrets, no remorse, he doesn't care about the other sims, he murdered his own children. I can't kill him, there's some glitch that makes him immortal, is it a glitch? or is it something more? Is this sim a metaphor for what my life may become if I stray off the path I'm taking? My sanity has been questioned because of this game, and my mental health will never be considered healthy or normal ever again.

I've always been a fan of The Sims series.  I owned 1 & 2 with all the expansions, but of course, they were on DVD.  Though there are ways to fudge them to work on Windows 10, Steam is my primary gaming platform, and it is certainly easier to deal with the installation that way.  I didn't like the whole "Origin only" policy of The Sims 4, so I didn't even consider that route.  At least with The Sims 3, I have the choice of running it on Steam or Origin if I choose.  However, I recommend running it on Steam, as Origin will change it to the 1.69 version which hasn't been received particularly well (Steam runs 1.67).

My initial thoughts are that  I am definitely pleased with The Sims 3 on Steam, though there are pros and cons to The Sims 3 in general.  The cons are that The Sims 3 tends to load slowly (though one can get around that with mods), and the blatant attempt to monetize additional items (via The Sims 3 Store) is pretty sad.  Still, one can turn store items off in the settings, which I was quick to do.  The other big con is by the time you've purchased the expansions, it costs a small fortune (why in-game item sales is particularly a pathetic cash-grab), but we're talking EA here, so one has to expect that.

Nonetheless, even though the game wasn't on sale, I went ahead and picked up the expansions, as I prefer to have a "complete set".  Though I spent a lot, I feel it was a semi-worthwhile investment, as I really enjoy the series, and this particular version is as enjoyable, if not more so.  There are a plethora of customization options, and the open world allows one to really create anything their heart desires and go in any direction versus The Sims 4 more linear progression.  Some of The Sims 3 DLC offers various adventures, and that is a nice addition to the series.  If you get annoyed with the Store listings, be sure to turn them off in the settings.  As far as I was concerned, I had already spent enough money!

The graphics are great, and personally I think have aged very well.  Though I'd recommend purchasing the game and expansions on sale, if you really enjoy the series and can't wait, I don't think you'll be disappointed.  Just be ready to jump through some hurdles with registering the keys and downloading the additional content.  Once you get the hang of it, the process is tolerable.  Like I mentioned, it really is a great game, and a huge plus that it is offered on Steam, I don't think I'm missing out on anything by not owning The Sims 4, I'm quite content with The Sims 3.

If you are looking for a diverse Sims game with a lot of customization and open world gaming, this game is for you.  It is a nice relaxing simulation that allows one to be truly creative.  I've already created Sims for my family members, and hope to create a world that mimics my local neighborhood, so I can create a house close to the one we live in.  The modding community is quite active, so that is yet another plus.  So far, I'd say that this version has been the best of the series, and that The Sims 4 is almost a step backward in some ways.

Without question, the Sims 3 certainly has its pitfalls, but the more I play it, the more I like it.  I really enjoy the creative freedoms it offers, and the fact the Steam version also plays on Origin is a huge plus!  Yes, it is without a doubt quite expensive, but if you are a real fan of the series, I believe it is worth purchasing!

I'll be honest; this is probably my favorite game EVER. It's my go to game when I'm bored, and it's the reason I even joined steam in the first place; because this game is so cheap when it's on sale. It's amazing, the gameplay is great for the price (even when not on sale!) and I have sunk SO many hours. (It only looks small, because most of my gameplay time on this game is spent offline; and therefore not recorded)

People have been complaining of the bugs that this game brings; and they kinda have a point, because this game is very broken, UNMODDED. This game has a very active modding community, and they have almost patched in all of the holes that EA left in on release. It's honestly amazing, and if you have any problem, you can always go to the VERY active community for help.

Let's not even talk about the custom content scene. (similar to the modding scene, but it's for custom content like hairs, clothing, etc) I have spent LITERAL HOURS just fretting which texture to use, which default eyes looks better, mindlessly clicking "Download this" on any Sims CC website available. 

And the core of the gameplay. GODDAMN IT'S SO GOOD. There are those small, tiny, details, like the outcome of an opportunity that you forgot to fulfill, or the scary music when a burglar comes in, that make this game as awesome as it is, and also why many people are still playing this game, because the sequel to this game, The Sims 4, is VERY lacking in these EXACT details. 

People complain about the DLC a lot, but TBH it still has more content for the price than something like The Sims 4. (Can you notice I REALLY hate the sequel?!?!) Anyways, this game is worth playing, for any purpose you want: 3 hour fun with a weird looking green dude that woohooes everyone? 80 hour fun with a perfect white-picket fence family? Your choice!

Please buy this game, to show EA that they're doing the sequel wrong, and that they already did all of this right, if only they would fix all of the holes that they left on launch. What if they do fix it? Ah, a simmer can dream. :)

The Sims 3 is inferior to The Sims 2 which is inferior to The Sims 4 which is inferior to The Sims all in my opinion.  If you want to play a Sims game try getting your hands on the first one.  It was already strikingly obvious when the second iteration was released that the constant churning out of Sims based games had much more to do with the phenomenal success of the series than a true desire to improve on the original formula.  Something that was never accomplished in my opinion.  Imagine what they could have accomplished if they had waited 8 and 10 years between iterations rather than 4 and 5.

My last point; and certainly not the least: The Sims 3 isn't a relaxing experience in my opinion:  You're constantly on your toes trying to get everything done.  

Avoid.

(Even though I bought university, which is alright imo) All the DLC add a lot to the game, but obviously some are better than others. As for the game itself... It's The Sims. Do I really need to explain how it works? You can mess around and either take the game seriously and care about your sim, or torture you sim and see how long they'll live.

A bit of a side note before I end this review, I want to point this out. While you're playing the game there will be a program running in the background of your computer, you'll need to use task manager to close it. Even if you aren't playing the game, as long as that is still running, steam will still add hours to your playtime. I have a extra 10 hours thanks to that. I'm not sure if this is Windows only, every system, or just me, but just wanted to point that out.

Anyway, I'd recommend getting this, but only on sale.

Day 1 of the Sperling household (Christin Sperling, Alfons Sperling and Roland Sperling):

Christin and Alfons are a married couple, she is athletic, he is a musician, both love being outside. They both took Alfons' *big* brother, Roland, with them because he is a writer who has fallen on hard times and needs a place to stay for a while.

Everyone was doing their thing until the hunger meters sunk. Alfons got up and into the kitchen. His mission; cook a stew. Due to fatal stove malfunction, a fire broke out. A mix of emotions broke out, Alfons and Roland were panicking, while Christin was celebrating the whole scenario. Fortunately one of the elderly neighbors was currently visiting and swiftly stepped in with a cool mind, armed with a fire extinguisher.

After the chaos cleared up, Alfons' attempt at cooking went bad, so bad, that Roland even caught fire. Fortunately for him, after Christin cheered, she extinguished him. With the stove now completely destroyed, It was Christin's attempt to "cook" something. However, there weren't many options, since the stove burned out, so the whole household had salad for supper.

Lesson: There's always a Roland, there's always a Christin.

10/10 would try to cook again!

This is the one to get, and it's even better with the expansions, which may make you want to look the other way, but hang on a damn second!

...here's what you do. 

Step 1: Wait for sale (Like the one on now 05/02/19).

Step 2: Add game and all expansions to cart

Step 3: Enjoy the potential thousands of hours of gameplay that you can discover here.

OR

Just start with the base game and if you like it, add the expansions that interest you most. 
However, you will miss out on a lot of opportunities and extra content that you might have otherwise discovered being one of your favorite things about the game, so I'd still recommend grabbing all of them, especially if you liked the previous games.

This one is pretty easy to get running on modern hardware and the modding potential is huge. It offers open world exploration, with loads of possibilities and it feels more alive than ever with the progression of the families and events around you. 
No longer does the entire game revolve only around your active lot. The entire map is your story now. Gone are the days of only people in your household aging, but your best friends/romantic interests and even family members who have moved out stay the same age forever. They will age with you, they will pursue their interests, they will find jobs, move house, get married, die of old age.
You can influence how these things happen with interactions, making you feel like you have more control what can happen than ever in the series. 

The biggest con I can think of is that it's no longer being updated and the performance isn't great on some machines, especially when you add mods to the mix. 
It's only a 32bit .exe so you wont get all the performance benefits that modern hardware can offer you, however most decent gaming PC's shouldn't have too much of an issue running at a playable framerate. 
There are also plenty of tweaks out there to help get a bit more juice out of your rig if you feel the need to seek them. (Check comments for a couple of recommendations in regards to this, however what may work for some, won't necessarily work for all. Follow instructions carefully and USE AT YOUR OWN RISK)

The game graphically isn't all that impressive, but it was never about the visuals here and it's not by any means a bad looking game, especially considering how old it is and how much is going on in your game at all times.

I'd also recommend The Sims 2 if you can find it, but it can be a real pain in the ass to get running on modern systems. 
If you have the patience to get it running, it's truly fantastic and you can tell it was made with a passion and a team that really loved what they were doing.

The Sims 3 is incredibly addictive! There is a reason that the title is such a legend. But there are two reasons that this game disappointed me in the end. 

Additional content is awesome. It has it's purpose and I can totally understand why it would have a healthy price tag when you first release it. But Sims 3 has been out for ten years and its downloadable content costs more than brand new games with all of the expansion packs (on steam). There are over 15 different packs you need to buy if you want to check out all that the game has to offer. These packs are seriously marked at $30 or $20... Steam needs to catch up!

The second issue I bumped into was a lack of auto-save mixed with random/uncontrollable deaths! I was having a blast designing the home of my dreams when I got a little "quest" to fix a stereo. I tried to do so, and I was shocked to death. With no feature to automatically save, I lost hours of progress and tons of customization. My only other option was to lose my main character and have my wife live on mourning my passing. After all of the time building his stats, it seemed a little crazy that there isn't SOME way to reverse this. The game is casual, and not meant to be some hardcore random perma-death type of title! It sounds laughable, but it ruined my experience and I will probably never play another SIMs game.

I've always loved the Sims, and 3 is the richest in terms of content and fun.

If you're like me and want a more realistic experience, don't buy/activate the Supernatural or Future themed content packs. For the best Sims 3 experience possible, I suggest 'Generations', 'University Life', 'Showtime', 'Seasons, 'Pets', 'Ambitions', and 'Late Night'. 'World Adventures' has some cool stuff as well, but I'd rank it lower. Any other packs are just bonuses

IMPORTANT NOTE: I recommended you get this game only when it is at a 50% or more discounted price.

Now if you're like me and you've never played the sims 4 or any other big life simulators, this game would be awsome to play. There's so much to do in the game, build your house (which I spent 5hrs building my mansion), go on dates, "woohoo", cheat on your partner, invest in properties, fire people that work for you, etc. there's so many things to do in this game and that's what I love. 

Now here's what I what I DON'T like:
1. The built in-game browser is awful
You have the option to create a separate EA account for the game which would unlock features and allow you to share things to other people in the Sims 3 community. The problem with this browser however is that it doesn't work well. It's slow (my internet isn't slow), and even after waiting I have to refresh the page a couple of times to load the page. I looked online and found other people experiencing this problem, but found no solution.

2. If you want more simple features for the game, you have to make an EA account and spend money (yeah there's micro transactions..)
The game has a currency called simoleon points. There are two ways to get simoleon points: 1 is through daily rewards by visiting the browser (again the browser is awful), and 2 is by spending money to buy simoleon points. These simoleon points are then used to buy more furniture, clothing, and different worlds. Now the game has it's own default furniture, clothing, and ONE world for you to explore, but if you want more of those you'll have to make an EA account and buy simoleon points. 

Another note: There are both premium and free worlds that you can download. Though, to get another free world, you have to make an EA account (again, through the terrible browser) and select the free world you want to download.  Also I've read on a forum that some of the premium world prices cost just as much as the entire game. I can't confirm that to be true because I'd hate to open the built in-game browser again, but if that is true, that is just... GENIUS!!! (sarcasm)

~ Summary ~
The game is good, you can sink a lot of hours into the game exploring the given default world and features. Though for what EA does, locking additional simple features of the game to make extra money, I think it's not entirely worth your money to spend on it's full price (currently $19.99). I recommend you be patient and wait for a sale when it's at a discount of 50% or more, like now if you're reading this comment and it's still on the winter sale.

Hoo boy. This is prolly the first PC game that I played a lot of, back in my tweens. It's easy to get absorbed in designing, colour-coordinating, and micromanaging these little little lives. 
You make one, you make another to play with when the first one is at work, you make some children to see what their facial features look like when you put them together, you micromanage the child, you make a dog, screencap the disgusting glitches, buy the goddamned DLCs, make another sim to keep them company, make another sim to match the curtains.

I reinstalled the Sims 3 last year, and played it only twice, spending an hour per sim in Create a Sim, maybe another hour colour coordinating the house, then a few minutes making them binge study and get jobs.
Installing the game took roughly the same amount of time as all that put together.
(For that reason, I have not uninstalled the game, for despite the fact that I hope to God I never play it again, if I do, I don't want to have all that extra time to spend thinking about it.)

The Sims, I suppose, is no more a waste of time than anything else is, but the Sims is special, in that it makes you feel the existential dread that most other time sponges are able to drown out, as your sims do their homework, get promotions, look after their children, do taxes, make the children match the curtains, colour the swimming pool tiles red to make the water look red because you're an edgy tween who didn't have the Supernatural DLC but still wanted to pretend your sims were vampires- what was I saying?

watch your sims become forensic scientists right out of highschool- the goddamn gifted little fuckers, why can't I be a forensic scientist

My point is, the Sims, depending on your point of view, is either a curse that drains you of the time you could be spending on being productive in your own life, giving you momentary highs of gratification that you prolong for as long as possible because you know as soon as its over you are left only with a slightly more ingrained sense of self-loathing than you were before, and are filled with the desire to go do things that make you hate yourself in more productive ways, at the very least

OR. Or this game is a lesson, designed to beat you into wanting to stop playing it, so you can go walk the dog, or become a forensic scientist or something.

If that is indeed the case, then A + on the find-the-item loading screens, the Origin program, the constant badgering to register your game online, the DLC that EA keeps advertising in Create-a-Sim, and the house-editing menus.
Never before have I felt more motivated to turn off my laptop and clean up the entire house.
No, my real house. My real house that I live in, with my real relatives, that have mild hoarding problems.

Thank you, EA. You helped make me the hard worker that I am today.

I have been a big fan and have own all of Sims every since the very first Sims came out for PC in 2000. I also owned all the add on packs any chance I got. Out of all the sims, including 4. This would be my favorite one. Though as 2 came after one and 3 came after 2, it seemed like packs came with less and less. But Sims 4 to me is the biggest rip off of them all. Sims 3 was the last one that offered still a wide range of extras in packs. Far more skins, items and you could even drive a car across the map or ride on a horse if you had pets added. You could even befriend a unicorn and take it home.

This would be the last open world pack in the sense you could actually explore every inch of map without load screens and not a few blocks or small sections at a time along with plenty of stuff you could interact with and collect. The only real thing that Sims 4 has against sims 3 is the higher quality of graphics and being able to get real close up to your sims. Besides that I feel sims 4 lacks a lot of content. You are stuck having to search for customized stuff created by others if you want more which only leads to risking issues with the game play down the line.

In this game, like all the others, you are able to build and create your own house or all/any plots. Depending on what pack you have you can build buisnesses and clubs. Another plus is you can mix revenues where as in Sims 4 its a bit more tricky to do or near impossible depending on what you are aiming to mix.

If you take a look and compare sims 4 packs to sims 3 packs, again you will see a lot is left out and lacking.

If you are a fan of sims, I fill sims 3 is worth having in your collection. Yes packs can be expensive but sometimes they do have discounts and sells on them, you just have to keep an eye out.

Okay, so I love this game.

I've had this game for just over a week, and on the winter sale I got the downloadable content for generations, ambitions, and university life.

First complaint is not towards the game, but towards Steam itself. If you're going to advertise that the Winter Sale is going to be through January 3rd, make sure it is for all the timezones. I checked in at 5pm California time and it was gone, when I wanted to buy stuff. 

But I have plenty to say, good and bad, on the actual game itself.

First of all, it's so fun! Sure it's time consuming, but it's addicting. You can do anything (almost, aside from a few things) that you can do in real life. You can have kids, which I love, and some of the DLCs feel worth it, IF YOU LIKE THAT PARTICULAR ASPECT OF THE GAME!! If you don't really like kids and the family life, Generations isn't really worth it.

However, there are many things.

First of all it crashes repeatedly. This is a new computer so it shouldn't be due to the computer. I only have this problem with one other game, and that one doesn't crash.

It tends to crash in Create A Sim. Which is really annoying, because then you have to entirely restart the computer.

I also think that the DLCs are overpriced.

But this crashing problem is why this review is negative and please EA, see this and fix it!! I hate to have to give you a thumbs down when I absolutely LOVE THIS GAME!!

...and if you are really seeing this EA, please don't make your DLCs so overpriced, they aren't worth it if they aren't on sale. I'm sorry but it's true.

I have played The Sims since owning a potato computer back in the 90's. Sims 1, 2, then 3, and even 4. I will give a quick overview of the differences between the Sims line of games.

The classic Sims 1 is good but restricted compared to the current versions, and has aged quite a bit. The needs system needed some work and was frustrating at times, but was a fun game overall. You got to play God in people's lives, what could be better than that? The Sims 2 improved some things like the needs system a bit, plus some slightly better graphics. The Sims 3 has even better graphics, as well as some more to do in the game, especially with some DLC packs. I think the largest jump in gameplay is from The Sims 2 to The Sims 3, and The Sims 3 might be the best game in the franchise. 

Comparing the two most modern Sims games, 3 and 4, they are basically the same thing. The exception is that 4 has slightly better graphics, the ability to plop pre-built rooms onto your lot and connect them like puzzle pieces. The building system is a bit more intuitive and user-friendly. And Sims can multi-task, something which lends very well to the game. Sims 4 is also much more expensive. I bought 4 for 5$ and each DLC is 30-60$ each. 

If you have no worry about money, I'd say go for The Sims 4. It's the most user friendly and building is much easier than previous versions. If you're on a budget or want to save money, go for The Sims 3. You can buy the DLCs for 5$ each, and the game is only 5$. You can get a good chunk of gameplay for 20-25$ (Base game and about 4 add-on packs). 

I have a few DLC packs for The Sims 3 and will not buy any DLC for the Sims 4, as it is overpriced. If The Sims 4 gets boring and I feel like playing a Sims game that has more content, I will jump on The Sims 3 to take advantage of some of the add-on packs I have. It's basically the same game as 4 with slightly downgraded graphics. 

So yes, in the current market I recommend this game. And I recommend it regardless as The Sims is a classic and leading life/people simulator and it's possible to sink so many hours into the game.

I've been playing for ten years but finally bought the collection on Steam. I will always recommend this game. The Sims 3 is entirely worth the price, from the expensive + lengthy expansion list to the misery of trying to get it to run smoothly. I've never seen an open world game be so customizable, and the fact that there's even more DLC from regular people makes it so much more expansive. This is the game for playing God.

This is definitely the best Sims in the whole franchise in my opinion. Much better than the Sims 2 due to it's great customizations for sims and objects, as well as the gameplay as a whole. But remember, this game needs a REALLY powerful PC if you want to play on high settings (and great graphics) due to it's open world gameplay. This is why in the Sims 4 the developers removed the open-world feature so people can play on a more reasonable and less powerful PC. Anyways, I'd give this game a 5/5, and if you're gonna play this game, I suggest you get the Generations, Late Night, Pets, and Seasons DLC. The base game is just not enough.

One of the best childhood games ever!

There was once a man named Gerald. He was an orange ugly freak with pink chest hair, but he had a way with words. He spent each night with a different woman, getting them all pregnant and abandoning his children. Eventually he decided he needed to make the perfect heir. His son became Bernard, who carried on his father's legacy of spreading their genes far and wide. Gerald passed on and had a park created remembering him which Bernard met all of his new interests in. When the third generation came around, there was only Gerald genes. Over time, the town died out, as everybody was related to this figure that became a sort of god to them, having changed the town so much. By the time that the fourth generation was supposed to happen, the town was empty. Nobody was left. People from neighboring towns say that Gerald walked in, and the town was never the same. This is how a town completely died out with the creation of one man.

10/10 long live Gerald.

The Sims 3 is arguably better than The Sims 4, even if it has less fluidity.
By fluidity, I mean the game lagging a TON when you want to move the camera -- occasionally. Only occasionally.

The Sims 4 barely lets you travel around: you can't even exit the little area your house is designated without entering a "leave your plot" prompt.
The Sims 3, however, lets you go anywhere in the little city / town you're in, without any loading screens or prompts.

The Sims 3 in general has a lot more depth than The Sims 4. You also don't have tons of MAINLINE CONTENT locked behind DLC a-la The Sims 4 $500 total DLC. (This game has DLC as well, but still. Not MAINLINE content.)

This game is a whole lot more fun than The Sims 4, has a lot better mods, etcetera. Don't buy The Sims 4 even if it seems worth it. Get this one instead.

Game didn't play well on Windows 10 system. After playing for 15 minutes, I closed the game. Later in the day I started a refund request, but it turns out that Sims 3 started a launcher application that was running in the background and accumulating play time on steam while I was away. Steam won't refund because the official playtime was over the 2 hour limit. End result: stuck with a disappointing experience with both the game and Valve.

Got this on the Winter Sale. Only to enjoy for a few minutes of creating a Sim, then realize you can't buy SimPoints until you buy the starter pack, so I'm stuck with cheesy clothing and hairstyles until I spend more money. EA strikes again. They won't be getting anymore of my cash.

It's a pity about the microtransactions. I liked the base game itself, but now it's a little too stuffed with trying to get you to buy things you don't want or need.

EA, in its infinite wisdom, took the natually occuring modding community of the first two games and heavily pushed their own currency driven DLC. The game is now absaloutely festooned with ads for small points based transactions for extra items- while the game itself if a good five years old and it *just* dropped to something reasonable in price for its age.

I would be a lot less underwhelmed by the endless DLC if they hadn't pulled a similar stunt back in SIMS2, creating their own little gated set of stuff packs you could only buy with a premium currency. When the game inevitably aged out, so also went your ability to access your purchases.

Leaving aside that, once unmasked from the "points" the actual pricetag of the DLC is rather expensive, you are paying real money for a digital item with no reliable back up.

I'm just going to get to the point with this review.
Sims 3 is not worth its price as the base game stands, you might as well be playing on an XBOX 360..
Currently, I purchased TS3 at a discounted price of a very low $4.99.. Must be saying something about the overall enjoyability/quality of the base game if each DLC module was lowered to the same cost.. (L0L . . .)
Anyhow, I would overall say this game is not worth buying, unless you happen to catch it @ a modest sale..
You'll still want to end up modding it anyways, because let's face it; PEOPLE BUY THE SIMS GAMES BECAUSE they want to either make people they know IE. themselves, or real people in the world. and without the massive selection that only MODDING can bring to this game(not to mention, no steam workshop ; /) you're left with accepting a character that is sub-par to the one you're truly wishing you could create.
 
I'm still personally on the fence if I should keep this, until I can actually afford the DLC's required to install the mods I want, or refund before it's too late and.. To.. R'..rent it. Not saying this game is absolute garbage, but for what you're getting you better have a speedy processor and at least a Tb worth of space if you want lasting enjoyability with this game. Keywords there were AT & LEAST.

The game is just as fun as it has always been. It has become pretty much unplayable though because of (I assume) poor programming. I play on a less-than-1-year-old gaming laptop with 16GB RAM, i7 processor and a GeForce GTX 1050 Ti. Despite that the game constantly freezes and often completely crashes, even when I use less than optimal settings. I have only made two families and no towns (so it can't be overly large save files) and I have no problems with other much heavier and newer games. The game is almost 10 years old and when bought outside of steam sales still costs 40 euros. There's no excuse for it performing this poorly on a new laptop with these specs. So to summarize: the gameplay is still great but the game just doesn't work properly. Do yourself a favor and don't buy.

To begin, this game is still one of the most overpriced titles on steam. 

Price aside, Sims 3 is a great time sink. Its charming and funny and really lets a player develope their own game world. The problem is, the game lacks an autosave feature, crashes frequently and even worse, often crashes when manually saving. Very often, I found myself losing hrs of gameplay to crashes, and lockups when manually saving. After putting up with the risk that any time I played my entire entire session could be lost if the game froze when I saved, I finally called it quits when for no reason I can discern, all of saves disappeared. The entire save directory was empty and could not be restored. Apparently that is what I get for not manually duplicating and backing up my save in another folder outside of The Sims 3 game directory.

Been playing this since release (without Steam), and it's always a delightful treat to play for long perioids of time. There's so many ways to play, and even now I'm learning new things from the base game. Make your Sim, build their house and control their life. Creativity is highly encouraged during gameplay, choices can actually change so much with the limited time your Sims have to live, and I have to say this game is equally as fun to watch (Providing the player you are watching knows how to cock about). 

Ugh, there's so much good to say about this game, without even mentioning the expansion packs. You really do not NEED them, to be fair. But they can make the game more fun depending on what ones you purchase. I only really have 2 gripes with this game. Even on my modern PC with amazing hardware, the game runs an average of 200 fps, but can easily spike to 20 fps when the camera moves down the street. Also, when I quit the game, the launcher still remains in the background for some reason, and I have to reopen it to quit it to play a different game.

The Sims 3 is a game I've been interested in for a long time, And boy howdy do I love it! So instead of rambling about all the bad or all the good and only slightly mentioning the other side, I'm gonna put it out blunt with some hopefully comedic commentary!
Be warned for (possibly censored)Swearing, And running in circles.
~~~~~~~
First off, Sims. S'great game. Runs fast on my computer and glitches appear to be low and unnoticeable unless you fuck with the cheats! At least, On my end.
In Sims 3 you can create a house or buy an existing empty one and make a household, Whether it be a single mother, An elderly couple, Or literally a cult. The game is fun but don't buy it while it's at 19.99 because HOLY MOLY Is it not worth the price!
While it's open-ended, You get one default town from the get-go and get some more when you buy DLCs, Which are the same price as the game. Most of the time these DLCs give you little things, Which DO NOT work with the price. Seriously! You gonna give us pets for 19.99? Throw in some lizards, turtles, birds, pettable insects, bees, And capybaras and THEN we'll talk!
Once you get past the horribly inflated prices that EA throws at you though, The only problems I have with the game are the limited sim creation options, The dependancy on the sims 3 exclusive currency to buy extra outfits, Hairstyles, And more. These are irritating and are thrown at you at every opportunity, But nevertheless are optional, Only proving to be important if you want a certain item that you NEED to spend simpoints to get, Which, If you have none, Or don't have enough, Cost money.
Gameplay is fun if you want to kill time. You can have sims set their house on fire by failing horribly at cooking, You can trap people in your closet by deleting the door and letting them starve, You can collect pretty rocks, And more. It can get boring and repetitive but if you have the right things you can just entertain yourself with more things, Like re-enacting twilight in the sims or giving sans undertale a deathfish.
Or a gun, If that's your style and if there's a mod for it.
Nevertheless, The Sims is great but not worth the price. I'd still reccommend it though.
Again, Wait for like, A sale or something.

Long review:

The sims is a sim simulation game. You will start by creating a family or a person and start decorating your house or buy a prebuilt one. And then you will find a job and advance in your career and get married and have kids and die :D Simple as that.

Cration is one of the storngest features in this game. You characters will have traits that will result in different options and interactions with different elements and people. You can change the looks of your sim of course. From eyes to whole body and accesories. You will be able set preset outfits for situations like sports, outdoor, casual, sleeping. All visual customizations are free at and all options are avaiable whenever you want. The traits can only be set at the beginning or when there sim is born.

There is town with neighbours and it is a dynamic environment. They will be working and moving around and getting married to each other. They will want to visit you or call you over. It is socialable. It is free to move in town and go to places and venues. You can also buy them and you may not work ever again.

The household creation is very detailed. You will be managing every architectural aspect of your house including painting and interior design and decorating. There are enough options provided to make you able to create completely different houses or mansions. Outdoor decoration is also available. Pools, parking lots, gardens and whirlpools etc. Inside the house, from trash cans to doors, lambs, decorations, ornaments, all housing devices, hobbies are available. You will find yourself surrounded with choices.

The ai behind sims are relatively acceptable. They don't always get stuk if you opt in the free will. But sometimes they do not exactly do what you tell them to do because of some weird reason. And you will notice they are standing around doing nothing but complaining :D But overall, the game manages your sims effectively. I have created a house of 36 people and they were all getting along well :)

You will have small daily wishes and big lifetime wish. Your sim will gain points to unlock abilities. The career progress is sometimes depends on skills like logic, charisma or painting etc. You should work on your skills. There are couple of aspects of your sim. Social, bladder, hygene, hunger, sleep and happiness. You will be watching for these situations.

The interaction between sims are mostly based on their treats. Some sims will be shy or evil for example. They may not be very good with people. Or some sims are charismatic and atrract people. There are actions to take in the game and this is where the sims is based on. There is a mechanic behind every action and it is based on the relationship level. When you want to do a good action, you may not alway be able to hug the other sim. But if the sims are close to each other, you will be able to do even more. You will start by introducing yourself and discovering treats and advancing through being an aquaintance to wife or husband if you want :D

There are couple of career options available. Each will have their own working hours and days and pays and requirements to promote. You can complete more than one career if you want.

There is a lifespan feature in the game. You will be able to adjust the length of the time required to advance. You will start as a baby, and toddler, and then teen and young adult and adult and elder. These can all be adjusted and it is amazing. I have shortened the baby, toddler, teen and young adult sections and extended the adult section and completed 4 careers :D :D I was like a sim god :P

There are services to call. Like maid or nanny. Police, fireman and repairman is also available. Tinkering is the key to improve some skills but be carefull. Sometimes you may end up initiating a fire while trying to fix the owen. Or even while cooking. My sim died because of  electricution while repairing the stereo :D And grim reaper came and turned my sim into ash and took the soul with it.

There are lots of additions for this game. Some contain social interactions and some contain household tools and decorations. Some even have game modes. But the base game already has plenty of options. So you are good to go with base game + 2-3 additions. Choose wisely.

There is a video recording tool in the game. I he heard there is a movie making thing too but i have never tried it. I assume it is another creative tool to get creative :)

The biggest drarback of this game is performance. The interiors of buildings are sometimes loaded asynchronously, thus resulting in white manifolds :S This happens when lots of elements are being processed. So it is not much of an issue at the beginning. But even with a powerfull computer, you will end up seeing this weird loading effects.

I also have sime 4 and ai is kind of improved in that game. But i would not recommend it since sims 4 base game is too limited and you will definitely need expansion pack to enjoy.

Overall: Sims 3 is recommended.

At one point the Sims 3 was a great game, I have very fond memories playing it when it first came out and I actually brushed off my old CD copy just to see if it was as messy as this verison. To be blunt this is why you should never ever buy a game that has had anything to do with EA; the game runs horribly compared to it's 1.0 version.. yeah they made the game run less well. Every single screen is plastered with microtransactions and is begging you to make an account to hook up to the online functionalities. You can't make a sim, design a room, buy some new furniture, or practically do anything without some simcoin microtransaction being plastered front and center to tantilize you. 

If you can ignore all that the Sims 3 is a great game and probably the best in the series but to me that's all just unforgivable and I'm very sad to see EA ruin yet another franchise buy squeezing blood from the stone.

Oh yeah and it still costs $100 to buy everything this game has on offer at a 75% discount! The running theme here is greed.

The Sims 3 has always been a favorite for me along the years. Regardless of how many times I've played it and how repetitive it gets I'll always come back to it, if my wifi is out or even if I'm bored and fancy making a new sim and making the leader of the free world while starting a family or making an evil criminal focused on becoming a criminal mastermind! Whatever my goal is for my new playthrough, I'll always enjoy it, The Sims 3 is always fun in my eyes.

However, I think it is completely ridiculous that I'm expected to play 20.00 JUST for the seasons, yeah, that's right, you have to literally pay for the weather. Although this may not come to you as a surprise as this is a game published by EA. So all the DLC in the game and how ridiculously expensive they are for the little number of things that you are getting isn't a problem with The Sims 3 personally, it is with EA. 

Despite my extreme dislike for Electronic Arts' theme in selling games along with a number of DLCs that contain items that should be in the main game already and also what you would naturally expect to be in a game, this game is still great. I don't want to make it sound unfinished or anything like that, there is still a decent amount to do and like I've said before, the DLCs don't really add anything, sure pets and a new town sound good but other than that, the other DLCs just add clothes and items in the game that really don't have any effect. So, this game is still good minus all the DLC, it's how I play it and I enjoy it every time. I recommend this game, I love it. 

Also, f EA.

The Sims 3 is an amazing game, and in my opinion it is one of the best Sims games. It has open world, and it has story progression. Story progession is this gameplay function where when you are controlling your Sim(s), other Sims that you aren't playing as are still living their own lives, such as they can get a job, get married, have kids, earn promotions, age, and eventaully die. Story progression is actually one of the things that makes The Sims 3 better than The Sims 4, as in The Sims 4, story progression is not there, unless you install mods.

Now, the pros and cons. (I added a gray area, for things that aren't bad, but aren't necessarily good)

Pros:
Story Progession.
Open World.
Quite realistic simulation of life.
This is a game for all types of gamers, the beginner gamers, casual gamers, normal gamers, or extreme gamers.

Gray Area:
AI isn't too bad, but it can be improved.
Graphics can be improved, although they aren't bad.

Cons:
A lot of microtransactions.
Expansions may not be affordable for some.
The base game without any DLC gets boring very quick.

I definitely would recommend this game, I recommend the base game at it's regular price, but if you want to buy all of the expansions, then wait for a sale for all of the expansions.
I bought all the Sims 3 games and DLC on sale, and they're always hours of fun.

Good game and fun to play unless you have mods; a lot of mods. If you play with mods and if you have a newer PC expect a crash when you least expect it, and I mean a ton of crashes. I still recommend the game because it is fun to play when you can play it without it crashing. It's still better than Sims 4 though. I'll give it a 7.1/10.

I haven't played the game for that long but I am disapointed. The Sims 3 as a whole is not that much better from 2. I mean they constantly ask you for money now and the bar at the bottom with needs, relationships, etc, has changed slightly. 

In the 1 hr I played this I saved multiple times. Each time it said "Error 12: Cannot save". After 58 minutes. It crashed. I lost my file; not that I could save it if I wanted too. Started it up again and got another error; it wouldn't even open. Tried again and this time it opened and I THINK it might have actually saved. 3rd time's the charm.

Honestly, besides being able to add invididual traits I didn't see any improvement from Sims 2. If anything it's worse.

There is an option to disable store content while in-game so you don't get bombarded with ads in the game you spent potentially hundreds of dollars on. But the existence of the content at all is inexcusable. The game doesn't really have server maintenance costs and it is thoroughly monetized with expanion and "stuff packs" already (which are insanely bad value for the price, at the same price as the expansions for some idiotic reason; especially as mods exist and are often better).

It's a capitalistic black hole and for that you shouldn't give it your money. But, that aside, it is actually quite great, and mods have done a ton for it.

You will kinda want many of the expansions, though. Seasons, Ambitions, and Generations are basically musts, they add so much. Pets is a must if you... want pets. Late Night is great; adds a ton of stuff and a nice city with suburbs and urban areas. The others are kinda up to what kind of game you want to play. Supernatural and Into the Future, especially, as they add (urban) fantasy and sci fi elements, respectively, and, while you can turn those elements off or on in each save you have, without them on, they add just a few items and are not worth it.
buy this and any expansions ON SALE or your wallet will scream and yell and sob. at you.

I have grown up with The Sims. My sister and I would spend hours on the computer building family's and houses and intergrating them. It's a game that has stayed with us over the years and has individually followed us into adulthood. CD's are not always viable so having access to The Sims through steam allows for easy game play. 
One thing I have noted is that the original PC version is the best. I have played it on PS4, Xbox One and also through this downloaded version and none of them compare to the original The Sims PC game you loaded with a disc, or 4 ;). 
The original PC version provides more variety with building homes and multiple family's. I have found that with this downloaded version and other gaming platforms, creating your character, adding families and building homes can be fairly limited in the respect that you can't easily switch from house to house. It's a minor annoyance however, and in the greater picture, doesn't really effect the game overall. 
Would I recommend this? Hell Yeah!

The best Sims game, and it's on Steam. Only wish Sims 2 was on here also. Can struggle sometimes because it runs an entire town at once, but most semi-modern machines should be fine with it now. Tons of content and some great expansion packs, it's the game you loved as a kid with some refinements and improvements, and not too drowned in EA annoyances.

I wish I had a mixed button. It's still the best Sims game to date. Albeit the DLC being pricey still (just buy on a sale). However through all that great gameplay is bugs, bugs, bugs. You'd think newer hardware should run this better, right? Nope. Its unoptimized severely. Certain DLC maps (looking at you Isla Paradiso aka Island Paradise expansion) have terrible pathing bugs that cause the game to lag out. However there are guides on how to mod and setup your game to be more maneagable and playable. Other than that, this game is a blast to play! So much content to explore and so many different skills to perfect. I recommend it if your willing to setup your game a bit.

We all know how much I love, love, love Sims 2. However, with Windows 10 being what it is, Sims 3 and 4 are the next best thing to experiencing the nostalgia of Sims 2. I won't deny it: there are a lot of improvements, both major and minor, that Sims 3 offered:

- Most meals now fill Sims' hunger meters up completely
- The game is more "open world" and provides fewer loading screens when traveling around lots
- You can now place furniture more freely (via the "sub-grid," as I call it)
- The writing/painting systems are far more thorough
- Traits allow for more diverse Sims 
- Graphics are well rendered

There's just a lot about Sims 3 to love! 

I AM giving Sims 3 a positive review overall because, yes, it is fun and enjoyable, despite not being Sims 2, and yes, as mentioned above, there are a good number of improvements and tweaks that make Sims 3 superior to Sims 2. However, there are also a few cons that I would like to mention:

- EA charges the same amount for each and every expansion as they do the base game (makes no sense)
- The Design Tool is mostly better, but can be a nuisance to use sometimes
- Hairstyles get worse with each iteration of Sims (for both 3 and 4)
- Only one neighborhood template by default (Sims 2 had many)
- Cheats don't work quite as easily as they did previously

Overall, though, Sims 3 is a great contribution to the Sims franchise. In fact, most of my anger about Sims 3 is the first bullet point - specifically, EA making it very financially difficult for me (and I imagine others) to buy the expansions. In my opinion, a lone expansion shouldn't cost more than half the base game (about $9.99 for Sims 3), especially considering how many expansions there are. Maybe I'm too nice a person, I don't know.

Absolutely phenomenal game. Truly. I wouldn't have put almost 900 hours (at the time of the writing of this "review") if it was a bag of turd and/or I didn't like it. I own The Sims 4 as well and I only have 43 hours in it, and less than half of those hours were actually spent truly playing the game. If you don't know what The Sims is, welcome out from under your rock. If you do know what The SIms is and you even remotely think you might like it, buy The Sims 3. It's a bargain for how much game you get, especially when you realise that it's sequel, The Sims 4, has less charm, less content in the base game, charges more for the expansion packs, and for some reason sacrifices the living and breathing, seamless feeling to the game worlds that the Sims 3 did so well and replaced it with smaller contiguous play areas, and separates even neighborhoods (which are often just a small street with 5 or 6 houses) within the same town with loading screens. Yes, The Sims 3 is worth every penny. And if you're smart, you'll grab all the DLC next time they get a big sale slapped on them. In The Sims 3, there really are endless possibilities. Also, you might want to bring your microwave and put it on your computer desk and buy a crate of microwave meals. Otherwise, you might forget to eat.

My boyfriend once borrowed my steam-login because he and his friend really wanted to try and play the Sims 3 over a weekend. So they installed it on his computer and had some fun - until the husband of the family got kidnapped by aliens. "That's just what happens," they thought. But they noticed that he kept having this moodlet that said he wasn't feeling well.
When he eventually gave birth to a tiny blue alien, they called me in a panic. I was both ecstatic and outraged. It was absolutely hilarious that these two, who'd been playing for maybe 3 hours in total had gotten an event that I, after countless hours, had never actually managed to get.

And I think that says a lot. I still haven't seen this event in the Sims 3.

Theres nothing like wasting away in front of the computer to make sure virtual people in a computer game live balanced, fulfilling lives whilst your own falls into disrepair around you. Enter [i]The Sims[/i], a series so consistently in-depth and interesting that its no wonder its the go-to game for people who dont play games.

That said, if you do play games youre still going to find a lot to like about [i]The Sims 3[/i] (if you prefer to complain about them on Reddit youll just find yourself annoyed by how much DLC is available). Create your household, set them up with a job; teach them a new skill; throw parties - you can do just about anything you can imagine a typical whitebread American family doing in the small town of Average, VA. Little counters along the bottom of the screen keep you updated on what your little avatars want; how theyre feeling and why; how close they are to levelling up a skill - the world is your oyster. Its easy to identify what needs doing to keep your little man or woman happy, and youll end up so obsessed with queuing up actions for them to do that youll complete transcend just how weird it is that youre playing God with people who dont even exist.

There are hundreds of hours of micromanagement here, and not a whole lot to complain about. The loading times arent great for a 9-year-old game, some of the user interfaces are unintentionally obscure, and you may find chunks of hard work deleted because you pressed back at the wrong time and the game didnt let you know that this menu was a point of no return. Other than these minor gripes, the only thing anyone would complain about is the abundance of (optional) DLC, but these people are the type wholl complain about anything; with no DLC, [i]Sims 3[/i] is as good a simulation title as youre likely to find, and is well worth the price of admission.

 Abduct any Sims who walk near your home. Force them into your basement, and make them paint for your amusment and profit!

 Mods! If you don't like how a certain thing looks, there's probably a mod for it. Want to make more efficent sensory deprivation chambers? There's a mod for it! Anything you could want to do to a Sim, can be done!

The Sims 3 is an experience unmatched in it's raw ability in allowing full creative liberty to the player over virtually everything present. While a little dated on the visual side, The Sims 3 delivers in an unprecedented display of content and replayability. The sheer magnitude of the gameplay possibilities is astonishing and has still left me in awe after hundreds and hundreds of hours across several versions of the game. The freedom that the game allows for the player is unmatched in any game and allows for The Sims 3 to feel like a full experience, not unlike a proper Thanksgiving dinner in which the turkey, mashed potatoes and gravy, cranberries, and plenty of other filling additions to the meal leave you ultimately satisfied and contempt with their experience as a whole. The most prevalent downside to The Sims 3 is it's glaring influence from none other than EA, which is found through the bloated list of expensive add-ons. While the content found in many of these Expansion Packs is quite refreshing and in some cases even better than that found in the base game (The Sims 3: Seasons, The Sims 3: Generations, The Sims 3: University Life), the fact that they are downloadable content and not part of the base experience are noteworthy. All in all the Sims 3 delivers in an experience that fails to disappoint. 9/10.
