[NOTE: I'm more than happy to answer any questions related to the game if you're on the fence about purchasing or just curious in general. Just ask in the comments. I've spent hundreds of hours playing this game over the course of years and have plenty to say about it.]

Without a doubt, this is the ultimate Sims game, which corrects many of the major flaws throughout the series (including flaws which were reintroduced in the subsequent game), although there are many issues even after the game's complete development. I'll begin with how it compares to the other entries in the series (including the new Sims 4), then some major flaws, the unavoidable question regarding DLC, and lastly how to make the most of your game.

Starting with the earlier games, a common gripe with Sims 1 is that Sims have no sense of self-preservation, and would often die without complete micromanaging from the player. In the Sims 2, the Sims reach an uncanny valley effect with most every Sim looking seemingly identical. In both of these games, Sims had vary little in the way of varying personalities, with altering their traits only changing the rate of which motives grew or decay with an occasional unique interaction here or there. Also in both games, there's little in the way of varying gameplay. No Sim seems to act unique, so it's incredibly easy to feel as though you've experienced everything the game had to offer once you clocked in a few dozen hours (even with all the DLC). But one of the more major issues In 1, 2, and 4 is that Sims are locked specifically to their home lot with little in the way of freedom.

The Sims 3 rectifies many of these issues, starting with the introduction of the trait and moodlet system, which gives each Sim a unique personality that you actually see reflected in the gameplay. In addition, Sims are intelligent enough to sustain themselves indefinitely, although they will need player input for major decisions in terms of careers, skills, or relationships. There is even now an open world with no loading zones, so your Sim is free to walk off the lot and use parts of the community to gain skills, refill motives, or improve relationships seemlessly. There is even an optional "story progression" button, which allows the neighborhood to progress with your active family. As the cherry on top, this game finally gives a convincing face editor which makes Sims look both expressive...and not all creepily identical both facially and physically. 

The Sims 3 isn't without major flaws, however. Even with all the (major) DLC, there's many bugs which, while correctable through player input, continue to hamper the game, such as ceiling tiles floating in the sky, Sims getting stuck, or minor gameplay mechanics not working. As I said, many of these things are correctable through some trickery as the player, but some bugs--while either minor or rare (such as cars eventually filling up parking spots on community lots)--can only be corrected through mods. But at least they're out there.

Another issue is the mountain of DLC. Each DLC is definitely an improvement upon the game (with some entries definitely stronger than others), but they are expensive and rarely go on sale. The game stands up fairly well vanilla, but the DLC is rather tempting, especially given that this is a game which can consume hours of your time. With all the DLC installed, however, you will encounter a problem. There are no in-game neighborhoods which come with all the DLC content in one place, forcing the player to either move from town to town to experience all the complete game has to offer, or make their own neighborhood with all the content themselves (which can take a considerable amount of time). There is a solution to this in the way of player created content, however, as many players have created neighborhoods (some of which are just modified versions of the vanilla neighborhood) with all the content present, and the game is made so that it will automatically replace objects you are missing (due to not having the DLC) with their closest available variant. All of this can be handled with the packaged installer, which makes downloading player created content (read: NOT mods) all the easier.

Now that we've tackled the major positives and negatives, we can start addressing the gameplay. As I said, the gameplay is phenominal. Sims are able to take care of themselves, will age and die, and form relationships as you go along. No life cycle is the same, with varying personalities and experiences that can make each new generation feel fresh. Difficulty of the game even varies with your own decisions, with larger families obviously being more troublesome to juggle. The Pets DLC also gives a new facet to the self-imposed difficulty, with cats, dogs, or horses effectively being seen as the halfway point in difficulty between adding an entirely new Sim to the household. With the inclusion of the phenominal story progression mechanic, you can (and are expected) to stick with one family the whole game while the entire town ages with them, and if you're ever feeling spoiled for choice, the game's ingame "Wishes" system always gives you goals to acheive. 

There's a lot to experience with this game, of course, but there's a common error that many new players make that can put a damper on your fun. To get the most of your gameplay experience, I would recommend using the default Sim lifetime (as you can modify it yourself) even if you want to test new content. Sims live just long enough that they pass away of old age when you've had enough of them (to put it coldly) and it gives just enough leeway for you to learn new mechanics and experiment. You don't have to make your own house (although it is satisfying to see a house you planned be interacted with by your family), as using the provided houses in the game work well enough. But if you must (which is tempting given how customizable everything is--down right to an in-game texture editor), then try to plan large. Never make rooms less than three tiles in width/length (including hallways) and give each interactable object at least a tile or two of wiggle room. Sim lifespan and the physical size of your house are the two biggest hurdles in terms of enjoying your gameplay experience. 

Ultimately, I would whole-heartedly reccomend this game, even if you're unsure of the creative aspects of it. There's obviously ups and downs to the game, but the gameplay is still deep, fun, and always offering something new, and the challenge is, as I said, self-imposed, but there are plenty challenges you concoct yourself or find online. Even if you're not the creative type, the game offers plenty of stock elements for you to use without sacrificing the gameplay experience. The sequel to this game, the Sims 4, is unquestionably a downgrade to this phenominal game (quite literally, as the Sims 4 outright removes gameplay elements--including the open world) and the Sims 3 will give you countless hours of entertainment for years to come.

I know this game is old but bear with me and read below why I think this decade-old game is still worth 19.99 as a standalone without any DLC:

TLDR: This golden standard of the genre has no limit to how deep the gameplay can be. Gently sugggested by the game, the story is entirely built up and polished into a masterpiece by you and almost everything is costumizable. Easy to pick up and nearly impossible to put down once you get going. I still would recommend to wait for a sale, but that is true for almost every game on Steam. There are many triple A games that cannot offer the same amount of entertainment for the hefty price tag of 60 bucks. 

I made a musically inclined single mother Sim with a teenage boy. She is a brave and good parent that always hepled her son with homework and spent her time selflessly on him. And he was a straight A high school student and a genius little chef with a great sense of humor that helped with the house chores while his mom worked late shifts at the theater to pay the bills. She climbed the ladder all the way from a backstage nobody to a rockstar. Her silk fingers were also good at raising a perfect garden to fulfill her life-time wish. She had a few bad relationships and never really settled down. Once she became a celebrity she would hold parties almost everyday and with their different schedules she slowly fell out with her son. One night she was upgrading a speaker for a friend when she got electrecuted, but being the stubborn lady she is (and I didn't know the danger of being electricuted twice) she continued tinkering with the stereo and got a fatal shock that brought in the Reaper. Gone from Sunset Valley in body, she was immortalized in the music and pop culture.
The boy dropped out of school. Became a recluse. Broke up with his girlfriend and lost all his friends. He still got by with the money his mom left behind. Grew frail and dirty. His books became his escape. He read and wrote his feelings all day for months. Slowly the now young adult got over his depression and took up writing seriously. Slowly crept out of his shell and found a new love, a pretty artist that had big dreams of being the next Picasso. The adult man then published a masterpiece kids book, and now is expecting a little angel that he will name Ellen, after her late grandmother.

[Edited for spelling]

I bought this game when it was on sale for 3$. I used no DLC and do not intend to. Allow me to summarize my first session. 

   Joodeen started out as a young bachelor living alone and working for the military. His dream was to become an astronaut and see the wonders of space. He worked very hard in life, often collapsing on the floor in front of his bed after arriving home from work. Every girl he talked to friendzoned him, and he found it very hard to make friends. His neighbors would often stand on his lawn and argue him if he happened to leave the house. It wasn't until late adulthood that he was finally married to an evil human lab rat whose skin had turned blue from high amounts of radiation. They were married only a few days from his birthday. He soon had two creepy gray alien children whom he loved very much but was moderately afraid of. About a day from their birth, he became an elder. With the sweet release of death quickly approaching, Joodeen worked as hard as he could to progress in the ranks at the military so that he could achieve his dreams of going into space. Unfortunately, he died in his sleep one day before he went into space. His whole evil family witnessed his ghost passing into the next life and were terrified, but also relieved, as they were now free to pursue their goals of conquering earth. 

RIP Joodeen, you never achieved your goals.

Player it via Steam in the first time, but then only via Origin, since there was a big sale on Origin only, I believe. Anyway, overall I really enjoyed this game, got many many hours (Steam hours as mentioned before were the first time) of playtime and they were all worth it. I purchased every DLC (Origin), because I'm a collector but also because all of them give some more content ofc, yet they are really overpriced. But if you really enjoy this game like me, you gonna get them all, since you can buy them cheaper via several trading sites. If you consider buying Sims 3 or Sims 4, I definitely recommend buying Sims 3, since it is just a difference between worlds, in the Style of play, and I missed very many aspects of Sims 3 in Sims 4, though Sims 4 is a good game aswell, not to get me wrong here. I think there is nothing much to say to Sims in general, since it is the only big game series in his genre and I think everyone knows immediately what there is to do, if they here "Sims".

Ok, much talk, there is one big contra: 

The game plays in a "free-to-move" world, means you can walk through the whole neighbourhood you are currently at, which is one of the big differences between Sims 3 and any other Sims parts. Anyway, the problem is, that also all NPC's (all other Sims and Pets (DLC)) can do this aswell, not being a problem first, but the more DLC's you have running at the same time, the laggier and more unstable the game gets, resulting in huge freezes if you speed up the game time, making it almost unenjoyable and unplayable. This is caused, as you can read up in several forums, of bad coding of the game, so that the pathfinding / routing of the NPC's is terrible, causing what I stated. There are several mods though, which could fix this, however it didn't work for me at all, and I don't like playing with activating and deactivating some DLC's rotational, only because it is lagging. However, for the beginning there is a mod called "Nraas", which is almost essential for everyone playing Sims 3 and pretty easy to install and understand. You can read up it's information in the Internet of course, if you want to. One more "big" (well not really big in my opinion, but many just really hate it) contra is the Sims 3 online shop, where you can buy Simpoints via the official Sims 3 website and then purchase diverse items, many people just don't like this way of money making.

After much talking, I just say I can recommend this game, but also keep in mind, if you are ever going to play with every DLC at the same time, it will keep freezing and lagging.

This Game Is amazing, to put it simply. I have played this game on origin for over 200 hours and I'm still yet not bored about this game. I bought this game on steam because all the DLC was at super low price and have majority of the Ingame content. I do not see myself getting tired of this game anytime soon. 

The Game Itself:

The Sims 3 is basically a life simulator where you play God over your Sims. Sims are low IQ creatures that you control in everyday life to making food and going to the toilet to sleeping. The more often you perform actions, the more your Sims do actions that you do  automatically. For example, if the icecream truck comes by alot, and you always buy icecream your Sims will start doing to automatically instead of you having to do. Jobs are a essiantial. You can be many things from a Cook to an astronaut. It is hard work as different jobs require different skills to master. You can be a world renown surgeon  but it isn't easy work. You need many skills such as logic which can be obtained such as playing chess and much more. 
Although you don't have to, the game plays out like this (in the most basic form). 

1.Get a job
2. Get a promotion
3.Find a girl/ guy and woo hoo
4. Marry the girl / guy
5. Get the girl/guy a job
6. Make Kids and raise kids
7. Promotion to the max (if you can)
8. Become rich
9.Die
10.Repeat with your children

Building: 

Building is very fun. Creating giant Mansions are a joy to do. Making the perfect home for your Sims are a big part of the game. The building mechanics may look very difficult to new players, but when you get the hang of it, it becomes very fluent and you can create many things. You can create your dream house that you will never have, and it never becomes boring to do. From a small trailer park to a big mulitmillion dollar mansion, you can do it all.

Cons:

The thing that sucks about the sims 3 is that it is in the hands of EA. EA are greedy. and greedy means they want lots of money. The DLC cost alot and are not worth the price you are paying. As good as they are, the stuff packs are just not worth the price that EA puts them at. I strongly suggest to everyone, wait till a sale comes. The Sims 3 barebones no DLC can get grindy and boring after 40 hours as you did pretty much everything. There are mods that can extend the playtime, but you need DLC for certain mods to work. 

Conclusion:

 It's a life simulator. You can be what every you want. It's unlimited freedom. Be a physco and kill sims by starvation of drowning. Plauge the entire city with zombies (from supernatural DLC) if you want. It's great. Don't get the game in Origin as Steam provides cheaper prices and more sales.

My only experience with Sims 4 has been through watching some friends, and hearing general complaints from some.

While I can't fairly compare - I love Sims 3. All of the options to expand environments, story lines, and characters are on point. However, I am bewildered as to the decision to charge $20 CAD or more for each DLC pack, when there are nearly 20 of the damm things! THIS MAKES SIMS 3 a $400+ GAME! Not only that, but this is not the newest release in the franchise... what other game series out there has done this? It's ridiculous. I'll find them in thrift stores, and on third party sites on sale instead... Very disappointing.

PROS
 Seemingly endless gameplay options, excellent replayability
 Smoothly functioning game, I very rarely run into glitches
 Access to the online Sims 3 community, custom items etc.
 Feels like what a sequel to Sims 2 should have been
 You can change the color and pattern of any item/surface
 Easily accesible cheats menu

CONS
 You cannot change the key bindings
 Insanely over-priced DLC, as well as real-money cosmetics shop
 More support is available for Sims 4 instead now...
 Many basic items, like a hot tub, are only in some DLCs
 Only 2 towns available in the base game

An amazing game that is incredibly replayable with so many choices! It is complete nostalgia for any sims lover and is a great game for people looking for a more casual simulator! Aside from minor bugs the game has been a fan favorite and my personal favorite in the series! Although it is missing some awesome dettail features from the Sims 2 like cinematics, a good memory system (although the Sims 3 Generations has one it is not ideal), and awesome loveable premade families with the best stories, this game offers wayyyy more features and makes up for minor downfalls! You will seriously enjoy the story progression! Like that and the open world aspect of the game make it a much better option than the Sims 4 which lacks too many features and feels more like the Sims 2.3 with a downgrade and betterish graphics :\ Until the Sims 5 comes out and offers as much as the Sims 3, this will be your go to! (P.S. I play on origin I have just boughten packs from steam during sales which is why my hours are so small!)

Ah, The Sims 3. The highlight of the series in terms of offering endless possibilities.
Clocking more than the 57 hours steam says I have played, I can say that even with just the base game, there is short of endless things to do and explore. It's a shame that The Sims 4 didn't build on all what 3 offered (then again, EA has its reputation to boot).
Usually I wouldn't even dare to give a possitive review to a game published by EA, much less give them any money. However, The Sims 3 (and its expansions packs) are my exception: I am weak, as much as I hate the developer, I love this game a 1000 times more. And it's very simple: everything that made The Sims 1 and 2 great, The Sims 3 just builds on and allows you to go beyond, offering so many great experiences that you simply can get lost in this game (again, steam says 57 hours, but I'd say it's over 200).
So yeah, as much as I hate EA, I have to give it to The Sims 3. The gold standard of the series.

Game is ridiculously expensive but you already knew this. What they dont tell you is it hasn't been updated for CPUs in about 10 years. You gotta find the solution yourself and make it  recognize your graphics card (edit game code files). Even THEN! The game has performance issues... it CONSTANTLY STUTTERS, LAGS and FREEZES for whatever reason. 

If it weren't for the bad performance I wouldn't consider the game play experience bad but it is... ITS BAD. Online comments I found said this is normal behavior. So much for a $200+ game. Plus you think you got all the content?? Nope!!! There's more.. even after you buy all the expansion and dlc, they got other stuff online for the same price. You gotta buy their currency then spend it that way. Just a money grab.

At this point the textures of the sims are pretty poor. I'm dissapointed but with an old game that is to be expected. 

Actually I think I just might sell it back if I can. Too bad it can be entertaining but with with the huge performance issues, definitely not worth the AAA price. it's OLD. My suggestions $5 base game and $1 each for DLC.  Thats it.

Edit: If you play this game past the 2 hours mark and only then start to realize the performance issues it will be too late for a refund on the game and ALL DLC (even if you never played the DLC). Don't get burned like I did.

***Note I may have fixed the game for myself since I made this review but I'm keeping this review AS IS.  There is no reason why I should spend this amount of money on this game and then also have to spend hours modifying it, hand coding and basically end up in my own tech support role.  This game remains a major money maker for them and they haven't bothered to make any patches for it in over a decade.

 My fix may not work for you (see comments below). I also used this guide found on steam

In all seriousness, to me, the Sims was always a weird series, it's like, life is bad enough as it is now, why would i want to play a simulation about life?

Well, that aside, i had lot of fun on the first Sims with its expansions back in the days, i played the second game, not as much but played it for at least more than 30 hours but less than 150 hours.
Spent above 150 hours on the first Sims.

I've never played the Sims 3 until recently, i decided to give it a try, i can say that it's pretty fun, i generally do not cheat on the Sims, i may have one or two characters who will cheat but not my primary character/family and the others, that's just how i like it (honestly though, i'd cheat right away if i could in real life).
It seems that this game has quests/missions or some kind of quests/missions which is pretty cool.

Expansions are a must and i'd suggest getting everything that the in-game store has to offer, you do not need to pay for the store items though, up to you to find out how.
With all of that, you'd have enough content for all your sims and families.

The Worlds from the store are pretty cool, i'd say thatmy favorite so far is Dragon Valley.

So yeah, it's a good game with lot of replayability, lot of content but here comes the flaws.

- Overpriced expansions/dlc and most of them should have already been in the game, they've released almost all the same DLCs for each game, come on now, just release it before the game is released but what do you except from EA Games?
- Expensive store, having all the items is pretty cool but let's be honest, you won't pay for it, you're better off downloading it online especially after having paid above 200$ for this game and its expansions/dlcs.
- Katy Perry dlcs... Do i need to say more? 
- Long, very long loading, i heavily recommend to install it on an SSD.
- You have twice your store items in your documents folder, by that i mean that if for example, you have 4gb of store items then it will be 8gb, to fix that, you have to rename the Sims 3 launcher to the name of the other executable and rename that executable to the launcher name, delete the .tmp files in DCCache and you're good to do, you should also delete files in DCBackup but not all of them, if you want a detailed guide, just let me know but there's probably already one somewhere on the internet and probably even on the guides of the Steam community but i still find it pretty dumb that EA Games has never fixed it and that's why it's a negative point.
- Optimization is bad, like every "The Sims" games, the game will run fine even on an old computer but except it to take time to load everything, the game being a 32bit game doesn't help at all.
- Distant textures are bad and it's pretty limited, there are workarounds online to make it better though but it still is a negative because sometimes it feels like a console game because of it.
- Can't go to other Worlds without having to create everything from scratch which is kind of a shame to be honest.


Now i'll go over its positive points quickly.

- Open world, you can now move your sims freely in the World which is a biggest plus for me, it's pretty cool.
- World Editor, you can download the World Editor online, unlike the SIms 2 which uses Sim City 4 as a World creator, the Sims has none (which would have been pretty great to be honest) so neither the fourth so that's why i'm putting this as a positive point.
- Lot of content once you got everything.
- Expansions are pretty cool except for the crappy Katy Perry stuff.
- Lot of things to do, lot of new content for the "The Sims" and "The Sims 2" players.


Honestly, it's the best Sims to date in my opinion but the Sims and the Sims 2 are still worth playing even today but once again, that is my own opinion, the Sims has that something that makes it so good while the Sims 2 has the already existing families and locations which are pretty cool too.
Forget about the Sims 4, it's not worth it, it's just not worth nor your money nor your time, it feels like a mobile game and a downgrade from the previous games, and a big one while at it.


The Sims all in one - 9.1/10
The Sims 2 Complete Collection - 8.9/10
The Sims 3 with everything except the Katy Perry stuff - 9.2/10

Sims 3 is an amazing game where anyone who has loved any of the Sims games in the past will adore. It has plenty of content and so much for your sim to do. Plus if you add any the many, many, DLCs to it, you have even more for your sims to interact with and do! (Though I 110% recommend for you to wait till the DLCs go on sale because $20 for just one is WAY, WAY too much!!!)

Though, there are some bugs that I doubt will ever be fixed, most don't break your game. (As long as you have the equipment to correctly play the game.) The only real bugs I found that I had any huge issue with is:

1. The loading screens take a while and it can be a bit annoying at times (But I also have 5 or 6 DLCs so that may be my issue)

2. When on the house building screens I get a bit of lag when I'm building for any longer than 30 minutes.  

3. Occasionally when I jump between buy mode and live mode the game will freeze for a short moment, which at times causes me to get concerned because the game has crashed because of this once or twice. 

4. The constant "Hey you can get this to add to your game if you pay money" is annoying and I really wish there was a way to turn it off.

Besides those, I've had very few problems, and any other problems I've come across have been hilarious, such as my toddler sims suddenly flying around the house when they move or my sim standing straight up while riding her horse. But besides that, I've haven't had many issues with the game. 

I 100% recommend the game if you are a Sims fan.

Sims 3 is a lifestlye of a game, I have played with multiple families, some reaching better lives then my own haha. Its very time consuming and great for those who love multitasking. Characters can be silly to look a like to your real life self. Its nice to have a game where you can live out a dream life, with just a click.

Pros:
+The vast ideas of what a character could look like.
+The DLCs, add more to the game when applied.
+Building a home from scratch is fantanstic with the tools they provide for you.
+You can download other player made sims, to give yourself the friends that also play.
+You can make a story by creating and being whatever you like.
+Finally got to have a loving family.

Cons:
-You have to buy DLCs in order to get the real good stuff.
-Paranoid with teaching my children to swim, (I TOLD HER NOT TO GO IN THE POOL)
-The big one, is there is no multiplayer...(I know it wouldn't happen, but it would be cool to be able to buy a sim server and host people from around the world to go into your world and live there too. But guess thats reaching for the moon)
-If you own a DLC then purchase a new one, it tends to bug the previous DLCs, had to redownload a few times, so the pets would stop being invisible, really annoying when you have a pet and its yelling at you that its sad or lonely and you can't see it to help. ; -;

Overall:
I honestly love this game, I wish I had the time to put into it like I used too, but I will play again once I own each and every DLC so I can start over and take full advantage of them all.

I played: 31+ hours, ongoing

Story: make your own!
Gameplay: basic life simulator/ management game.
Framerate: looooong loading screeeeeeeens
Vibe: chill
Difficulty: intermediate

Character customization: lots!
Character design: kind of unnatractive character models, fixed in the sims 4 with a new artsyle. more realistic options.
Art style: realistic and simple
Replayability: infinite!
Online Features: few, but there are basic steam community stuff.
Addictiveness: h i g h

P2W (pay-to-win)?: no
Microtransactions?: yes, but it lies in DLC and payed costumes.
Worth price?: Yes!

Absolutely great game, but there is a problem. It is also a game that was broken by its developer. DLC's kept adding more stuff, but the engine simply couln't handle it. Or perhaps the engine was just a one giant mess in the first place. Either one of those. Or both. Now the game eventually becomes unplayable.

For example my last game ended the very moment my character was married and bought a bigger house. Not even a really big place, but middle sized. And the game started to freeze every few seconds. Totally unplayable. The game before that (with a different PC and Windows version) ended when my character moved to a different town. It ran well for a few minutes and then started that same freezing problem. Using certain console commands I was able to get it working for a few minutes and then the problem was back. It was not fun anymore.

Apparently there are utilities that try to alleviate these problems but I haven't tried them yet. I have heard that they may help a bit, but are not a perfect solution.

Anyways it should have been developer's job to fix the engine, because these problems started when this game was still actively maintained (as they were still releasing new DLC's). So I cannot really recommend Sims 3. It is an amazing game but the problems are just so very bad.

Bobby is an evil, insane beanpole with a mohawk who lived in a trailer. For some reason, Tori found this attractive. So Bobby married her, moved into her fancy house, and knocked her up. Then Tori's fat roommate - let's call her Amanda - saw Bobby cheating with their other roommate, Monika. So Bobby had Amanda transferred out of the house and into his old trailer before she could tell on him. 

Right before Tori's water broke, she caught Bobby making out with Monika. So Bobby divorced Tori and had her and Bobby's  child (who inherited his evil gene) sent to live in the trailer with Amanda. Then he married Monika and knocked her up. Now, their other roommate, Ayesha (who despises Bobby), takes care of the baby while Bobby and Monika play video games and go dumpster diving.

Bobby's cheating days are over. The divorce was too painful. His new plan is to use Monika to populate the entire town with his evil children, but send them all to Amanda's house. Meanwhile, Monika will build herself a fancy aquarium, Bobby will work on becoming the leader of the local crime syndicate, and Ayesha will continue cleaning up the messes they leave around the house and paying most of the rent.

To be quite frank, I'm completely outraged.
I would think paying around 400 for a game plus all its DLC would be completely outrageous at the best of times, but this game is 9 years old! It's an utter joke that EA believe it's an acceptable price especially considering the main reason for my outrage;
Bugs, game-breaking bugs. 
The Sims 2 was relatively stable, most people were able to play with the game heavily modded without issue, this game however has many people (including myself) experiencing game-breaking bugs with completely unmodded saves.
The two issues I've had was getting stuck on loading screens, which I spent a full day trying to fix (where I discovered this is an extremely common problem, and there are dozens of posts around the web from people with this issue) before realizing that oddly, the loading screens work fine if the game is minimized, so I went on with my game for a while.
Then out of nowhere, I attempted to load my game yesterday and recieved the error message  "A serious error has occurred. It is recommended that you restart the application", despite what the message implies restarting the game does nothing.
So I went to search for a solution online (where I once again discovered this is an incredably common error, so much so it has it's own page on the simswiki) however this time I was unable to fix the problem, I spent all of yesterday and the first half of today trying every solution presented online, none of which worked (which didn't surprise me since most people on the various forums about this issue found no success with them either) meaning the only real solution is the delete the corrupt save file. Then what? Start a new game and hope the same thing doesn't occur after pouring many hours into another save?
Honestly I actually wish the error had appeared SOONER, then I might have a leg to stand on while asking for a refund.
I mean ffs, I only brought a fraction of all of the DLC but the cost still totalled 155!!
I spent 155 on a game that can corrupt your save out of nowhere!?
Well, I was already pretty damn sure I was going to boycott EA with the recent controversies, but I'm now 100% certain this will be the last EA game I ever buy.

The Sims 3 is a sandbox game.  If you like to set up scenarios and see how they play out, you will find few games that offer you the power and flexibility that this game gives you.  The Sims series attempts to simulate "real life", especially the interactions between people.

There is a tremendous amount of content available via DLCs and the user community.  Good instructional videos and reviews are plentiful.

Though this game is old, the graphics are surprisingly timeless.  It may be that you adjust to attune to the style of the game.

The Sims 3 is the last game in the series that features a relatively large open world.  The Sims 4 uses 3 to 5 house neighborhoods.  This has a significant affect on the gameplay.

While there is a great deal of criticism for the number of DLCs (and especially for the prices), significant discounts are frequently available.  If you load up during one of these sales, I believe you will be happy with the value.  Though the stuff packs generally provide marginal benefits, most of the expansions significantly increase gameplay.  The full set is particularly impressive.

The game runs smoothly on my system, even with all the DLC.  There is a known performance issue with the Island Paradise map.  It can resolved via mods.

You know what the Sims 3 is about.  If this your type of game, give it a try.  If you like it, load up on the expansions at the next sale.

10/10

***THE GOOD***
---EVOLUTION OF THE SIMS SERIES: Sims 3 is everything that was awesome about the Sims 1 and 2 and dialed-up a few more notches with some awesome new stuff tossed in for good measure. Sims 3 isn't just more of the same, it's building on the foundation set by its predecessors and does an amazing job of it.
---REPLAYABILITY: The Sims series, generally, has infinite replayability. In essence, unless you're just messing about with drowning your sims or something like that, the challenge of the Sims games is to create a family and see how many generations you can keep it going. It seems like a fairly straightforward goal but there's lots of stuff to do along the way and a whole bunch of ways you can go about doing it. I've, personally, gone 3 or 4 generations in one save file and not had to replay content because there's so much in this game that you can do!
---REFERENCES: Sims games are packed full of clever references to pop culture. For example, if your Sim works as a doctor at the hospital, you might get an event that references the hit medical drama 'House, M.D.' and there are some fantastic Godfather references in the criminal career path. As a gamer that seriously appreciates clever use of references, this is a definate plus!
---VIRTUALLY UNLIMITED CREATIVE FREEDOM: Besides clothing and hairstyles, which are fairly limited without purchasing the DLCs (not so limited that you'll find yourself saying "really, game?" but noticable nonetheless), the Sims 3 gives you a world, some characters and a plot of land and tells you to go nuts. If you've got the Simoleons, you can build pretty much anything. Castles, big sprawling mansions, elegant cabins, dark horrifying dungeon house, etc, etc, etc. The list goes on and on. The character creator in Sims 3 is shockingly in-depth for a game of its age since it gives you the freedom to create just about any size and shape person you like. You can make some seriously deformed individuals if you've got the mind for it.
---A LOT OF WAYS TO GET KILLED: There are a LOT of ways to die in this game. I'm not certain exactly how many ways Sims can die in Sims 3 but here are some that I've encountered (not an exhaustive list, by any means):
   1.) Immolation
   2.) Electrocution
   3.) Struck by freaking lightning (with Seasons DLC)
   4.) Starvation
   5.) Drowning
   6.) Time Anomaly (with Into the Future DLC)
   7.) Old Age
   8.) Hit by a meteor
   9.) Death by ranting
   10.) Eaten by a shark (with Island Paradise DLC)
   11.) Flew too high with a jetpack and fell to your death (with Into the Future DLC)
---YOU CAN GET META: Now, in case you're not aware, when you create a new save file in Sims 3, you create a new town. Thus, if you have 3 different saves, you've got 3 copies of that town, the only difference being the family you've decided to create and play with. Now, you CAN, if you want to, have multiple families running on the same save file in the same town. Of course, you can only control one at a time but it presents an interesting opportunity for you to really go nuts and make the town into anything you want it to be!
---CHARM OUT THE WAZOO: Lots of stuff in the Sims games is total unexplained nonsense. The language, the currency, the fact that you age so darn fast compared to real life, the fact that you can set it so you can't age at all, the inexplicable cultural significance of llamas, and teleporting lawn gnomes. But, as rediculous as all of that is, it grows on you. The Sims 3 is a really charming game.
---YOU CAN HAVE CHILDREN WITH THE GRIM REAPER (IF YOU'RE WILLING TO KILL A WHOLE BUNCH OF PEOPLE): This is hard to do without using the developer console but here goes. If a Sim dies, the Grim Reaper comes to collect their soul. If you're quick enough, you can strike-up a conversation with Grim before he departs. He doesn't stick around long enough to befriend him though but if enough Sims die, he'll come back frequently enough that you can start a relationship with him, Woo Hoo (sex) with him, and have reaper babies. Hard to do without the console (with the console, btw, shift-click on Grim and select 'add to household' and he'll become playable. Note that this has been reported to be gamebreaking but, hey, it's your choice).

***THE BAD***
---DLC DLC EVERYWHERE!: Sims 3 has a metric tonne of DLC; all of it WAY overpriced. The fact that there is SO much content available in those DLCs makes them tempting to buy but trust the Steam reviewers who say that they're only really worth it if you can, somehow, manage to snag the base-game or, better yet, the DLC itself, on sale.
---IN-GAME INCENTIVES TO BUY THE DLC: They aren't everywhere but when you're browsing the more creative menus in the game, you'll see lots of banners and "you could have this" or "all this could be yours for the price of..." style blurbs trying to tempt you into buying DLC packs. Intrusive and annoying but, honestly, not a deal breaker for me.
---MONEY: Now, I'm going to preface this by saying that this is probably just my experience with the game. However, I found that money, and my lackthereof, in-game is scarse unless you get work. Though, I think, there should be an option to begin the game with an inheritance or something, there isn't. So, I find myself using the old 'familyfunds family name #' console command a lot to finance the dream mansions I like to build. Underhanded? Mmhmm, but I don't regret it. There's a reason everybody talks fondly about the money cheat in the Sims community. (Press CTRL+SHIFT+C on main menu and type testingcheatsenabled true and hit enter to enable cheats, by the way. Use CTRL+SHIFT+C to open the console in-game from the on.)
---MANAGEMENT HEAVY: If you're not the kind of gamer who enjoys such games as Roller Coaster Tycoon, Sim City, or other such games that require a degree of skill with micromanagement, you probably won't enjoy the Sims 3 either. As fantastic as the Sims 3 is, there are times when it feels like all you're doing when you're not designing, buying, or building things for your sims is making sure they don't die because of their own ignorance. I get that this is intended to be part of the game's charm (and, I admit, I do find it charming that the sims themselves can behave in very bizare ways), it can get tiresome. This isn't a game I think you can play all-day, it's best enjoyed in short, 2ish hour play sessions once in a while. Otherwise, you might burn yourself out on it.

***VERDICT***
Solid 8/10 for me. If you've got $20 (or your regional equivalent) to spare and you're looking for a neat game that you can sink a few hours into here and there, pick-up the Sims 3. It can seem dated at times but it's better than the Sims 4 in literally every measurable respect.

One of the best Sim games out there. While I wasn't really into this type of game for the Sims 1 & 2, I have played them and prefer 3 over both and 4.

The amount of hours I've put into this game over my life is more than I'd like to mention, and lord knows how much time I'll sink into it now that I have it on steam. It cam be incredibly boring if you only do the surface level tasks; get a job, find a spouse, make love, have baby and do it all over again. Once you start to diverging from that, it becomes incredibly addictng. You could also just murder the entire town by inviting them over for a party and deleting the doors so you can watch them all slowly starve to death. Your choice.

It gets a lot of shit for the price of the DLC, but I'll give you a bit of advice:
Buy Ambitions - expands job and work life opportunities
Buy Generations - expands what each generation goes through in life
Those are the only two that I think would be worth it to everyone considering they not only add loads of content, but also expand upon a lot of lacking areas in the base game. The rest of the DLC can be skipped without fear of mising out on much. I will list the DLC that can be worth buying if you're interested in the subject, though:
Pets - I like this expansion, but not everyone enjoys the added responsability (and annoyance)
University - I don't much care for it, but others seem to love it. Seems pointless in my eyes. It takes forever to put your sims through it and you don't really gain much.
Seasons - Love the idea as a weather fanatic, but performance suffers and it's not uncommon for weather to ruin a lot of the game for most of your sim's life when on default. I've had kids who get Fs in school because they only went one day and the rest of the childhood phase were snow days so the school was pissed at their attendance.

The rest of the DLC is so topical and specific that you'll know if you want it or not. Be warned, some of it (like supernatural,) can really mess with the delicate balance of being a life sim and pretty much all challenge can be lost. Also with a lot of the DLC and store content your sims have an unusal focus on it. Like the store's ice cream maker and deep frier. You can have a house full of millions worth of futuristic entertainment but your sims will still spend all damn day cooking deep fried chocolate ice cream. Households full of 8 sims will likely have a que for the fucking things.

And seriously, DO NOT INSTALL ALL OF THE DLC! I see people do this all the time when they torrent the game or get it from a friend or just buy all of it because they think they'll be missing out. It will be next to unplayable, especially on an older computer. They're released the way they are so you can pick and choose what content you'd like in your game. Having all of it will tank your fps even on a high end machine and cause your sims to be so confused and bipolar that you won't be able to keep up with them. They'll go from casting magic spells to having issues with hormones to fawning over a cute dog to filling out university surveys to pissing themselves because they're so busy.
Install the two I mentioned and pick and chose what you think you'd enjoy in your game. Trust me, they're more than enough to see in every expansion pack.

Despite all the DLC, the base game itself is still very much worth it. It feels basic, but it still very fun. Think of the DLC as adding on your favorite spices and sauces to an already nicely cooked meal. They're not needed, but give it the personal touch it needs to shine.

Arguably the best experience The Sims franchise has to offer - Unfortunately it's about $420, but that's better than what EA on Orgin is asking for The Sims (series) 4 being well over $500 and (at present) growing.  Granted Sims 4's packs have added gameplay features that it's prededecessors haven't seen.  However, The Sims 3 was missing little refinements a heavily expanded Sims 2 had that made migrating to the new season a reluctant transition...  Three packs later, The Sims 3 came into it's own and became a worthwhile step up from that point on.
The Sims 3 takes everything that made it's predecessors the engaging hit franchise it had become and brought your Sims experience into a seemless open world, leaving lot loading along with the entire world aging together even for a more realistic and immersive experience.  With one of the more recent expansions, Island Paradise you can have your sims live and traverse a life that invokes TV shows like Magnum PI.  Between the content available from the packs and the modding community, The Sims 3 is worth getting if you want a rich experience within this franchise.

If you're going to get into The Sims, buying the The Sims 3 (fully expanded/boosted) here on Steam is the only way to go, as Origin can be a nightmare during installations/reinstallations with missing product keys you have chase EA up for.  Again to bash EA Origin, but NOBODY does a sale quite like Steam - This one such game you should only get when the big sales roll around!
As for Macintosh users...  Because of how EA handled the porting, this game is an unstable mess and I would recommend buying The Sims 2 Super Collection (App Store) for the next best thing if you're looking to get the best experience at the best price - Otherwise if money is no object, I suppose you could go all-out and spend half a grand or more on The Sims 4 and all available packs.

Ultimately if you're looking for that pinnacle experience, then The Sims 3 with all the packs is going to be the ticket!

I'd like to recommend the game, as I enjoy playing it... when it works. But in the end the stability is something you'd expect from a game in Alpha. I've had games routinely get corrupted to the point they won't load.. after a few hours of game play the game starts getting choppy and objects can no longer be interacted with, etc. In a game where development of your character and home over time is the point, a game that has an artificial reset switch you have to hit regularly due to bugs that make it unplayable is frustrating at best. This could have been a very pleasant, relaxing game but instead is a perpetual troubleshooting nightmare..

Decent game for it's time, but overpriced and finicky to make work on win10.

For an old game, it's good! But it's maybe $10 worth of good, not $20 (minus all the expansions). For awhile, it even ran pretty well on my win10 computer- not great, mind you, but acceptably for an old game (was able to work around the issues with some delving into various properties and a few online guides). 

Now aside from gameplay issues (glitches, quality of life aspects lacking, etc), there's still a pretty big issue with buying this game: it simply won't run. 
It's not just a problem I've had, my sister tried to buy and run it, and encountered the same thing. Pulls up a black screen and won't load any more, no error messages to help you find a cause, or anything. Seems to be with the base game, since uninstalling/reinstalling didn't work. Spent 2 hours trying to figure it out with various online guides, messing with advanced system computer settings, etc, no luck. 

This game is dated, and while fun for its time, probably not worth YOUR time and stress. Do yourself a favor and get sims4 if you're going to spend the money.

If you choose to try it and it works fine, fantastic! But be wary, it may be a pain to make work.

I was a bit skeptical about this game at first. It seemed like the game was all about getting a lot of money and then building a huge house with what you earned. Needless to say, the reviews that I read were pretty positive, so I went ahead and bought it.

I played for 8 hours straight in the first 8 hours that I owned it. 

This game is beautifully created, and it runs completely fine on my 2010 model WIndows laptop. You can create your own town in this game, and it's really fun to experiment with a different amount of Sims living together, and you can also, in a way, create your own stories with it. You can become a musician, a journalist, an athlete, or anything that fits your taste. I HIGHLY reccomend this game to anyone who is thinking about making an investment in it.

I don't know why I like simulating regular human life so much but no other game has really tried.
I played The Sims 1 and 2 for 1000s of hours when I was young and I've tried 4 for 100 hours.
What impresses me the most about the franchise is the AI and the sheer level/amount of code running in a busy neighbourhood playing 8 sims + pets in an enormous cluttered house including sped up time and a fully free camera.
In #4 they shrunk the map and chopped it up with loading pages so it could later be released on consoles. The Sims 3 is PC dedicated.
I've become so efficient at scaling an 8 person family into epic riches that I now prefer making my sims live homeless or in squalor. I love using the texture customization tool on furniture and decor to make piles of decrepid junk and virtual filth. As far as their personality, I'm much more interested in making crazy/evil sims with as many disorders and phobias as possible.
When building I find myself making bomb shelters, vaults and torture chambers 40 feet underground with a camouflaged entrance and security checkpoints at each floor.
Once in a while I will just build -or buy then upgrade- an elaborate dream home and max out every skill while chasing ambition points, but it's simply not as fun, realistic, or memorable than simulating terrible/bizarre lives. 
I have most of the DLC but just let me tell you that vampires, fame and magic can pull you out of the realism quickly. Furniture and Clothes packs aren't worth it. I recommend just a couple of your favorite large expansions and they'll come with plenty of new assets.
I would never buy sim points either.
Thanks Maxis for all the simulation! There have been rough patches, cheesy marketing gimmicks and times I thought the bugs had ruined it all, but I will always recommend The Sims because summing it all up, I've just had too much fun not to.

The most underrated (by hardcore gamers) gem made by, surprise, surprise, EA. That's right, back in the days EA made epic win after epic win. I still fondly remember Need for Speed Underground 2, FIFA games and Burnout Paradise.

Pros:
+ Oh, my, the sandbox. In this game, you can do ANYTHING. And by anything I mean ANYTHING. It's kinda like a realistic Garry's Mod. This is my first experience: here's your sim, here's a city, bye-bye now! In this game you can go to the dance party... as Lenin! And call Stalin on a dance-off! Yeah, man, now we're talking!
+ Open world. You can go anywhere you want. No restrictions. Want to read a book? Go to the library! Want to workout a little? Go, go to the gym! And you know the best part? No loading screens. Magnificent!
+ Doesn't get repetitive. Sure, you might say: "But you should manage your sim's needs!" Well, yeah, that's true. But the whole management process and ways of fullfilling even the basic needs are anything but repetitive. Sure, you can live a boring life of "eat, sleep, urinate," LOL, but that's not the point of the game. You must fullfill needs [i] at the right time [/i] and [i] in the right place [/i]. These actions don't take long. They're blazing fast unlike, say, in fucking WoW. If the action is extremely slow you can speed up the game or plan your next actions. And the amount of actions is INSANE!
+ Speaking of planning. No, it's not just a virtual dollhouse. It's a down right RTS merged with an architect sim and RPG. You have needs to manage, goals to achieve, actions to plan, skills to level up, friends to get, lots and cities to build and money to spend. Planning, planning and planning again. That's why Sims 3 is not Garry's Mod. And that's why it's so unique.
+ CAS. Yeah, it's not [i] that [/i] cool as The Sims 4's CAS but it has a Create-a-Style and still better that TS4's CAS in some areas. And it's functional. The Exchange proves it.
+ Story progression. When you're doing your business, city's inhabitants live their own lifes. They age, have kids, steal an ice cream truck and die in a horrible pain on fire. And if you download Story Progression mod, the sims' life becomes even more varied.
+ Did I mention mods? It has lots of them. They're awesome.
+ Build mode is well thought-out. So many options to choose from. You can make the house of your dreams. Or horrors if you want to turn your sim's life into nightmare, you monster.
+ 14 floors! 14 fucking floors!
+ Over 100 ways to kill a man without getting your sim's hands dirty.
+ Kids turturing, yeah! 
+ Traits! These things affect how your sim behaves. There are lots of them!

Cons:
- If you have uncompatible mods/too much mods/bad weather outside/too much stuff in your room/God knows what else the game will go NUTS! I stopped experiencing issues after a third clean reinstall and presetting the lifespan before installing mods but God knows maybe I'll have more. Or you'll have more.
- Game lags frequently. Probably because of so much stuff to compute.
- Loading times. They're ASS! FUCKING BLOODY ASS! EXTREMELY long, IRRITATING AS FUCK! But you can deal with that.
- There's A TON OF DLCs. To buy all of the Store items you probably need to sell your house. Thankfully, DLCs are sometimes sold with a 75% discount making the base game with all the DLCs cosl like your regular AAA game (THANK GOODNESS).
- These DLCs increase the loading times [i] even more [/i]. Oh, the horror.

All in all, that's a great game. Definetely buy it. And if you won't buy it because you think it's just a casual game than... okay, don't buy it. Why should I give a fuck?

It was on sale, I grabbed it. I have played it on my Origin account, and it's a nice time waster if you don't feel like doing anything gaming related. I can just sit and watch whatever I create go about their daily routine without putting too much effort into anything. 

The self automony is pretty good, sims will keep their levels in check and based on what traits you assign they'll keep their surroundings in order. I just wish they payed their own bills and repaired stuff as it breaks. Minor inconvience, but I guess you can't get everything.

Visual wise, graphics still hold up, everything looks visually pleasing. I was able to set the game on my monitors native resolution of 1440p and 144hz refresh rate. Great!

Also the music in the game is good with a variety of tracks to pick from. Usually with games that have music, you end up turning it off. I haven't done that with the Sims 3. 

So yeah pick it up, it's a nice stress reliever, just make sure it's on sale first. That's my recommendation. Don't buy it if it's not on sale though. 20 USD per expansion pack is silly especially being how old of a game it is.

I had The Sims 3 for years but lost it a while ago, so I decided to purchase it on Steam. I had The Sims 3 and The Sims 4, and honestly in my opinion, The Sims 3 is much more fun than The Sims 4. The Sims 3 has an open world, a bigger world, more things to do and you can have hours of fun with just the base game. Though on The Sims 4, the worlds are small, many loading screens, no open world and there were things pulled from the base game and were put into expansion packs just to get money out of you. If you want more of a realistic expierence, The Sims 4 will give it to you. But if you are wishing for more exciting gameplay, The Sims 3 is for you.

The Sims 3 has some bugs here and there, and the loading screens take FOREVER! The game takes even longer to load when you purchase expansion packs. The Sims 3 base game gets somewhat bland if you get hooked because there isn't much to it after a while, that is why there are so many expansion packs, to earn money more and more. I recommend getting the base game and expansion packs on sale only because there is too little to do for the amount of money they cost. Expansion packs will spice up your gameplay though, so if you aren't sure you like The Sims 3, get one or two packs to start with or just start with the base game. Don't buy the "stuff" packs unless you really, really love the game.

The Sims 4 is boring, too little and way too expensive! $40 just for the base game, and it's not even the "deluxe" version, and that's not including all the expansion packs that they are adding. And these expansion packs include stuff that are from The Sims 3 base game! Yes, the game looks more realistic but The Sims 3 has more things to do and it is just more exciting overall. Don't let the age of The Sims 3 stop you, it's so much better and you'll get hooked right from the start.

You can start relationships, friendships, families, build your own home, go to work, hang out with friends, explore different locations and basically live your dream life, but virtually. You can almost do whatever you want with your Sims! I recommend The Sims 3 all the way, you totally need to buy it, but only on sale. It is not worth the $20 price. Thank you,
~Quality Cow
If they had been any more insistent on ramming microtransactions down my throat, I may have gagged.

I'm new to the world of Sims, having only started playing Sims 4 last year. I decided to buy Sims 3 to see what all the hype and clamor was about and was sorely disappointed.

Despite having a laptop that just barely meets its minimum requitements, I can run Sims 4 with almost all of its expansions and game packs installed. Sure, it lags at faster speeds, but I'm fine with that. On the other hand, I tried to change the wallpaper in my Sims 3 house and it nearly overheated my computer... that's not okay. I knew Sims 3 had performance and optimization issues, but I didn't realize it would be that bad...

The open world is kind of neat, but I found CAS and Build/Buy Mode to be rather limited as far as variety go. I did really like the wishes/lifetime achievement system, it had more "weight" than the whims/reward traits in Sims 4, I guess (and just having more traits in general was nice, which is one of my biggest gripes with Sims 4). Unfortunately, due to the aforementioned performance issues, I wasn't able to delve too much deeper into the gameplay.

Maybe when I upgrade to a better computer, I might try out Sims 3 again (the fact that I would need to upgrade to play a ten year old game seems rather silly). Until then, I think Sims 4 is a better and certainly more optimized choice.

This game is actually a pretty great game. However, since it's an EA game, there's nothing much to expect from the developers towards a game that is almost 10 years old. The EP's are extremely overpriced, and I'm just gonna mention that I don't have any of them, or the stuff packs either. I believe that the things you get in the EP's are simply things that should've been included in the base game, like Seasons, University life, etc. I recommend picking this game up on a sale, it normal goes on for around $5, I think. Just know that it is the most neglected Sims game, but I still prefer it more than 2 & 4. If you plan on playing it, I highly suggest that you download Nraas mods, especially Overwatch, ErrorTrap and MasterController, since they help run your game much easier. If you want to also be reminded to save your game once in a while, download Nraas saver, I think the deafult is 30 minutes real-time. Before you download any mods just make sure you know how to download CC (custom content), and make sure that you know the basics. Your cc folder should have three files in it, packages, overrides, resource.cfg. You can download the frameworksetup file from the internet, specifically from a website called Mod the Sims. After that, just rename it to "Mods" and you should move it to documents > Electronic Arts > Sims 3. That's it. CC is great, and it allows you to get so many cool stuff in the game such as clothes, hairs, skins and all that. You can also download custom worlds, houses, etc. one of the most well-known websites for CC is The Sims Resource, and it has a lot of things for you to download, just make sure you download stuff mainly from featured artists, since a lot of CC can be bugged when you get it into the game. 

Overall, I do recommend the game, and it's totally worth it.

The Sims 3 can be a fun game. There's just one problem: If you want the full expansion+stuff pack experience, you will find yourself spending upwards of 500 dollars. If you want EVERYTHING, including all the store content, you will find yourself spending exponentially more so.

Unfortunately, you will probably need those expansions and stuff packs to actually get any major enjoyment out of this game, as The Sims 3 can be barebones without them.

It's the Sims. There's a few mods which let you increase the reality & whatnot. Only DLCs I'd recommend even considering are Supernatural and Into the Future. If you're enjoying the game, then Pets, Seasons, & University Life are decent during a sale.

8 Years Later, you still need a high end PC to play this. Crashes often.

But if you do have a beast of a PC, it'll still not run well, Google Overwatch Sims 3, it's a script package that fixes bugs in Sims 3.

Edit: Well, The Sims 4 is out, and although none of the DLC for The Sims 3 is going to ever drop below $20 (Which maaaaybe one or two of which is worth that amount), it seems like this is as low as the price is going to get. It's a Sims game.  Depending on your experiences, it's better than 1,2 or 4.  But that's my opinion.  It's a great way to waste some time if your bored.  Just be ready, and understand that this is an EA game, so it's broken with no support from the devs.  Luckily, there are mods that minimize almost all of the game-breaking issues.  If you do plan on getting this, I suggest that you also get mods from NRaas to help protect your saves, and generally fix problems that this game can cause.  A few mods that you need to start off with would include:  Master Controller, Error Trap, and Overwatch.  Also, stay away from the Exchange on the Sims 3 website.  They will cause issues if the files have corrupted files embedded in them.  And, loook at all of the dlc!  The game runs better with a few of the EP's installed.  If you want more, expect the game to slow down.  And look at those prices!  Wait until they go in sale!  They normally go for around $5 U.S.  If you have any questions about bugs, glitches, or other game problems, google them to find 10 years worth of community forums.  The community on here is pretty decent as well.  With plenty of people willing to help you out if you have issues or just general questions!  

If you've liked any other Sims games, then this is a good choice.  There are tons of custom content that you can get to do pretty much anything you want, and make it look however you want it to.  Mods and cc make this game unending with stuff!

Sims 3 is A very good game w/ most of the expansion packs. If your low on cash don't bother buying until a sale. (You'll save a lot more money that way) The Base game is very empty without some DLC. (Most of the DLC should of been in the base game IMO, but EA are a bunch of money hungry bastards...)

I reccomend Generations, Pets, and Seasons, they are a necessity in my book.

There is also a pretty active modding community. You'll have no trouble finding more content to give your sims. Just remember, the more Custom content you add, the longer the loading times.

I'd also like to note the longer you play sims 3 on a save game, the more unstable it gets. I reccomend downloading the NRAAS Overwatch Mod ASAP. This will help combat issues. http://nraas.wikispaces.com/Overwatch. I also strongly reccomend geting NRAAS story progression, as it fixes EA's buggy version of Story Progression. http://nraas.wikispaces.com/StoryProgression

Remember the days when The Sims was fun? It was a simple experience. Your characters got a job, they increased their skills to do better at their jobs, and made more money so you could expand your house and get better stuff.

There is way too much going on with this game! Tons of arbitrary objectives. Did you want to design your house a certain way? Forget about it. Your character wants to buy a red lamp, and increase his painting by 3 points within the next 3 days. Character personality creation is so complex. Am I really expected to believe that the AI in this game is THAT advanced? Is this level of depth necessary in a game where most of the events that take place revolve around generalities such as, "I enjoy sports" and "I need to poop"?

This franchise has turned what was originally, a simple, enjoyable experience into a click fest. It is like getting tons of notifications on your iphone and constantly addressing them, even though they are just uniportant blurbs and spam.

Nostalgia aside, this game is the best of them all. With the armada of expansions available, and the mods that are out there, the game can be quite enjoyable. Although there isn't as much creativity availible this time around with the faces of the characters, the creation is still enjoyable. Fact about me: I didn't know this game existed until 2013. I really wish that the creativity and whimsy of the first three was in 4, but 2 & 3 are the only ones that are still amazing in the latter half of the decade. Overall, I give The Sims 3 a 10/10.

I saw videos on this game on youtube, and I loved the concept, yet it didnt seem right for me, it just seemed like the game would get boring after a few hours.

But boy was I wrong. 
I haven't had much time to play it in much depth, but I love it. The concept of controlling someones life is incredibly fun! You get to decide what they'll be, how they'll get that, and what they will do during that action. I love the customization for characters, and if you didnt know the game is much more fun with map and customization mods,  which can be found from certain websites, but please be careful and make sure you are using safe websites.

[b] Pros[/b]
- The gameplay is very fun, there are many things to do and many challenges to attempt if you are bored
- Many custom made maps, houses, characters, hair, clothes, etc.
- The graphics are not nesicarily bad, while sims 4 does have better, the graphics are actually still quite good, and for a game with this theme, amazing graphics are not needed.
- The music is ok, but the game is more fun with your own music, or perhaps chatting with people while playing.
- The game is best bought on sale, but still worth 20 dollars.

[b] Cons[/b]
- Certain DLC, are very expensive! Only a few are actually worth the money, and almost all should be bought on sale, or even better they should just be put on lower prices.
- Sims 4 does improve on lots of things that Sims 3 didnt have, but overall they're quite the same.

Overall rating,
8.8/10
A great game, and lots of fun, but I must say that this game is not for everyone. It's a game made for a certain group of people who enjoy making another life the way they like it. So try it out and see if you like it or not!

ahhh, the Sims. the love of my life and the bane of my existence. ive sunk nearly 700 hours into this game, and have hundreds more logged into the XBox version back when i was younger as Desperate. what's to say about this game? well, for starters, it's way better than Sims 4, so jot that down. Sims 4 may have the graphics, updated animations, and looks, but Sims 3 has all the charm, customization, versatility, and open world. Sims 3 has long loading times, but you only ever get one big loading screen for a whole world, as opposed to a gajillion small loading screens.

i've been in love with the Sims series for a long time. i'm a sucker for character customization in games, and Sims 3 is basically "Character Customization: The Game". I guarantee at least 50 of my gameplay hours are JUST me making tweaks to my Sims. and, indeed, making Sims is almost an art form. as you play the game and get a better feel for what looks good and doesnt, youll find yourself going back to update old looks.

i will say though, the vanilla base is fun to play and versatile on its own, owning the right expansion pack is what kicks it up a notch from good to great. i personally recommend Supernatural for Baby's First Expansion Pack, if youre into vampire husbands and occassional zombie infestions paired with a lovely gothic aesthetic and chairs wearing corsets for some reason. if that doesn't appeal to you, try Into The Future, for all your solarpunk desires, weird hairdos, bizarre picasso clothes, and expansive questline needs. Pets is another popular expansion, but i would not make it your first, personally, as the pets are a bit buggy. unless, of course, you like when mr fluffles turns into an extended slenderman polygon abomination. i own Pets and it's good fun, but it adds another layer of micromanagement i often forget to bother with (oops).

pros of game:
+character creation
+character creation
+character creation
+can make a self insert and have them date your fave fictional character
+make a hideous goblin and breed it until it has pretty babies
+the modding scene is huge, active, and full of fun stuff to install (caveat: always back up your game. a wonky mod can cause pretty nasty side effects)
+the micromanaging is super friendly to control freaks like me. pause and fast forward whenever you like!
+character creation
+healthcare is free, accidental pregnancy isnt a thing, there's no racism or misogyny, life is good
+the expansion packs only add more layers of fun gameplay and quest lines

cons of game:
-microtransactions, anybody?
-still full price for some ungodly reason despite being old as balls and the sequel being out
-expansion packs are also full price
-stuff packs are not worth it. ive waffled on buyng them solely to say i own every expansion but decided against it. some expansion packs are also AWFUL
-seriously the microtransactions in this game
-WHY IS IT STILL FULL PRICE IT'S BEEN YEARS, EA
-if you hate micromanagement, you will hate this game
-game is HUGE, will eat all your disk space and CPU, and has the nerve to ask for more
-i run this on a (decent but not gaming oriented) laptop, so maybe this is just my computer being a stupidhead, but it still chugs on me on the lowest settings, so be warned
-the character customization can be overwhelming for a new user

i recommend this game to:
+people who love roleplaying
+people who love micromanagement
+people who LOVE character customization
+people who enjoy silly games without much violence or conflict
+people who love messing around and doing dumb stuff like recreating shrek but with the Sims

stay away from this game if:
-microtransactions are a deal breaker for you
-you hate micromanaging
-you don't care for character customization
-your computer overheats easily
-you crave action, conflict, and fast-paced stories. the stories in Sims 3 affect me about as much as a gentle breeze, and im the emotional sort

Tl;Dr
A good game, has good and bad aspects, but personally i would get it on sale because why the shint is this game still full price

I waited 9 years to finally purchase a decently priced bundle of the base game and 3 expansion packs only to find out that this game has been unsupported for nearly 4 years. First sim I created wanted to become a superstar athlete, however because of a bug (which had been fixed at one point but resurfaced due to an expansion pack release) could not win a single game.

Without third party mods this game is a downward spiral of bugs that will start caving in on itself after about 30 hours of gameplay. Meanwhile the developer still tries to sell this title at a premium price and continues to push on-line content in your face while playing.

I cannot recommend this even at the price I got with the 3 EPs, because too much of my play time has been spent fixing the mess of bugs that have been ignored by a very greedy developer.

Too many bugs, too many crashes, too many problems. They gave up fixing this game and rather made The Sims 4, because it was easier. 

Is this game unplayable? Nope. You can play it, but before you buy lots of DLCs like stupid 8===D (like me) here is a way how to make it work:
1. Dont buy many DLCs - they will collide. Lot of community members suggest to buy only 2-3 DLCs. Less DLCs = Less problems. 

2. Dont buy DLC: Island Paradise - the most unfinished one - bugs, freezes and crashes. Need community patch to only play it, but still it is not working correctly. 

3. Google: NRAAS mods for The Sims 3 especially these otherwise you will have hard times to play this game.

    A) NRAAS Master Controller - allows you safer interaction - like dont use wardrobe or mirror to change appearance - it can cause scripting error of your sims which might result it many crashes of game. With this tool you can customize them again and again and much safer + it has lots of very usefull features (like removing fame level from celebrity sims which later becomes troublesome). 

    B) NRAAS Overwatch - deletes non-used cars and turns off TVs and Radios in non-active families. Reset stucked sims and pets (very useful!). This way it removes frame lags which would happened without this mod. 
    C) NRAAS ErrorTrap - fixing gamebreaking bugs. 

    D) NRAAS Traffic - allows you to set 0 celebrities limo - once you get your own limo - game starts spawning them to you and it will cause frame freezing and crashes. Not with this mod. You still can have limo from your carrier, just those celebrity ones are buggy. 

    E) NRAAS Woohooer (not-compulsory) - this mod allows much more sex in game + it fixes dialogues options (in vanilla game if you ask about age, sign or job - you are flirting.....this mod marks these and similar dialogues into friendly actions, not flirts),

   F) NRAAS Decensor - allows you to downsize or fully remove censoring. Nothing to get pumped about, since chars are like barbies and kens - details are missing. Good only if you dont want censoring crystal big as your whole bathroom.

   G) NRAAS Story Progression  (voluntary) - this one makes your city more alive, with more living citizens who are actually doing something - they are getting married, changing work positions, buying stuff. CAREFUL: this mod requires high end pc since it is really demanding. SUGGESTION: Never use this mod in University, World Adventures - China, Egypt, France. Use it only with your home towns. Because if you use it on university - students sims are starting to look for jobs instead of studying and will try to live like normal cities but it isnt allows on university and it will cause some troubles (not with performance) like nobody will graduate etc. 

   H) Other NRAAS mods by your taste =)

This game is The last good sims game in my opinion! so here are some pros and cons!

Pros :
- you can get community made maps and content for your game!
- you can travel to other parts of the world if you buy the world adventures expansion pack!
- you can actually travel freely in you town!
- building and running a resort is always fun!
- you can build your sims up by getting them into their dream jobs and maxing out their skills!
- making a whole town one massive family is fun ........
- putting custom sims in your town makes for some good times! 

Cons :
- you only get about 10 % of the game with the base game . the rest is unlocked when you buy the 10 + expansion packs and Stuff packs!
- this game runs VERY POORLY on old systems!
- it can glitch with in compatible content

Verdict : 
it is still worth a buy in 2017! it is even better if you can get it on sale when it is 5 dollars!

Why do people enjoy The Sims? Sims Freeplay and that game people used to play on Facebook were much more enjoyable. In fact, my favorite Sims game of all time is Sims 2 on the DS - which is why I gave this a shot in the first place. I actually much prefer the quest-based style of that game - which still offered all the fun of changing your outfits, building relationships, and interior decorating - than this game where you have a 100% blank slate that requires tons of creativity to figure out what to do with. I like setting up my character and house and that's it. Why do you want to watch a loading bar while your character goes to work? Don't we watch enough loading bars? I don't get the appeal at all.
