If you like The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and Second Life, but you want more family interactions, you're going to love The Sims 3! As you all know, in The Sims 3, everyone has the ability to create his or her own family, build epic houses for their sims, and play their lives out. But now, anyone who has this awesome game has more options for their Sims and Households than ever before! Depending on which expansion packs one has, the Sims can have magic, pets, become a celebrity, and even experience weather patterns!


Gameplay-Simpler than you may think, but not smooth all the time. See the section on graphics below to find out why. Gameplay Score-7 out of 10.

Items-Plenty of stuff to find, use, wear, and so on. This includes items you can buy from The Sims 3 shop. There are a lot of items you may have to buy from there, so be aware. Items Score-8 out of 10.

Weapons-If you count all the wands your witches can use, then yesh, there are weapons. People have provided guns to download free also...Nice! Weapons Score-8 out of 10.

Ammo-The only form of 'ammunition' is the mana bar all (Or most) Supernatural Sims have. Therefore, it's not enough to warrant an actual score. Ammo Score-N/A.

Armor-The only 'armor' Sims have is their clothes, and they don't offer any protection. Sims don't really need it anyway. Armor Score-N/A.

Plot-With an uncanny ability to create your own plot (or plots) by making use of pictures and videos, the possibilities of having a 'perfect plot' in The Sims 3 are endless! Plot Score-10 out of 10.

Characters-Once again, depending on how many Expansion Packs and/or Stuff Packs you purchased, you can surely create just about any character in The Sims 3. Characters Score-9 out of 10.

Sound-Most of the sounds here are easy on the ears, except maybe for humming a tune or perhaps releasing noxious...Yeah. This is it. Sound Score-7 out of 10.

Music-Like many other games of the 2010's, the music isn't really of the best quality, but some folks may disagree with me on this one. Music Score-4 out of 10.

Graphics-Well, there may be some problems here, as the graphics may result in much lagging or even crashing. Sometimes, I've even had to reset my EA password over this! Not cool. Otherwise, the graphics are nice to stare at. Graphics Score-6 out of 10.

Final Score-The Sims 3 can be a truly great game...If you can afford all or most of the expansion/stuff packs it comes with. And even if you have all those, you'll still have to make additional investments from The Sims 3 Store to make your Sims, their homes, and skills unique in your own way. Final Score-9 out of 10.


Sure, the game and its expansion packs together will cost a lot of money, but if one were to carefully save up a little money every month (Even $25 would be enough) then they could have a near-complete collection in a relatively short frame of time...If one is patient. Yes, the game has its fair share of glitches, but unlike in Skyrim, one can have more pets and more children! Plus, those children and pets can have children of their own once they're old enough. The possibilities are nearly endless in The Sims 3!

Game is a bit like Marmite. You either love it or hate it.

I picked up the Sims 3 as I wanted to dive into the Sims universe, and it was easily the best choice of my year.

The gameplay controls and mechanics were admittedly difficult to get accustomed to and took a few hours to work out, but as soon as I picked up the basics, I understood the game and how everything worked, and so I found the game entertaining to control my own Sim and live a lifestyle.

The custom content - not to be confused with expansion/stuff packs - was a great addition to the game too. Clothing, hair, objects, and many more items could be implemented into your game through the Sims 3 website for free.

One of the most repelling things for me was the sheer amount of DLC the game offered. As EA made this, I should've known better. I refuse to purchase any additional content (minus custom content) as the base game itself is plenty enough and most of the DLC offered are nothing but money grabs which add no value to the game experience in my eyes.

In my time of playing the Sims 3, I rarely experienced any lag or frame stuttering, and kept consistent frames around the hundred mark, while rarely falling below ninety, which is fortunate for me as I play on generally high settings, in particular, the Sims detail, texture detail, and shadows/lighting detail. A note that custom content can [i]severely[/i] impact the performance of the game, but not by much unless you have a few dozen custom content added to your game.

Pros:
- Sims 3 it's the best one in the franchise.
- It's one of those games that you play 6 hours one weekend, get bored and play another 6 hours with a new family after some weeks.
- The best part for me it's designing and building houses.

Cons:
- Even when the game it's good, if you only buy the vanilla version you feel that there are not a lot of objects or stuff to do. (I was disappointed by the amount of objects/furniture).
- It's really expensive to buy all the DLCs even on sale.

Conclusion
I would recommend to get the vanilla version and try it, if you feel like there's not a lot of stuff and you have the patience, research and install some mods. I wouldn't recommend to buy the DLCs. Get the "The Sims 3 Plus Showtime" bundle, it's cheaper than just the game.

If you like the game you will put a lot of hours into it, but it's not for everyone so keep that in mind.

Before I get into the good things I need to say: this game is incredible FRAGILE. It has no auto-save function and it freezes, crashes or corrupt saves often so PLEASE be aware that you have to manually save every half hour or so and you should always save it twice (in two slots) because it is incredibly frustrating if you play hours to build up your family and next time you load the game it is just all corrupted and gone.
There is everything from 
- "freezing when you try to go to university or otherwise travel" (always save prior to travelling or enrolling or dropping out, re-load the last save, go to Edit Town, click in the top left corner the university or travel setting, don't do anything in university/travel location and just click "return to game" on top of screen, now try to travel again)
- freezing and stuttering when the game gets too big (8 GB RAM and tons of GB hard drive don't matter, it happens at memory footprints of 1-2 GB already) or interactions get hang up somewhere in the world where you aren't even looking
- items getting bugged (you can't remove an object that is in front of the baby crib as the object is considered still in use and your baby is starving to death because you can't step close to the crib because of it -> use a cheat to delete the object, huge bummer if the object is the patterns doll ...)
- corrupted saves which won't let you select your family anymore or members of it or the family trees or name of everyone are messed up (click on edit town, move the family out and move back it or to different house, usually that fixes it as somehow THERE the tree and names etc still exist)
- corrupted people that are invisible now (use a dresser or such to change the outfit to make them visible again)
And yes there are load screens. Lots of them. And it takes sometimes several minutes to load when travelling. But usually that is only the first time or between generations to university. Afterwards it goes much faster.

That being said ... the game is incredible addictive. I've played Sims 1 many years ago. Had Sims 2 but the latter was just a pain on Windows 10 and modern sized screens. I've waited a long time debating if to get Sims 3 as it is a steep price even with sales of 75% off and Sims 4 out already (roughly $100 for the whole Sims 3 pack). Was wondering how much all this money would be worth it. Finally bit the bullet and I don't regret it except these insane game instability and corruption issues that make the manual frequent loading so important - and saving takes 30-60 seconds at least. But there is so many new features and things to do and explore that makes we be in awe for the complexity of this game. You can now play a career as architect where you get paid to remodel and re-decorate people's houses. You can edit colors and textures on everything, objects, clothes, doesn't matter. There are adventures on travels, for example you can explore the Great Pyramid in Egypt, something like a puzzle game with looting items. You can learn songs from people of different nationalities and teach them to others.
Lot's of these make it well worth the buy. I just wish they would bring out a remastered version that was more STABLE/TOUGH. I would honestly pay extra for such a thing...

I only bought this game and dlc because it was on sale. Let me make this clear,This game is not worth full price nor is any of the content. EA NEEDS to reduce the price of the game and DLC ! I'm sure they have made plenty of money on this game. Greed is not attractive. But overall a great game, extremly buggy and save games corrupt often. (I would like to prefice this review with the fact that I have logged at least 200 or more hours on another computer when I had played the disk-based version of the game on my old laptop. Long-story-short, the laptop broke, I lost some of the main disks, I said fuck it, and bought the whole thing again on steam to avoid the same problem. If you take any part of this review to heart, then know this: do NOT buy the physical copies of this game. I don't care how cheap it is, that will be money lost to the void once that computer breaks and the steam version is at least a little more user friendly in transferability. Alright, here's the review.)

I love this game. I grew up with this game, and have seen numerous ways to create, love, hate, kill, communicate with, etc., my sims.

The game, in summary, is a life simulator. It's basically just that in the base game; that is to say you create sims (or, if you're weird, use some template sims) that you have to manage the basic life needs of food, social interaction, fun, toilet usage, and so on. Although, this is just a base, because the place where the game REALLY shines is the DLC. And yes, I know its already lost points in your mind and that this is just another EA money-maker, but hear me out on this one.

Yes, I admit that the only way to experience the full extent of the game is to buy all the DLC, which also means that you are either stupid, rich, or stupidly rich. That's just EA being EA. Despite this, the game is FANTASTIC if you CAN afford the DLC! They open your world to a multitude of possibilities in several different scenarios.

In Supernatural, you can become a werewolf, fairy, witch, or vampire and do many different things with the Supernatural world presented to you, like starting an impromptu zombie apocalypse or creating a wide variety of mystical potions with awesome effects.
In Showtime, you can take up a large number of different jobs in the performing arts, from Pop Singer to Escape Artist (don't quote me on the names, just trust me they're there), and become a celebrity of varying magnitudes in the process of rising to the top of the charts.
In Into the Future, you can travel to (you guessed it) the future, where you can meet your descendents, discover a whole new world of technology, and either screw over or progress the future depending on your actions in the present.

The list goes on. This is also leaving out the unique maps specialized for each individual expansion pack and the special secret things that may come with the packs (like the ability to have men give birth to alien babies in Seasons). Regardless of any of these perks and gameplay aspects, you still may not like this game unless you happen to enjoy managemnt games revolving around the every day lives of some group of gibberish-speaking bozos. I happen to be fond of such games and the bozos that reside within them.

In my opinion, this game is wonderful. Not the best, but an easy 8/10 in my book, even with only a few expansions. If you plan on getting this on a budget, get 2 or 3 of the actual expansions and, if you feel that you need a little variety, 1 stuff pack. I can't determine what combination would suit you (Seasons and Generations for normality or Supernatural and University Life for a weird-stupid-good time), so just see which one fits your fancy. My only major advice is to not get the Master Suite Stuff. It's just terrible considering the price.

When I was feeling stupid and rich, I bought almost everything I could. I spent two months working off the debt. It was not worth it. So, make sure you know what you're getting yourself and your wallet into before-hand. Ye hath been warn'd.
Dis game is terrible. It is quite expensive but not worth it. I would give it a 0.2/10. I would reccomend the age for 8 to 100+? Thats all.

This is a game where you'll be playing it and suddenly realize that you just spent the last 6 hours playing a game about the boring monotany of life, the same boring monotany that you were trying to get away from by playing a game in the first place. At this point, you will start reconsidering your life coices and realize you are wasting your life playing a game where you are controling a character that is loaded, lives in a huge mansion, and is the CEO of a company; meanwhile, you are a 20 year old vergin, who hasn't even kissed a girl yet, and has no real aspirations. Like WTF, I don't want that, I shouldn't going through a mid life crisis while playing a videogame, I should be sitting on my lazy ass, dick in hand, and not care about shit! Why do you do this to me Sims?! WHY!?

For some, god forsaken reason, dispite this, the game is incredibly addicting, and will slowly suck your life away as you play it, slowly turning you into a gelatinous blob of flesh and bone.

The people who created this game summoned Satan himself to grant them the unholy power to create this game and leach the lifeforce and money of gamers everywhere.

I mean, what can you say about Sims that hasn't been said already? You can do basically anything you want with mods or you can play the vanilla game and still enjoy yourself. There are so many ridiculous challenges online that you can do to keep it entertaining for hours on end. Sims 3 is my favorite out of the Sims games. I love a lot of the packs that you can purchase with this one, such as Seasons or City Living.

The real negative that I have about Sims in general is that it is published by EA and all of the expansions and packs are way too overpriced. Never buy these games or the packs at regular price, they go on sale at least once a year and you can get them for a reasonable amount around then.

I have spent wayyyyyyyy too much time on these games and I will more than likely continue to do so.

[b]Not Recommended[/b] to literally anyone, due to EA's disgusting business practices. The overwhelming majority of the content is behind paywall after paywall, and the basegame constantly tries to sell you everything hidden there.

The game is solid enough, but so much content is arbitrarily bundled into DLCs to the point that the basegame is just not a satisfying experience, combined with the several GB of additional "store" content purchased through microtransactions.

In total you would have to spend several hundred dollars to get the full sims 3 experience, and the content in the store and DLCs are NOT just what are advertised. Any towns besides the one or two default are hidden behind paywalls, as well as several random features such as laundry, smart phones, the ability to do real-estate with your phone, and the whole celebrity system, as well as numerous skills, the overwhelming majority of furniture and clothing items, and several careers.

All in all it feels like every time they started to make a content patch, they decided to release it as DLC instead. Hell, most of the bugs from launch are still present in this game, and many features promised before launch and in trailers aren't available anywhere, even in the DLC.

The entire game is also constantly trying to sell you its shit, even when you already own it. Between giant notifcations about store content in-game, advertisements for DLC and store content on the loading screens, and giant ads in the completely unnecessary game launcher as well, though the launcher ones have all been replaced with equally gigantic sims 4 ads.

These disgusting business practices combined with the fact that the basegame is so slim on content and the fact that all of it is so agregiously, ludicrously overpriced means that I refuse to recommend this game to anyone, despite a couple hundred hours of playtime. Even if the damn game goes on sale, avoid it. The last thing you should be doing with your money is giving it to EA... But if you already own the basegame and want to experience the actual full game, you may or may not be able to find tips and help on a certain tumblr blog that may or may not be really easy to find.

EA should be ashamed of themselves with these micro transations. You already bought the damn game why should you have to buy simpoints just to get some "cool" items. This practice has turned me off of the sims until EA gets there heads out of there ass.

DISCLAIMER: Before I had a PC, I played the PS3 version for probably over 100 hours. My time played in total on Steam is not accurate at all.

PROS:
-Feels like the world is alive around you.
-Even though the game is almost 9 years old, the graphics are still very good, and almost every gaming PC can run this game smoothly at very high settings. 
-You choose the way you want to play, whether it be starting a family and living the simple life, or becoming the President in this game, you have almost unlimited freedom to do what you want. 
-There are plenty of mods out for this game that can make your experience more fun and enjoyable. From new user created maps, to murder and nudity/sex mods, there are plenty of mods for every player for this game. 

CONS:
-DLC for this game is outrageous. The base game is $20, and all 19 DLC for this game also costs $20 each. 
-The game is still a little buggy and glitchy. 


Overall: 8/10

My recommendation for the DLC is to get "The Sims 3 Bundle" when it's on an 85% off sale. This bundle includes the base game, and in my opinion the main 3 DLC, The Sims 3: Generations, The Sims 3: Pets, and The Sims 3: Seasons. These 3 DLC are in my opinion the most important and most content filled DLC for the game. Some, possibly many will disagree, but it's my opinion.

I gotta say... I'm addicted to Sims! I usually play my CD version, due to havig all DLC there, but I'm currently in a year-long process of switching to the Steam version for the simple fact that it's way more convenient. I've probably amassed half a year of my life playing any version of Sims (I've played the original, 2, and now 3 -- I hate 4 though...) The Sims 3 does have rather poor performance from the start, whereas my Sims 2 didn't start having awful performance until I downloaded over 3,000 CC + mods. That's annoying, but I've learned to live with it to ease the addiction. I'm waiting for Sims 5 to come out before buying 4, so hopefully I won't have to adapt to 4! Though I have seen 4 played on a friend's PC & it does seem to run a LOT faster. My recommendation is: if you're new to Sims, get 4. If you've played 3 at all, get 3. Even if you're coming from 2, if you haven't played 3, 4 is much closer to 2 than 3. Though honestly, I don't think I'd even go bak to 2 if I had the right hardware + the CDs still... 3 is much more customizable which I love, and wastes more time ;)

Oh this game, so much time enjoyed creating families. Sims has been a game that i have greatly enjoyed for the longest time, as well, it's a pretty addicting game. Since i have had this game for the longest time, i felt as i need to make a review for it.
Starting off with base game, its pretty fun in its own right but without new twists and things to do, it gets pretty boring after a while. Although not all the DLC is worth it full price, so its better to get them on sale. Some packs are pretty cool to get when you can though, like Supernatural, Seasons, Pets, and etc. There is pretty much a pack for anything but again, better to buy on sale as not all of the packs are worth the $20 pay. Sims also has a website for extra content like worlds, clothes, hair etc. Which is pretty nice as well since you can get them with simpoints, but not worth to send money for as you can either redeem a game and get 1000 for free or watch some ads to get some. 
You can either add game packs or expansion packs. The difference? One adds little stuff for housing or for sims, and the other adds new worlds, things to do, stuff for both sim and housing. So yeah, choose wisly.
Overall I love the sims 3 so much. It's always a game i can come back to when i am bored of other games. There is so much to it, new games, adventures, generations. I can say that this game is worth the buy if you wanna spend hour after hour playing. :D

Of course I absolutely love this game!!! You do need the DLC's if you want more variety and it's best to wait until they are on sale.  Usually they go on sale about 1-2 times per year where you can get a few for the price of one.  Some DLC's are beter than others though so really look for the ones you like first if you plan on getting them all over time.

This is a complete sandbox game with many different styles of gameplay.  Legacy generations of sims; creating sims of every imaginable color, size and style;  building and/or redecorating homes in the grandest of architecture with a color wheel to change your colors to anything you want; and even questing if you're into that sort of thing. The only caution is it's so much fun the addiction is real.  Using NRaas mods will make your play more smooth if you're not against mods.  Have fun!

PS: My gameplay is MUCH more than the hours shown as I boot through the TS3W. exe instead of going through the launcher.  Also, my Steam purchases are a backup to avoid the dreaded 1.69 Origin update nightmare.

The Sims 3 has been a game I've played since it came out. Unfortunately EAs nonsense with not allowing me to install it on a new computer had taken that from me! So when I found out this series was actually on Steam, you can bet I was crazy excited! The only downside is slowly rebuilding the collection I once had. Thanks for stealing $260 from me EA! But seriously, this game is more fun (imo) than Sims 4 with a lot more adventure related themes to it, especially with the Supernatural Pack and the Worlds Pack. Always a great time, right down to the crazy Slender Man Cat glitches!

I'm running a i7 4790k, GTX 970. I purchased this game, and all of the DLC yesterday during the steam sale for 75% off. As soon as I post this, I'm going to see if it's too late to return it all. 

It runs wicked slow. Lags, jerks, takes 10 minutes to load, another 10 minutes when loading between towns/university. I have no custom content installed. All I have is the game and DLC direct from Steam. My computer is way beyond what is needed to run this game. And yet.

Spending $45.00 on a game that just flat out doesn't run well is not my idea of fun times. Belatedly, I realize that the internet is full of folks advising that Sims3 just runs terribly, on pretty much all systems. Winning!


***Also be aware that I did not encounter any issues with running the game until several hours into gameplay, and it slowly... slogged.... down. At this point, it is apparently too late for a refund. Just... don't bother.
For some reason all my characters turn evil and owning sweatshops with prisoners writing books or painting to sell in order for the family to pay the bills.

This is by far the best SIms game ever created.  Sure, it's old - but it's fun ... and fun... and fun.  There's nothing more entertaining than watching your little minions scuttle about the land, doing your bidding. It's a little fantasy world, where you can make your own avatar, and live the life you might have had if you were say - a doctor - or a burglar.  Fantasize to your hearts content, and bring your fantasies to life with lifelike puppets in your very own theatre.  Travel to faraway lands - meet and make aliens, and have plants and shrubbery bring you riches and wealth beyond your wildest imaginations.  Design houses - and have them literally float in mid air.  Create a basement and fill it with your most exotic hand-made wines.

And that's just for starters....

The world is your oyster - and this game is your world.

This game is a robust but not (unsurpringly) accurate depiction of real life. But importantly, it's fun, with virtually infinite replayability, and expression of arhitectural creativity especially.

Pros:
-Build mode is AWESOME. You can create any house you want easily! And unlike CAD software, you can see, control, and influence people within them.
-The included towns are extremely content-filled and fresh. I absolutely love the open world concept, it's just AMAZING. Just go explore.
-Customization of the actual Sims seemed kind of silly, but's it's actually pretty deep! Now I know the diallemmas women face while picking what to wear. (Maybe.) 
-Did I mention the thriving open world?
-Social groups and personalities for Sims
-Customization of items! Put any texture almost anywhere!
-The game is really what you make it!

Cons:
-Sometimes interactions feel a bit "fragmented." When there's a party going on it feels like a Sim is just part of a small interaction instead of the whole scene, at least to me.
-Some annoying bugs with Sim interactions, sometimes they will wait forever to do something even though another Sim is right there and available.
-Even with a fairly high-end PC, there is still some performance issues, especially drops in frame rate on occasion and camera lag
-Even with fast SSD drive, loading can take A LONG time. However, not a huge issue, the amount of content in the neighorhoods and item/clothing options is staggering!
-EA is trying to push it's Shop-Mode crap on your pretty hard. Turn it off in settings, but there still is that rather annoying (but not obtrusive) icon in Buy Mode to buy virtual stuff with real money...
-BIGGEST CON: Massive amount of overpriced DLC. Each DLC is worth about $3-$6 on average. They do deliver though, there are some great ones. Need at least a few of the good DLC's (Seasons, University, Generations, Late Night, Pets)  for an excellent experience.

Tip:
-Enhance (or fix) this game with good mods, found on Simtropolis. Skip intro and Sim height mods are awesome.
If you are still buying premade PCs from Walmart, don't complain when the DLCs slow your already slow machine down even more.

After years of convincing myself The Sims 3 is the worst thing to have ever come out for The Sims franchise, I finally succumbed to my curiosity and bought this game.

And I couldn't be more glad that I did and that I've proved myself wrong all this time.

THE SIMS 3 (was and still) IS AH-MAH-ZING! 

Disregarding my absolute hatred towards EA's business practice, The Sims 3 is just sooo much fun to play and the Expansions truly feel like they actually are Expansions that you can always opt in and out any time, unlike their most recent addition to the series (which I also admit to be an addict to).

The base game for The Sims 3 is alright, and you might have seen or heard people saying hundreds or maybe millions of times which Expansions are best and essential for the *MAXIMUM IMMERSION*, but I'm really not favoring one over another since they really all do feel like they expand the base game, as fun as it already is.

The pacing for The Sims 3, in my humblest of opinion, is very much like the original in that the needs bar is rather quick to deplete and I love it.

Anyways, if you're into drowning yourself in a virtual world, I got nothing else to say other than GET. THIS. GAME.

Again, the only downside that stains this game is none other than EA's business practice.

no rebinding keys, no autosave, an ingame microtransaction shop, and overpriced DLC...yet this is still an ok game. 

fug :-DDD

EDIT: On the other hand, there's a decent amount of mods and you can at least work around the ludicrousness of some of the DLC prices and knuckleheadedness of EA so this still gets a rec I guess

The Sims 3 has introduced a touch more realism to the game via updated graphics, for me, the graphics are a little 'too' realistic. The cartoony element of the game is what made me fall in love with its predecessor The Sims 2.

There is extreme creative control with regards to customisation and open-world gameplay.
This is not to say that build-mode is simple, however. Certain aspects are likely to cause irritation.

Gameplay style has ironed out many old flaws from S2, but as usual, there are plenty of new bugs!

Despite The Sims 2 being my continued favourite for the series due to the incorporated storylines, The Sims 3 leaves most to the imagination. If played with all expansion packs it only enhances entertainment.

Overall, I really enjoy this game. I would recommend to any Sims fan.

The Sims 3 is the Sims 4's older, and better cousin. Not only does it have years and years of extra content, it also has better features in the base game. It's fun, even though it's ten years old and the graphics aren't mindblowing, it's well worth the purchase. However, the price is extremely extortionate, considering the age and the fact that EA has abandoned the game, and that these days most people will consider it bug ridden abandonware. If you plan to purcdhase the game, I'd recommend waiting for a steam sale, (I brought my copy for 6.25) as otherwise you are wasting your money. Another thing to mention, is the DLC. I have nothing wrong with the game's DLC, but some of it is just so, so bad. If you plan to purchase DLC, make sure you have made sure its what you want and its worht the money, as it can be hard to uninstall them and have the game keep working. Overall, I'd recommend it, as the positives and fun factor entirely outweighs the negatives, but then again, be warned, you may need some mods to make it run on your PC.

Sims 3 are the best sims IMHO, and I've tried each iteration of the series. Only things holding it back from a 10/10 are the BULLSHIT DLC policy (with the cost of this game + all DLC, you could literally assemble a decent rig, it's 19 DLCs at 20 dollars each, plus another 20 for the base game... you do the math) and the performance. The game's engine is clearly pushed past it's limit and too often you get problems like glitches and "lag" because of this (I know it's not ACTUAL lag, since it's not an online game, but you know what I mean). It's infuriating to play this game almost 9 years after it's release and still struggle to make it run well. 

So, I'm downvoting the game because the whole DLC thing was pushed WAY TOO FAR here... I love The Sims 3, but the cost is simply unbelievable. It shows you how much EA cares about the playerbase. Only get this if it's on sale, as I did, and still... After carefully picking only the DLC I could get the most out of, it set me back some 40 dollars... for a 9 years old game that still doesn't run as it should.

Overall, I'd say the base game is worth the 20$, but make sure to get the expansions when they're on sale, and just avoid stuff packs altogether.

I could be wrong but I think there were a lot more items in the previous Sims games that came with the basic game. I found it rather disappointing for such an old game to be priced that high with so few items. Yes, you can download stuff for free and also download pais stuff in game, but the latter option shows me only about 3 items per kategory and for the first option you should have about every expansion. That's would be over 600 Euros in total :D . You can't filter the free stuff very well, at least I haven't found the possibility to filter only for stuff that is compatible with the basic game. The faces you can create always loo kinda similar, the fact that there are not very many hairstyles to choose from (compared to games like Oblivion) doesn't make it better. The clothing choices are also not great.
Everywhere I get the feeling that you need real money, and a lot of it, to be able to design a decent Sim, house or whatever. My bad impression of EA still got worse with this game.
I won't lie, it's still fun for me after 20 hours, but I would have expected more items and less $_$ .
It's okay I guess.

All about this game I love so much except the devs. Well there several things you guys need to know before buy this "masterpiece". 
Firstly, I enjoy playing this like going to college, doing sh*t, pick a girl and marry her on the same day, etc etc. Until the game crashes on itself, so I must repeat the sh*t I have done, yeah maybe that's my fault you know actually I forgot to save. On the second time, I remembered to save, and the game still crashes on some point. This happen continously until I wrote this review.

Second, back when I played this on my laptop, the game didn't crash, but worse. So for example I have finished my degree, got a promotion on job, a wife, a new house and sh*t happens. My sims stuck on the bush in front of his office and even he can't die although he had reached his last day. That's just one in a million problems this masterpiece could have. Sometimes, you could get a state where you can't load your savings, or the menu on game didn't fully load so you can't play, etc. That much of bugs you can fix it by delete your savings and repeat from the start. You know I have the supported graphics card and this game just too broken.

Third, this game past eight year and the devs can't fix any bugs or think about pricing on DLCs and the game itself. I realize that so many people spend their 20 bucks only for the base game. Maybe you guys could wait until the devs generously fix this game. If you desperately want to try, just don't buy on full price.

The game is extremely enjoyable with all the lives and scenarios that can play out. Comapred to other Sims games it has a lot less in the base game than the Sims 2, however it will more than make up for that with the DLC and creator content available. As for how it compares to the Sims 4, besides a bit dated graphics the Sims 3 is superior in every category compared to what can easily be called a gutted cash grab with little inspiration less.

The main downsides to the Sims 3 that is very noticeable is the loading time, if you have an SSD it isn't that bad, but for anything else prepare to wait a long time to the point you question whether the game froze or not (it didn't just wait). Beside that, the price tag on the DLC and base game is way too high for the year it came out. The DLC is a big cash sink, but do you research and pick what is right for you if you only want a few. As other reviews have pointed out the Sims 3 was effectively abandonned by EA by the time the Sims 4 came out. If you play and notice bugs, glitches, or crashes THERE ARE community online fixes for most everything.

Nice little life simulation. Ran fairly well on my gaming desktop, with odd soft-locks here and there (game would 'lag', as if framerate was dropping, but components like plumbobs over Sims' heads and particles were animating normally). Has a great modding community, notably the nraas collection. Sim AI appears fairly stable if you place objects properly, but I've experienced bugs where a Sim would become unresponsive and cancel out any command given to it. 
Biggest complaint is the sheer price of the base game and its expansions. Twenty dollars is excessive for some of the content they add, and the lack of discounts makes it even worse. In fact, some of them are hardly expansions - they're "stuff packs" and merely add a handful of new objects. What makes it worth the same as an expansion? 

Would not recommend if you are not the type that can cough up tons of cash just to enjoy the game a bit more. Also includes microtransactions (because everyone loves those, don't they?) and will often flaunt the fact that things are out of your reach.

This game suffers from Tori Spelling syndrome, what's that you ask?

It's basically waking up from a night out that you can't remember a god damn thing about. Turning over to find what at first you think is a horses head that someone's left as a warning. But after a little more investigation you find its Tori Spelling. 

Excited that you've finally fucked someone famous you start to imagine how great its going to be to tell your friends. You start to plan how you will tell them, Borrow those 90210 DVDs your sister has kept for years. Invite your friends round and put the DVD on while shouting "if anyone's fucked someone on this show raise your hand"

This is when it hits you, just when you're about to take a selfie with her while she sleeps. It's fucking Tori Spelling, you quietly sneak out of your own house,  hoping like Christ, she'll be gone when you return sometime next week and all the while praying nobody ever finds out that you fucked Tori Spelling. 

This game is Tori Spelling.

Greetings
I've played this game for many hours and I can say it is definitely worth getting,  The wide variety of customization options and available activites for the Sims add almost endless playability.  However, I have only ever played the game with DLC which brings me to a complaint I've seen come up in a lot of reviews: the price of DLC.  Many people complain that the game and DLC are still being sold full price even though they are so old.  Here's the thing, I have the core game and six DLC, while having only payed about $30 to $40 total (a single full price DLC is $20).  This game and it's expansions go on sale relatively requently and when the do they get a MASSIVE discount.  Like the DLC drop to five bucks each, same with the core game.  There are bundles that become an even better deal.  So here's my reccomendation: put the game and any DLC you want on your wishlist so you are notified when they go on sale.  Then get them while the prices are down.  You won't regret it.

I believe there isn't anyone who hasn't played or even seen the game. For at least some "gamers" (lol), but yeah. Would recommend it for those who love simulation games and make-and-design-your-house thingy. You know how Sims work. So why u reading these reviews?

I got 3, Pets, Generations, and Seasons for around 19 total. That's probably what it's worth.

On new hardware you will need to do a bit of work to get it running properly and even then the performance will progressively lag as the in-game world accumulates clutter, needing further modding to get optimal functionality.

On top of that the game is still by default priced stupidly high, likely to put people off of buying it in favour of the similarly priced Sims 4?? I don't know.

The gameplay, as the Sim's careers progress and they go from broke to stinking filthy rich is probably the best the series has produced, although The Sims 4's ability to have Sims multi-task is something I already find a glaring set-back.

The building construction is the series' best, and has had its functionality stripped back considerably for 4. Although if you've tried 4, and then move on to 3, it will look old.

4's isolated lots replacing the open world also results in a much more stable game that is able to handle many more sims in the same space at a time without performance issues.

The Sims 3 is the series' high point, but no one should ever pay the price they're currently charging. Given its overall performance and the constantly increasing content via its many updates, I'd probably recommend 4 at this point unless you can get 3 for cheap. Then again, The Sims 4 is also grossly over-priced, so maybe go and spend the money on an indie game and save EA Maxis their smug satisfaction.

And now I've said that... I'm going to go play some more...

I'm giving this a thumbs down because it's essentially bug-riddled abandonware. I definitely got my money's worth though, and it is fun to play. Just, at some point, everything will start bugging out and you'll discover the EA have basically left the game in a playable but broken state and they are never going to fix it.

Some careers cannot be advanced, some events can't be attended, the option to let your sims age or not randomly toggles and sporadically will stop working until you delete numerous files. The status of the check box is often the opposite of the status of the option, so sims will age while the option to have them age is turned off.

So basically: tread with caution. Probably worth it on sale for a few bucks.At 40 smackeroos, you have to be joking, until it gets patched properly (i.e. never).
Daylight robbery at its finest.

I originally had a glowing review of this game, but that's since changed. I hadn't played the game for long enough for the game to reveal the ugly skin underneath.

60 FPS

This game is generally quite addicitive, and at first there seems so much to do. After playing it for a while, you'll run out of things to do, and all you're doing from there is the same stuff again. 

50 FPS

Thankfully, this game has modding support. So you start downloading mods to give yourself more things to do. Some make the game much more interesting, and soon the game is fun again.

45 FPS

So you're continuing to play, settings yourself challenges, and eventually doing massive tasks like creating massive families with specific goals, and completing one of these tasks that you set for yourself feels fantastic. You really feel like you're able to manage it all, and with the right choices, you can complete any task at hand.

30 FPS

The game feels strange after a while. Something is.... off. You can't quite put your finger on it. Things feel a little more sluggish. You continue to do challenges, as well as just mess around, and doing interesting things like, for example, letting a sim do their life completely autonomously and seeing what they get up to. Sadly, they don't have the free will to leave a lot on their own for anything besides work.

20 FPS

Woah! Lag spike! Woah! Another one! You don't remember the game running like this. Whatever, maybe your computer is getting old. You can always replace it...

15 FPS

10 FPS

5 FPS







I cannot reccommend this game. It obviously wants you to keep playing, but here's the thing. The longer you play this game, the slower and slower it will run. It has horrific cache problems, eventually building up to the point where 2 seconds of in-game time took about 20 in real life! You will probably eventually quit due to how poorly it runs. The developers clearly cobbled this game together, and did not test what happens in the long run. I'd say to go buy The Sims 4 instead, but that game is void of so many features that The Sims 3 introduced. 

In other words, pick your poison. The sims 3 that becomes unplayable eventually, or The Sims 4 with missing most of the fantastic features.

Fuck EA.

My most favorite game The Sims 3 is a life simulation game that has over 11 expansion packs and 9 stuff packs (20 DLC Items). I admire it for the multiple town locations to live from and the vast options that have been brought that The Sims 2 (PS2) could not deliver. The Creation system has expanded massively and revamped their reward system from "Wants and Fears" to "Wishes"!! The option called Story Progression allows sims within the neighborhood to have free will which allows the sims to be uncontrolled. There are multiple ways to Die in the game as well like Age, Starvation, Drowning, Electrocution, Meteor Shower, A Mummy's Curse, Thirst, Watery Grave, Human Statue, Transmutation, Freezing, Ranting, Shark Attack, Running out of Air, and Time Anomaly... lots of ways. There is a mobile phone version and a console version both of which are pretty decent.The skills in the game are much more refined than in the predecessor but with a larger selection to chose from and same goes for careers. There is even a "Create a World Tool" !!! Sure there are fualts as any game has and all games have limit and price to pay. Overall it's still my most favored game that is just about a decade old and is still as good as when It first came out.

Sims 3 is a fantastic simulation game. I've bin playing the sims every since it first came out back in the day and the sims always amazes me. Sims 3 by far is my favorite out of all of them you can do so much in building, customizing, character creation, and many more. You can do anything you want in the game you could create a sim, find a dream job like a chef for example and work your way up to the top becoming the best chef in the city! Or you could become a family man and have a wife or kids and watch your kids grow up, and finally you could just become a crazy evil sim and cause chaos throughout the city either by stealing other sims stuff, inviteing them over traping them in your basement and forceing them to paint, or you could trap them and burn them to death. The things you can do in this game is endless which why it makes it a fantastic game I highly suggest getting Sims 3 if your looking for a good simulation game Sims 3 is worth every penny.

Ok so something that has been on my nerves for a while is how buggy this game is and has always been.

So to start off with some of the bugs (the uni bug where you can lose your save from many many bugs) that have been there from very early on have never been fixed, instead EA just rolls out another expansion filled with stuff (and even more bugs) to distracted you from the old bugs and charge you an arm and a leg for it.

This game Still costs a small fortune with is in my opinion insulting as they are still getting large amounts of money for a game that they won't fix. (and these are small bugs but game braking, I will never play this again level bugs)

Now some of these bugs have been fixed but the fan made patches and EA still has not fixed them. now some of these bugs could have been fixed with some of the old "Cheat" commands however unlike sim 2, the sims 3 has a much smaller amount you can do with out going in and messing with code or getting a mod.

Now don't get me wrong, I have spent and will probably continue to spend way to much time on this game, It is a really fun game. The issues with the game are not with the game but EA.

The fact that every new replace of the sims comes out with out any of the content that WILL reappear as an expansion that cost almost the same as the base game is expectable at this point, We are all well aware that EA only has a small fraction of a care about the games and only really care about is how much money they can squeeze out of use for the same games remade over and over, (at this point I'm wondering if EA even has a development department or just a rehash department).

If you enjoy the creative and somewhat freedom of the sims and have a load of spare cash sure get it, but I would suggest look at getting the sims 1 and 2 as they had a lot more to them, less buggy and more control over the system if there was an issue (plus you could do some funny things with them too)

All in all, I feel that the Sims 3 is a prime example of the failings of EA and their lack of respect to wards the gaming community and their customers as a hole. I love the game but I can not in good consciences recommend this game due to the unending list of bugs that have not and probley never will be fixed by EA.

You know, I'd say I'm a typical gamer. I love most genres, but I'm a big fan of games like Fallout, Civilization, Ark, GTA, you name it. I'm not really the type of person the sims appeals to. 

And yet, I have over 100 hours in the Sims 3, and I'm not going to stop anytime soon.

I think it's because sometimes, you need a game where the chaos isn't ghouls running up to you and screaming at you. Where it isn't someone running you over with a million dollar car in GTA online. No, sometimes, you need to escape life with your own little charming parody of it. And that's what the Sims franchise has always been to me. The Sims 3 is the ultimate Sims game in my eyes, and I love every second of it. I love how expansive it is, how sentimental it can be, and how much fun it is in its imitation of life. It's always been one of my favorite franchises and I'm thankful I have this in my library. 

Check this series out if you haven't yet because you thought it wouldn't appeal to you. It just might.

Been a fan of the Sims franchise since the first game was released ages ago. This is a great development. Lots of career paths to choose from, with branching paths for extra value. The biggest change this game brought was the ability to leave your house and go explore the city, and they nailed it. Skills come with challenges that reward you for practicing, keeping your Sims happy and fulfilling their wishes grants Lifetime Happiness points that you can spend on permanent (and powerful) perks. There are even some activities outside of the normal like collecting space rocks, visiting the ghosts of your loved ones, and opportunities around town for fun and profit. Feature-rich without being overwhelming.

Get it on sale and choose which expansions you want because otherwise they won't be worth it. Some of the DLC/Expansions also cause major lag or crashes (the Into the Future EP is a well known one) and some only add a few sometimes barely even 5 items (the Town Stuff EP for example) to the game so be careful. If you get it I'd suggest heavily modding it to get a bunch of great stuff.

Expansions I'd personally recommend would be: 

The Supernatural EP for potions to boost abilities, turn people into clowns or frogs or even change a human into supernatural beings! Then there's zombies which are super annoying during the full moon but can be a fun "Zombie Apocolypse" scenario creator, witches which can buff/debuff, upgrade objects and even curse people, werewolves which can scare people with roars, hunt down resources and bite people to transform them too, vampires which can hunt and drink blood and can make sims fall in love with them through vampiric mesmorization and new kinds of ghosts each fully controllable and different colors to represent different deaths.

Ambitions adds a bunch of professions and adds more specific verisons of some existing career paths and the ability to become self employed. It also adds Genies, go figure.

World Adventures for martial arts, chinese/french/egyptian decorations and furniture, the ability to make tombs (which are fun to create gauntlets and run unsuspecting trapped sims through MWUHAHAHA!) and some really nice premade lots to take back to the regular maps.

Pets for Horses, cats, dogs, even lizards, bugs, rats, raccoons, birds and even unicorns (there's some really crazy modded animals for this one) and also strangely this one adds the ice cream truck? Weird o.o

It does however get kind of boring after awhile even with mods.

I was lucky enough to snag The Sims 3 on sale, I would not readily recommend paying full price for it. The only limit to what you can do here is your imagination. I wouldn't take it too seriously, but it's a fun boredom buster that's really easy to get sucked into and has a lot to offer. It could be more realistic and can become monotonous, but the expansion packs add a lot more interesting content and although they're pretty expensive for what they are, they are entirely optional and, in my opinion, the base game's good enough on its own as long as you switch it up regularly and set yourself clear goals. After years of playing the sub par Sims ports on PlayStation, I'm really happy to finally be playing it on PC, the way the developers intended and am seeing a drastic improvement. I feel like The Sims is just one of those games that has universal appeal and that, assuming you're going to actually play it enough to get your money's worth out of it, I feel like it's something that everyone should download.

This very game to be honest has to be one of my favorites. Sure, i have a work PC, and most of the time things freeze, take too long for loading, or become blurry, but that all aside, this holds a place in my heart.

I mean sure, my first Sims game was practically like the PC versions, (Unless you count Freeplay, then who am i to judge) But this game combines what 1 and 2 did perfectly. It's a good thing you have an open world to explore this time around, instead of 1 (Heck, if you even call it open-world exploration) or 2. If you need a impending decision of which Sims game to get first, don't get 4. This one is better.

Sure, it may lag your computer some, and DLCs are over-priced, but heck, who can't pass up traveling the world, getting the profession of your dreams, own a perfect pet, experience the supernatural, Live in a bustling club-filled city, be a singer, go to college and have the time of your life, experience all four seasons, Make all ages have perfect family time, Live the island life, and even travel to the future? It all sounds like a dream to me.

Please, if you're looking for the perfect life simulation game, buy the sims 3.

I decided to make Sim based on Jack the Ripper, and even named him Jack Ripper. Wanting to make him a serial killer of women, I was upset to learn that I cannot kill people in this game without mods.  I looked up onlin the best way to kill people, and most of them said to lock people in rooms, burn the house down with people, or to drown them in the pool by taking out the latter.  My first attempt would be to lock a girl in a room.  I put her in a small bathroom, deleted the door along with everything else, and waited.  A few days go by and she starts making weird noises.  I let it go on for 2 weeks before her annoying voice made me let her go.  Killing that way was out of the question now. My second attempt was to lure someone to a pool, and delete the latter.  The girl then climbed out of the pool, and this was another failed attempt.  My third idea was to get a bunch of people into a house and burn it down.  I threw a large house party, bought a fireplace, carpeting and a bunch of plants, lit the fireplace, got my sim to walk out, and deleted the doors.  The people actually started to put the fire out on their own.  I attempted this 3 or 4 times before I gave up.  My 4th and final attempt was when I decided to get a woman in the bathroom, deleted the door, and light the house on fire.  This started to work well, because the room that the fireplace was put in burst into flames.  Unfortunately, the fire wouldn't enter the bathroom, and just ended up burning all of my stuff.  I ended up giving up my evil ways, for I was not able to kill a single person through my attempts as murder.

In the end, Jack Ripper ended up getting married to the girl I tried to burn to death in the bathroom, and they have a nice sweet daughter that dreams of becoming the leader of the free world.  She's adorable as fuck, and I feel like a grandparent.

Decided to create an orphan sister (teenager) with her little brother (kid) who are currently living with an old lady.

- Needed to generate income to live properly, so the sister had a part-time job after school.
- The old lady had to be the maid, chef and as well as the handyman, so the household won't crumble to dust. But somehow, everytime she uses something, it breaks.
- The boy had to make paintings and sell them.
- The school gave homeworks everyday, they had to finish it while having a part-time job and selling paintings so they get good grades.
- Managed to run everything smoothly.
- Sister got a raise a few times.
- The old lady excelled at cooking, cleaning and being the handyman. Fed them well and repaired every broken things. Although it was mostly caused by her.
- The boy improved his painting skills, thus his paintings cost a little more.
- The old lady tried to upgrade the stereo so it won't break anymore. She got electrocuted. She left it alone and decided to upgrade the microwave instead so it would cook food much faster. She got electrocuted again, which she then died, met the grim reaper, made a deal with him and they both vanished. 
- The kids were in school when it happened. Both mourned for 2 days straight  after they heard the news. 
- Sister had to cook and work while do homeworks everyday to keep both of them happy.
- The boy still had to paint.

After sometime living without an adult, with hardwork and dedication...

- The sister became a five-star chef. Married her old co-worker, and has twins from a different father; a girl and a boy, who became a musician and an athlete.
- The boy became a novelist and an artist. Every sunday, he makes more than 10k, and his paintings cost around 1k to 3k. Engaged with his old friend he met from school.
- They all live in a villa house up on the mountain.

How do I feel?

Satisfied as fuck

Skynyrd broadly fit into the hard-driving improvisational blues format pioneered by the Allman Brothers, although the band's welcome bent for brevity keeps most of the tracks tight and to the point. On the other hand, their nine-minute "Freebird" jumps out of the group's debut LP: It offers a tour of blues guitar expertise, conducted by Allen Collins and to riveting effect. In fact, Skynyrd work with three lead guitarists, a density of stringy instrumentation at times recalling Byrds as much as Allmans.

Eclectic (a shared predilection for much Southern rock), Skynyrd leans on everyone from Rolling Stones ("Tuesday's Gone") and Ry Cooder ("Things Goin' On") to Lovin' Spoonful ("Gimme Three Steps"). Lead singer Ronnie Van Zant mostly sounds like Keith Relf imitating Mick Jagger. Al Kooper's unobtrusively dapper production emphasizes the English connection with ever an eye to poppy parts, a mellotron here, electric 12-string there. But the blunter blues tracks form the album's meat with cuts like "Simple Man" revealing a no-nonsense powerhouse rock unit of modest proportions but considerable promise.

When Lynyrd Skynyrd harks back to Allmans and Wet Willies, Mose Jones suggest John Fred or the Box Tops, appealing to the Top 40 heritage of white Southern rock. Jones (previously called Stonehenge) forfeit Skynyrd's energy, relying instead on Uncle Al's dandy studio sweetenings  if one can ignore for the moment an atrocious Kooper gospel goof, "Get Right (With God)," which unfortunately opens, closes and gives Jones' album a title.

The band's style ranges between spruced-up acid rock ("Here We Go Again"  a Moody Blues rerun), loping New York Rascals soul ("Kiwi Stumble Boogie") and Motown  modified Allmans ("What Kind of Woman Would Do That"  one of the record's better cuts, conceptually and musically). While vocalist Randy Lewis strongly recalls the Guess Who's Burton Cummings, the band, with Kooper at the controls, proves adroit in all fashion of disguises.

Kooper handles Jones as well as Skynyrd, but ultimately it is the latter's intensity that impresses most. Both bands could profit from a more concentrated and single-minded approach, even where proficiency partially forgives virtual parody. But for Skynyrd at least, magnolia muscle carries the day: a significant victory for Kooper's Southern Strategy.

Even when my sister bought Sims 4, I didn't like the graphics so I stuck with Sims 3. During last year's steam summer sale I bought a large number of the DLCs, avoiding the lower rated and purely furniture based ones, and I've loved what each of them has added to the game. The only thing I have to say about this really is that, with such a large Sims fanbase, I find it hard to believe that all the DLCs have to be priced so high, hence why I bought them only in the sales. I feel that they probably have so many people buying the DLCs that the sheer quantity of sales could probably equate to less money needing to be asked per DLC, but as I have no SIms development knowledge, I guess there is only so much I can say on the matter.
My mum has been playing Sims games as far back as I can remember, with my sister and I watching her, so I think for me SIms will always be a nostalgic game, and I think Sims 3 is one of the best Sims games that I've played overall. I also love how you can make money in this game fairly easily without the need for a 9-5 job that you have to prepare your sims every day for; I feel like that monotony can be easily left to real life, and you can do the dream job(s) that you want in the game.

i will start off by saying i love this game, and i've put an unhealthy amount of hours into it. however, every game has its quirks. this game has lots of good to it, but also lots of bad.

[b] some of the good: [/b]

-sims 3 has by far the most customisation. you can personalise almost everything in this game, from clothes, to hair, to pets, to even the hardwood floor patterns in your home. 

-the custom content community is outstanding. you can get just about anything for your sims, and for free.

-most of the expansion packs add lots of fun new things for your sims to do, but some of them are pretty silly. i spent over 1,200 simpoints on a washing machine/dryer pair for my house, and months later i installed Town Life, which implemented laundry things that i could buy with simoleons. which i'd known that sooner.

-there are entire cities with lots of things to do, and there are different ways of transportation to get there. you can buy a car, use a taxi, or just buy a bike. you can also get a magical flying vacuum, if you're into that.

-you can play this game however you want. realistically, or fictionally. this game has no boundaries.

[b] some of the bad: [/b]

-this game runs like total crap. i will fully admit that. even the base game by itself can be slow, and lag like hell, but when you start installing expansions, you'll see the performance tank. mine will get hung up and freeze for a few minutes. you can download mods like NRAAS overwatch, which help a little, but not too much.

-the longer you play this game, you'll start to notice textures disappearing, sims not rendering, and things glitching out. you might hear your computer's fan kick up a few notches, too. my custom built gaming PC is no match for sims 3.

-unfortunately, this game is very easy to break. i've broken mine just by planning my sim's outfit twice within 3 minutes. it just stopped loading create-a-household. 

-there's no autosave, of course, so if you're going to play this game for long periods of time, you need to save it manually every once in a while, because once it freezes and crashes (which is pretty damn likely), you'll lose all of that hard work.

-the further your sims progress, the longer your loading time will be. my very first save file takes about 45 minutes to load, and i'm running the game off an SSD. 


i will always recommend sims 3 as a great game to start with for new simmers, but people also need to be aware of the bad things about this game, especially the performance issues. it can be very discouraging.

First of all, the full price for a game and DLC of this age is shocking, especially considering that Sims 4 has been out for a fairly long time as well. I definitely wouldn't have bought any of it if it wasn't for sales.

I'm mostly a fan of building stuff and don't play the way most Sims fans seem to play (make families, advance in careers, having babies and all that). I mainly enjoy building on the city map, which Sims 4 does not offer. The ability to recolor really everything is priceless and another feature Sims 4 doesn't have. So for builders, Sims 3 is clearly the way to go. The base game already has a good selection of materials and the various DLCs and mods let you build pretty much anything you can come up with.

But the performance. Jesus Christ, the performance. I have every mod under the sun to make the game run better, I read every forum and guide. And the conclusion is: your PC doesn't matter. Either the game likes you and you can run it on a potato laptop older than the game itself, or the game doesn't like you and would crash, freeze or eternally load even if you put it on a NASA computer. I'm in the latter category. Just starting a new game can take up 20 minutes, depending on the city. Once it runs, it is all consuming and even alt tabbing will crash it. I can only play it in offline mode, too, otherwise the game freezes if any minor thing happens in the background. It runs somewhat smoother in windowed mode, but won't let me navigate the city map - which is kind of important for me.

Since it all depends on luck and if the Sims stars align for whatever system you try to run it on, I don't know if I should I recommend it. It sure is a lot fun for a city building fan to design individual buildings, but it is also frustrating to have your entire progress erased due to some mysterious file corruption from just trying to load it.

If you like to gamble or are dead certain luck is on your side, knock yourself out during a sale, I guess.

( Just to start this review off I would like to say that though my time playing the Sims 3 on Steam has been short, I've played almost 500 hours on my old Origin account, so I'm not someoe who just randomly decided to write a review of this game on a whim after only playing it for a little while.  ) 

(IMPORTANT PURCHASING ADVICE, skip if you just want a review of the game)    v   v   v

If you're thinking about getting the Sims 3, and you're looking at it on Steam, you've made the right decision to use Steam as a means of doing so. EA, and Ea's Origin aren't exactly the most loved things out there. Don't get me wrong, I loved the Sims 3 and 4 while I was able to play them on Origin, but due to an inncident with the company I am definitely no longer using their services. In short, what happened to me was that my account was hacked and all of my games were completely removed. I switched credit cards a number of times after having bought the Sims, and since I needed certain credit card information from the company which I used to purchase my games with, I would have to run through 3-4 different companies for credit cards whom I no longer used just to try and get my games back. This effort was fruitless and I ended up losing what was probably 100 or more bucks in expansions and other games etc. After trying endlessly to use EA's forums and live-help it was clear to me that they weren't goinng to do anything to help me. I was sad because I really had enjoyed playing the Sims family of games for a long time. Once I found it on Steam, I was ecstatic. So, due to EA's rep as a company, I definitely recommend purchasing this game through Steam.


( Review of the Sims 3 )

Alright, I don't even know where to begin with this game. As you likely know, the Sims family of games is a life-simulation game. Simple. However, simple is definitely not a word one would use to describe the Sims 3, the ammount of customization options is absolutely incredible, especially when you take into consideration the ammount of content that is at your fingertips with custom content and expansions that make this game, in my opinion, the best, most personal game in the world. The Sims 4 definitely improves upon a lot within building homes and creating sims, but this comes with a hefty cost. Say you find this amazing shirt for a sim, and you'd like it in a dark pink color, to match the color scheme you've picked out for your sims athletic wear. In the Sims 4 they've ripped out this function completely, meaning in this case you get to choose between only 3-5 options for color combinations. If you had this dilemma in the Sims 3, you could choose the EXACT color you were looking for easily! I can't stress enough the word EXACT!! Literally you can go to a color wheel, mix colors or find a number online for the exact color you want and paste it in. Don't like the texture? Import your own, or apply one of the many textures already available to you within the game! It's incredible the ammount of sheer personalization available to you in the Sims 3. In my opinion, the Sims 3 is a preferable alternative to the Sims 4, only because it's actually open-world and offers tons of customization options that are stripped in the Sims 4. 

I reccomend grabbig a few expansions while they're on sale, the two i reccomend as essentials are seasons and generations, and probably late night, since they add really important features to your game. The rest can be added depending on what you like. For example, if you really want to raise a horse, or a cat or dog or something, pick up the pets expansion. If you want to be a mermaid and run a paradise resort, pick up Island Paradise. It is important to know that the Sims 3's controls may be hard to learn at first, but once they're feeling smooth, you'll be amazed at how much fun you can have, and at how many hours you can sink into this game. I think that a lot of games are often found appealing by how much they allow the player to sort of 'begin anew' and 'start a new life', which is literally the whole entire purpose of the Sims. If you're interested, be sure to note that if you don't like the game, you will probably have played over the time you are allowed to for the return period so possibly ask a friend who has it if you could try it before purchasing if you're still on the fence.

So let me get started here by saying a few things.  First, Ive always been a long-time fan of The Sims but I had to learn early that not every expansion is worth the money.  With the first Sims I, quite literally, owned everything you could possibly own.  Sims 2, I became a little more selective after I purchased one or two Stuff packs and realized they werent really that impressive.  Now that Sims 3 is here Im avoiding the Stuff packs all together.  

When Sims 3 first came out I purchased it immediately (physical copy).  Quite frankly, the core game let me down.  Coming from such an amazing experience with The Sims 2, the third in the series felt like a step backwards.  You didnt get to experience owning a shop, or a club, and you sure didnt have any sense that your character existed outside what you did at your home.  If youve played an earlier Sims game then Im pretty sure the core Sims 3 experience will let you down too.  With the Steam Summer Sale I felt the time was right to give my beloved Sims series another chance.  I wasnt disappointed. 

If you were like me, and were on the fence about buying The Sims 3 because you look at the DLC and just go WTF? then let me help you out here.  Right away ignore any Stuff packs because, like always, you can find better items on mod websites that will cost you NOTHING.  As for the expansions, there are some that are good and some you should avoid.  During my purchase I did some extensive research to find out exactly what would add to The Sims 3 experience, and what was a waste of money.  What I came up with was the following;

University Life opens up a large new campus town with an entirely new way to gain work experience prior to entering the workforce.  It opens up relationships for your teens, social groups, social networking, and an entire platform of awesome.  This is most definitely a MUST for your Sims3 experience.

Supernatural gives you the ability to get away from the mundaneness that is human.  It opens up zombie attacks, werewolves, witches, fairies, and all kinds of cool supernatural skills and abilities.  This is a must for anyone wishing to take their Sims experience beyond a real-world simulation.

Seasons brings in just that, the ability for your Sims to exist in a season other than summer.  Youll see the trees turn color, snow start to fly, and with that your Sim will be able to perform tasks and run into issues due to those seasonal changes.  I found the Fall particularly challenging, as there was a lot more rain (which increased illnesses) and the ground was covered with leaves that brought more cleaning tasks than you would normally have to deal with.

The Pets expansion is another must-have, for the simple reason that if you want to experience a simulated life you have to have all the options that life gives you.  Theres nothing more boring than playing The Sims without the ability for your household to have a pet to care for.  Along with that comes more interactions with not only your own family members, but random animals as well.

Generations, put simply, brings actual Life to The Sims 3.  Like normal life, each stage brings about a new desire.  Children, for example, excel at imagination and make-believe while their Grandparents get more out of life by watching their grand children and reminiscing about life.  In addition the Generations expansion adds to the University expansion and opens up several more career branches for your Sims to enjoy and experience.

I was on the fence when I looked over Ambitions, I really was.  From the description it seemed like all that was added were new career options.  That said, I didnt realize how important those options were.  Not only did it open careers like being a Firefighter or Investigator, the careers were more playable than other careers.  Instead of going to a workplace and simply vanishing into the building while you worked, you actually played-out some of these locations.  For example, as a private eye you had to use your home computer to seek out cases, then go and solve them.  As a firefighter you go to the fire hall and do all the things firefighters do while waiting for a call.  It also brings in more eco-friendly traits and a few self-employment options that I have yet to explore.  I was glad I got this expansion.

The Late Night expansion was another one that I was kinda on the fence about.  While I was fairly intrigued that it added Vampires and Celebrities to the mix, I wasnt really sure if I would make full use of the clubbing scene.  That said, with the addition of celebrities came the ability to become one, with all the upsides (fame/fortune) and downsides (scandals/paparazzi) that comes with it.  Or, you could simply skip all that and become a member of the film industry in other ways.   Did I mention it also adds a completely new city area and a bunch of new party items?  You could easily skip this expansion but I felt it added that one missing aspect that I enjoyed in the expanded Sims 2 game.

So, you might now be asking yourself, with so much DLC required to make this game actually good why am I recommending it?  Put simply, because after the mentioned DLC is added, the game IS really good.  I, honestly, wouldnt buy The Sims 3 as a stand-alone product, or with the DLC at full price.

That said, if you can manage to buy the base game, with my suggested expansions, on sale then by all means GO FOR IT!

The game is known for being one of the most popular and fun Simulation games on the market for emulating real life. This was my first sims game, and I can say that I am sold completely. The Add-Ons make the base game even more fun. Whether you're trying to have a Sim of you and your crush getting married and having kids, or you secretly try to kill a real life enemy in a sims game, or you just want random sims to control and emulate another life, this game is here for you. It does it in a fun way, where the interface is nice (but a little annoying and janky). Great game to start out with if you want to try the Sims.

I have been playing the Sims series since Sims 2. I've had a trial on Sims 4, but felt that Sims 3 had more to offer (and I aready owned a decent amount of packs). I love looking at CC/player-made content, because some people have great graphic designing skills and can make beautiful additons to the game. I've downloaded new hair, clothes, lots, and items. You can even find items to accentuate a character to really evolve their narrative. I love Sims because of the imagination in creating characters and what their lives are like, their relationships, their jobs. Expansions are great for interactive items, but CC is free and can really add to the game with non-interactive items. If you learn the game well enough, you can do a lot with the Sims for exciting, different experiences.

My personal experience is this game is a withering cash cow. They will pump you for money and not give a damn about your enjoyment or overall experience. i attempted to contact them directly regarding the issue and heard nothing. That was over a year ago. Maybe you'll have a better experience than me but just be aware of the company ethos and the risk you take.

My fiance has asked me if I have locked anyone in the basement yet, so I sleep with one eye open now.  
(I'm pretty sure he's the inner psychopath this game unearths.) 

In all seriousness, it's a classic. They've added a lot since the last time I have played The Sims years ago. I find that the expansion packs are just too much for the base game. If the expansion packs didn't cost as much as the base game, it'd be neat to play more of the expansion packs. 

The Exchange is great for EASY creator installation of items, sims, lots. etc., but it's hard to get certain stuff when you only have certain expansion packs. Even with advanced search, for just the base game or certain expansion packs only, you'll still get an item that will fail to install as it will need a certain expansion pack that wasn't listed when you use the filter. 

I still love the game, in general, so I wouldn't steer anyone away from it.

Bought this on a whim because it was massively reduced a couple of months ago and I loved Sims 2 so thought this would be an improvement. While Sims 3 is good, and I would recommend it, it is no way near as good as Sims 2. In my opinion, the Sims tabs (where the info about your sim is and their wants/needs) are just too small and there's no way to make it bigger. Creating houses and decorating them is also not as easy as it used to be in Sims 2 and the standard furniture you get is pretty dull (although you can customise everything which you couldn't do on SIms 2).

If you like the Sims franchise, you'll probably also like this but for me it's when I compare it to Sims 2 it's just doesn't stand up to it at all.

7/10 would recommend though.

I've played this game for a long time, before I even had Steam. I have a lot of fun with this game and can spend hours upon hours on it. The biggest problem, though, is the sheer amounts of bugs and lag. No matter how much my specs were improved this game was still lagging. Some things that have helped are nraas mods, and some routing fixes available for towns on modthesims. My game was still lagging though, and then I figured out that it was the amount of Sims in my household. Somehow, the amount of Sims affects my performance more than the size of the lot or settings. So if you have had lag spikes, that may be one of the reasons.
