I've played over 250 hours of this game and have every non-furniture dlc except for World Adventures. While the dlc's are expensive, yes..I recommend buying this game anyway. I shall now list off my favourite dlcs to give you ideas if you do not want to buy alot of dlcs.

-Late night (Bars, celeberties, apartments, new jobs and skills..pretty cool.)
-Generations (Tbh it's mostly centered around children. So if you like sim kids, get this.)
-Supernatural (Spooky creatures, a new town, jobs, skills, traits..)
-Into The Future (40 dollars, so get it on sale. You can make robots, change the future, skills and jobs..)

My least favourites:
-Pets (20 dollars for pets? Tbh not really worth it. But you can use horses for racing to gain money.)
-University (Not really worth it tbh. You can just pay your way through it to get a degree.)
-Seasons (Just adds in what it says. The events are kinda boring.)

Note: I got The Sims 3 while it was on sale for 5 dollars, it is normally $20 (Extremely overpriced for an 8 year old game that barely works!)

The Sims 3 is a game that may appear cool at first glance, but is actually very badly made and you can tell that EA just put together a sequel (You could call it a prequel) to The Sims 2 just to make a quick few hundred million dollars. The game appears to have better graphics, until you look at the sims themselves, and see that they look like round faced dolls and that the charm of The Sims 2 art style is gone! The music is really great though! Unless you have a really expensive computer, you probably won't be able to have a smooth time playing this game. It comes with a beautiful open world, but it slows down the game too much. The game is very stereotypical when it comes to sims, and most good gameplay features from the previous game are trimmed down or removed, such as aspirations, fears, or interests. But you can do some pretty interesting stuff. Read on to find out more:

Score: 3.5/10- the only reason it isn't zero is because of the immersive world and this stuff:

Pros-
Cool/weird things you can do in The Sims 3-
Fall in love with 10 people at the same time
Burn to death while cooking pancakes
Be really rich
Kidnap neighbors
Kill people that you don't like
Crush kids with meteors
Crush their parents with meteors
Crush their parents friends with meteors
Crush the whole town with meteors
Be an evil witch/warlock that sets people on fire
Woohoo with 3 people in photo boothes on one date
Get married 5 hours after meeting someone
Collect space rocks
Stay out past curfew (Almost impossible due to stupid telepathic police!)
Be a magician
Go tomb exploring
Build torture houses
Set your house on fire
Be friends with Death
Revive people
Own a business
Have kids with 10 different people
Have a family that has been around for 10 generations (Legacy)
Freeze your sims to death
Go to university just to get killed in a fire that your pyromaniac roommate started
Create an obese guy with green skin
Find a genie lamp
Get crushed by a bed
Have a bake sale with your kid
Buy from a kids bake sale
Steal from a kids bake sale
Drop a meteor on a kids bake sale while the kid is standing there
Befriend aliens
Woohoo 10 times in a row
Kill old people to free up space in a household
Use cheats to make a baby age up and die of old age within 2 minutes
Play a sim from birth to death
Marry your imaginary friend
Smash a dollhouse
Egg houses
Marry a rich person, them drown them
Marry a premade woman, and kill their premade childhood best friend that was supposed to marry them 
Become a celebrity
Make a crazy cat/dog person
Be a kleptomaniac (Steal stuff)
Harvest (Steal) plants from a neighbors garden and they don't care
Take toys from your neighbors child's toybox and they don't care
Be best friends with everyone in town
Be hated by everyone in town
Save sim lives as a life guard or firefighter
Kill sims and build a huge cemetery in your yard with their graves
Don't pay bills, have tv repossesed by repoman, invite repoman over, trap him in a room and starve him as revenge for taking your tv
Have your sim devote their life to writng books and never do anything else except occasionaly socializing, using the toilet, eating a small meal, and napping
Get a nutcracker guy worth 1000 dollars while trick or treating 
Invite neighbors to a pool party and drown them all
Meet a spring unicorn, befriend them, adopt them, and have them set your enemies on fire with their powers
Be struck by lightning 

Gameplay pros-

Immersive gameplay
You can play generations
Creativity to design house and sims
Fun events 
Lots of creatures to play as (Requires expansion)
Beautiful, open world (Slows down game so you cannot enjoy it)

Cons-

Game is extremly slow on any computer that is not over 2000 dollars
It crashes constantly
It limits cooking by time of day (Cannot make waffles for lunch)
No aspirations or fears (Replaced by unrealistic wish system with only wants)
No actual stores (Your sim disappears when they go inside)
Premade sims suck (Example: Bella Goth is an 1st grade idiot with oversized eyes, no cool alien story/womanizer story/dead husband story like in sims 2, premade sims are obviously geared towards small girls)
Children are extremely limited (Cannot play piano or garden), but they can somehow MIX POTIONS and INVENT THINGS
Curfew is insane (Police cars come out of nowhere and arrest your teen sim who is far from the road!)

No Rodney's Death Creator :(

Dumb mourning system (Sad for stranger in the same household that you hate, not sad for best friend neighbor)
Pointless forceful punishment system for kids and teens 
Limits you to 8 sims per household (Unlike The Sims 2, there are no cheats to bypass this)
No rotational play 
Cannot drown sims by removing ladder (Sort of good)
Deaths are stupid and badly animated- Person fades into ash after burning (Obviously fake), same with vampire thirst death, and people disappear into the water after drowning
Lots of pointless "traits" (LUCKY!!!?? UNLUCKY!!!?? How are those even traits!?)
Very stereotypical (Traits largely resemble stereotypes of flirty people, nerds, evil people, good people, insane people, etc) and ages can be very stereotypical (Look at the elders or toddlers/children)
Sims are ugly plastic dolls- All the sims (Especially kids) have these ugly plastic faces and weird clothes, take Bella Bachelor (TS2 Bella Goth)- A premade sim, for example. She looks like an oversized ugly doll that was made to represent a toddler, not a child. (Look her up online), Extra pro- I can kill her or do a makeover
Cars are terrrible- They are stored in your sims inventory (Yes, you read that right: INVENTORY) and they magically appear on the street when they are needed. And when your sim gets in, they just FADE OUT and REAPPEAR in the car!

I loved this game. But if you want it now, know there's just *so* many problems with getting it to run well at this point. And EA would *much* rather sell you the inferior Sims 4 and get you started on *that* batch of DLC than actually fix Sims 3. Last time I tried to play it, I had constant crashes and weird bugs. I thought I'd boot it up and maybe install mods to get it in working shape, but they're just a huge pain in the ass. Here's a fun bug as a for instance: some of the music tracks are entirely unaffected by the settings for the music volume. Including mute. And there's *no* master volume slider.

I mean, this is the best version of The Sims there is (barring the ridiculous DLC, which has been talked about extensively) and if I could give it a mixed recommendation instead of only yes or no, I'd give it that. But, with how poorly maintained it is and how locked down EA kept it, it can be practically unplayable. So I have to give it a no.

The Sims 3 is a lovely game. If you don't know what it is, then how are you even savvy enough to be reading this. Anyway, The Sims 3 is a game focusing on the individual families and towns in which they live. While there are many hours of fun to be had with  just the base game, I would suggest getting an expansion or two as well. I can't recommend any to anyone I don't know, but I do suggest that before you do, watch LGR's reviews of each of them. This is an all-around good, fun game for anyone who feels that the city manager games are too much stress. It is good for asking, "I wonder if..." questions.

Based off of my currently limited experience with this game, I would love to give a neutral response, but that is sadly not an option.  The Sims 3, on it's own, is a great game.  The customization is acceptable, the graphics look nice but aren't over the top, it runs on my outdated computer, and I enjoy playing the game.

Here's my problem with the game.  There is a large quantity of really good content locked behind a very large quantity of money in the form of DLCs.  While for most games this isn't a big deal, I feel like The Sims 3 DLCs don't provide enough bang for their buck.  I personally cannot afford to be throwing twenty bucks into one game just because I would like to access some new furniture or game mechanics.

If EA games were to take a hint, I would suggest that they make the DLCs free, or at least put a huge discount on them, once The Sims 4 begins to surpass The Sims 3 in revenue.  Most people are going to move on to The Sims 4, so why not make it easier for those people with outdated computers to enjoy the full Sims experience?

I would gladly put at least $100 into this game, but the combined prices of the DLCs and the game far exceed this limit.  It is still a great game that deserves plenty of playtime, but if you're on a budget, prepare to be dissapointed by the massive quantity of good stuff you just simply can't afford.

You may complain about the price now but have you even seen the prices for the sims 4 and it's expansion packs? Nowadays, each and every game pack and expansion pack costs 20 to 40 dollars, and the packs only offer something that is far more exclusive than the games before it. Making them well, more expansive.

I grew up with the sims, and my naive child mind, despite dodging every single innuendo the game threw at me, always had a soft spot for this franchise and its a shame that EA threw it into this rut, milking it for what it's worth. By now, the total for all the Sims 4 packs combined is probably way more than what this game provides. And even bundles for sims 4 game packs don't do it's justice, providing about a 29 dollar savings for what already totals to be more than 70 dollars if bought separately. And since more game and expansion packs were just released/will be released in the near future, there is no possible way those prices are ever going to go down.

But back to the older games, In my own opinion, 2 and 3 were the golden age of the Sims, and I barely remember anything from the OG (since I haven't played it since I was like, I dunno 7 years) so it's hard to comment on it. But all the older games seem to have a lot more to it, especially in their base form and with no mods attached. If I were to do more extensive research on it, I totally would! But unfortunately I along with my family have been in a bit of a rut financially so I really cant invest in such a thing. But I digress.

My point is, Sims 3 was possibly the last good game from the franchise, sure the sims 4 looks nice and pretty, but my hunk of junk called a computer cant even run that high of a quality. But it is super dumbed-down with what you can do with the game without expansions and the always online DRM is a total turn off. But in the Sims 3, being online is optional, and the game is still fully functional offline.

And say what you want about the prices, once the Sims 4 era ends all the expansion packs for that game will make the other ones seem like a steal more than anything.

Despite being an older game, I have sunk many hours into this game. The fact that there is so much to do in the base game and modding is an option, the possibilities are endless. The Sims 3 is notorious for its overpriced DLC. However, this issue no longer scared me off once I found this Steam release. Now, the game consistently goes on sale for 75% off, including all the expansions. That means that all the expansions are only about sixty dollars. Considering how much content each expansion offers, I'd say it's worth the price of admission.

The Sims 3 honestly has extremely fun gameplay thanks to the deep mechanics held inside. There's plenty to do, and as long as you don't cheat, it's also quite rewarding.

The biggest star here are the mods. New neighborhoods, items, clothes, vehicles, gameplay, etc. Even with just the base game, this game can still be very engaging with the assistance of mods.

In conclusion, now that the expansions can be purchased way cheaper than before, it's easy for me to recommend this game to anyway. It's still the best Sims game to this day (although I think Sims 2 is a close second).

Like masturbating: You get a sudden urge to play it, do so for a good 10 hours (okay maybe not a perfect 'simile'..... hehheh 'sim'ile) and realise what else you could have done with your life in that time. Its a huge timesink where you recreate an idealistic life while neglecting your own.

This would be a kind of half-hearted joke review as the game does have a very catharthic sense of fun all in all, but the excessive dlc definitely doesn't help endear the game, I have ambitions, Late Night and generations Expansions and the game feels heavily incomplete without them, the other ones are relatively passable but the 3 aforementioned EPs (alongside seasons) do feel neccessary.

 Given the fact I hear Sims 4 is even worse in this regard, I'm quite glad I skipped it, in fact, I always feel *heavily* reluctant to make any purchase for this game, I would say with the packs it is actually alot of fun, and very modular (unlike sims 4 at the moment).

 But irregardless, this game cannot get an honest review and still be positive, with such massive reservations i have about this addition to the series, especially since Origins blatantly negelects the steam version which can be easily broken, I did get my moneys worth out of it undeniably, but its almost a requisite more than entertainment at times, given the excessive cost.

If your a sim fan, you likely know alot fo these pitfalls and tricks, so heres what I found to be really good addons:
City Hub instead of neighbourhoods makes your sim feel in an expansive world
Ability to customize and paint outfits, furniture etc. is welcome
With the mentioned EPs, you get interactive careers added and alot of new minigames and life goals for stuff like building robots, a true City as opposed to suburbs, Nightclubs and hotspots to meet VIPs and get famous etc. 
Finally Generations heavily revamps all ages of your life and specific moments like weddings, Check the wiki for more details.

If your not a sims fan but are very interested in being one, I would pick up the base game first if you can get it for roughly 10 dollars max, but this is effectively a trial version, I have been steadily adding EPs year by year and the games cost has started to bloat, but indeed the game feels tellingly more complete, but at a cheap price, you can carefully evaluate it for yourself.

This game's really what you make of it. I set out to make a haunted mansion so, of course, I needed some ghosts. I took a family of 8, piled them into a room full of fireplaces, rugs, stoves, and swimming pools and set about the task of slowly killing them all. 

After all the screaming stopped I had one survivor, the mother of the family. She had somehow avoided burning to death with her husband, siblings, and children and wasn't in the mood to swim so I kept her alive with all she had seen. With a little building prowess I made her a dungeon below the house so this, now rather beastly woman could forever remain with her family as their ghosts terrorized the new family. I was certain hilarity was about to ensue. 

I had hoped that the dead would bring forth unholy vengeance onto the world and rampage through the house, driving the new owners to their graves as well. What I got was...Well, rather than do anything terrifying, the ghosts just came and went as they pleased. They'd sit in a comfy armchair reading books and watching the couple sleep. They'd take baths and go to the toilet. One time a ghost made a chair levitate but that was about the extent of their haunting. To top it all off, the mother didn't really seem to mind after a while. She wasn't traumatized at all. 

What I'm saying is, murdering an entire family and leaving the mother as the sole survivor for entertainment purposes really isn't worth the effort. So I left that family of ghosts and made a new family only to have more fun ruining their lives in more conventional ways, like social ineptitude and poor financial management. 

All in all, it was a pretty good game.

HOW TO SHOOT UP A SCHOOL

-Make a family of profoundly handicapped people, each one with their own disability
-Buy the shittiest house possible
-No toilets, beds or doors, only suffering
-Have the most unlucky and clumsy one try to cook
-Burns the house down
-Collect insurance money

10/10 would burn down a house with no doors or windows filled with disabled people again

Ok so if you're going into this only having played the Sims 2 and the Sims 1 you may be very suprised. This game takes a whole new turn some may say for the better and others may say for the worse. I've played the majority of my life in video games on the Sims 2 and the Sims 1. These games absolutely no object other than to see what will happen, I've always found this really appealing about these games. Recently, my manapause has kicked in and has seen me created large dynasties of families and going back and looking through the families I had created. I huge pet peeve of mine with the Sims games is the need to purchase extra content in order to fulfil a full experience, while there's companies like Rockstar and Bethesda who release almost montly free Download Content, that adds more than some of these weak ass expansion packs do. I will say I am happy that you no longer need to download the expansions in chronological order meaning you can purchase whatever expansion packs tickle your fancy. Another thing that pisses me off and has no place in video games is stuff packs, what's the point. Paying twenty dollars for new skins of furniture, what a waste of money. I will say I did purchase three expansion packs and they were very much so worth it. These packs made me very happy as they added content to every aspect of the game. That being said not all content packs are worth the twenty dollar price tag. Luckily, you can find them on sale many times. The formula for the Sims series is still there, all Sims have needs and aspirations that need to fulfilled in order to keep your sims happy and their lives moving forward. One huge aspect of the Sims 3 that a love is the lack of loading screens and the ability of an open-world game. This is definetly worth the purchase itself. And I'm glad it's on Steam unlike any of the other Sims. Some of those other money hungry aspects really make the game worth less than it would be but it's still deserving of a purchase. 

Final verdict; 7.5/10 a game that is incredible, but money hungry EA bastards fucked it up.

Okay, I don't think the game is bad. It can be fun to screw around with fake people without too many consequences or whatever. But, it's best to buy it with some expansion packs because the base game can get boring on it's own. The problem with that is, the expansion packs are pretty expensive. Nearly all of them are the same price as the base game, without a bundle or deal. Considering most of the expansions don't double the content of the base game, that's kinda a rip-off. That being said, some of them are pretty fun to have, such as the Seasons, Pets, and Supernatural that can add new types of sims and make interacting with other sims more entertaining. But some of the expansions, like the ones that just add furniture or clothing, which still cost the same as the base game, are completely not worth it. Not to mention there is what is called "SimPoints", which is a type of currency you purchase with actual money, that you can use to buy certain in-game items or different maps. The price for SimPoints is also pretty inflated. It kind of feels like EA is trying to constantly tempt you into spending money with this game

I just finished making my first family...

In The Sims 3, you basically create families (or play pre-made families) and live their lives as you would your own. The Sims franchise has improved throughout the years and I'm pretty satisfied with this version. 

If you have never played before, you can do almost everything you would in real life. Own a house, go to work, go to stores, go to friends houses, host parties, learn to cook, play chess, watch TV, and have relationships. 

It's a really fun game. The Create-A-Sim is also fantastic because you can customize basically every part of your Sim, including your build, clothes, and personality. It also has a memory book where it saves important parts of your Sim's life, such as you got a promotion or had a baby. It's also customizable. There are websites you can go to where you can download extra clothes and items. 

There are a few cons, though. The Sims 3 is integrated with EA's wannabe Facebook, so it prompts you to login in a lot. It also has a few glitches and problems, but what else do you expect with an EA game? I recommend backing up your Sims and houses in case of a problem in the future. 

Even with the cons, this is a game you will most likely enjoy and spend a lot of time playing.

The game is amazingly fun to play, and there's such a wide variety of ways to do so - especially with the Expansion Packs.

Pros:
- Fun
- Can easily get invested for hours at a time
- Very customisable
- Expansions can really enhance the experience

Very Minor Cons:
- Can sometimes take a few minutes to load a save, but it's really nothing bad
- Expansions are quite expensive

Honestly, Sims 3 is one of the best sims games.

I have gotten addicted to this, raising a virtual family and seeing how their life plays out in front of me. Sims is one of the best, if not the greatest life simulator game ever. The good thing is if you want extra things added into the game, it is one of the easiest things to do. One downside I have had is when downloading an expansion pack at the same time as the game it seems to take a little longer yet suprisingly fast for a game this large. The game has many possibilities. I myself only have the pets expansion but I feel I got my moneys worth out of the game. At first glance it is expensive (I got it on sale a year ago for Chinese New year.) but once you play you realize just how much it adds into the game. Overall, this game is amazing and was definetly worth the money, and I am looking forward to getting other expansion packs.

I hope this review helped, and have a great day or night.

That aside, the game is enjoyable if you're looking for a role-playing game in which you immerse yourself into the character and what they do day to day. I myself am one who searches for the most enjoyable RPG games, and ones which can offer many things. So, I personally recommend if you're looking for a "Live your Life RPG" get this game with the following DLC:
- Seasons -> Creates worlds with 4 Seasons [ More RP Events, Things to do..] + OBJECTS
- Pets -> Duh. Pets. [Dogs, Cats, Horses, Birds, Rats, Hamsters, Fish, etc.] + OBJECTS
- Generations -> In depth family options + OBJECTS 
- Late Night -> Celebrity Status + Bars + OBJECTS
- Ambitions -> Further Career options + OBJECTS
- Town Life Stuff -> To do stuff around Town + OBJECTS

All of these DLCs together will create a very in-depth gameplay experience of your Sim(s) life(s).

All in all , Great Game.

I am a person who have played the sims way waaaaaaay back in the old days. I've played sims, sims1, sims 2(pets,cast away, etc), i have also played the sims in mobile as well as the one in facebook, as well as the sims 4.

Honestly, i've played so much sims in my life. But sims 3 is second to the best for me, cuz sims 2 is still my number one favorite. 

This is my real review.

Sims 3 is a really good game for me despite the lag and crashes it gives me when i get DLC's. The sims 3 opened a whole new kind of experience with so many choices of DLC to choose from. 

and that's the thing with Sims 3, they have DLC unlike older versions of sims. I'm not sure if i would treat that as a good thing or what, because in my opinion, sure the DLC we buy gives more features and more things to do but it's not enough for the price we have to pay.

This is why i prefer sims 2. When i bought my Sims 3 Pets, i expected so much, and this only cost me disappointments. I was expecting to get a PET PARK/PET SHOPS/PET ETC. but all i got are pet furniture, and well...pets with the addition of horses you can ride. The addition of horses is okay for me, but i didn't bought Sims 3 HORSE SIMULATOR, i bought pets, so why is it that only horses get a special building. 

Cuz in sims 2 pets, you are literally experiencing everything about having a pet. Dogs can use trees as toilets, pets have their own park, pets have pet salons, pets have everything. 

That's what i feel lacking in sims 3. Their DLC's for me doesn't have ENOUGH features as much as the sims 2 has. 

but still, i would recommend it cuz i still find it a good game, i just voiced out what i felt was lacking. :) happy gaming to you all~

you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients
- To Make the Dough
375 grams (3 cups) plain flour
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 eggs
1/4 cup (50 ml / 3 tablespoons) olive oil
1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) water
Extra flour for dusting 


- To Make Cheese Filling
15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese
5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) "3 Cheese Italian Blend" (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago)
Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend.
1/2 cup cheddar cheese
2 eggs, lightly beaten
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon pepper


- Extras
Your favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana)
Parmesan cheese
Basil
Fried vegetables
Shrimp
Fish slices
Chicken pieces 
Make the Ravioli filling.

- In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork.
- Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper.
- Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency.
- Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. 

Make the Ravioli dough.

- Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix.
- Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed.
- Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough.
- Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic.
- Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters.
- With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles).
- Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesnt suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor. 

Fill the Ravioli shells.

- Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough.
- Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle.
- Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a homemade touch as well.
- Repeat this process for all your dough circles.
- Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together. 

Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.

- Roll the dough into two sheets
- Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups.
- Fill with the ravioli mixture.
- Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling.
- Remove and separate the finished raviolis.

Cook the Ravioli.

- Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil.
- Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test.
- If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest 
- Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed plates

Serve it up.
Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!

Here's my issue with The Sims franchise in general - they give you a base game with huge chunks of content intentionally missing, so that in order to actually enjoy it, you'll need to spend additional money on expansions.  And then more expansions.  And then another expansion.  And after about $100 sunk into it, you'll finally have a fun game that resembles the previous version of The Sims that you upgraded from.  See:  Sims 2, Sims 3, Sims 4.  Knock it off, EA. This is why people gleefully pirate your games and never feel the slightest bit guilty about it.  

Anyway, I finally decided to buy a legit copy of this on Steam because it went on sale for $12 (base game bundled with a few of the most important expansions) - which is reasonable.  If you get the other expansions on sale for $4.99 each, that's also reasonable.  If you're thinking of paying full price for any of it,  you're out of your mind.  And don't even waste $1 on Island Paradise because it's buggy as hell and you won't be able to play it.

All that being said, I regularly get sideways and play with my virtual dollhouse for hours on end. Once you've gotten most of the expansions and your pc is running it nicely, it's really quite fun.  Just be smart about it and wait for a 50% off sale.

Sims 3 is a fun, enjoyable game that I have spent countless hours playing. 

I would like to be able to 100% recommend the game, as it is a virtual world with unlimited options and customization, however, there are also reasons why I wouldnt recommend it. 

Im choosing to not recommend it, and this is not because the game itself isnt good, it is because of the numerous glitches and issues that come along with the game. 

I have been a fan of sims for years, and have Sims 2 Pets for Game Cube, Sims 3 for Wii and Sims 3 for PC. Out of these three, Sims 2 was the only one that didnt have a lot of glitches. There were some small ones, but nothing that makes the game unplayable. 

However, in both the Wii version and PC version of Sims 3, while the game starts out being relatively glitch free, as you progress through the storyline, the glitches gradually become more frequent and begin to affect the fun of the gameplay itself. 

As of three or four years ago, I had to stop playing the Sims 3 for Wii, because every time I would try to load the game, within two or three minutes in live mode, it would freeze completely. 

I purchased Sims 3 last year during the summer sale, along with the Pets expansion. There was a special offer that meant I was able to buy both for way less than the normal price. That was the only reason I even considered buying the game.
I love Sims, dont get me wrong, but given that I know how many glitches were in Sims 3 for the Wii, I wasnt willing to spend full price on a game that may or may not be playable at some point in the future. 

To give you an idea of the types of glitches I have encountered, I will first of all list all the expansions that I have currently.
I have:
Sims 3 Pets
Sims 3 Generations
Sims 3 Supernatural
Sims 3 University Life
Sims 3 Seasons
Sims 3 Ambitions

I got the other expansion packs at the beginning of this year, again on sale. 
The game, while it often lagged a lot, worked relatively well until the beginning of February, when a strange and very frustrating glitch occurred. 
I was trying to get my sim to walk to the fridge to get some food, but every time I tried to issue the command, the bubble indicating that they cant go there came up. My fridge was in the same exact spot as it had been since I started playing that save file. I couldnt figure out why my sim couldnt get to the fridge, given that there wasnt anything visibly in front of the fridge door. So, after trying to remove the invisible object, I decided to move my fridge one spot to the left. I issued the command to my sim again, and they simply walked over and completed the task. However, the fact that there was some kind of invisible object blocking access to half my kitchen still remained, for which I couldnt find a permanent solution. 

There were other annoying glitches as well, but for the PC version, this was the one that really made me frustrated, because while I could just move houses, I had everything in my current house the way I wanted it and I didnt want to have to buy a new house because of some invisible object. This, in addition to the numerous issues I have encountered with the Wii version as well as the PC version is what caused me to get so frustrated. 
Sims 3 would be an extremely fun game, but the enjoyment of playing it is greatly diminished by the glitches that interfere with the gameplay. 
In conclusion, I do not recommend the Sims 3 game, unless you are willing to deal with the problems that will more than likely occur the more you play the game. I wish the developers of the game would have taken more time and effort to smooth out the issues instead of trying to get it done quickly in order to be able to sell it to the public. Quality is always more important than quantity.

WASTE OF MONEY! Overall the game is very good. But it has an achilles heel - It freezes every few moments. I've since tried the numerous "fixes" on the internet to absolutely no avail. Have requested a refund. Would have expected these sorts of issues to be worked out at this stage in the games life - especially since they're still selling it. But no, they've left it broken and still for sale, robbing people of their money on a game they know is broken and have no intentions of ever fixing.

Excellent guilty pleasure game and man, what a time sink this game can be. The game has an excellent modding community as well. I recommend waiting for steam sales before you buy any of the DLC though, and stay away from the "stuff packs" they are generally not worth getting, especially for the price.

One important thing to note is that the loading times in this game, as well as the time it takes to save are unforgiveably bad, I recommend putting the game into windowed mode and then forcing it into windowed borderless with the windowed borderless gaming software so you can tab out and do something else while it loads / saves. Thankfully the game only has to load once since it is open world (unless you are traveling to a new neighbourhood, then it needs to load the new neighbourhood as well)

Before you start playing The Sims 3 I strongly recommend you get some important mods, nraas overwatch as well as nraas debugger. Overwatch will do a check and cleanup of your game neighbourhood once ever 24 hours to fix the awful performance that plagues this otherwise great game and fix sims getting stuck etc. Debugger will allow you to wiggle around other bugs and issues you run into, it will basically allow you to do anything for debugging purposes.

Enjoy the game!

This is about the Sims 3 overall and not any specific expansion.

Pros

- Endless Sandbox. The game is never predictable. The game never ends.
- So many contents. Without the expansion packs.
- Awesome soundtrack.
- Enitre game World feels open, alive and connected.
- Sims not under your control can age and die and have life of their own.
- You can customize the lifespan of Sims and their pets.
- Vastly Improved AI over Sims 2.
- Very engaging character customization screen.
- Wonderful house editor.
- Create-A-Style lets you practically create your own dress textures.
- Huge Mod Support.

Cons -

- Load / Save times can be extremely slow due to staggering number of contents (especially if you have 2+ expansion packs)
- Sims cannot multitask.
- Some Annoying NPCs will often bother you.
- Sims have problem with staircases often.
- If left on their own, Sims can make the stupidest choices.
- Partially intrusive Sims store ads in-game. You can turn these off, but bad practice overall.
- Overpriced DLCs. While expansion packs are sometimes worth getting, Stuff Packs do not add new features to the game bar a few cosmetic items and costs as much as the base game itself!

Recommended Expansions:

Pets
Generations
Seasons
University Life



For all those interested, this game does not come with any additional DRM except Steamworks. There is no cloud save support and the save game sizes can be huge. You need to back them up manually or get a software that does.

Creating a Sims 3 / EA account is entirely optional.

Overall, this game is clearly the grandest Sims game in the series and even surpasses the new Sims 4. Get it if you can tolerate the performance issues that comes with installing extra contents. This will kill all your time. Worth getting during a Steam Sale.

Really nice game, my favourite version of the Sims, but the glitches and sudden game shutdowns (often when I go to town view) are getting old...

I do like the ability to turn free will and aging on or off, to tick off certain weather types, adjust time frames for growth stages and seasons, etc... I also appreciate being able to edit the clothes' colours and patterns, as well as hair colour, etc... Relationship shifts can be so sudden they're hillarious at times, with full free will... I've shaken my head many times at how my Sims have cheated on their lovers, broken up on a whim, grounded their kids for missing school when said kids were stuck in front of the school unable to move all day lol, etc... I like the lifetime wishes, opportunities, roommates, choices of traits, lifetime rewards...

What I hate, however, is the game becoming unplayable at times because a glitch occured during transfer from university back to home (for instance). My Sims can't be selected, in fact, the whole household dissapears from the house altogether while their roomates keep on going about their activities. I had to delete a gamre and start over because of it! I eventually found a way to fix it by making a copy of my household, saving copy to library, evicting the old household and replacing them by the new copy, but that means they lose all their connections with friends, etc... You'd think that, with the kind of price each expansion sells for, these sorts of major glitches would be ironed out before the game is released, or patched at some point... Apparently not, seeing as it's been a few years now since the game came out... A pity.

But, overall, a good game.

Fun when it works.

With  16GB of RAM, an 8 core 4 GHz processor, and a Radeon R7, my rig is many times more than the recommended requirements. That being said, it works, okay for the first 20-30 minutes or so of playing then it starts lagging terribly. So I save my game (takes about 1-1.5 minutes to save), then reset my computer. I am unable to reload my save file because it freezes, I waited it out for 10 minutes a few times and it never loaded. Started another game, worked for a bit, couldnt reload it later.

The game itself is great fun, but the piss poor optimization of it and crashes makes it unplayable. Do not buy, and if you get a free copy, sell it on G2A.

Yes, I like being a voyeur, and watching a couple of teenagers trying to get it on. Yes, I enjoy trying to find ingenious ways to trap and kill my beloved Sim-family. Yes, EA managed to impress me enough to do something I rarely ever do; buy some dlc.

A wonderful game, that is sometimes charming, moving (emotional) and even frustrating; three adjectives that should not exist together in a computer game, but certainly should in a west coast soap opera.

The Sims 3:

[h1]Positives:[/h1]

+ Purchase a house for your family or build and design your own with hundreds of customisation options. Buy pools, decorative garden plants, televisions, computers, exercise machines, kitchen appliances, cars, toys for toddlers, sculptures, pet animals (DLC)....the list is huge! 
+ Work as a master criminal, a journalist, celebrity or even a detective + more! Attend University to further your studies and become a video game designer, sports agent or arts appraiser (DLC). Go travelling to Egypt, France and China (DLC). This game is packed with plenty to do.
+ Many different skills for your sims to level up, science, cooking, athleticism, logic, charisma etc, so you can have a very diverse gameplay experience.
+ Optional quests or objectives will become available from schooling, work and elsewhere, allowing you to participate in one-off opportunities with rewards.
+ Several neighbourhoods to play in, each with a unique layout.
+ There's a large amount of playtime in the Sims 3 for players of all sorts. I managed to get over 100 hours out of it.

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]

- Micromanagement is very unresponsive, Sims refuse to complete workplace objectives over and over and decide what they want to do themselves, instead of what you've told them. High free will means Sims react to basic needs problems like feeding a baby or bathing themselves, but it also results in ignoring your human commands repeatedly, which gets infuriating after a few hours.
- While I acknowledge graphics aren't a major focus of Sims gameplay, it could definitely be improved. Aesthetically, this game is disappointing.
- The game is quite expensive, even though it's now 8 years old (as of 20/02/2017). DLC is also pricey, so make sure you absolutely want this game before paying in full, or wait for a sale.
- Bad pathing by Sims, they don't interact with the environment well and get stuck in certain spots. Could be much smoother.  

- Despite the vastness of Sims 3, it can become boring after awhile. Once you build a mansion filled with the most luxurious objects money can buy and had a family, there's really not much else to do. This game has a cycle of repetition, whereby you continue to do the same tasks over and over, just in different ways and styles. Sure, the kids in your family grow up and you're able to control their lives, but it's like starting from scratch again, where's the sense of accomplishment in that? It's the balance between fun and repetitive content which the Sims 3 suffers from. There's a real conflict here, with the many facets of variability trying to shine, but then a monotonous feeling sometimes overshadowing it. 


Overall Score: 7.5/10

Oooh Sims 3 on sale for a somewhat reasonable price, so I can finally test it out!
I bought the Island Paradise, Pets, Generations, Ambitions and Seasons as those either added content I was interested in or expand the game in interesting ways.
 First impressions were really well, everything is highly customizable and I spend an hour making a loner fisherman/scuba diver and his trusty dog and finally move into my housboat. The troubles soon became apparent though as the game freezes very frequently for 5-20 seconds. Now I read elsewhere that it's especially bad with Isla Paradiso as there are tons of pathing issues that cause these lags. EA just never bothered fixing their 35$ expansion pack....
I downloaded a modded version of the worldmap but have to start a new playthrough and I also read that there are mods that watch for these pathing errors and resolve them more quickly than the game's own routines but this is a sorry state of affairs.

Sims 3 seems to otherwise really be the high point of the series and I wish there would be a "Remaster" with most of the expansion packs but mostly bug free and on a better technical base that can actually handle all the assets. That would be way better than the trimmed down Sims 4 or whatever they have planned with 5.

<edit>
I have since bought the Late Night expansion and started a new playthrough in Bridgeport to see if that has unplayable lag too. No Lag! Oh joy!
I played all day, getting a lone teen (created a mother then deleted her) with her two cats through school and into adulthood where she started a career as a mixologist and I was looking forward to opening my own Bar at some point. Saved and quit to eat dinner, loaded again and I can't interact with half the objects anymore. What the heck is this?? Quite a few people seem to have the same or similar issues, some other players may give well meant advice but nothing worked for me. Not buying a new toilet or deleting my cache files.

I should know better than to give EA any of my money but it's been ages since I played the Sims 1 and I really wanted to again. When the game actually works it was a real joy and I'm amazed by the breadth and depth of the gameplay but if all my games end sooner rather than later in a technical game-over then I'm not motivated to start again.

Of course it's too late for a refund now but shame on you EA and Maxis for having a game wonkier than Fallout or Skyrim. This is a Gothic 3 level of f'ed up.

This has without doubt been the longest, hardest and most frustrating experience trying to get this game running compared to any other game I've ever played. I have a very powerful PC. But the game constantly refused my email/password telling me they were invalid - why? I've never had an EA account. So I couldn't create an account. Tried it within the games interface, on EA's website, which also kept telling me my serial number was invalid even though I copied it straight from the steam startup page!
Then I found another EA webite (why does EA have another site that essentially does the same thing?) It eventually accepted my details and told me I had registered my game! Yay! It also told me I had 1000 sim money whatever it's called and when I get in the game I can download some sim stuff. Great I thought. Now I knew I needed to register the game so that I could get achievements and use the store to buy things etc. I figured that out eventually. So I start the game, setup the graphics and sound etc. I find the Download button, click that and find nothing there! I start looking around all over the place, and realize that there's no sim money, no stuff to download to help you start off! 
Now I know I bought the game on sale, but REALLY EA? After all that you put me through, you couldn't even give me a few credits?
I'll never buy another EA game again, and even though I just bought this today I don't really want to play it at all!
That's my review.

I've owned 1,2 and now 3.  This is easily the best of the 3 versions of this game I have played.  I was a little disappointed at first because start up was a little clunky and confusing.  I'm 45, so take that with a grain of salt.  I also expected a lot more content.  Build mode seems to have more stuff, but I'd have thought there'd be a slew more items in Buy mode, especially since I sprang for Pets, Ambitions and one other pack I can't think of off the top of my head.  The game play is what sold me.  It's so much smoother as far as getting from place to place both within your home and within the town.  It may be partly because of the Ambitions pack, but you can make a lot of meaningful money other than just getting up and going to work ad nauseum.  I also like that life gets easier to manage as a reward for putting in the work.
Don't judge me. But I like this game.

The Sims franchise has earned its place in my top 5 all time favourite games. Only WoW could rival the number of hours I've put into these games. The Sims 3 builds nicely on the previous Sims and if you wait long enough the DLC becomes extremely affordable. I bought the base game at launch years ago and the only redeeming quality back then was the sheer amount of amazing modders who put items up for free for download. EA has tapped into that and offers an in-game and launch screen store where you can top up on furniture, clothes, and other sim items. I've personally never put any additional funds into peices of furniture, but if that's your bag it's there. If you own all the DLC you don't need to seek outside downloads.

Sims 3's sim creator makes for almost infinite cosmetic and personality options. Although Sims 4 is out and I've owned this game since launch, it has enough staying power to hold me over for years to come. As a general rule you can wait to buy the newest Sims game for a year or so and pick it up on the extreme cheap during the Winter/Summer sales. The only real changes from version to version is usually graphics and some improved AI for the first while. There isn't much incentive to leave this version when the Sims 4 has limited DLC. You get used to your sims going to university, having seasons, taking vacations, and being vampires that terrorize the neighbourhood. And yes, you can still torture and burn your sims to crisp, create a little graveyard, and have the ghosts torment the new family that moves in. 

Cons: 

-Why is there a Katy Perry expansion? It's just dumb.

The Sims 3 Review - Raymond KT

*EDITED AND UPDATED!!*

The Sims 3 is the third major title in the life simulation video game developed by The Sims Studio and published by Electronic Arts

Sims 3 is the perfect example for a brilliant, fun game that works without any violence right. It's both more of a role-playing game than it's ever been before, and more of a design game than it's ever been before. It may suffer a few glaring compromises, but it's an essential play for anyone with an interest in what videogames can achieve outside of a targeting reticule.

I'm not going to say this is a bad game, it's Interesting game. With 19 expansions, there are alot of possibilities and random things that happen in The Sims 3. The sims are actually quite realistic and literaly seem to have pesonalities of thier own. You can create two identical sims right down to their traits and they will still surprize you. They are real enough infact, that its possible to feel for them when they have good times and bad. 

After investing alot of time in this game, about 200 hours, I have noticed there are alot of problems as well. There were many times that I found the action menu options and how the actions are executed were impractical or down right nonsence. I've noticed easily hundreds of times the asperation system failed. Options normally in the action menu tend to sometimes go missing when the sim has an asperation related to said action. Sometimes asperations do not get checked off no matter how many times you complete the task. The asperation system just plain sucks on how the sims seem to mosly get asperations after you just completed the action rather while you are working on the task, at least in cases where  they are learning skills or advancing in a profession. Several times I've seen a new lifetime wish pop up even though, the sim already completed its lifetime wish. I have a sim that never did get a lifetime wish. Most notible problem I have run into with this game are the crashes, not so bad by themselves, but add to the fact that even with a SSD the time it takes to save the game is terrible. This game makes me hate saving to the point that I lose entire game sessions due to a crash. That said, saving can cause a crash itself. This is the worse, because when it crashes while saving the whole save file is lost. I lost a whole family I put about a hundred hours into developing over this ...thanks EA Games t('.'t)... That said, It may be a great idea to regularly go into your save folder and create backups. I think this game is great, but EA with 19 expansions got sloppy on the way fitting it all together it seems. 

Don't buy this game at regular price. Personally I think this game and all expansions should be combined, debuged, streamlined and repackaged for sale at about $60 USC.

First of all this is a great game. Everything is beautiful and the concept is very clean. I played sims 1 and 2 at launch many years ago and i skipped the sims 3 for 7 years before trying it but it still looked great! This is a real classic revamped without competition in the industry.

Second, never ever buy this game if you are a gamer. Everything seems nice until you really invest in it. 

The review says I've played 37 hours but i've loaded the game for about 7 hours of the time. The first couple of hours works like a charm, then you try something new. Then you begin to get 4 fps after 15 minutes of play everytime you reload the game. Then you spend 2 hours on forums checking what you should do to speed up your game. Cleaning of the game cache, deleting a couple of files, ok.... There is no greater disapointment abandonning a game so well designed because of technical issues.....

After 5 tries of solutions that worked for other people, you get really sad because even if you are a game engineer (which I was for almost a decade), you still can't find the solution to your problem; Welll, the last solution people on forums is that I should get a super computer. Sorry guys, I don't believe having 8 more gigs of RAM on top of my 8 and 300 MHz more clock speed on my i7 will do the trick, this isn't how it works.

I think the root of all the problems is one of the DLC i got from steam for free that causes all of the problems, but I tried to re-install the game without it and the launcher gives me a fatal error if it isn't there (pets dlc). Now I am just enable to boot the game (haven't tried more than 30 seconds though, think it stills try to load old files from previous install in the document folder).... if you can't figure how to launch a game in 2 min... than you are not in 2009, less in 2017.

So, should you buy this game, don't buy any DLCs. Get the vanilla game and make sure you are good before installing anything else. Play at least 20 hours of it and get your sim making another baby sim and make it go to adulthood.

At this point, I think I'll just skip everything Electronic Arts does from this point...

The Sims 3 is really fun and addictive! Still, it is important that buyers be aware of what they're actually getting prior to investing in this game. If you do not do a little research ahead of time, you may end up feeling disappointed once you begin to play. 

The Sims has always been a franchise built around DLC. If you are trying out Sims for the first time and you decide to only purchase the base game (to experiment and save some money), keep in mind that you will not be able to do many of the things you probably have seen in player videos and previews. That being said - I would suggest reading through the descriptions of the available DLC prior to making your purchase. Choose what might be worth investing in based upon what you hoped to get out of this game. 

For instance - are you simply looking to play around with one character - walk him/her through their daily life, get a job, climb the career ladder, etc? If so, the base game may work out just fine for you. If you're looking for more, you may want to choose a bundle, or purchase the game with some DLC, right away. Still, think carefully before spending your money. DLC for The Sims is relatively costly. If you know you would enjoy playing with cats, dogs, and horses, and engaging in outdoor seasonal activities - the main bundle (with generations, pets, and seasons) may be worth the expense. But, if you're more interested in traveling the world, creating vampires and witches, or living the college life, you're probably better off skipping the bundle and just buying The Sims 3 plus one additional DLC that meets your needs. 

In short - The Sims 3 is a great game - but you may be disappointed, or end up spending more than you'd like for content you do not need or care about, if you do not do some research before making your purchase.

Also considering how much fun it is I am happy to support this game with my money.

Anyway here are some fun experiences from the game so far:

-I make a family where the man is an inventor and the woman is an artist. After about a one week of sims time: man has set himself on fire 3 times, electrocuted himself about 4 times; And ofc his wife saved him every time he caught on fire.

- I make a witch family and plant the yard full of apple trees  with the apples that I have conjured. Zombies start hanging out in my giant yard and try to eat my apple trees, obviously I go and ice spell them so they freeze solid. So yeah.. there are now 3 ice zombie statues in my yard..slowly melting.

- I create a crazy lady with too many small pets. I tell her to pet a snake, it's cute, but then she gets bitten. I am not sure what I expected to happen...

- I create a family consisting of young people that wish to be in a band and make money with their music. They start practicing their guitar skills, but  one week in game time the cat has made more money than the two humans combined! Ok yeah, he found a really rare beetle and a rare lizard while hunting and I sold those along with dozen of other small animals, but still, this cat pays the taxes in this family.

-I have a poor family that decided to have a child, they manage it somehow financially and things are going well. Taking care of the lil leech isn't quite hard as I thought...so I decide to let them make another baby to add some difficulty. They get twins. I am doomed.

It's just like playing to original for the first time!

I've been playing the sims since it came out on Nintendo DS (I still do) and turns out my dad played sims for long time too on the computer. The sims is literally a huge part of my life and after awhile I wanted to purchase this version. Due to not having a computer that could handle steam before, I ended up getting steam the same time of the holiday sale unknowingly. I ended up getting the sims 3 bundle that contains the game, generations DLC, pets DLC, and seasons DLC, which was pretty awesome because these were the 3 DLCs that I had wanted and getting them on sale for the holidays and then on sale in the bundle was pretty awesome! The only thing is that due to it being so expensive, unless your are really desperate, wait until a sale because buying regular price for all DLCs isn't worth it no matter how awesome the sims franchise is.. $400.00 is just too much for all DLCs... However, the gameplay is really fun and because of having a computer that can now handle this game even at the highest, I have no issues with freezing or slowness, it runs very nicely. Even though I've had no problems with the loss of game progress, I would make sure to save every hour or so because I tend to play for 2-3 hours straight at times and the last thing I want is to lose my progress when it could of been prevented.

Love the game overall, though the wait time for the loading is quite a pin (can be waiting anywhere from 3 to 5 minutes on average with each loading screen). A few small glitches here and there, but nothing too serious, they're usually quite amusing to see anyways.

The Sims 3 in the least, is a very Dynamic and enjoyable game. There are tons of new things added from the previous game "Sims 2" (Yes I know this is very late considering the 4th one is coming out). But also, there are things that I were felt missing from the previous game. It's weird to explain what they were, it just feels... gone. But, it makes up for it with new features, such as Perks, and added features.

The only real problem I have with this game, and what's preventing from giving the a 10 or even a 9 is, that the DLC is WAY over-priced for what it's worth. DLC at it's Maximum should be $20 not $30-$40. Average DLC on any game is usually between $10-$20. And then you occasionally have the $25 DLC. but, Anything more than that is far too outrageous. Especially, if some of the DLC costs more than the actual Base game. I doubt even SOME Die-Hard Sims fans would be willing to pay for that much.

My final score is and 8/10

Very similar to the Sims 2, except with more options, freedom, and things to do and buy. Moving around between properties (either residential or community) without any loading screens is by far the best aspect of the game. You can also roam the neighborhood without going to any specific lot. 
The best expansion packs are World Adventures, Island Paradise, and Supernatural; they add multiple new worlds, new achievements, things to do, and lots to buy or build. 
Only negative changes they made in The Sims 3 is you cannot build a new neighborhood from scratch, you have to use one of the pre-existing ones. Also, the graphics for the Sims faces seem to have gotten worse since The Sims 2. Annoyingly, you can still only build up to five floors. Other than these few things, the game is a masterpiece.

Made a werewolf guy (supernatural DLC) who's hot-headed, fearless, and cocky, and a vampire woman who is composed, proper, and a neat-freak live in a house together. Naturally, they clash at first: she can't stand how he leaves his dishes everywhere and runs around on all fours sometimes, while he finds her stuck up and pretentious. But over time, they start chatting more and realizing how much they have in common.

Their friendship hits a rough patch at the full moon, when he transforms and ruins a bunch of furniture, and she goes a little nuts and attacks him (apparently there's an action called a "lunatic slap" during the full moon that she did on her own). But they bond over fighting a robber together and playing lots of hopscotch, and soon their bond is stronger than ever. It pretty quickly moves to "Romantic Interest," and all of a sudden they are flirting and kissing all the time.

After a few in-game days of this, it's time for them to "woohoo" for the first time. He gives her a big dip kiss, and they go to the bed with swelling music and falling rose petals. Right as I'm wondering how birth control works in this game, since I'm not ready to raise a hybrid werewolf-vampire baby, she falls out of the bed and dies. The grim reaper shows up and takes her ghost away as I stare at my computer in shock. Apparently she died of thirst, unwilling to feed from him and not wanting to interrupt the romance to go drink.

Now he's walking around the house grieving, surrounded by walls covered in all the paintings she made. He tries desperately to resurrects her while her ghost is still haunting the place, but can't find the necessary ingredients to make the potion he needs in time. He finally moves on when he finds a puppy at the animal shelter that needs a home, and starts forming a warm friendship with the zombie next door.

8/10 would play out a young adult paranormal romance novel again if it weren't so incredibly slow and if each DLC wasn't ridiculously expensive.

After playing the sims 3 for around 300 hours I can surely say that the game is fun and provides a enjoyable experience. In Sims you basically make yourself a character or family and go on through the game while seeing your characters grow up. Your family will slowly grow as your starting character begins to grow old and ends up sadly dying as death himself comes through your front door to take your orginal character's soul away. The gameplay is a little bit repetive as you basically give your family characters orders such as cook/eat food or go to work/school everyday until their is a holiday or weekened for them to take off and instead chill at home. You will have to pile up money to expand your house and add new additions to it, which may be a grind, but you may easily use cheats or gain a well paying job to quickly create a fair amount of money. Graphics are nothing to praise or spit on, but it is thankfully easy on the eyes as you will be playing for sometime to see progress take place in your world. One down side is the DLC really which is a valid reason for some negative reviews about this game, yet I wish to note that the game is still fun without any of the DLC. You will still have fun with the base game and if you ever wish to try something new then simply start a new family or pick up one of the DLC packs when they are on sale. I reccomend Sims 3 to those looking for a different game that requires you to have a little bit of devotion to have progress take place. I give Sims 3 9/10 Broken Sinks

Buy this instead of The Sims 4. On sale, all EP costs around US $60. Stuff Packs does not really worth it except when they are $1 each.

When you have multimonitor or doing alt-tab quite often, Borderless Gaming is very recommended as this game does not natively support borderless.

This game definitely got performance issue which sometimes major. So just be wary. You have been warned. You could find some tips and tricks in order to enhance the performance of the game, such as using RAMDisk, although some of it is debateable wether it is really improving or only intermitent.

Download recommended mods such as AwesomeMod or NRaas. AwesomeMod is said to not supported in Steam version of TS3, but actually it is just because of different versioning. It should run smoothly despite warning messages on not using supported version.

After all, The Sims 3 is the best installment after The Sims 2. Both games have their own ups and downs though. But still it is way better than The Sims 4 which is actually The Sims 1.5.

The Sims 3 is an incredible game. It makes life seem just about the same, easy at first, harder as you continue, or just depending on what kind of life your sim lives. The base game itself without any DLCs or CC installed, is very small, but still quite entertaining. You do indeed have to play it for quite some time to get your Sim somewhere great in their simlife. With DLCs and CC installed, it's even better. CC can be made completely by you or found on the internet and made by someone else, but it gives you capability to fully customize your game, and the fact that the developers let the players create and install CC is grand. the DLCs make it possible to live in the city, or with pets, etc. Without it, if you were to let's say install a pet, it wouldn't work out. The DLCs and CC make the game much more than the base game is. As well as the many other versions of the game that you can buy, it puts so much more variety into the game and makes it so much fun to play. It's definitely worth the money in my opinion, just make sure that if you go all out, you have enough storage for it. It runs slow on my computer because I have the minimum requirement of graphics drive and a lot of CC.

I won't lie, the game has a crap-ton of glitches. However, it's still a very entertaining game, and can certainly be a challenge if you're new to the game/have lots of sims/ect.

If you need a challenge, start out with two or three sims, buy the biggest empty lot you can find, and make them live homeless until the two of them get enough money to build a house. Got to say, after watching my Sims pillow fight with the Grim Reaper, freak out at the sight of a mummy and then start casually chatting with it, burn their house down and then complain about some unseen object in their way, angrily fistfighting with burglars one minute and then shaking their hands the next, I can't bring myself to regret the time I've invested into this game. It's not even close to as charming and playful as the Sims 1 or Sims 2, but it can be a lot of fun. I love the Sims 3, I find it extremely fun and addictive. Now you're probably wondering why the big red thumbs down? Well... First of all, the game costs $400 for all the DLC and there are Micro-transactions! Micro-transactions should not be in games I pay for or in single player games! This is a complete waste of money, where I could buy about 30 games with $400 rather than getting a bunch of DLC that are a complete waste of money. I don't mind buying/paying for DLC, but when I have to pay for extra content to get the full experience, and it will cost me $400 when I have already bought the game and if I want to have couches, fridges, clothes, expansion packs, etc, it will cost real money, this just makes me question how stupid does EA think we are? I would recommend buying the game, but the DLC will make the game actually a lot better, so its recommended to buy the game on sale and pick it up for about $100. I sure as hell thought the game was fun and had a lot of things to do, but paying huge amounts of money into a game is way too much for me and I'm pretty sure for anyone else.

Is the game fun? Yes. Is the game extremely addicting? Yes. Is it better than the second one? Yes. Better than the fourth one? Yes because it's on Steam. Are their any problems? Yes. Error Code 12 sucks but at least you can get around it. I will link wiki guide on how to avoid Error Code 12 and what to do when you get it. However, Error Code 16 is the worse. It happens to all of us when our save games get over 4gb. EA never decided to fix this problem and who knows why. Regardless, even with the two errors that will drive you nuts at times, the game is fun and worth getting, but get it on sale. EA doesn't deserve your money because they refuse to fix Error Code 16. lol

new review:
Still downvoting cause of how shady it was. a 2 hour refund time limit eaten by an hour of loading?  Also newcomers can't really get into the game for at least 5 hours(it took me a further 3 hours to figure out the hybrid of controls i needed) in between character customization(hint! don't start out with a toddler sim in the family! you want some perks from later in game or you'll just be sitting there constantly taking care of it....my original household basically starved from lack of money to buy food...) house customization and the still outright janky controls. It tries SO hard to be done entirely with mouse and you simply can't do that. 

on top of that theres been some bizarre behavior with the game itself. For absolutely no reason i can see(i'll cancel out EVERYTHING so sims is the only thing running) the game's fps will just flat out tank. i'm not a graphics and fps freak like it seems 80% of the internet is..but it was choppy. my cursor going and appearing and disappearing over the screen choppy and sometimes seeming to almost crash.

in 20 something hours my play has been mostly boring money gathering stuff. most exciting thing was someone dying right outside my fence and the grim reaper appearing. character was brave enough to take the grave(and apparently the body and ghost...?) to the cemetery...


Original review

First off i'll say that for those that like this sort of thing go for it. But i believe the PC version has janky controls. I kept trying to rotate the camera and kept zooming in and out instead. and I'm not one for graphics (I'll happily play snes games[secret of evermore] alongside ps3 games) but theres something a bit off putting about the sims faces with certain eye and facial styles..and the hair not sitting right on some just added to it.


The real reason I've downvoted this is it took me an hour to get into the actual game itself! registering,trying to figure out how to enter the codes that were already automatically downloaded(this was my first main sims game. i played castaway before) and then the loading screens for the game ate up so much time that by the time i realized i needed to refund it asap it had already squeaked over the 2 hour limit (by probably half a minute :/ ) for refunds,,and continued squeaking by! 

 i had accidentally launched the launcher again and didn't realize it! I was doing computer updates and just couldn't restart and by the time i found out it was the /launcher/ (hidden waay in the middle of my programs list between similar looking icons) it had already rung up into 4 hours. I want my refund on this and the 3 packs of DLC that were recommended..but i can't get it! :/ . i'm on a brand new computer,while not handbuilt like some so proudly claim i carefully picked it for medium-high end gaming so as far as i'm concerned the loading screens are to puff up gameplay time and rob you of your refund. Quite disappointed and i say stay away unless you can get a guaranteed refund.

If Sims 4 didn't exist, I might be giving this a negative review. As it stands, I've played The Sims 4, it sucks, I hate it, it's a step backwards, so here I am reviewing The Sims 3 again.

PROS:

-Graphics are decent, the default hairstyles and clothes aren't horrific like they are in The Sims 2
-Still fun without expansion packs
-Obviously tons of customization
-Lots of playability
-Open-world, unlike other Sims games
-Can chat with the grim reaper

CONS:

-The expansion packs!!!
-Oh my god the expansion packs!!!! Why do they cost so much!!!!
-I like the face/body sculpting idea from TS4, wish that had been a thing
-As others have mentioned, the game sort of destabilizes over time. The game lags and the visuals "catch" while the sound keeps going. You have to wait a sec until it fixes itself. Happens more the longer you play in a particular neighborhood
-Not all the DLC is good. I've tried all of them and some of them are a waste of time and money. I find the item packs pointless as I can just get items from modding, some of them are super unstable or just plain boring. Island Paradise (??) is pretty unstable - I still play it because I can deal with it. I recommend University Life, Supernatural, and Pets if you're going to buy some. WAIT UNTIL THEY'RE ON SALE THOUGH!!

I still recommend the game!! I've dumped so many hours into TS3. By far my favorite sims game

EDIT: I played it a ton before I bought it on steam :) Disregard the amount of hours I have on here and don't be rude, thanks

I would definitely recommend this game. 

Pros: 
- Good character creation 
- More personality traits. 
- More job opportunities. 
- You can rotate furniture diagonally. 
- You can change how long your character stays a certain age (toddler, adult, elder, etc).
- More ways to kill them. 
- Last Sims game with pools. 
- Better storylines for the premade characters (if you're someone that really gets into the story aspect of it).
- Relationships with other sims is more complex (in a good way). 
- And much more that I can't think of off the top of my head.


Cons:
- You can't go inside buildings anymore (meaning you can't see what's inside the building). 
- Dating is kinda weird (you don't really know how good the date is going). 
- Group outings are annoying. (they just are, I'm not quite sure how to explain them). 
- Aspiration rewards aren't "tangible" items anymore. It's character traits or abilities to "enhance" your sim. 
- I still haven't been able to figure out how to get rid of roomates completely (if anyone knows how lemme know bc those b*tches are annoying as f*ck)

SOMANYINGAMEPURCHASES('nuff said)

WHAT CAN I SAY? YOU ARE A PERSON in a PC, PLAYING WITH PEOPLE'S LIVE WHO CAN PLAY WITH PEOPLES LIVES in pc TOO.
And you can have ghost babies, and kill your sims in different modes. You can be the villain, the nerd, the vampire, the witch, you can travel through to the future, or to another cities. Choose a job and make career, have pets, do anything. You can build your house the way you want, and put all the peronality on it. Because you can.
You can make your own contents or download other player's content, and personalize it.

I can spend hours in this game, just in the ''create a sim'' mode. Because imagination flows away. 
You start thinking about the character, his expressions, his clothes, his personality, and then you go to the part of construction, to build the character's house, and again the time goes by and when you see, you are playing like for 5-7 hours and it's already dawning. And you didn't ''started playing'' yet. Like I said, you can be everything, and do anything. 

This game is not made for those who seeks action and adventure. Its a simulation game. It's not made of levels for you to beat on. It's endless, and that's one beauty on this game. If it's not your "game type", please don't underestimate the game.
It's a very good game, but it didn't hold my interest as long as I thought it would sadly. You will definitely get your dollar per hour ratio out of it!

Because this game simulates so much about life, including being a gamer, I recommend it, and give it:

The Game Within A Game Award

The Sims 3 has vastly changed - and improved - since I've last played The Sims 2. 
I purchased the game as a bundle that included three expansion packs: Seasons, Generations, and Pets. In the game you can now travel throughout the town or city without the loading screens. This alone is a great feature to the game as now you can jog, bike, drive, or ride to a location of your choice in a matter of seconds without waiting for the game to bring up a new load screen. 
The Sims Pets have brought in horses as well! You can choose from a number of breeds and then cusotomise your horse's coat, bridle, sadle, and reins. The horses have different outfits for shows too! 
Each of the packs included have downloaded fast and run smoothly. The game is a little slow but overall that's not unexpected on my little laptop. I plan to continue to collect the expansion packs around the holiday sales. (Otherwise, they can be a little pricey for the overall payoff.)

[b]PROS: [/b] Unlike Sims 4, 2 and 3 was a big leap in features, graphics and content. There is so much that can happen, and the city continues to move even if you're just watching the events of one household. Building homes has been drastically improved, very gorgeous results can be obtained.

[b]CONS: [/b]Cash shop features have snuck into the series, a nauseating and unfortunately effective addition. Third party is invasive even after the splash screen?? Why? The biggest thing for me is the music; The Sims 1 had one of the best soundtracks, a series of hilariously peppy muzak renditions that filled the game with a  so the soulless feel of the newer ones is worth mourning. 

[b]WORTH: [/b]Pricing for expansions is absolutely asinine, and they don't go on sale often. $379.00USD for all DLC of a game released in 2009? Insanity. Still, when they DO go on sale, they go up to 75% off! Your patience will be rewarded.

[b][u]OVERALL: [/u][/b]If you like to build a world, this is the ultimate sandbox to play in. If you can step around all the microtransactions, you will find underneath, a spectacular game worth hours of your time.
