Had this game for about 4 or 5 years now, and I still find myself coming back to it occassionally. There's just so much fun this game has to offer that other games can never hope to recreate. Did you ever want to help a nerdy vampire body builder with social anxiety slowly work his way to the top of social class in the neighborhood? Or maybe experience the torment it is to be a single gardener with a large plot of land and way too many cats? You can only find these unique and quirky experiences here, and help these seemingly helpless cases prosper into greater portions of themselves.

Even if you uninstall this game after playing it for a good while, it'll always welcome you back with open, warm, nostalgic arms.

---ignore my play-time. I play through Origin now and have about 182 hours, not including Steam play time.

Hypocrite Alert, -- I keep buying them at full retail but fuck I just cannot get enough of this.

----- STEAM TO ORIGIN USERS
Log into your Sims 3 Account via browser; register the CD Key from Steam under Account, removing the hyphens and when you open Origin (Assuming you've used the same EA Login) you'll get a prompt telling you there's Packs for you to download.

Steam Key appears - XXXX-XXXX, etc. so when you enter it on the TS3 site, it'll be XXXXXXXX
------

Get it on sale, never buy any Sims game at full retail price, if there is another game (The Sims 4) in the series.

EPs I recommend; Pets, Seasons, Generations, University Life and Supernatural. -- Ambitions if you're feeling like Professions is lacking variety - You won't get professions unless you have either Generations or Ambitions (not sure about any other EP.) 

These together add to a massive amount of replay value and is the ultimate realism (excluding SN) if you're doing Legacies, etc. Avoid Islag Paralagalot (Island Paradise; unless you're OK with having to delete, remove or modify loads of shit)

If you get pets; and I cannot stress this enough, turn Pets [b]off[/b] in story progression after two sim days to avoid lag / stuttering when spawning strays (and this game loves spawning strays).

OR - you can get Nrass - Overwatch mod. It becomes the watching eye and fixes in-game errors where you cannot. -- such as sims being stuck and not being able to find them etc, etc.

Again, if you buy this full price, just expect a lot of content but a lot of bugs, etc. [b] there are mods that contain patch fixes etc, but quite a few of them are out of date or are featured in another mod, for example "No Fridge Shopping" removes the option to buy food; which is what was needed, but adds silly recipes for them and can't be changed without having to download a stand-alone program to open and edit the files.

>>> FOR ANYONE HAVING TECHNICAL ISSUES LAUNCHING/LOADING GAME <<<

I got The Sims 3 along with the Showtime and Late Night DLC's and I had nothing but technical issues (black screen after launching, didn't recognize my graphics card, wouldn't read saved game files, wouldn't read/recognize it's own game folder/files and created completely new ones everytime I tried to launch the game.....) I searched the Steam forums for solutions, and managed some workarounds. But in the end, once I managed to start a game, I couldn't shut it down or I'd lose everything that I'd done because the game rewrote the file folders everytime I launched. I was frustrated and angry, which anyone who'd read my original bad review could confirm. 

*** I'm now playing The Sims 3 and DLC's I purchased on Steam on Origin instead and have not had ANY of the issues I experienced trying to play on my main gaming laptop. >>** For anyone else who's had similar issues and has tried everything suggested in forums, simply create an Origin account and redeem your game/DLC keys then download and install to play. **<<

HUGE shoutout and thank you to roberta591 over at EA Answers HQ for this solution!!!!! =)

Both Sims 2 and Sims 3 are the best games in the series, although Sims 3 has a lot of bugs. Most of them are easy to fix though. I will write a list of bugs and how to fix them, and then the major game breaking bug I'm still trying to fix.
These are glitches I ran into in my 58 hours of playtime with all expansion packs installed:

1. Sims getting stuck in a frozen position.  How to fix: use cheat "resetsim first and last name" 
2. University seems to be stuck in loading screen. How to fix: Edit town right before going to University, although you can also wait it out, but it loads for like 30 minutes.
3. Can't adopt stray cat or dog even though you are BFF with it. Fix not confirmed, but might work: ask stray to leave, and when it returns the adopt option will appear.
4. Sim stuck in sneak mode after getting grounded. How to fix: Either send your sim to boarding school, or go to edit town, evict your family with their house, bulldoze the empty house, place the family and house back where it was.
5. Can't use bed. How to fix: The same fix as glitch number 4. Not the boarding school fix, the eviction fix.
6. Can't get mail. How to fix: use the buydebug on cheat and testingcheatsenabled true, shift click the mail box, click object, click delete it, go to debug buy menu and buy a new mailbox.
7. Grim Reaper not taking away dead sims. How to fix: This glitch means the grim reaper is stuck, just do resetsim Grim Reaper in the cheat menu to fix it. Reset the dead sim where the reaper got stuck too if you can find the stuck reaper.
8. Bowl of food or any object getting stuck in your sim's hand. how to fix: resetsim first name and last name.
9. Certain sound effects stopped working. How to fix: save your game and load it again or relaunch the game.
10.  The worst most game breaking glitch of all, and the one I only know a one time fix for... Sims stop aging when your new generation sims have a baby, even though aging is on. I tried a few stuff that the devs said would work, but it didn't work. I fixed the issue once with the help of a youtube video, but that fix only works once. If your aging stops again, it won't work. That trick is to go to main menu and copy your saved town by clicking copy town next to the delete button, and then play the copied town. Aging will be back in working order until your 3rd generation's baby grew up into a toddler. That's where I'm stuck at the moment, and I searched for a solution for quite some time. People say either use mods or start a new game and delete the old save. I refuse to delete my save though, I played 58 hours with my family. Also, I don't want to download any mods, because the mods changes some things I don't want to change, plus I don't know how to mod games in general. I hope you found my fixes helpful though, and I hope one of you guys can give me a permanent fix that always works once the sims stop aging, because I really want to continue playing with my family. 

Why do I still recommend this game? Because it's excellent and the world feels alive and completely dynamic and open world.  It not only feels that way, it is that way. Literally. For example, while you are living your life, other sims will live theirs, and you can see them do it. They move, get married, have kids, adopt pets, age, die, go to visit others, visit the park and other places, etc, plus you can affect their lives by interacting with them, like you can break up a couple by kissing someone in front of his or her lover, etc. I bought all the expansions in the sale for about $74. Great game, lots of content, and if it's 75% off, affordable if you want to buy all dlc.  As I said, the only bad thing about the game is the bugs. The aging bug in particular. I heard some people had success moving them out and back in, but I haven't tried it yet. Anyways, if you got the money and you like sims or the genre in general, you will love this game. Just use my glitch fix list if you want a smooth experience.

I don't normally review, but I wanted to counter the baseless negative ones that I've seen popping up. I've loved my time with this since I brought it a couple of days ago and haven't put it down. Incredibly fun and diverse gameplay that doesn't stop being entertaining with or without DLC. The community is vast and amazing, so even if you get bored with what you can come up with there are always challenges and mods to download galore. 

On the topic of DLC, listen up folks - you're not supposed to buy it all, and you don't have to. The stuff packs are just decoration and not worth buying. The EPs - University Life, Late Night, Supernatural - add /different/ worlds and specific themed content ouside of the base game. The only ones that are integral really are Generations, Ambitions, Seasons and Pets. Which all come in a cheap bundle together during this sale season. Buy what looks good to YOU instead of wanting all the DLC for no reason.

I bought the Sims (TM) 3 on sale. I have played the original one and the second one aswell so I knew what I was buying. I bought 5 DLCs aswell; Seasons, Generations, Pets, Film and Supernatural. It all came to about 20  or 20 USD. I have played it for sometime, just to see what it is. Here is my opinion on it:

It doesnt get more causal than this. There is no end goal at all. Just buying stuff, and making the sims interact with eachother. You can give your sims a life goal. I have not tried to achive that yet. As of now I am in a relationship. We have a dog. And he and I get to work. Then I buy stuff and then I wonder "What am I doing?" I dont know if I find it boring or funny or what. 

As I said, I knew what I was buying, but it was more for curriosity of the franchise that I bought it. Especially out of curioisty for the many, many, many DLCs for the game. I bought 4 DLCs and I dont understand how they work. Are they in the game? DO I have to play other maps to use it? How do they change anything? I see that some Sims are now zombies. I guess that is the supernatural one. Also there are animals running around. I guess those are the pet ones.

So the "game" is a... thing you do. And I guess its okay. What I find objectionable is the ingame currency thing. I have bought 5 DLCs and it feels almost like I just get the option to buy more things with REAL money. I can buy things in the Sim store with more real money (not sim money). I dont feel there is much add-on things I can buy in-game with the DLCs.

I really dont like micro-transactions in game. But I guess that is what I get for buying a EA game.
Also the whimsical soundtrack annoys me.

Now... Why do I still recommend it? Because you should know what the game is. And if you like this types of games, the drawbacks is just a reminder. If you like soap-opera games, where the charaters live theire lifes and do nothing but exist, and you dont get depressed or sucidal by it, then this game gives what it says.

The Sims on it's own is good for stretching the creative mind, allowing you to try new achievements and experience different modes, but after a while you're repeating the same formulas and you're sims eventually do the same things regardless of your intended mission in life. It's hard to keep a family going after say the first generation dies as you'll just be repeating everything unless you have more to do. By regularly buying the expansions, the sims will continue to be enjoyable and allow you to try new things. I would suggest buying these on sale however as I don't think they are worth the 29.99 they are charged at.

Also the gameplay is slowed down considerably so if you don't have a fast upto date computer only stick to a couple of DLC's. Certain one's are better than others. Into the Future for example is good as it allows you to have new tools and enter new worlds, along with the additional accessories and lifetime achievements. If you liked The Sims and\or its sequel, I'm sure you will like The Sims 3.
Think about The sims 2 and add: better graphic, better AI, better skills ad job rewards, bigger neighborhoods, collections (metals, rocks, insects and fishes), free roaming through your neighborhood and complete customization of both color and texture of every object you can buy (consider that the last two features are, years after release, still missing from The Sims 4!).

The "only" negative thing I can say about The Sims 3 is that, as time passes by, your savegame will become bigger and slower to load, for example: I've 4 expansions installed, a 5 story house with hundreds of objects in it and 3 sims, it takes about 30 minutes to load (with a Core i7, 16gb of ram and about 500GB of free disk space) and I'm forced to save every 10 minutes or the game fail to save and corrupts the savegame. Sadly support and updates have stopped few years ago.

First and foremost, Sims 3 is a nice game. I don't like how much dlc it has but the base game itself is fun. Since it's on sale, I went ahead and got the bundle. I suggest you do the same before it's too late. The price for everything kept me from getting this game for the longest time and now's the time to grab everything. Personally though, I'd just grab the base game and maybe the bundle. One other complaints I have by the way is that the game tends to crash from time to time. In about 3 or so hours I've had two crashes. It doesn't break the game for me but it that bit definitely isn't fun.

On to the game itself, it's precisely what you'd think it is. A Simulation. A simulation of the day to day lives of people. I like to think of it as a doll maker that let's you take it a step further by letting you watch your characters come to life and follow their dreams, aspirations, and then die a hilariously human death. The game can feel a little off putting upon first starting it up. After my first hour, I felt rather unsure of what to do next. I had created two characters based on a favorite book of mine, "Good Omens," and then had them move into this house out near the country. I contemplated whether or not this game was for me but when I was a child my sister had Sims 2. I remember enjoying it so much that it got me to stop playing World of Warcraft for a few days. That was truly quite the feat back then! After spending some more time with Sims 3, I now know why it temporarily broke my addiction back then. Because the Sims too is a fun and addictive just like my all time favorite game WoW! Now then, Sim 2 isn't Sims 3 per-say but it's just as I remember it. You got a few characters, have them go to work and do basic upkeep, form relationships, etc... Every little virtual day they grow more and more. Heck, after a few hours with this game I feel hyped up to go clean my house, continue working on my skills, and follow my career. Let's play the Sims first though heh...

All in all, I recommend Sims 3. It's a classic game franchise that's both fun and relaxing in nature. Perhaps one of the nicest things about this game is that it's a game anyone can enjoy. There's no tremendous learning curve, no brutal challenges, and no end in sight! Unless you count crashes but still... Play as you wish and there's no rush. If you've been looking for something to relax with, maybe get a little creative, or perhaps take a break from constantly dying in other games, then Sims 3 is for you!

So a while ago, I made a review for this game. I said it was great; 8.7/10. I take it all back. You wanna know why? My game is legit broken. I installed no mods, not a single one. Totally 100% broken. So how is it broken? low Frame rate, graphical errors, studdering, screen tearing, all at lowest settings. Hell I even tried playing at 480p. Still nothing. And I've had this game for a while, like a year or so, and just now it didn't work. I tried downloading it from Origin, nope. Reinstalling? No. I even called EA support, take a guess. No is the answer. 

SCORE: 2.4/10. I guess it's kinda playable, not really. Not really at all. Its messed up. It legit goes from 60fps down to 1 or 5fps then back up to 60fps, then down to... you get the point.

The Sims 3 is the best Sims game you can get. Either playing it normally or dicking around, it's a lot of fun. What more could you ask for? You can be a total creep and make your high school crush so you can bang her and have seven children, or you can be the sadistic fuck you are and lock a sim in a room filled with ovens and fireplaces and burn them to the ground.

The DLCs are very pricey ($20 each) but you can always wait until a big sale goes on and you can get them for $5 each. And trust me, the DLCs add a lot of really fun content and immensely improve the game.

I had played the Sims, The Sims 2, The Sims 3, and The Sims 4.

Of course, I've been playing the Sims 4 since it came out, and despite all the content, it's lacking more content, you get me? Then I see the Sims 3 on sale here on steam and I thought, hey, why not buy a bunch?

So far, worth it.

It's pretty nostalgic and exciting to play the Sims 3 again. There's just so much content on this one than the Sims 4 (they really need to catch up a lot). The one thing that I missed about this was the colorpicker. Creativy is much more flexible here and the imagination is endless. Then there was the open world aspect of just this huge town and city, no loading screens whatsoever. It's just.... Ahhhh, relieving.

On the other hand, the Sims 4 was a little more entertaining with all the hype graphics and awesome changes, especially the sex and gender where a sim's sex would be male but identified himself as female, or vice versa. Gameplay is less laggy for me than the sims 3, probably because it wasn't open world.

Either way, it's hard to compare and contrast both worlds, since "one was born from the last." They're both so good if you can really play it right.

Overall, I like them both. So worth to play The Sims 3 again.

I love The Sims games, but I don't believe it's worth it to pay CAD $19.99 per DLC, after you've already paid CAD $19.99 for the game itself. The Sims 2 on PS2 was my favorite out of all the games, because you could control the sim instead of just telling them to do this or do that. However, my second favorite game in the francise is The Sims 3 for PC. Now, I've played more than just The Sims 3, so I can honestly I like it better than The Sims Castaway, The Sims, and The Sims 2: Pets. Note: The Sims 3 is the only one I have played on the PC, the rest were for PS2. There's just more customization, better graphics, more actions you can do, more speech choices, and more ages. I would love to get the DLC's, especially Pets and Supernatural, but as I said in the beginning of this review, it just doesn't seem worth it to me. I know the developers and everyone else involved in making the game deserve to get paid for what they worked so hard creating, but the prices aren't realistic. Most average gamers don't have the money to pay for all of these DLC's that, really, don't add near enough to the game to be worth the same amount as the actual game itself. This is why I give the game about a 8/10. If the prices of the DLC's were the same as what I paid for the game (CAD $4.99 during the 2016 Summer Sale) and they had included the option to have control over your sims like in The Sims 2, then I would give this a 10/10.

Summary? Great good, bad DLC prices, 8/10 rating.

This is absolutey One of the BEST games ever created. I know that alot of people do not take this game even closely seriously, and just make goofy looking characters do stupid things for a laugh, and hey, some people like this game that way. I play this game seriously, I put great detail into each one of my created sims, so much so that they hardly fit in with the other sims. I have quite a few DLCS, While not all, I would DEFINATELY Recommend Into the Future and Generations, as those offer ALOT of stuff. If you want different types of people, want to cast spells or be a werewolf, then get supernatural. Get the sims 3 With Pets to save like 10$ on the pets expansion. There are a few DLCS i reccommend that i don't have, those being Ambitions, Showtime, and Late night. This is An amazing game, While there aren't as many mods and things to add to your game as there were in the sims 2, the sims 3 makes up with that with some great new features and most of the main Expansion packs offer WAY more stuff. One downside i saw in this game was the sims 3 store. I don't want to have to Pay extra to get 1 item or 1 house in the game, i would rather have these extra things in the store for free, now that sims 4 has released, i would like to be able to play my game with more things, but sadly, that isn't possible. There are not many things that you can't get just because of sims 3 store though, most of the extra content is in expansion packs, i suggest at least 3 of them with this game, Those Being: Generations, Ambitions, Into the Future. With these, you have a TON of more options, and the other expansion packs offer way more to your game when you get bored. That wraps up this review. I give this game a very honest 10/10 rating, it is one of the few games that really deserves such a high rating, this is a masterpiece. Edit: Get the Bundle that comes with 3 of the expansion packs, it will save you alot of time and money.

If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!

- Serves 4
- 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook
- 325 calories / serving
- Healthy

INGREDIENTS:

- 1 orange, zested and juiced
- 2tbsp soy sauce
- 2tbsp sesame oil
- 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli
- 5cm (2in) piece root ginger
- 1tbsp sunflower oil
- 1 garlic clove, finely sliced
- 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced
- 150g Straight To Wok Noodles
- 400g (13oz) fillet or sirloin steak, cut into thin slices

METHOD

Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.

Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.

Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.

Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the beef and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.

Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the beef to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

The Sims 3 is a very interesting game that can be incredibly tricky to get into.

First off, don't buy all the expansions. If you play the game whilst running every single expansion at once, your performance will tank and there will be so much shit in the game that it will be impossible to play with any kind of focus.
The best way to experience THe Sims 3, in my experience, is to install the Seasons, Ambitions and Generations along with any of the stuff packs that interest you, if any (though most of them aren't worth it.) Your game will still run silky smooth, you'll have loads to do and your sims' lives will be flushed out to the best degree possible without the sheer amount of content becoming overbearing.

I know many people think that EA is cheating them by splitting the game up into 20 some expansions, but it's not meant to be played all at once. It's designed for you to pick the expansions that interest you most, playing with all of them simply isn't possible unless you really enjoy consistent lag spikes.

The game has a lovely sandbox feel to it. You can make a sim that looks like you and see how your children could end up looking 20 generations down the line, or you could make a fat black man with a voice that could break glass named Nethaniel Ticklehack that really enjoys setting other people on fire and sleeping with balding men in his spare time.

While the vanilla game alone can be rather barebones, it's still incredibly fun and worth the buy at the price.

The Sims 3 is the first game I have ever played in the Sims franchise so I do not know if this is one of the best or one of the worst in the series but what I do know is that I have enjoyed every minute of playing so far. The game is basically a family-life simulator where you have to look after however many Sims you want. Anything that can be done in modern day life can also be done on The Sims 3. The main idea of the game is to make your Sim(s) excel at their job(s), give them a beautiful house, give them a partner/family and complete wishes and opportunities that your Sim(s) get but most importantly, to complete their Lifetime Wish. If you are a fan of family-life or games where you have complete control over your life then this is a game you will have many good memories on and will most likely enjoy playing.

Things I liked, the fact that this game is like the real world, in the fact that your sim will age, (unless you turn this off), go to school, or job, and the many ways that sims can die.
     Things I didn't like so much... not much that I didn't like, other than the fact that young adults can't be siblings with teens at LEAST! This enraged me, because if I take a look at me and my little sister, when I'm 20, she'll be only 15! I mean come on! In the real world, sometimes adults have siblings who are like 20 years younger than them. 

     A minute ago I was laughing, but now I'm cringing, at two different, but insanely funny (to me) memories I have of this game. The one that I was laughing about was when I killed all but one sim in my household, and Death must of been exausted, (thanks to me), and after about 1 minute of me waiting, he fell asleep on my bed. This made me laugh so hard my sides hurt!
     About the memory that made me cringe. This time I was being kind to me best friend, and she wanted to play the sims with me. well, we made our sims, and I got up to use the restroom, within 5 minutes, she managed to start a fire. I came back, and she hid my laptop under the couch. I grabed it, and saw that the only sims to survive were hers. Her mistake? She sold our fire alarm. *facepalm*.

Ok my play time doesn't actually show how many hours I've sank into this game just how many I'v accumlated to buy extra content from steam on the cheap. First off your sims 3 codes you buy off Steam now works with EA origins. This is important if you previously own sims packs. Steam makes you buy another copy of the Sims 3 to buy the extra content. Not cool steam its livable. On the good note; during the steam mega sales you can pick up more content for about 4.99 - 9.99. I have all expansions all store content and am missing only one world and a handful of stuff packs. 

In general I love this game. I've owned it since it came out. Purchased most of my content pre-steam and amazed how cheep you can get stuff for now.  I've scored most of the store content by watching adds on EA and about all my content was purchased for free.  Now that steam has its new controller I am slowly migrating my content onto steam. 

This is the only sandbox you will ever play that lets you actually make your own video game in whatever style you want. You download the world creator tool and you have hours of interesting things you can do with your game. Program in story lines and challanges for your sims and you have a whole new game. You have the ability to generate maps and new worlds. You get mod content and the sky is the limit.  Lets face facts the sims 3 is just wierd and its not for everyone. How many games do you know that allow you to have ninjas who work as a perfessional jockeys riding unicorns and only eat tofu cheesesteaks?  

Now for some of the negative reviews I'm reading. I'm running a top of the line graphics card I play the game on highest levels. I do not have the new nvidia pascals. Only a 970. I have no issues at all. Most of the people who are griping do not realize that there internet cache actually plays a roll on how well the game runs when its in online mode. You donot have to use online mode unless your working on showtime achievements or your planning on buying something in game.  All players need to regularly clean out internet explorer even if you don't use internet explorer to maintain a healthy game.  Because it is how the game originally connect to EA. Most of the lagging etc comes from IE beeing the worst of all the browsers and no ability to change this in your code.  Another issue is too many expansion and stuff packs on at one time. While I run all expansions and all my content most pcs are not capable of doing this. EA suggest limiting how many packs if you want quicker load times.  I don't bother because I use a special mod called Overwatch that peserves the integrity of my game by optimizing the game in other ways that EA didn't think of. Mostly by removing lost sims stray horses and animals and cars that your sims careless forget to drive back home to there houses.  This makes the who game run much smoother and keeps the game from becomming currupt do to user neglect/error.  Mods make this game you can find nearly any type of mod you can imagine. I highly recommend anyone who has ever played minecraft or similar games to give this one a try.

Having spent more money on this game than any other - indeed somewhere in excess of fourteen times as most of my purchases I'm - disappointed.  Firstly it has either not crashed at all or only crashed once on a Windows 10 machine with virtually every extra installed (I went for it in last Steam sale).  But...

    1)  The towns now feel completely depopulated.  Particularly difficult in the nightlife city where every second NPC is a celeb and your interactions are limited with them.  Neighbours just don't run or pass by as much, colleagues from work don't come home, and the time clock moves so quickly that you can rarely interact with anyone long enough to have an impact. 
   2)  The moving to real time now messes badly with character development.  In Sims 2 when you left your house time effectively froze so when you came back it was the same time you left, no matter how long you were away.  This enabled you to have 30 - 40 hours in a day - and far easier to get stuff done.  Here it is real time throughout - but punitively slow.    Showering, going to the toilet, and cooking and eating some waffles now takes two hours.  There simply aren't enough hours in the day - even with shortened work hours.
    3)  Building anything is a complete pain in the butt.  In the Sims 2 you'd simply select a lot and then place the pre made building there.  Having a task for my Sim to go to a bar and there not being a bar in my Sim's world (and they can no longer transfer - major downer) I tried to build one. And tried.  And tried.  Even after searching the internet I was no wiser.
    4) Everything is very expensive.  You have to rise high in your career before you can do much more than cover your taxes.
    5)  Loading is even more ponderous than Sims 2 although the spot an object game (flawed) helps the time pass.
    6)  After spending a LARGE amount of money on the game it was disappointing to see so many items still shut off behind a Pay Wall.

    This is not a bad game.  More hours in I might appreciate it more.  But it is A game, no matter how thinly E.A. slice it.  At 75% off in the sale I spent more on Sims 3 than a brand new AAA game.  And it's not as good as Skyrim which I bought for 5.00.  Few games are but still - E.A. charge VERY HEAVILY INDEED for this game.  For the money they are taking this should be an unalloyed joy... and it isn't.

    E.A. seem far more focussed on gouging ever more cash from their customers than giving them great gaming experiences.  After this I wouldn't buy Sims 4 at 90% off.

Don't get me wrong, if you endure these unavoidable and sometimes destructive issues, the game is very addictive.

Cons:

-The game is very simple and doesn't have much to it unless you buy overpriced DLC.

After a hard day of killing zombies, saving the world from alien hordes and ruling a kingdom in a far off fantasy land I like to take it easy for a few hours and see what it would be like to be a normal person. After a few hours of reading a paper, meeting new people, using the toilet, and making myself dinner I feel ready to go back to conquering the galaxy as a xenophobic insectoid race.

Seriously though its a life simulator, if you haven't played Sims before then its one of those games you don't get sweaty palms playing or scream as the monitor because you've died 20 times. A break from the norm and a relaxing game to play for a while. Thumbs up!

Pros: Addicting gameplay full of action and drama
         Satisfying to see your house(hold) build up and become
         even better and larger
         Great maps and lots of features
         And you have a goal, so it's not just the usual "live your life"
         and just repetitive gameplay. It changes, the more you play,
         the more drama, and it gets more exciting the deeper you get
         into it and the choices you make reflect upon you. It makes
         you happy that you did that certain thing.



Cons: In-Game Purchases
          Not having everything and
          having to buy them with "Sim Points" or real money
          DLCS costing the price of the game, and the "Seasons" aspect
          being implemented into a DLC. Honestly the "Seasons" really
          should've came with the game.
          No changing character height. (You only get taller as you age)
          


Overall:
       Overall this is a great game and worth the price, if you really want a DLC,
       do what I did, wait for a discount, but if you can't wait, it is worth the price.
       I would also recommend that you buy this game WITH a DLC Pack, it's only
       10 more dollars, so if you have $30 dollars on you, go for it. Either way
       even without the DLC it's a great game. If I had to rate it out of 10 it would be
       probably a 8.5/10, because they didn't implement those aspects on the base game
       instead, you had to buy the DLC. That is why I took away 1.5 points. The base game
       needed more aspects that were important to the player.

++++First of all: I don't have any of the "The Sims 3"-DLCs. This is a review for the main game and for those who don't know whether they should buy it without DLCs or not.++++++

Short version: 
Buy the game during a sale (not for the full price) if your focus is not on building fancy houses with a lot of different furniture  but on interactions with other sims, career and the "real" gameplay. 

Long version:
I bought the main game - during the summer sale - and got a pretty good game for 9 euros. I have no dlcs because I was not willing to buy the "full gaming experience" for about 130 euros (summer sale price!). 

So, what is good (compared to former sims games)?
+ Nice open world card without loading screens
+ more interpersonal / social / skill features
+ you got a cellphone - you can even take photos with it (what a time to be alive!)
+ game works fluently under windows 10
+ even going to work is now much more interesting as you can decide whether you just wanna hang around at work doing nothing (with the negative consequences) or you can work your butt off to get some goodies

What are the Cons?
- You don't have that much equipment to equip your home
- The first 3 items of each category e.g in the buying mode are things you have to buy in the online store if you want to have it - so you are permanently told what you _could_ get but you don't have 
- The game is from 2009 - from a time where such games had very .... let's call it "interesting" ... graphics... Even the graphics from The "original" Sims weren't that odd. It's edgy and stuff.. just like they tried to be cool (and maybe they were in 2009 but today it seems just odd)

Conclusion:
I really liked the "original" Sims and the Sims 3 somehow reminds me of my first experiences with The Sims (I didn't like The Sims 2 very much even though I had all DLCs). However - the Sims 3 has a open world so you can walk from neighbour to neighbour, from park to fitness center and so on which is quite nice. And don't forget the much more interactions with other people - even if they aren't always that logical, but somehow funny:

- a burglar breaks into your home
- he gets caught by the police because of my Sim's alarm
- my Sim runs panicked into the room where police and burglar are having a huge fight
- the burglar falls in love with my Sim (because f**** you thats why)

As I've said in the short version: buy the game for some bucks (during a sale) - I would not recommend to buy it for the full price - and try it out. But note: If you want to play The Sims 3 only for equipping your home as majestic as f*** than you won't have much fun with the main game because there aren't so many items.

Sims 1: Has OK Graphics (Although crappy when you look at it now), gives you a decent start to a life simulator

Sims 2: Awesome game, Awesome graphics, had more actions and scenes in which made it really better than the first one (And did I mention better graphics?)

Sims 3: More customization to sims (traits favorites, etc), GREAT build mode, online store to buy stuff with Simpoints, has aspects from both Sims 1 and 2 on it (Except for scenes which made Sims 2 really awesome), you can control how long sims live and interact in the city and not have to wait through a loading screen every. freaking. time.

Sims 4: Basically everything up above, but focuses more on your sims body customization and feelings. (You can move body parts around to suit your liking) (Haven't plsyed it to an extent because i only got a free trial on origin)

My rating for this game? Asides from the Sims 2, DEFINITELY A SOLID 10/10 this is basically the best thing that ever happened in pc/console gaming since the sequel.

After trying to get this game working on my PC again for months, and eventually realizing it was an issue with the OS and having to reinstall Windows (a big annoyance that the game couldn't fix the components itself through a reinstall), I can say this is a fun game. There's a lot of things to do, see, and customize in the base game alone, as well as plenty of free mods if you're into that. 

I wasn't around to experience issues at launch or compare it to old Sims games, but for me the gameplay is very good, with only a few small issues (Sims are always getting stuck and saying they can't reach a certain spot, for one). It performs well and has lots of options, both graphically and gameplay-wise. I haven't played the Sims 4, but I hear that game doesn't have some basic features of this game. I think I'll stick with this one for now.

Overall, I'd recommend this, especially when it's on sale.

Sims 3 is a competent life simulation. it's somewhat heavy on the cleaning, homework, bad smells and bad moods for my taste, but that can be modified through programmed in cheat codes, along with money, housing, etc.  

the reason I do NOT recommend the game is because the game constantly pushes the player to buy stuff inside the game for MORE MONEY.  CONSTANTLY.  Any time you add a couch or flower pot to your little sims' house, five much nicer options are presented that you have to pay real money for.  This is very irritating and completely unnecessary. 
Also, the player must purchase DLC for BASIC simulation areas like weather, beach visits, careers, etc.  The whole thing is a pretty annoying money grab.
It's completely annoying that the player spends anywhere from $20 to $60 on a game and the game constantly pesters the player for more money.  
I own many games and DLC that never pester the player for more money.  Sims 3 is VERY unusual in this regard. 
If you buy this game, do NOT spend more money for clothes, furniture, houses, etc.  there are plenty of sites that offer free downloads of stuff that is much better than what is sold inside the game.  Also there are many mods that improve this game for free.

Right now I'm addicted to this game.
The Sims 3 is probably the most fun I've had playing a Steam game since Garry's Mod. 

The gameplay is simple; you create your own Sim, whether it be yourself, a celebrity, one of your best friends, your boss, coworkers, mom, dad; the possibilities are endless. You then buy a house, furnish it, and you are all set. You can even have multiple Sims in your house as well.

This game is basically a life simulator; give birth, nurse a baby, send him/her to school, get a job, grow old, and die. There is a big and blooming mod community, so tons and tons of mods are available to download. The graphics are a bit dated, and the Sims look more like Barbie or Ken dolls, but the gameplay makes up for it.

There are multiple expansion packs, but try to get them on sale because with a Canadian price of $19.99, that is way too much for only minor changes to the game. The expansion packs are only $4.99 CAD now, so try to get them all before the sale ends.

Pros:
+VERY addicting
+Mods
+Seeing what your Sims do, how their kids do in school
+Easy-to-use interface
+Lots of expansion packs
+Realistic animations

Cons:
-Expansion packs cost way too much money, Into the Future for $39.99?
-The fact it's an EA game
-Graphics look dated, especially clothes, they look pixelated and murky
-The fact Sims do whatever they want, regardless of your control

Overall, extremely fun game, and you will probably get hooked. I say buy this for full price, but if you find it on sale, get it then. :)

Come one, come all!  Come see the Sims!  Make your own based on yourself, your family, your best friends, your worst enemies!  And that's not all: create your dream home!  Put in and around it whatever you like, including a pool, garden gnomes, a telescope, and a teleportation pad!  But don't just stay at home, go out and see the town: visit the beach, catch a movie, purchase a book from the bookstore.  Achieve your dream! Become a famous athlete, a renowned author, a prestigious composer, or the most popular politician!  All this is possible in The Sims 3!

Well, the intro up there pretty muched summed up what you can do in The Sims: just about anything!  If there's anything I missed it's mostly from dlc that includes pets, college, and more items (not sure whats in every dlc).  That being said, I have a lot of fun playing this game, basing sims on myself, family, and friends as mentioned above (none based on enemies yet).  I find myself playing for hours on end, losing track of time, planning to play for an hour or two then finding I've played for 5!  Always trying to increase skills, become friends with one more person, finish upgrading that one item-one can lose themselves!

If there were any flaws, they'd be in the some aspects of the game that aren't explained very well in the Lessons.  Though for the most part, those are few and far between.  Recommend if you have an imagination, like to create, like to have fun.

Story of Craig Adams:

Craig was a simple man. He had no life, no job, no girl and no family. He didn't realise his loneliness but one day, he became controlled by a mysterious person called "The Player". Craig was scared, the player started changing his personality and clothing. The player said "I'm gonna make you a success". Craig was excited and he soon found a job after playing CoD. After his first day he met a girl who he got on pretty well with until he found out she was married and Craig beat her up (because of the player). Craig met another girl and they became good friends. Eventually Craig invited her over and that's when things went to the extreme. Craig lost his virginity and became a father. After that, his girlfriend had a baby girl and Craig had his birthday. Craig and the player knew that he needed to get married so Craig asked his girlfriend on a date and proposed. The wedding was only two minutes and Craig had a family. As one last goodbye, Craig thanked the player and lived his life. Craig is now dead. The end.

Honestly, the only thing I wish this game did was give the player the ability to build homes without having to first create a household. Design and architecture are things that really interest me, and I love creating and designing houses, but it's tedious to have to first build Sims. Sure, I could speed through that process by choosing Randomize, but I would still have to wait through at least two long loading screens. I wish this wasn't necessary. Sometimes, I just want to build a house.

Other than that, I like Sims 3 better than Sims 4. Sims 3 is pretty straight-forward for a new player to get into and there is a good deal of DLC that sometimes is very inexpensive (note: always wait for the sales; $20 for a single DLC for a game that's nearly ten years old is kind of ridiculous) that add a lot to the game.

I can't believe what a microtransaction wasteland this game has become, I spend 6 on this game to be told "LOOK AT ALL THIS STUFF YOU DON'T HAVE" and have it dangled in front of me whenever I'm creating a family, buying items for my home and building stuff.

I do think the price is a pretty good deal for the amount of time you'll get out of it, but the base game is genuinely just showing you all this stuff you should buy, and it honestly gets extremely annoying. It's not really what I remember when I first started playing it, sure, it's the same game, but it's so full of "LOOK AT THIS ITEM FOR 200 CREDITS"

Also if you want all the expansions you'll have to part with a LOT of money, Sims is definitely one of my favourite franchises of all time, but the old ones didn't throw DLC in your face, sure, there was a metric f*ckton of expansions that you CAN buy, but it wasn't plastered all over the game. Honestly, the game is great, the DLC isn't.

The Sims 3 Is a great game. It's a roleplay where you control your Sims to do everyday chores and activities. You create or choose a household, and play through the household. It can be a little glitchy, but that might be because my computer is running low on disk space. I got the Pets add on along with the game, so I will also include a bit about the Pets DLC. In the Pets DLC you can add a dog, cat, or horse into your household. You can also adopt one In-game. You can also find a unicorn and find a way to adopt it. You play as the pet and some of the mood bars might have changed to something like scratch or thirst (which I personally think should be for Sims as well. I also have a FEW cheat codes in a thanks for reading :) to activate them press L Shift, Ctrl and the C key at the same time. There will be a bar at the top of the screen that shows what you type. The codes are like passwords and are CAPS SENSITIVE! Here are the codes :
Motherlode = 50,000 Simoleons

testingcheatsenabled True = you can press shift an click on a sim and pretty m uch any object and have special options, click and drag on the social or any other mood bar thingy, and even on relationship bars, to lower or increase it

familyFunds :insert last name here without colons: :insert money amount without colons: = pretty much UNLIMITED MONEY.

Instead of writing a big paragraph it will be easier to just make a list of the things I do and don't like about The Sims 3 :D

Things I like about The Sims 3 -
- The fact that you can custamise clothes and furniture
- You can age up sims before they are due to age up e.g. you can make a baby a toddler staight away
- You can make new outfits for sims who are aged as a child or older whilst playing the game
- The sims look much more lifelike
- You can get your sims to brush their teeth
- You can name teddy bears and goldfish 

Things I don't like about The Sims 3 -
- You can only play one family
- The option to pay actual money for furniture shouldn't exist especially with how expensive expansion packs are..
- There's been a random guy standing outside my sims house for a few days..
- You have the option to follow your sim to work, school or to give birth at the hospital but you can't go inside..

10 out of 10 would Sims again.

There's a lot of customization, so if you're dedicated enough, you can create almost anything or anyone. (With some limits of course) The game goes on for eternity, and when you toss in all the DLC and/or custom content to this life simulation stew, it's almost impossible to get bored with. Of course there's the bugs, and sometime the game can run kinda badly (depending on how great your computer is) but those are usually fixable. It's wellmade with an overwhelming bundle of stuff and fun additions... if you're willing to pay the same price of the game for DLC. The Sims 3 is the next sensible step of development for the The Sims series, namely the open world feature. It's a great concept, but some people may find this game incredibly laggy. I personally haven't had issues with it, maybe the occasional crash, but other users have reported serious lag. All I can say is check the specs; don't chance it is doesn't meet minimum requirements. The Sim customisation and traits is great and adds a lot to the gameplay, but I've always found that the Sims look a bit weird, and the game has lost some of its charm compared to The Sims 2. Not to mention, EA love a good cash grab, so the normal price is a bit steep- definitely grab it when it's on sale. Also another to keep an eye out for is the Story Progession is broken. You can get mods, and I'd recommend NRaas' mods, but there's a chance it can seriously slow the game down. Overall, I've never had any problems with this game, but definitely get it cheap.

You can do anything.

Want to have a polygamist family? Want to roll around in money? Want to travel to Egypt, steal treasure from tombs, and have an affair? 

With Sims 3, you can. If you only have the base game and none of the DLC's, you can easily get mods for the game that will add an endless amount of things: instant money, incest, custom jobs, etc. With Sims you [i]can[/i] have the character live the life you imagine for them. 

 Relationships.

This is by far why I've played Sims 3 for as many hours as I've had. In Sims 3 you can find a boyfriend, marry him, cheat with his brother, and divorce - all in the same day. Sims 3 doesn't have morals and doesn't want you to have them either. 

For that reason, you can cheat as much as you want, have as many kids as you want, or embrace the single, celebrity rockstar life. If you want to have an arch nemesis and revel in kicking their trash can, you can. 

Or you can be the seemly modest grandmother who writes erotic tales at night and takes care of her grandchildren, plays chess with her husband at the park, and bask in your retirement during the day. 

 Everything is up to you.

From the design of the house to the look of your Sim to their likes and dislikes, you control anything and everything. You aren't limited in any area for even their needs you can control. If you use a cheat code, you can easily make their needs (hunger, sleep, etc) to 100% meaqning you'll have more time to focus on the fun aspects of their life. 

With Sims, the character is entirely in your hands. 

 This game lags.

A lot. It's known for crashing without warning, freezing at any vital moment, and can be quite fussy to run. I've learned that when you first launch the game - DON'T DO ANYTHING. Just let it play through the cutscene and go to the main menu. Don't try to skip it, don't try to rush it.

The same goes for when it freezes and lags. 

Otherwise it's going to sulk and quit on you just when your Sim becomes famous or is about to have their baby. 

 The base designs are...bleh.

I used to think they were amazing - the blocky hair, the ill fitting clothes, the ugly looking earrings. However once I discovered the world of mods, I learned how awful the base items are. Unfortunately installing too many mods can severely lag your game - so you'll have to be strict about which ones are worth keeping and which aren't. 

 There are bugs.

A lot of them. University can cause errors with assigning you to "study" when you aren't enrolled in school, a Sim that is aging up can end up with their bones disjointed and their head all stretched, your Sim can decide they can't walk forwards because dust is in their way, etc. 

Overall the Sims 3 is by far the most beloved of all the games I've ever played, aside from Harvest Moon, and is a MUST play. Absolutely amazing as a simulator/choice game.

The game is very entertaining and very enjoyable, and despite that there is already the fourth sim game, this game still is quite so much fun to play. If you're ever a sim fans in the past you just need to get this one, the game is so much fun to play with mods a couple of expansion pack make the game further increasing the fun.

I own nearly all expansions and had a lot of fun playing The Sims 3. At first I did not think a lot about the game breaking features others were complaining about. From time to time the game kept slowing down (resetting your Sim or all Sims helped at first), a few save files were corrupted, loading times were very loooooong. 

But now the only thing I can do is  start a new game on a at max medium sized map and play for about 1-2 hours before the games frezees (without some mods even this would not be possible), which is only "interrupted" every 3-5 minutes by a few seconds of action.  

These game breaking features have been mentioned time and again after initial rlease, nothing has changed. As mentioned above, I had fun playing The Sims 3, but this was in no way woth the couple of 100,- $ spent in total. 

There is no justification for a non working product like The Sims 3 to be sold to customers - NONE! 

But there is still hope as EA finally released a patch: The Sims 4

[h1]My thoughts on The Sims 3[/h1]

[h1]The Port[/h1]

The port is a very interesting one. The options menu is very buggy with the settings sometimes resetting to default as well as sound options taking a bit to actually change or just straight up not changing at all. The video options are varied and nice as well as descriptive but not very informative in terms of certain options, such as edge smoothing, as well as there being no settings for keybinds or mouse sensitivity, besides mouse inverting. Overall the port isn't bad besides some awkward Windows 10 support and performance related issues.

[h1]The Graphics/Performance[/h1]

The graphics for the game are not the greatest with low res foliage, decent at best textures, awkward lighting and some rather bad modeling. That being said this game was from 2010, was completely open world and obviously needed to compensate for what it was offering. The performance on the other hand is very not good. Actually running the game is absolutly not problem it's very easy to max out the game on even some low end systems but the game is an absolute stuttery mess, even on lower settings. Many people have reported lots of stuttering on high end and low end systems alike. It's a big problem with the game that I can't let slip. It's not very stable at all with its performance

[h1]The Story/Atmosphere/Characters[/h1]

Non-existant story but the atmosphere of being in a lively environment is very much there but that's all I have to say. I can't really comment on the characters all that much.

[h1]The Controls[/h1]

Direct mouse control with keybinds for camera movement and some menu controls. Besides a feeling of mouse acceleration nothing to really say about this.

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay is absolutely phenomenal. This is an amazing life simulation game that really feels like you're taking part in, and leading, someone and really being that person. The animation system is absolutely fantastic, besides some bad animation transition, the character interaction is complex and unique and the game as a whole is extremely well done. The AI is a bit stupid and not very good but I can excuse that for how good the rest of this game is. The characted customization is the best I've ever seen, besides maybe Black Dessert Online, with in depth characted facial construction and amazing clothing customization, with the option of creating your own clothing. The only fault is the lack of hair-styles, facial hair, hats and the really crappy body hair and tattoo options but those can be excused.

[h1]The Conclusion[/h1]

This game is a fantastic game with many flaws but I would no doubt recommend this to anyone looking for a good simulation game to throw on to waste some time. Not to mention it's one of the good EA games that are on Steam so there's a major plus.

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]

[b][i]Port - 7.5/10
Graphics - 6/10
Performance - 3.5/10
Story - *no rating*/10
Atmosphere - 9.5/10
Characters - *no rating*/10
Controls - 8/10
Gameplay - 10/10
AI - 6.5/10

Average Rating - 7/10

Actual Rating - 9/10

As far as Sims franchise goes, this was by far the most impressive with the interface and abilities that you had in your arsenal.  What impresses me the most is how indepth you can make not only your sim, but their house too.  The DLC as usual was woefully bought, but enhanced the game to greater depths than the base game could have ever achieved.  With this being said though, the Sims themselves are only ever so slightly smarter in their world, they still need much care and attention( which for me who likes to only build dream homes, finds quite frustrating when all my sim wants to do is eat and watch tv..............sounds a lot like me on the weeks) Never mind that last comment.  The worlds are fun to explore and the challenges in caves and quests keep the game alive a new.  So in all i feel that even though The Sims4 has a better handle on the actual day to day lives of your sims, the the Sims3 is still truely the better game.

Been playing The Sims 3 for two weeks now. I played it two times with the same customized household. Only because the first save was deleted when I reformatted my laptop, so I have to repeat it ALL OVER again. (Imagine my patience.) 

My findings:
- game still crashes even after it's reformatted, even if I followed all the troubleshooting steps mentioned on both Steam and The Sims 3 forums
- still end up getting my data corrupted after leaving The Sims University and going home, even after I followed all the do's and don'ts of what should be done before and after graduating

The second one I mentioned above, seems to happen after my Sims get their second degree. Their lifetime wish is to be a Major Master (three degrees). 

My work around for this is: once they got graded and affirmed that they passed their degrees, I save them as a new household. Then, I move that new household to a house in town, and playing it as a new game. I haven't gone past that. Meaning, I haven't explored any other glitches after that.

Because I didn't play the game for a day now due to the sadness of loosing their friends. They still have all their money, items, skills, and degrees. But they lose their friends, which takes time to build!

I say, don't get too attached playing the game.

But why not? I loved The Sims and The Sims 2. It's addicting that I don't even recall the last time I ate or took a bath. But, well, if you want to play the game, you should:

= be okay with it crashing sometimes, then talking at your computer, praying for it to work continuously this time.
= still love the game even after the number of times that you tried to troubleshoot some glitches.
= be patient if you end up having your data corrupted by some unknown game force.
= still love the game even after you've read thousands of threads and comments about game bugs, glitches, and all that stuff that you didn't know and researched before... because you just really really want to play the game.

I'll finish this review, and play it again. I have to. They still need to have a job and a family and all the blahblah that this game satisfies my mundane life.

..are there any actual serious reviews for this game? Eh. Here I go.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
- DLCs are all the same price- some bring some lackluster minor content, while others bring a whole new game. It depends on the DLC- oh, and not to mention, the game is basically worthless without the Pets DLC. At least, in my personal opinion it is. The only reason I'm not playing the Sims 4 is because there is no Sims 4: Pets released.
- After a certain amount of time, the game lags and freezes up. Sims get stuck on things, and if you can't find out who they are and do the required 'resetSim [firstname] [lastname]' cheat, it'll move at a snail's pace on even the best computer.
- EVEN AFTER YOU MUTE THE DAMN MUSIC, IT STILL BLASTS YOUR EARS EVEN WHEN YOUR VOLUME IS SET TO 10/100. Chill. Music. Music needs to chill, and this bug despartly needs to be fixed. DESPARTLY. Please. Ow. My ears. They are bleeding.
- No, but seriously. There is something wrong with the volume settings. They do not work. At all. The game still blasts your ears.
- Did I mention loading screens? ..No? Well, be prepared to meet them. For thirty minutes at time. Every time you change towns. Every time you go to university. Every time you go to visit china to try to find that stupid thing you can destory bolders with but you NEVER KNOW WHAT IT IS EVEN AFTER HOURS OF PLAYIN--

[h1]NEUTRALS[/h1]
= I.. umh. Limited customization options for the pets? Also, if you give your sims high free will they will do nothing but stuff the dog's face full of treats or spam pet the horse. It never ends. N E V E R.
= DLC's are needed to make the game interesting if you aren't doing challenges. Some things should just have been added to the game since they're so minor. Also, where are the patches? No? They've moved onto the Sims 4 without fixing some of these major bugs the game has had since day one? Oh? Really? That's okay. Toootttalllyyy okay.
= Aliens, no. Nobody asked for you. Stop abducting my Sims while I'm trying to spam level my Logic skill to get a promotion. Stop.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
+ What the sims is known for: CUSTOMIZATION. You can make your sims as realistic as you want, as crazy as you want, as stupid-looking as you want, as insane as you want, as perfect as you want, as.. well, nearly anything that you want. It's one of the game's core features- to grow and develope the family you have produced over many hours of hardships and learning, only to have things set back or your only sim killed by a meterorite in the lands of China. Yes, that actually happened. Not fun. Not. Fun. Otherwise was okay!
+ Random things. You may only start out with one town and you DO need the DLC's to do most of the interesting things, but otherwise it's pretty grand. If you get the DLCs, say, one every four months, the game actually has a long lifespan. Try to go for 'Generations,' 'Pets,' or 'World Adventures' first. Those are just my personal reccomendations- not even I have all of them yet. Someday. Someday...
+Traits and interactions are fun, and can cause a few good laughs every now and then. Yes, it can be unrealistic- you can get married the same day you enter a steady relationship with someone- but really, it's the Sims. What else do you expect?
+ There's mods for.. just about anything. This game has been modded to hell and back. Plus, on top of that, the amount of challenges this game has(see '100 Baby Challenge,' it's one of the most common ones) causes replayability. Just remember to save! 
+ You can bribe Death with a flower.
+ Unlucky sims are basically immortal- they cannot die from any way other than natural causes.
+ Did I hear genertics and hidden traits, anyone?
+ I'm going to add more later, but this is a good game. If you haven't played it already, or seen a video on it.. I'm so, so sorry for whatever rock you've lived under.

Good game. It's fun to mess around with the town and people and there's lots to do.

Buy with actual cash to upgrade and unlock other aspects of the game, it's littered with extra DLC  available purchases that makes me wish the entire game was bundled rather than simply buy the main vanilla game, then have all this other stuff at a premium price.

---

Pros:

- Game play was fun

- Easy to understand

- Little learning curve

- Can spend hours playing

Cons:

- All the extra DLC stuff makes my mouth water, but too pricey as hell

- Interface can be overwhelming sometimes

- Time consuming (good or bad thing)

- Can begin to feel like a grind game fast

---

Conclusion: 

It's a decent game, good graphics, re-playablilty which is huge for myself personally, and you can get a lot of fun hours out of this game, though it tends to feel like a grind after a while. A lot of other aspects of this game I would really like to try out, but it's all pay to play, which makes me sour right off the bat. 

All in all I would rank this game at about: 5.5/10

Having to re-review this now, given a few years of play. 

A Solid State Drive is a must for this game, else the load times are just too long. It's gradually matured from a, well, bit of an empty shell, into a fully fledged game, which I suppose is how any game in The Sims series tends to go. 

I still lament the loss of player-buildable "downtown" areas. Yes there are some, but most are now "rabbitholes" that your sim dissappears into and interacts with via the right click menu, rather than directly. I liked designing restaurants, clubs etc. Ah well. 

The new features are welcome however, such as the design a style feature. Almost infinite customisation, which means I can design different style interiors rather than always resorting to the same two or three sets of furniture or wallpapers. 

All in all, pretty good.

In short, its a fun game if you get a few expansion packs to go along with it. However it, and the expansion packs are so ludicrously expensive that you shouldn't buy all of them, or too many even at a discount. Sims 4 has been out a while, but 3 is only marginally less advanced, so in terms of price/quality (and drm-idiocy) this is imo the better choice if you want a Sims game.
I will always have a place for Sims in my gaming heart. Love this game to pieces.

The Sims 3 is a great game. Many people will say that The Sims 2 or The Sims 4 is better. The Sims 3 is the best Sims game because it has open world. I can't imagine a Sims game without open world. Open world allows you to travel to anywhere in the town. After the initial two-three loading screens, the only loading screens you'll encounter are when you use a mirror to change appearance, a dresser to plan outfit, or if you move, and even then these loading screens are quite short. You can customize your Sims fully, with all of the basics and many more clothing, accessories, hairstyles, and outfits available. Whatever you don't have, you can most likely get from The Sims Store, which you need an account for. You use your money to gain SimPoints, the currency used. While The Sims Store is overpriced and it will cost hundreds of dollars to buy all of the items, if you want to make an emo Sim, you will be able to buy all of the emo clothes, haircuts, and furniture without spending too much money.


Enough about The Sims Store. The Sims 3 is great because of the endless possibilities. You can have an amazing variety of Sims, all with different personalities (which are fully customizable,) careers, houses, families, and Lifetime Wishes. The game runs very smoothly on my computer. There are also Skills and Opportunities, somewhat similar to real life. Opportunities will randomly be presented to you, with a brief description of the Opportunity, usually with some humour added in too. Opportunities often require you to do something in exchange for a reward. You may have to visit certain areas, fix broken objects, make food for certain establishments or Sims, or stay in late after work ends. Rewards vary, and may include better relationships with co-workers, bosses, or other Sims, job or school performance, Simoleons (in-game money,) or Skill gain. Opportunities often have a deadline. Skills are like skills in real life. Skills include Writing (typing), Painting, Gardening, Cooking, Handiness, Charisma, and many more. You can build Skills by practicing, which is different for each Skill, or by doing tasks that improve that Skill, as each Skill is useful for a specific task. You can also build Skills by reading books, watching TV channels, learning from other Sims or by having certain Traits.


Overall, The Sims 3 is a good game that has unlimited replayability. It has its cons, however. The same old Sims get boring quickly, as Sunset Valley, the town that comes with the game, always has the same Sims when it is first started. However, the starting Sim's babies and descendants can vary. By creating an account, you get another town for free. A few other cons are that in a household of 8 (the maximum amount) Sims, it is really hard to have fun. You are constantly taking care of their Needs, which are Hunger, Bladder, Hygiene, Fun, Social, and Energy, and the rest of the time you are building Skills or Relationships, or improving job performance. Also, the stuff packs and expansion packs don't add very much, and are overpriced. The Sims Store is also overpriced.

Ah Sims 3, I had purchased this game around 2-3 years ago (As of 1/22/16) on disk and didn't play an insane amount of hours in that timeframe (Maybe 20 hours at the most) but I still did enjoy my experience. Fast forward to the steam winter sale, by this time I had already lost my disc somewhere in the depths of my closet. The game was only 6$ and I decided to purchase, AND FFS I DID NOT REGRET IT. On to what the game has to offer
GRAPHICS
Graphics wise Sims 3 is not impressive, the game is pretty old as it is. Nothing really special about those graphics. If you looked close enough you might be able to see the pixels. The few water sources that there are in the game the water effect is really trippy and ugly. Hope your not one of those graphics only matter people because you'll hate this game for eternity.
6.5/10
GAMEPLAY
The Sims 3 is a life simulator and well it does a great job of being so. The game mainly consists of doing well whatever you like! When you first start up the game you create youre character and pick his traits and 'Lifetime Wish" which you try to complete during youre lifetime. Quick Tip; If you don't wanna worry about dying of age, go ahead and go to Options and turn aging off. After that you pick a starter home and you start youre great life journey. My character is a weird hybrid of an artist/painter/gardener/athlete who never leaves his house, but what you make of youre Sim is all up to you. I love the gameplay and it's amazing.
10/10
REPLAY VALUE
There's not much to say here, IT'S HUGE. You can play this game over and over and over again and never get bored of it. Oh and if you do get bored of it there's a LOAD of DLC you can get (20$ each DLC). Maybe the DLC is a bad thing but it really adds a ton of new features. Like one DLC is Back to the Future themed, while another is a Paradise island theme, really the DLC'S add a ton of depth into this game.
9/10
Story
Well you sorta make your own story with this game, I will not score it.
Audio
The sims have there own weird language that they speak in. It's really interesting. The music gets INSANELY repetitive and got on my nerves quite fast. The rest of this games sound effects are mediocre and nothing to get hyped about.
7/10
TL;DR
Sims 3 is definitely worth a buy if you're interested in simulation games and a game that aged well and has lots of replay value. Though the sound effects and graphics aren't good at all.
OVERALL SCORE
8.2/10
+Lots of replay value
+Very Good gameplay
+Aged well
~Lots of DLC, though they add quite a lot to the game
-Bland graphics
-Bad audio

So, I made a married couple, set them out with loads of money, totes no cheats (does 'familyfunds' asparagus 75000000' count as cheats?), and started with some skills, while waiting for their first day of work. Suddenly, they both wish for a first child. "Fine. I'll just spend a few thousand to make an awesome bedroom for this wonderful kid", I said to myself. So I did. I let them try for baby. After a few seconds, nothing. The next morning, nothing. No child. They were unsuccesful. So I made them try again the next night. Again, nothing. I start gathering some lifetime hapiness on both of them, to invest in the fertility trait, while trying again every night. Each night, nothing! This was becoming a joke. Finally, I get the fertility trait for each of them, and they prove succesful. 1 child. 

5/7
- Blood, sweat and tears required for 1 kid.

Just kidding, there's more. 
I let the baby be born, while making sure it lives the best life it can (which is almost literally nothing), and it became a toddler. Awesome. Trained it to shit, walk, and talk as quick as I could, and made it the happiest kid ever. Finally the time comes for this kids birthday. It was the transition from toddler to child. I couldn't wait. I had a party room set up, music pumping, varieties of food, a birthday cake, many different activities to make this the best party ever. I even adopted a puppy, as this childs 'birthday present'. I was stoked! Everyone arrives, everyone has a great time, and then I decide to make it cake time. Everyone gathers, as the toddler blows out the candles, and everyone spins those spinny things and cheers. Those moments felt like minutes waiting for this awesome kid to grow. He did. Everyone cheered, and everyone went for cake. This is when everything turned to shit. Like, not normal shit, "shit" shit. Anyway, About halfway through my new child's cake, is when one of the guests stepped up, and died. Of old age. She died, right there, at the kids birthday party. Right there at the dining table. Everyone freaks out. Then, someone else dies. Old age again. I stared at my horrified sims, and thought, "Damn, EA". As everyone gets up to mourn, a third sim dies. OId age yet again.


10/10 Would go to loads of trouble to have one child live an awesome life, to have it ruined by 3 stubborn old people who decided to die at the kids birthday.

I created a sim family consisting of one ugly, mean old lady and 7 absolute a-holes who constantly squeal and annoy her. I wanted to see if this would push her to the brink of insanity and this is what I found:

Day 1: Lady moves in with roomates. Everyone seems to be happy.
Day 2: Roomates get in fight with each other; woman remains unaffected.
Day 3: Maid service is hired. Woman gets in fight with roomates.
Day 4: Woman gets in fight with maid. Woman gets in fight with roomates.
Day 5: Roomates are moving out, woman unemployed and repo man is taking their furniture. Maid no longer shows up.
Day 6: Woman cannot feed her family; everyone starts slowly dying of hunger.
Day 7: 2 people are dead from starvation. The rest are on the brink of death. 
Day 8: All roomates are now dead. Woman is the last one to die.
Day 9: A new family moves in; a woman and 7 roomates. They walk into the house only to be greeted by 8 urns.

10/10

Regardless of how I may enjoy the game in the near future when I finally get it to work, EA is a piece of shit for making the Sims a so expensive title after a shitload of years. The only reason I bought it is that I don't bother with downloading pirated copies anymore and the game was on 'sale'. 

Anyway apart from the absurd pricing (not even AAA titles released around 2009 still cost this much) the DLC grab is the worst I've ever seen (compared to it Payday 2 and Rome Total War II shine for their decency) and the game is so incomplete without any of them that you will have to purchase at least one, or get a cracked copy of it.

Finally the only reason I'm wasting my time writing this, really, is that as I mentioned above the game doesn't work properly. Compatibility problems with W7 and 8 are massive and the troubleshooting required is at times just too much. I've been able to play some 4 hours and after relaunching the game everything turned wrong. First the costant crashing every 10 minutes, then every 5 and finally the freezing (every 2 or so). I tried to update again my gpu drivers only to find out the game does not recognise it and pick the built in intel card (playing on a laptop). Not saying the game will never work, but like Bethesda did with FO3 a label stating there are issues with newer systems and graphic cards should be added to the store page.

I always been a huge fan of the Sims since the first game. I had all expansions of Sims 1 and 2. I bought all expansions of Sims 3 during 2015 holiday sale.

I'm very impressed with the game. It's an amazing one. What I dislike the most are the huge and boring loading times even with a computer that is overpowered compared to the requirements of the game. That's kind of annoying. But I like the 'open world' thingy. Wish they could have optimized better so it's less laggy and less long when we have loading screens. That's probably another busted work by EA sadly.

Overall, this game is lot of fun. It's very first time I have fun making the Sims live. In previous game, I was mainly building house and making beautiful neighborhood. In this game, I enjoy making my Sims live their life a bit more. 

I would recommend this game to any fans of the Sims that are patient enough for long boring loading screens.

A great life simulator, however having been developed by EA there is, of course a sort of money grab to it. Unlike what some people seem to think, the base game is the full game with all the bits and pieces.  The DLC (while many and costly) is only EXTRA stuff that influences some parts of the game such as having pets and being able to be vampire, etc. Base game is great and highly recommended especially if you enjoyed previous Sims titles. If there is any of the DLC you want however, wait for it to go on sale such as during Steam's winter sale as it makes them a lot better priced. Following this strategy your getting one of if not the best Sims games for a fraction of what EA (and Origin) would make you pay for it. Save yourself some funds and research the DLC and only get the ones that add content you actually want. Finally prepare to chuckle at random times because of the way Sims communicate.

I've been playing since the first Sims for PC (still loaded on some of my computers), and this is the best version I've played yet. It is hours of entertainment even without any expansion packs. However, the x-pacs are probably the best part, as they really do expand the entire scope of the game - not just add new content. For example, Ambitions adds tons of new careers and lets you go to work with your Sim.

You can sign-up to the official site for free content, free SimPoints for daily deals and other content, and more. You can watch ads on the site for more SimPoints or purchase them outright. You can even design your own creations and offer them in the Exchange, as well as download other players' content for our game. On Halloween, they gave out free holiday content.

I have greatly enjoyed playing the Sims 3, from creating pleasing homes for my sims to building their careers and families. In the Sims 3, the story for your characters can be as simple or complex as you want to make it. And, although I have moved on to The Sims 4, I still like to dust off my favorite families and play them from time to time. 

When I first started playing, I wasn't sure how well I would like it, despite the glowing recommendations of friends. The more I delved into it, though, the more I liked it! That said, simulation games aren't everyone's cup of tea, so if you're in doubt about whether you'd like it, I definitely recommend buying it on sale.
