This game is extremely fun and addicitive, no doubt about it. There are lots of possibilities, and even when you've figured out the perfect strategy to have a successful sim it's still fun.
Between all of the reviews, the biggest complaint I've seen is the absurd amount of DLC, all of which you have to buy. The thing is, as crazy as it sounds, [i]you don't have to buy all of it[/i]. Some of the DLC is objectively not worth it, and doesn't add enough to the game to warrant spending even a penny on it. But other expansions add a lot of gameplay, and are very much worth the price.
I personally bought two DLC packs, spending 50 dollars on the game total, and I've spent almost 200 hours and counting on this game. I spent more on games I played for only 2 hours.
So overall, I highly recommend this game. I also recommend doing a bit of research beforehand, and buying a DLC or two that you think would add the most to the game. For 50 or 60 dollars, I'd say this game is totally worth it.

I've played Sims for so long now and I've played it on xbox, PSP, xbox 360, mobile and now on PC. It's one of my favorite games for several reasons. I will list the pros and cons of my overall gameplay experience below.

PROS:
-The requirements to play The Sims 3 are very low
-You basically have full control of the Sims, which ofc is limited to the features of the game
-There are optional expansion packs available to, well, expand your features
-The Exchange provides additional (and free) downloadable content that are made from other players
-Funny stuff happens while playing
-Basically an endless amount of fun! (aka it has good replay value)
-Get creative with it, no gameplay can be exactly the same because different scenarios happen

CONS:
-The expansion packs are pricey and sometimes don't even add too much to the game
-My Sims has glitched out a few times when trying to socialize with a huge group of Sims (it might just happen to me though)

EDIT: After going back and re-reading my review I noticed that it was more of a DLC rant than review of the Sims 3. I will now attempt to rectify that. For more on the game, go to the paragraph that starts with "Gameplay:".

Let's establish the difference between "Expansion Packs" and "DLC"

Expansion Packs are like mini sequals to games. They add new features and expand upon the old ones. An example of a Sims 3 Expansion Pack would be World Adventures or Island Paradice. These two added signifigant ammounts of content to the game, as well as add new features like treasure hunting, and exploring, as well as adding new areas and features to base game items, such as the training dummy, and board splitter.

DLC is usually much smaller than an expansion pack in that the ammount of content added is neglegable to the overall experience of the game. This can be seen in things like texture packs, or more specifically to the Sims 3, "Stuff Packs". Or the cutting of features such as the ability to make your own towns, and replacing that with the ability to buy more (non customizable) Pre-made towns.

*Just making the quick note that while you can still create custom towns for the Sims 3, it has been made a far more tiedious process, requireing you to download a seperate program with a less user friendly interface, as opposed to the town creation system used by the Simes 2.

In short, Expansion Packs are reasonably priced additions that improve the overall quality of the game, while DLC is a form of nickel and dimeing justified by the additions of insignifigant content, and should never be the same price as an expansion pack, or full game.

Gameplay: The Sims 3 does not make any great bounds in inovation from the Sims 2 (The sims are a bit smarter, they won't drown if you take the ladder out of a pool now). It's still the same Point & Click style "God Simulator" where you can create your own sims (less customization options for vanilla, more added with each expansion pack), create your own house or customize a pre-made one. (While there is decent variety in furnishings etc. the developers still push the microtransactions with an in-game "Sim Points" store, and DLC page).

You can still do (more or less) all the same things you could do with your sims from previous games, go to school, take several different carear/job paths (more interesting options with DLC), go to university (DLC), get married and start a family (streamlined without DLC), or even more outlandish things like go to the future (DLC), go live on an island with mermaids (DLC) Become a fantasy creature, things from fairies, werewolves, etc (DLC). Become a preformer (Limited options without DLC). 

You can also controll the longevity of your sims. Change the lifespan of a sim from 30 days to 1000, your choice.

The game is owned by EA. EA has it's own gaming platform (Origin), since EA has it's own platform, it doesn't bother to optimize or patch any of it's steam variants (See Sims Medieval). So if you wan't to play this you're going to have to use Origin (same with any game made by EA really.)

The Sims 3 is a really awesome game. This is nearly an accepted fact, of course, because everyone loves The Sims. I'm sure that there are plent of other reviews that will tell you all about that, though. This review here is a cautionary tale, though most of you likely won't need it.
There are those of you, however, who won't consider ahead of time what a money-suck this game will end up being. Do not be ashamed to admit this, I myself have this problem.
You see, I'm a broke college student. Living off about $200 a month for food, I have a very bad habit of just not eating for days on end so that I can buy video games instead. The Sims 3 was the first game I bought on Steam. Prior to that, I was a dreaded Xbox gamer.
I bought the base game + pets for 29.99. Let's round that up to $30, remembering that I suck at math. That's our first number. 30.
I bought The Sims 3, rather than waiting just a few weeks for The Sims 4 to come out, because I have no impulse control whatsoever, and thought I'd save money by buying an older game. Perhaps I did initially save money. This, however, went down the toilet after six more DLCs, at 19.99 each. Round up to the nearest whole and our second through seventh numbers are each 20. For simplicity's sake, let's just multiply that out now to $120.
But wait, there's more (there always is): The Sims does this darling little thing where it shows you all of these awesome items and worlds and stuff that you can buy with points, or whatever they're called. I don't remember at this point. Now, I know that I spent at least $50 on these, not all at once, but over time. There was some cool stuff offered, and I like cool stuff.
If we add all of our lovely numbers together, we get $200, though without rounding, I suppose, it would be $199.93. This, however, is a very low guesstimate, due to the points I purchased. Keep in mind that The Sims 3 was not at all new by the time that I spent all this money.
This is entirely my own fault, of course. And I do take responsibility for it. However, with 7 total DLCs (world adventures and into the future likely causing the bulk of the issues), my game was unable to run after a while. It now crashes inenvitably after just ten minutes or so of play. These DLCs are HUGE, and to anyone who plans on buying them, it is important to remember that you really need to choose which ones you really want, they do put a strain on your system.
I actually bought the game thinking that it would be easy for my computer to run, since it was all sandboxy and such. I was dead wrong, and don't even know where I came up with that idea. Pretty much any other game will treat your computer with more kindness than this game will. At least in my experience.

In short, I do, in fact, recommend this game. But I do so with caution. Just know what you're getting yourselves into, and also remember that the Sims may not seem as fun now as it did during your childhood. In fact, in this version, Sims can get out of the pool without a ladder. Isn't that lame? I think so. Anyhow, have fun and don't go broke.

The Sims 3 can take awhile to get the hang of it if it's your first time playing a Sims game. But there should be no problem learning since there are tutorials you can view for pretty much everything in the game. Anyways, The Sims 3 is a life simulator and open world sandbox that lets you do whatever you want and play how you like. First thing to do is start creating your Sim. There are tons of different customization options for them from the type of clothes they wear, accessories, facial features, the way their body is shaped, etc. You can also download additional clothes  and accessories from the Sims store and even user created content! You can give them traits which make up their personality, make additional Sims and choose how they are related to each other, name them, then move them on into the world to start living life. There is no story mode but you can choose a "lifetime wish" which is exactly as it sounds. As you play, you can work on fulfilling your Sim's wish and in reward, you get lifetime points that you can spend towards special things that can make your Sim's life easier. ...Or you can ignore that and do whatever you feel like if you want! Your Sim could get a job and work to pay bills for the house or you can be completely irresponsible and go dumpster diving if you like. 

Your Sim can interact with other Sims as well and get to know them. You have several conversation options such as chat, gossip, insult, compliment, etc. You could become friends, enemies, or even lovers! The game will let you have romantic relationships with a Sim regardless of their gender. So they can be gay or straight. Your choice. 

Now the next thing to know is that your Sims have "needs" which are an important part in the gameplay. The needs are represented by bars and they change color depending on how your Sim is doing. Your Sims have needs such as hunger, bladder, energy, social, hygiene, and fun. You have to pay attention to these because they will affect what happens in the game. Like if you ignore your Sim's hunger needs, they'll die. Or if you don't bath them, your Sim will stink and be embarrassed around others. Your Sims can also automatically control themselves and they will do things such as get something to eat or hop in the shower if their needs become too low. But keep in mind that this does not always work because they may wait until a certain need becomes incredibly low to fix it and it's good to always check them every now and then to make sure they're not too busy talking to someone for several hours rather than eating!

Now, the lifestyle you want for your Sim is entirely up to you. You could work your way up and become rich, get as many friends as possible and become popular, romance up several people and have several girl/boyfriends, or just maybe take a walk in the park. Haha. That being said, I totally recommend this game and there is plenty to do and many ways to live your life however you want. And there are also many expansion packs that completely change the world and add lots of new content onto the already lot there is. I've easily spent over 50 hours and that's only in the base game with my first Sim family. Totally worth it!

The base game is certainly recommended, as it's fairly cheap for a solid and highly amusing life simulator. 

There are also mod packs out there for people who want to spice things up without investing in any of the 19 DLC packs. Because seriously, EA. Seriously. It's neat and all that you kept the game alive for as long as you did, but seriously, EA. Can't you at least pretend to not be greedy and evil? Can't you at least pretend you aren't trying to drain the life out of every IP you have by milking it to death, casting revive, and milking it to death again? Can't you at least pretend? No?Seriously, EA.

But yeah, the base game is a bit buggy and a bit clunky, and for me it is prone to crashing (but then, so are Skyrim and New Vegas since I've put so many mods into them) but still recommended! No way in hell I'm buying any of the (at the time of writing) $379.81 worth of DLC packs, though. Stick with the base game only!



SERIOUSLY, EA!

Here is a brief overview to anyone who could genuinely be new to the Sims Series.

The Sims - a revolutionary game that never predicted the level of success it would experience. Long outdated by today's standards, but wonderful nostalgic feelings ensue when played.
The Sims 2 - a brilliant, near-flawless expansion to a wonderful game, nearly perfecting the piece. Good graphics and mechanics make this one of the best of the series.
The Sims 3 - a different take on the Sims by including a pre-rendered town to live in. Allows a greater variety of play at the expense of a slight lack in diversity of objects and things to buy.
The Sims 4 - We don't talk about this. Ever. Turn back now.

The Sims is the best life-simulation game around, hands down. I personally enjoy the Sims 3, due to the open world nature(opposed to the Sims 2, just in your house, or Sims 4, with locations, but not just one big world), and the enormous amount of add-ons that can go in to customize your game. Want retro 70s clothes? They have it. Seasons? Check on that. Pets? Hell yeah. Vampires, witches, and things that go 'bump'? You bet! With dozens of worlds, thousands of outfits(and what can only be billions of combination outfits), and hundreds of building materials/household items you can buy, this game is already incredible. But the best part is in life simulation. Every sim, no matter how much you try, will look different, act different, and have different wishes. Even minor things like having a hotdog will propel your sims into a whole new world of wishes and hopes, from cooking, to a new job, to opportunities that accompany this. A brief pass with someone at the supermarket can bloom into a relationship, a family, and any number of other possibilities. Every single playthrough is different, and that allows you to experiment as many times as you wish. Even with a single game is varies greatly day-by-day. One day, you could have an aspiring author, the next, they want to join Sunset Valley's Finest, or their worst. How they react, is up to you.

This is definetly a game where you want to get as good as possible. This isn't very hard though considering the sims has always been a life simulation type of game, meaning that it really doesn't take ANY skill whatsoever to get better throughout the game. What I mean is, in order to fully get the full expiernece of the sims 3, you want to upgrade your house, eventually have a family, and have a career. Being a person who is very lazy and doesn't mind playing a casual game once in a while the sims is a fantastic installment in the series...however... there are some flukes to the game. When I first launched the game it wanted me to install a patch that would update my current version (like any normal game that needs updating). I downloaded the patch and I thought that everything was fine... until I re-launched my game and it said to download the patch again. Since it wouldn't let me into the game without the patch notification going away, I had to restart my computer twice than magically it worked :|. Depending on what you are running it on (low or high) the game may look glitchy as well, but in my opinion, a potatoe could run this game. One more thing that I must include is that if you are new to the sims DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME. I have heard countless people complain about how the game is broken and doesn't make any sense when in reality they never have played the sims before. I do recommend this game but it definetly has way more flaws than corrections.

[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
The Sims 3 is a life-simulation-sandbox developed by a division of EA known as [i]The Sims Studio[/i], the Sims 3 was released 2009.
The general idea is to progress your character/family through the game by building/buying a house, purchasing items to supply your Sims basic needs; Hunger, Social, Bladder, Hygiene, Energy, and Fun.


[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] I personally admire Sandbox games because of the flexibility you have with story, and game elements. Each person will have their own personal story playing through the Sims. [i](If you don't care to hear the story of my first Sims game: Skip to Gameplay)[/i]

I created a Sim that looked like me, and proceeded to move into a house and begin to work on building my life. After getting my first job, the car for work showed up earlier then I expected, and I sadly didn't have time to eat my Waffles, so I left them on the street and went to work.
After putting in a hard eight hour work day, I returned to my waffles on the street. [i](I had watched them the whole time from my above view. I watched them... mocking me.)[/i] Now, any sane person would know not to eat waffles left on the street for eight hours, but I'm not sane, I ate those suckers after getting home. Then proceeded to vomit in the toilet for the next few hours.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511831776

Eventually I became familiar with the weird 3D controls, married a lady who turned into a grandma the day after we were married [i]( *Condescending tone* Being the noble man that I am, I reloaded my save file. In my defense, she didn't tell me she was three times my age when we dated!)[/i]

After getting married, becoming the leader of the free world, and having a kid... I died of old age. This is when I realized my terrible mistake; I shouldn't have made an avatar that looked like me. Eventually My son brought me back as a ghost, but I felt wrong after seeing myself die in a video game like that.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] It's hard to articulate how weird the controls are for The Sims 3, you can zoom in and out, rotate the camera, switch between Sims, the GUI [i](Graphical User Interface)[/i] isn't the weird part about the controls... It's when you're trying to learn the key-bindings, which mouse button does what, clicking and holding the scroll wheel, among a host of other keyboard shortcuts.
It took several hours of play time to get familiar with the controls, I suspect I might have been helped or hindered with my experience working in 3D modeling programs such as 3Ds Max, Source SDK, and Blender.
There is a lot that can be said about The Sims 3 gameplay, but the best way to sum it up is that this is a Sims game. This was the first Sims game I played since trying it at a friend's house when I was younger.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511831787

[b]Achievements:[/b] There are no Steam Achievements on the Sims 3, however if you're objective or goal oriented, there are in-game accomplishments that you can work on earning. These accomplishments are shown on your Sims 3 community profile page.

[b]Price:[/b] This is where The Sims 3 gets sticky, and I start to get cynical... The Core game is priced at $19.99, that's an extremely fair asking price for the core game. But wait, there's more!
If you look in your furniture section within the game, there are advertisements for more furniture that you need to spend real money to unlock! [i](Really EA? We didn't spend enough?)[/i]
But wait, there's more! Each DLC pack (19 packs in total) costs $19.99! This is where many people start mumbling about EA having a money grubbing exploitative business model[i](Or maybe just me)[/i]. If you do want to get the DLC for the Sims 3, it's recommended you look for bundle deals that are on sale to get the most out of your purchase.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=510203419

[b]Conclusion:[/b] to recap, Story: flexible and unique. Gameplay: takes some time to get used to the controls if you're new to the series. Achievements: None on steam, but accomplishments in game. Price: Fair for the core game, however the marketing design is to shake you down for more money.
I recommend this game to people who enjoy simulation games, play casual games, and like building houses.

Do you like the way EA sells DLC for The Sims 3? Or do you think they should include more in the core game? Feel free to let me know in the comments, thanks for reading my review.

Firstly, this game is really good and highly addictive. The base game is good, graphics are nice, gameplay is involving and good fun. I'm no expert but this is the best Sims game I've played by far.

The big downside is that you only get one world/map with the base game and there's one additional world you can download free. A huge amount of the content for this game is essentially in-game purchases, where you are forced to spend your real-life hard earned cash on buying new stuff for your sims. This sucks, and particularly when 'building' the game hassles you to spend more money and is essentially teasing you with content that you'd have to pay real money for.

If you're prepared to spend about 100 on this game (incl. the base game) then you should be able to have a game with enough maps and 'stuff' that you can get a lot of playing time out of it.

Even after spending that though, you'll probably realise that some of the additional worlds you've downloaded would be much better if you also had a similarly themed expansion pack (e.g. Dragon Valley  better with Supernatural expansion, Sunlit Tides world better with Island Paradise expansion). So then you're looking at more 30 expansion packs to get additional features which you would expect to be with the actual world itself.

If you want the 'complete' game, you're looking at well over 500, possibly somewhere nearer 1000.

The Sims 3 is much more fun than a cheap car, but if you're not carefully you'll have spent enough that you could've bought one. It's such a shame really, as it's a brilliant game that seems overshadowed by it's awful payments system and expense.

If you have the disposable income and think you'd like this game and like the concept, then buy it. It seems to be the most acclaimed Sims game and really is great fun to play.

Great game, but poorly optimized.  The more expansions and stuff packs and items you download for it, the slower it will run. This game eats my life. Micromanaging activities is a pain in the ass. However, managing everything your sims do is the highlight and it can take hours. You are constantly making sure everyone's lives are planned out. In fact, you can make yourself a sim and manage yourself in this world. These sims will literally learn, mature, get a job, reproduce, complain and eventually die. The gameplay is endless and unpredictable. Play only if you want to micromanage things. Every gameplay is different; however, the vanilla game is limited so after that it is mundane and boring with no extra content unless DLC is picked up.

You can also be the devil and torture various sims to death. 

Expansion is worth picking up. It will add loads of more hours, features, jobs, options, etc. to the game and you will find it difficult to stop playing unless you hate managing things.

I can't recommend this game. I've had a love hate relationship with the sims for a while. I like to joke about it with my friends that I hate sims but i can't stop playing it. But after what just happened, I'm uninstalling it and never touching it agian. There is this error code, error code 12, basically if you play the game for too long it loses the ability too save. Mind you, this error is VERY common, if you play the game for over an hour you run the risk of running into it. I'm just playing vanilla too, with very little custom content (like about five pieces of it), from what i've read installing expantions just makes it worse, especailly seasons. So anyway, I'm doing a challenge called a hundred baby challenge, for anyone who doesn't know what that is it's basically where you try to have a hundred babies all with different guys. I was at 78 and had been working at it since last summer. I had just finished woohooing a guy and I went too save and got error code 12.  I was frustrated and didn't want too play a half hour of game agian, so i tried doing a save as too see if it did anything different. I still got the error, so I closed out. I went into play tonight and what do I find. I DELETED MY GAME! The game I  had been playing for a year, and was so close to finishing. For people who are going too say or think, "Well this is why you keep multiple saves", just NO. You do not release a game with this serious for a bug, and if it does get realesed with it your fix it. From what I can tell, they never came out with a patch for this problem, making it very clear that the creators just do not care. Other problems with the game include the fact that it takes forever to save and load, crashes are very common, the vanilla version can get boring after a while meaning that if you want a more exciting game you have to drop another 25 dollars on it for an expantion, so it's a game that can end up costing well over a 100 dollars, some of the expantion packs are things they should have in the base game like rain or dogs, this game eats up a ton of memory, and the clothes and hair in the vanilla version are ugly, so you have to either get expantions, buy new hair and clothes from the store, or get custom content. I know that last one sounds like a nitpick, but the game is a virtual doll house, dressing up your character it half the fun, so that's a big problem. I haven't checked out the Sims 4, and I don't think I will, but if it is any better, skip this version and just get the new one.

I neglected my kids for a week and when the social worker showed up to take them I built a room with only stoves, fireplaces, and rugs. Then the firemen came to put out the fire but decided to enjoy my kickass swimming pool and go skinny dipping. This game is so realistic 10/10.

Let me start by saying that my rating for this game is not based on the game play. To play this game as it is meant to be played gets very repetitive and boring after awhile. To finish the game you have to live a long successful life and then die to be completed. BUT... If you are into building houses and landscaping, then I highly suggest this game. I can spend days building a property and then it is fun to share them with the online community and see how many times they are downloaded. The game itself comes with many items to build cool stuff with but there are a ton of expansions to buy which makes this game the most expensive but the best I have seen so far where you can build any house and property you can dream of. I also own The Sims 4 on my Origin account but I enjoy building houses more with The Sims 3.

Protips:

- Install the mods NRAAS Overwatch and MasterController (plus integration) to help reduce lag, crashes, and have workarounds for otherwise game-breaking bugs. NRAAS Register is also helpful to reduce lag via extended population controls. Overwatch is [b]mandatory[/b] to avoid any town eventually crawling to an unloadable halt, no matter how many different save files you make or how awesome your gaming machine is (this is due to a bug that spawns ridiculous numbers of cars in NPC Sim inventories).

- Disable memories immediately, and be sure to re-disable them when the game inevitably resets all its settings as if you've never played before (it likes to do that every once in a while). The memory scrapbook concept is a cute idea but very poorly implemented, as it will create huge save files and additional lag from all the memories being recorded by every Sim in the game.

- Get the fixed version of the Isla Paradiso world if you want to play in it at all (the fairly-unplayable version comes with the Island Paradise expansion). NRAAS Register becomes much more useful for this world specifically, because you can turn off immigration, wild animals, tourists, and other things that make even the fixed world laggy. Overwatch will also disable NPC Sims from adopting pets, which is a good idea because kittens and puppies lag the game out badly due to being unable to go up and down steps.

- Don't get a vacation home in the World Adventures expansion countries until you are absolutely sure you are done with opportunities related to that country. Buying a vacation home makes it almost impossible to get opportunities afterwards, especially in France.

- Either don't buy a home plot or alternate house in the To The Future expansion, or be prepared to randomly lose the lot and everything on if you change the future setting (which includes normal, distopia, and utopia settings). If you edit the future town to include buildings like a grocery store or school, these changes can also be randomly undone.

- Research expansions ahead of time for content and purpose, then add the ones you want to your wishlist and keep an eye out for Steam sales. Usually the big summer sale will at least chop off part of the obnoxious pricetags. Even the base game bundled with the Pets expansion can be steeply discounted if you're lucky and haven't picked up the game yet.

- Make multiple save files for games you care about. I use 8 different saves sequentially numbered for every world that isn't just a random test of something, and I overwrite the oldest save with each new save. That way if one save becomes corrupted, I have 7 to fall back on, with varying degrees of playing time lost. Even with mods, some saves will corrupt, especially if the game crashed while saving.

- Save OFTEN. The game likes to crash, bug out, or become unplayable any time it feels like, regardless of mods.

- ???

- Profit.

I find it extremelly hard to recommend this game to anyone. 

I got it for my girlfriend; rather, I got an 1/8th of this game for my girlfriend. The full game, DLC and all, is roughly $420, microtransactions included. I can't imagine that production costs were so incredibly high that EA needed to charge me an entire paycheck to play a decent, addictive (but far from extraordinary) life simulator. I didn't know that I could hate EA anymore than I already did, but I do.

The fact that there is a Sims 4 with a similar business model means that taking advantage of its customers seems to be a viable way for EA to make money. I urge everyone to spend as little on this game as possible. Hell, just torrent the game. It's single player, after all.

I have been playing the Sims since the orginal and have always loved the series, so I may be slightly biased.  If you're a classic sims lover then you will enjoy the Sims 3, it continues to hold the spirit of the original game with more and more possibilities available via DLC and expansions. Extra special bonus if you get this for 40% off in the Steam sale as I did!
PROS:
-All the expansions you could ever want.
-You can now be multiple "races" (supernatural i.e. ghost, vampire, fairy, etc.)
-Traits system gives your sims more original personalities.
- The ability to have a generation of sims and to tailor their lineage exactly to your liking.
- YOU ARE GOD.

CONS:
-Some of the expansions include things that probably should've been included in OG game.
-Takes up a lot of space on your computer and can be difficult to run without a gaming PC or laptop.
-You will lose chunks of time IRL to this game.

Now that I am nearing 300 hours on this game I feel that I can review this game. My god do I love the Sims, there aren't many games where you can have Ellen Page marry Beverly Crusher then watch them cry over the death of their cat, Wesley. But my favorite moment is when a burgular broke into Ellen Ripley and Sarah Connor's house, that poor poor burgular. You can allow your imagination to run wild with the characters you create, and like I said before you can make an Ellen Page and Beverly Crusher then marry them. That's an A in my book. 

My biggest complaint about this game is the way DLC is implemented, with each DLC pack being $20, and to have a complete version of the game will cost you nearly $400. The way EA carves up their games and sells them to the consumer bit by exspensive bit, and the in game purchases like clothing truly show how they want to squeeze money from the consumer.

The Sims 3 is a life simulator game of which you are master- create your own people, or Sims, choose how they act, their traits, and their destiny in life with life goals.

Pros

-Easy to use interface, all interactions are easy to access
-An overabundance of mods
-Several expansion packs
-Very interactive social options
-High quality at affordable prices
-Doesn't go overboard with fantasy unlike other life simulators
-Lifetime wishes

Cons

-Extremely long loading screens
-Some expansions (Supernatural, Pets) add unnecessary features that just seem too unrealistic for a life simulation game
-Some expansions (Showtime) are just reboots of other expansions (Showtime=Late Night)
-Rabbit holes

The Sims 3 is very much worth the price for the base game. However, I would wait until sales are up. While the game does has its flaws (and boy, it does), it truly is one of the best life simulator games (very little) money can buy!

I have been playing the sims since the very first release, and honestly it's the most absorbing game in my library. It's the most wish-fulfilling, creativity inspiring game there is, period. It has its lovers and its haters, as do most games. I'm definitely the former. What other game would allow you to create a dysfunctional family consisting of an aging slut, a ghost, a zombie, an evil child and a criminal; all of whom live in the same house, have affairs with one anothers spouses, and then ultimately all get burned to death (by YOU) allowing you to entirely remodel the house ready for the next victims.....I mean family. It's great, and the possibilities are endless and it entirely panders to the schadenfreude, sadomegalomaniac culture of our socially desolate lives. If EA could just charge loyal buyers of the expansion packs less for subsequent editions, that would be great. That's my two cents.....out!

I absolutely adore this game. Great graphics, aswell! If you love making your own character (designing it & all) then this game is for you! If you want more, then buy an expansion pack! I bought the 'Pets' expansion pack and I absolutely love it!

[h1] simulation at it's finest [/h1]

This game is fun for the whole family. If you have played any of the other sims games then you know what to expect, make a sim (person) give them a job, find them a girlfriend/boyfriend and start a family. The sims 3 really changed alot with the other sims for example the city is now an open world city so not more one lot houses now the city is your lot. There is so many new things involved with the sims 3 that you cant describe it, you need to just jump in the game and find it.

[h1] just stunning [/h1]

You may also notice that the graphics got a smooth upgrade. Sims now look more like real people than worn out dolls. Also your needs such as hunger got an update as well so you dont have to eat and use the bathroom every 5 minuets which gives you more time to explore the city or maybe call up a friend and hang out. There are way more sims in the city than there was in the sims 2 cities which leads to a more realistic tone in the game.

[h1] rewards everywhere [/h1]

As the game is fun you will find that the longer you play the more rewards you can get for example you pay have spent all night at a night club and found some girl to talk to and then later got married to her just to find out she is very famous. Even looking into a telescope at night can be rewarding as you can find new planets and stars and name them and get paid for find them. The game can get a little boring for a while doing the same thing over and over again but anyone who is a die hard fan will love the sims 3.

[h1] verdict [/h1]

The sims 3 is a game where you can do anything and i have not seen anything like it. Even though the game can get borning after awhile its still fun, enjoyable and a great way to pass the time in the real world. I give the sims 3 4/5 stars.
Fun to play every so often. More worth it than The Sims 4 at the time of writing this.

The Sims 3 was everything I wanted The Sims 2 to be. It looked great and had all the variety and freedom that the original had, but 2 did not. I appreciated the challenges and goals of a virtual life, but I already have to try and meet those goals in real life, why would I want to deal with them in a fake one? 

No, thank you. Like everyone else, I want to be president, then quit to be a criminal, and along the way I'd like to build a mansion and have at least one neighbor that I'm always mean to because you don't get to do that in real life. 

The bonus of The Sims 3, though, is that it was so popular for so long that there is at least one expansion pack for everybody's interests so the game can just keep going on and on. The other bonus is that, for now at least, Steam regularly puts the expansion packs on sale. I keep meaning to purchase more packs, before EA pulls the series all together in favor of their own distribution site.

Sims 3 is great compared to it's predecessors in that you can give Sims personalities...as in...you can make all your friends in Create-a-Sim, give them your friend's quirks, and throw a party with all on them to see what happens! Or go out and enjoy life for realsies. But what's the fun in that? In Sims 3, you're a god of your own little world. Besides re-creating friends, I like to re-create houses and characters from sitcoms. 

You don't NEED DLC to have fun, but hey. If you wants pets or vampires or weather or whatever...that's on you. You also don't HAVE to download any extra goodies. Just ignore the kinda-sorta ads for premium items that appear when you're placing down furniture or dressing your sim. They're suttle...just items you can click on except boxed in gold so you KNOW it's a paid item. THAT'S the only bummer for me besides needing a decent computer to run the crispest images and have the fastest loading and response times. 

Overall, very fun, I've wasted much of my life playing this vitual sorta-doll-house game, but damnit it's worth it.

-So many stories to create!
-So much custom content to get from the interwebs!
-Replayable! So much!

Cons:
-It's pretty difficult to remove unwanted expansions if you 'aren't'/'don't live with' a computer guru.
-A lot of the expansions add a lot of content, which equals a fair bit of lag and game freezes that leave you fantically clicking the mouse and banging the keyboard, hoping that the sim you hand crafted don't die from lag.
-Open world=Sims constently moving=Sims constently getting stuck=LAG! Liberal use of 'resetsim *' to reset all the sims in the neighborhood back to their homes is required!

Other than those cons, the game is very fun! I recomend to anyone that enjoyed Sims 2, and are a bit scared of Sims 4. Just make sure that you have a semi-beefy computer.

Considering the amount of DLC that was taken straight out of features for the base game, it's a pretty incomplete product. I remember getting the Showtime edition because it was fine at the time to spend 50 dollars for a video game, and for the most part it has been a satisfactory experience for me. My sims have been happy, well fed, and die at appropriate times to headcannon roleplays. However, I would still consider the game incomplete with the amount of aggregious DLC that could have been base game content if EA wasn't so greedy, but then again the game is still playable without the DLC so you could do the regular get a job, have kids, raise them, marry spouses, etc; that being said, you won't be able to send them to college, take vacations, have pets, have an apartment, become a professional magician, defend westeros, become a vampire, use magic, and a whole lot of other things without a lot of DLC.

I've always enjoyed playing the Sims. I loved one, two, three (Sims 4 is getting better). Yet, the expansions on Steam are very overpriced. Luckily, I bought the other expansions via Origin, when they came out, but, even with just the regular one here, it's still excellent. 
I do recommend this people simulator if you want complete control of life.

This game is ridiculously huge to begin with, but for some strange reason it doesn't seem to have enough of the essential content to create a good story with the sims. I mean, in some ways it's a lot like Sims 2 (which I have loved for so many years), but in other ways, its frustratingly different. For example, in Sims 2, I felt satisfied with the game that I bought -- even though I hadn't bought any expansion packs yet. The game was able to stand on its own and impress me without having any extra content. With Sims 3, I feel this horrible dissatisfaction with the content, dispite the superior graphics and the exciting new *live* neighborhood. Oftentimes I can ignore the feeling, but some times it is dishearteningly glaring. 
There is always this subconsious push to run back to steam and grab up more DLC so that the game can achieve some kind of tolerable level of "rightness" -- almost as though EA was trying to do this on purpose. It seems awful, but I am starting to believe that they just broke the game up into pieces, called it DLC, and tried to sell it to people piecemeal!
An additional problem, and a rather gamebreaking one for me, is the sheer size of this game. Once you build it up to a reasonable level with "Pets" "Ambitions" and "Nightlife", things start to go seriously wrong. Bugs and glitches that once were just annoyances become major problems, lag that was pretty tolerable before is now making you mad, and loading times that were originally only a lengthy 5 minutes are now running into the range of 20 minutes -- and this is on the lowest settings possible! I have also begun to experience issues with the game essentially *growing* the more I play it. It automatically starts to get fatter and more sluggish every time. Not to mention the crazy amount of inconvienient game crashes!
All in all, I suppose coming so late to the game, I should have heeded the bad reviews and steered clear of it, but as you all know, sometimes, in pursuit of a dream, a gamer is tempted to try something that they know probably sucks. 

 I would only recommend this game to someone with a ton of patience and a 5 star computer system :P

The Sims series has been around for a long time, and even though The Sims 4 is now available, I would dare to say that the Sims 3 is a better purchase at the moment. If you have played any other Sims games you will know what to expect. Here is a great new installment in the series that offers plenty of character and house customisation (Even if some of it is behind the DLC Paywall...)
If you haven't played any of the Sims before then The Sims 3 is probably an okay place to start.
Create a character and start on a limited budget, over time help your Sim become Rich, Famous, Hated, Loved, Poor and Lonely anything you want!

Breakdown:
Graphics - 8/10 - An improvement on the Sims 2, but can still be a little choppy.
Gameplay - 8/10 - Everything the last games had with added aspiration bonuses among a few other additions
Customisation - 9/10 - Make your Sim, build you house. Plenty of items to choose from, the rest is down to you!
Longevity - 8/10 - I didn't find this as addicting as the first Sims, however you can still lose hours on this if you get into it.
Worth the Money? - Yes. However if you are new to The Sims, i'd wait for a sale.

Overall - 8/10

Welcome to the more recent installation in The Sims franchise.  I'm sure anyone visiting this store page and looking into this game already knows what Sims is all about, so I'll keep it short and sweet.  The Sims is a life simulator basically.  You take control of a household of people and live a virtual life basically.  You make them use the restroom, sleep, eat, go to work/school, play games, watch TV, interact with others and so on.  There is also a fairly average home building/modifying feature in The Sims that allows you to create your own house, or add on to an existing one.  You can work at your leisure, picking the wallpaper/paint, flooring, exterior siding, roofing, grass type, placement of interior and exterior lighting and furniture and so on.

This game is uniquely addictive and fun, with plenty to satiate your simulation needs, however.  Keep in mind that this is made by EA, and as such, comes with a lot of baggage.  Yes, there is a lot of DLC that adds some neat little features and whatnot, but [u][b] no[/b][/u] you do not want to buy it.  The DLC is ridiculously overpriced and never goes on sale.  To add to that, this game itself should honestly only be bought on sale for $15 or less, considering that EA has released The Sims 4  recently.  But, in spite of the financial issues that plague all EA titles, this game is still a solid outlet for entertainment.  8.5/10.

It is the grey.

Embrace the love/hate/apathy.

For a older game, it still has its charms. Gets quickly boring after a short while but for the few bucks I got it for on sale was worth a play. This is going to be an unconventional review, to help people who want to buy the Sims 3.
Overall, I'm a fan of Steam, and I buy most of my games through it now just out of convenience, and a bit of consumer loyalty dashed in. However, The Sims 3 is one game that I reccomend NOT buying through Steam, for many reasons.

Overall the game is good, and I do reccomend it, especally now that it's no longer being added to make it easy to keep track of what you do and don't have for it. But buying through Steam will come with some headaches. Read the ENTIRE review for a STRESS FREE path to fun with this game on Origin, otherwise you may run into issues!

This is one of a very small selection of games that is much better purchased and installed through the Origin platform. Support will be much quicker and prompt to assist you than Steam will be able to, and by having it on Origin, it allows EA support to be able to assist you more easily because they cant look into anything on Steam. In my journey through installing the Sims 3 I was able to get assistance from EA support within 5 to 15 minutes, steam can take 20 days.

Second, having them regestered and installed on Origin provides you with lots of extra bonus content in-game, not a lot for each DLC individually, but it all adds up, and allows for even more free items on thesims3.com. If you have already bought sims 3 on Steam, or part of it, thankfully it's easy to use THE SAME keys you already bought and use them on Origin, they work, I can confirm it. (You might need to fiddle with removing "-"'s, but the key is the same.)

BUT STOP! This part is important, if you want to migrate your Sims 3 purchase to Origin, then read carefully, or you will have a lot of headache. Do NOT regester your steam keys straight into origin itself, instead go onto thesims3.com, make an account there and regester the key there instead, and it will automatically put your game into Origin for you.

This is important because thesims3.com is where your access to a LOT of content is, and because that website came before origin, both of them only talk in one direction. Thesims3.com can tell Origin you have the game, but Origin can't tell thesims3.com anything. Yes, it's dumb, and yes it should be fixxed, but at this point it's unlikely to change.
But having both see that you have the game regestered has benefits, so regester on the website, play on Origin.

Overall an outstanding game if you like The Sims, but Steam is not the best place to play this game specifically.

Moved into a new town and got a job as an investigator. Somehow within the time of two weeks I mastered my job, becoming the best female investigator in the town, and became a superstar. Paparazzi started lining up outside my house, taking my picture and asking for my autograph. About the time that I got around to one of my easiest cases, I was hired to find some black mail on someone for a friend of mine. Rummaged through their mail and their trash cans, and couldn't find anything, I accepted it and started to head back to my client, giving them the results. When I got to her house, she was locked away in the cellar doing something or another and her baby, which for some reason was a vampire, was just sitting there in the forty-two degree weather. I picked it up and started to feed the darling child, waiting for her mother. After about a couple of hours or so she didn't come back so I decided to take the baby. I changed her name to Arya and then turned to a demigod that started following me around ever since I moved into this town, and then had her transform the baby into a human, add her to my family, and then make her look more me. Went home and decided to cut my losses on the case, happy to have a new baby. When I got home I decided it was time for a change, and divorced my wife shortly before an earthquake shook my house and this weird portal thing showed up in my back yard. This strange guy game out and explained to me he was a time traveler named Emit and that his time machine just broke. So I abandoned my ex, and carried my new baby around with me as I started to collect power cells lying outside my house that this guy needed to fix his time machine. After it was up and running, the guy traveled back to his home town and I stepped into the portal, following him to the future with my baby. 

After getting set up and realized I had no valid money here, I turned to my demigod friend again and then bought a mansion before I started to set up my empire designing robots. I started to get really good at it, and as time continued it became very hard to do this and take care of my daughter at the same time, so I did what any sensible person who stood atop an empire of robots would do. I made a robot, a very special one, and then persionalized it for my dear sweet child of mine. I designed it after an old video game, and named it Legion before I gave it various personality chips, including a modified nanybot chip. After various tune ups I realized that unfortunately Legion was an outdated model, something I had to acknowledge as the empress atop a robot empire. I went through and made my greatest breakthrough, designing an updated robot that I named Legion Mk II, and shortly afterwards I gave him sentience. I also gave him the ability to feel different moods and such, and then gave him the capability to love. I sold all my other housebots because I decided they were outdated and no longer needed. 

At this point I went back in time with my baby, and Legion Mk I and Mk II. I decided to keep the Mk I for old times sake. As I got back home I talked to Emit and told him I wanted to do some good for the world. At this point I remembered my ex, who was still living in my house in the present. I took Arya with me on my quest to turn the future into a Utopia before we went back to the future and I continued to improve my empire, satisfied that the world Arya lived in was now the best it could be, and that she was safe with Legion I and II whenever I was busy. I decided to do some exploring and discovered a crashed alien ship, it was pretty cool but at this point I was really home sick. I went back to the present with Legion I and II and Arya, and then decided to move back to my home town. 

It was at this point that I decided to head off to University, leaving Arya behind with Legion Mk I and Mk II, my ex left behind in my old town. Not long after I got settled in, I met a plant person. I was a little confused, but didn't really care. I wanted to get my education as soon as possible and get back to my dear sweet child of mine, and I ended up missing her very soon.

The Sims 3 was around a long time. Building on the Wishes mechanic of the second game, this one has Lifetime Rewards, where you can gain points for keeping moodlets high and fufilling their various desires.
These points can be cashed in at any point.

Personally, I recommend getting the Supernatural and Late Night expansion packs if you like cities, and like an easier way to be immortal but still allow aging. Being a vampire is pretty fun.
Late Night adds a small city to play in, which admittedly feels a bit... empty. You'll want to play custom towns off the Sims3modding website.

Beyond that... Sims 3 is a mostly open world, non-instanced Sims game. It has problems, sure, it's buggy, it can do a lot of things at once meaning when you save your game it takes forever, you will find horses hanging around a single empty lot if you have pets.
Also, don't get seasons: much of the weather effects are really resource intensive and may kill your game.

You know what The Sims is at this point. Start by drowning, burning and starving your sims in a puddle of their own urine and then move onto to legitimate achievement and using expert fishing and culinary skills to make your sims immortal.

Then google "Skinner Box" and feel a bit bad about yourself.

While the base game isn't much, the true power comes from the expansions. All expansions are made to work in synergy with the other and create more content exponentially linked to the number of expansions you have.

So the base game + supernatural + ambitions means the ambitions system now works for supernatural careers like alchemist and unlocks "synergy content." Without ambitions, the system wont be there for supernatural.

As your game grows, the synergy content grows as well. When you own all the major expansions (not the stuff packs), you get an absolutely massive amount of synergy content.

So far here are the expansions:

Ambitions - adds interactive jobs, new jobs centering around craft skills. Adds scrap metal robots that become obsolete when you get into the future. Adds scrap yard, fire station, and other job based commecial lots.

pets - adds pets. Nothing special. Not much synergy content. Requires NRAAS mods or the wild life bogs down your game. Adds pet park commercial lots.

into the future - this is VERY unbalanced and practically cheating. You can create overpowered sim-bots that can max every skill, then teach your kids those skills or craft an infinite amount of high end items. They can even hold max level jobs meaning a single sim bot turns the sims into easy mode permenantly since sim bots dont age. Adds futuristic commercial lots like a future lounge, a fancy bar run by robots.

University - this adds social groups, "drugs", alcohol, multiple commercial lots like coffee shops, comic book stores, and bowling alleys. Adds plant sims. Adds science skill, and science objects like the science station. In here, you can clone practically anything and everyone. You also The science objects here are overpowered. You can even buy a brain enhancer to respec your entire personality whenever you want, even random strangers. This expansion also adds social networking, where you run a website and gain followers based on what you do. For instance, talking to a ghost and blogging about it is good content. This applies for other expansions as well, where you can boast about a good performance in show time or a cleared dungeon in world adventures. A good blogger can also get famous in late night.

Seasons - This adds seasons that tie into other expansions. Island Paradise resorts are effected by what season it is. No one will want to go to a resort in the snowy winter. Adds aliens, and alien technology like the weather controller and UFO car that you can use to terrorize the city.

Supernatural - adds supernatural creatures,  huge addition to  crafting ingredients, lunar cycle, and magic. The lunar cycle means that 1 night means there is a full moon, which means all sorts of supernatural creatures come out like zombies. This sounds cool, but it turns into an annoyance. The zombies become loud, annoying hobos on your porch after a while. Adds supernural lots like the vampire lounge (fancy bar), and the werewolf bar.

late night - adds fame, which ties into all other expansions. Adds even more powers to vampires. Adds nightlife commercial lots that tie into the commercial lots of all the other expansions.

Island paradise - adds all sorts of water activities, boats, house boats, and the ability to run a resort or hotel. Adds mermaid sims. NOTICE: YOU NEED NRAAS BUG FIXES TO USE THE ISLAND PARADISE NEIGHBORHOOD WITHOUT ISSUE.

Generations - adds a whole bunch of rewards based on what you do in your sim's life. Adds a bunch of inspiration rewards for living a good life, often in overpowered items. Adds another science object, the chemistry set that is  just as overpowered as the other items from university.

world adventures - you travel the world, complete dungeons, and if you have late night you can get famous doing it. Adds objects from Egypt, France, and China. It adds TONS of rare and expensive collectibles including rebuilt sarcophigi, statues, and dive wells. A good haul of artifacts can make you a very rich, or the museum very profitable if you own it. Adds mummy sims.

show time - ties into late night. adds performance careers. Adds genies. adds a whole bunch of items that should have been in late night like the DJ booth.

It all depends on what you want from your sims.

I can't really recommend this game to low-income players, but I can't give it a bad rating either, as it is QUITE fun once you get into it. Sims 3 is probably the best life sim I've ever seen/played. If you like life sims, than you really should get this game. If the idea of helping a person, or persons, through daily life sounds tedious, then it's not the game for you. The basic game comes with two towns you can mess around with, one of which is a free download. You get to build your player's lot up any way you'd like within the limits of the games included inventory.

You help a character you create, and motivate to make big (and small) desicions regarding their entire life, from schooling, to Careers, to Hobbies, to whether they brush their teeth or not after eating garlic dishes. The interactions within the world can get crazy intricate... Or you could make it your business to create a Sim with the right motivations, and just let them do what they wish. This usually doesn't end well, but many have tried it.

I will caution you about the mircro/macro-transactions that Sims offers it's players. If you are not satisfied with the content provided, you can get more, but it almost always costs extra real money for your video-game objects. If you want additional towns, for example, you'll need to be willing to part with another 20-30 dollars to purchase it. You can also buy some pretty cool furniture sets with real money too anywhere from a few cents, to $25 for some of the truly premium stuff. While this is fine for folks with money, this can be problematic for younger players, or people with limited income. Once you've bought the furniture, you CAN use it in any future saves; so at least you don't have to pay through your teeth multiple times for individual things.

If you get this game, try to be determined to stick with the limited content you start with, or you will find that you've forked out over a hundred dollars in no time. Otherwise have fun with it. It's really quite entertaining sometimes.

Frankly, I don't see anything The Sims 4 is offering that's better or more advanced than what The Sims Cubed already has. For that reason, I'm not going to bother purchasing The Sims 4, and will instead enjoy the great little time-sink with the grossly-overpriced DLC I already have.

As far as this great little time-sink goes, I'll cover the bad things first: Glitches of all kinds are apparent, from screen tearing to improper model loading to Sims getting stuck on invisible bumps in the carpet. It doesn't look like The Sims Cubed is going to be getting anymore support, either, since EA has decided to publish The Sims 4. Gameplay gets repetitive; even though you get to customize your Sim's appearance, gender, etc, and personality traits and ambitions, these things just don't feel like they have enough of an impact on the game itself. Most personality traits and Life Ambitions merely give you an extra option some radial menu somewhere, but do not actually impact how your Sim behaves or forms relationships with other Sims. Skills are way too easy to learn - you can master any given skill in about twenty minutes real-time if you push your Sim to interact with the right objects or people often enough. This makes your Sim even more bland, as there is no challenge for them anymore. And I wasn't lying at the top: the DLC is grossly overpriced for what each pack adds to the game.

On the other hand, the best thing to say about The Sims Cubed is that it's fun. That's the whole premise of The Sims franchise - to have fun playing god in a world of almost-human-beings. It's voyeuristic. It's vicarious. It's reality TV where you decide what the characters are going to do every day. Each expansion pack adds enough new content to the game to make sure that there's always something new to do. I wouldn't recommend buying The Sims Cubed unless you're also going to spend some money on a few expansion packs, like World Travels, Pets, or Seasons. If you do, The Sims Cubed will keep you playing for a long, long time.

A fun life simulation and a great way to kick back --BUT, thanks to EA being notorious in its tendency for rushing things which invariably leads to problems and not patching their stuff, the game is VERY buggy at times, and lags like crazy even on high-end machines --and no, that is not due to mods. I had no mods until I installed NRAAS ErrorTrap and Overwatch mods just to make the gameplay smoother. It's sad that you need mods to do what the developer should have.

However, putting the lags and bugs aside, it's a great simulation/sandbox game and the dynamics work well. The AI occasionally resorts to Radiant AI kind of confusion, but that's why you're there to guide them little fools ;)

On a personal side note, I wish the Sims were less "perfect". I mean the way everyone looks pretty (i.e. flawless skin, smooth features etc.). Sure, you can adjust the sliders to give ridiculous proportions and there are mods for adding scars and whatnot, but I don't like the obvious bias nor how it affects realism --and even if you deliberately try to make a Sim that's as ugly as possible, they're still pretty -or look like something from a kids' game.
Also, people die but don't get injured (save for getting burned) in any visible way (what do they pay those doctors for anyway?). It would add a sense of depth to the game if it had a little "rough around the edges", and not just beautiful people starting a career, getting married, reproducing and dying. 
But that's just my two cents.

Let me start out by saying I love this game, but I can't recommend it.

When I first bought The Sims 3, I played around with it for a few hours before realizing there was really nothing much to do, nothing much to buy, nothing really interesting to put in your house.  I've been playing The Sims since 1999 and this was the most boring Sims game I've ever played. 

Then I found out why.  The base game is not a complete game.  It's the bait.  And the DLCs are the hook.  In a sickeningly brazen cash-grab that shows absolutely no respect for gamers or Sims fans, EA put out a skeleton of a game, made people pay full price for it, then released the rest of the game through waves of overpriced DLC.  Now some of that DLC is really good and adds a lot of interesting features to the game.  That's great!  What's NOT great is that a lot of this should have been included in the original game.  More clothing options, more house decor options, job options, skills... 

Now I'm not saying things like the option to attend the University or visit the future should have been included in the base game; those are perfect DLC additions.  What I AM saying is that there needed to be more to the base game.  

EA released a bare-bones sims game, knowing that they could take more money from people if they released the rest of the game via DLC.  There are now 24 Sims 3 DLCs available on EA.com, each with a cost of $19.99.  That's a total of $479.76 in DLC.  Of those 24, thirteen are just "stuff", adding nothing substantial to the game, just more stuff.  

But it gets worse.  The game is full of micro-transations to buy MORE stuff.  For example, as you browse through outfits for your sims, or furniture for your sims' house, you'll notice pieces of clothing or furniture that you have to pay extra to access.  Really?  Almost $500 of DLC isn't enough, EA?  You have to add micro-transactions?  I never thought a video game would make me feel insulted, but EA managed to pull it off.

The shame in all of this is that The Sims 3 really is a FUN game.  Unfortunately I had to buy nine DLCs (all on sale for $7.99 because $19.99 is WAAAY overpriced, all with substantion gameplay additions, none of those stupid "Stuff" packs) before I could have fun with this game.  

Enjoy my money now EA, because this is the last Sims game I'll be buying.  You took a fun little game and turned it into a w-h-o-r-e.

I started off with a tiny, one-room bungalow in a new neighbourhood. I had no job. I had no friends. All I had was my sole aspiration: to become a Forensics Specialist - Dynamic DNA Profiler. I spent every evening alone, playing chess into the early hours of the morning. I would paint random images throughout the day on my easel, stopping only to sate my appetite, or occasionally wash my bodily odour away. I didn't talk to anyone. I didn't need anyone. I just needed this job. I was going to be the best. And then that day came. I had reached the pinnacle of my profession. Finally I could stop worrying about my career and enjoy the finer things in life. But being at the top is perhaps the loneliness place you can be. I still had no friends. No lover. No relations of my own. I tried going out to community lots but by this time I was old and the youngsters found me creepy and odd. I once again found myself spending the days alone in my home, trying to be the best at everything. I'll show them! I don't need anybody! I've come this far on my own! But, whereas time had once been my greatest ally, it had now become my sole enemy. Yes, I was the best at all things. But I had no one to share it with. I sat alone in the place I had once called home, surrounded by all of my beautiful creations, and I felt even more miserable than at the start of it all.

Now I'm going to try out this game.

10/10
So that's what having a life looks like.

I'm writing this as the Sims 4 is out, but this one is still worth your while or if you are considering getting into the SIms, just read the review for the story so far.

SIms allows you to create and guide the lives of a Sim single, or family through the course of their daily life. You can build homes for them, decorate, manage their daily activities like work and play and develop skills that help them in their life.

The Sims for the most part are autonomous meaning that they will act in the interests of their own self preservation if left alone (and they have the sufficient skills to take care of themselves). Guiding them during the game play slowly equates to developing good habits they need to survive in life although there are some of the real life missing elements like trolls and troll groups, the challenges there provide a good foundation for learning much need life skills and balance of the basic elements in life. It also encourages creativity in your own real life (for instance it might get you thinking that a night out to dinner and a movie every once in while is imperative to your health at some important social level).

All in all it encourages healthy lifestyle decisions without constraining one to "conformity" and rewards them.

One of the best and most fun aspects of the Sims line of games is designing your Sim. During this process you can choose the physical, mental and emotional characteristics of your Sims even giving them a background story. This can really flesh them out and once again what a wonderful tool for character exploration.

In Sims 4, they've really added some new features to the Sims you can create which allow for intelligent emotional lives as well. Sims 3 still holds its ground if you're on a limited budget and want to try a game from the Sims franchinse.

There's an online store as well that you can make purchases for your Sims and from time to time they offer free seasonal items for the holidays that you can use to decorate your Sims dwellings for that time of year.

One of the nice things about Sims is that if your looking for a change in pace from the action genre, this one would be a good start as its pacing is anything but tense and stressful bar trying to wake your Sim up in time to get ready for their day. Still challenging and magnetic gameplay that will keep you coming back. 

When you return to your action game, it will have a bit of zest put into it by the change in pace. You might even consider that the baddies you're blasting away have simulated families somewhere who are depending on that baddie to get rid of you and make it home safely. You might end up developing a bit of a complex and conscience about it. Read Philip K. Dick's "Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep?" aka Bladerunner and you'll get what I mean.

These Sims are pretty darn convincing in ways, but don't put them through the Voight-Kampf or Turing test.

You might spoil the illusion.

Highly recommended.

Plays too much like other EA games - I found the experience to be identical to Battlefield 4.

Here's how a basic game goes:

Start up the Sims 3. Spen about 15 minutes syncing for all the DLC I don't own. The spend roughly an hour trying to get logged in to origin. Register a new email, re-register with origin, spend another ten minutes trying to figure out why that account won't work either.

Once I've done this for a while and feel confident enough, I move forward to the second part of the game. I ignore all those warnings that I'm missing out by playing in offline ,mode, because I don't think it will effect the later game much. This involves laying out the very basics of a house, then immediately crashing to the desktop.

All in all, this procces can only really be streached out to four or five hours of quality play time, tops. I'm told there are thngs like careers and characters and a whole, whole pile of really good, expensive DLC at the very end of the game, but it doesn't really seem like you need to bother with them to complete the game or experience everything it has to offer.

EA needs to realize that their Origin engine is flawed to the point that all the games built around it play exactly the same way before they get any more of my money.

Sims 3, for all it's faults and troubles is probably the best Sims game to date.

The open world provides a sense of immersion not achieved by earlier games.  This is a feature that was missing in previous games.

There are a wide variety of expansion packs to provide additional functionality for just about anyone.

You can pretty much play the game however you want, you can make your sim an upstanding citizen, a socialite, an excentric recluse, a crook or anything inbetween.  You can have your sims befriend everyone and be known for being nice, use them to express your darkest desires to ruin all your neighbor's lives, or even ruin their own lives if you so chose. 

That is not to say the game doesn't have it's problems.   It is probably the buggiest game ever released by EA, and that includes Sim Copter and Streats of Sim City.   It is using an archaic branch of Mono which makes the Mono releases chosen by Unity3D look new, and has a severely garbage collector that leaves unnecessary cruft everywhere and instead vacates other objects from memory as soon as you leave the lot they are on.   It seems either the core programmers didn't know how to mark something as a cached asset, or just didn't bother.   Despite the size of the game, there is no attempt to use either a disk heap, or a secondary virtual memory segment to store cached assets, and until recently it didn't even support over 2GB of game memory space.


Tech support is nearly non-existant, but fortunately the game has finally stopped being update to support expansion packs, which would commonly break the game completely for older expansion packs, so there are fewer issues.

To put it simply, the game itself I give a wonderfully positive rating as a near perfect game for it's category.  It is everything a Sims game should be.  However, the backend is flawed at best, and often downright broken, while tech support is downright non-existant.   Frankly, I think EA could care less about technical support or keeping their older games functioning on newer technology, and I think recent reports of having the worst customer support in the video game industry are not only accurate, but an understatement.

Still, if you can put up with these faults, The Sims 3 is certainly worth your time and frustrations.

The Sims 3 is a great experiment in the simulated genre, and it's apparent that it'll stand up against its successors (e.g. Sims 4) it still reeks of the cash-grabbing tactics of EA, with over 20 expansions that just make it a point of overkill unless they're heavily discounted.

If you're a hardcore Sims fan, then you're already going to buy everything, but the fact remains that the create-a-texture option solves a lot of issues that EA would rather you pay money to solve in the form of completely new items.

Sims 3 gets a positive review, but just barely. It's enjoyment is hindered by how bogged down it is with expensive downloadable content that tries to sell itself as essential to an enjoyable experience one moment, and an experiment in caveat empor the next.

So SOOOOOOOO buggy.  You have to play with cheats enabled.  You need cheats to repair your sims regularly as per official EA policy.  The longer your game lasts the worse it gets.  The game like to crash, and there is no auto-save meaning you can lose hours of game-play.  

The game makes very poor use of your RAM. Every time you edit your sims home the game has to stop and reload textures for each item you modify, even for identical items.  The game also fails to clear your RAM properly so you need to restart your computer every 3 hours to maintain smooth animation.

The game regularly suffers from broken AI, disappearing objects and Sims falling through floors.  Those are the least annoying bugs.  A game for sadists and masochists alike.

I moved my Sims games over to Origin a long time ago. It's where they belong. I have no opinion on EA as a developer/publisher.

TS3, as it is called by it's players who identify themselves as Simmers, is aptly the third offering in the series. It offers total customization on evertything, which in hindsight stands as a development milestone that has no equal. It is an open world sandbox, where you can either try to do little goals presented by the game to have a little direction in your play, or totally go and do your own thing.

Wanna build a dinasty that stands the test of time over many generations? Go do it.
Wanna play fashion-designer and have avant-gardistic Sims populate your game world? Go do it.
Wanna mod your game into something totally different than what it was when you bought it? Go do it.
Right down to:
Wanna be a playah and impregnate every woman in town? Well... Go do it.

TS3 is many things. It's instantly playable, it's pleasingly colorful, it's quirkily humorous, it has some sweet tunes and you get unlimited customization and unlimited ways to play the Sims. Now that TS4 is out, it becomes painfully obvious how chockful of awesome ideas TS3 is and how amazingly optionfilled the player-agency in TS3 is.

So, what went wrong? Well, Maxis was busy coding SimCity and left development in the hands of an unproven studio that brazenly rebranded themselves into 'The Sims Studio' to hide the fact that they were called EA-of-Canada originally.  With each new idea they implemented, they broke something and they even managed to break stuff that was broken to begin with. They patched and patched to little avail and to this day TS3 stands as one of the most innovative sandbox games ever, but more broken than the most broken Bethesda title in existence.

Still, in the current Sims-franchise landscape, TS3 is the one game to have. As a Simmer since 2000 owning everything that has 'The Sims' in the title, I can confidently say this. It expands on ideas introduced in TS2, it doesn't have bedtime-tale graphics and it allows the player to create their own stories and experience much better than TS4 allows.

Free from any consideration involving EA, TS3 is a good game and if you can keep it running long enough to make some self-generated progress, TS3 becomes one of the more enjoyable experiences you as a gamer can have. Open mind and all that goodness.

I therefore recommend trying this title, but don't buy it on here. Keep an eye on Origin Sales and buy the game there. Unless your Internet-full-of-yourself-ego bars you from doing that. I'm not the one to judge.

I've been a massive fan of Maxis for aslong as I can remember. I've played many hundreds if not thousands of hours of sim city during my teens, however, somewhat surprisingly, this is the first sims game I have actually played.

Sims 3 gives you the ability to take control of a sim in a virtual world. There is no laid out path for you in the game- will your character be a teacher, scientist, rockstar, criminal, the choice is yours. Along the way you can get married, have kids, and this gives you the ability to control the lives of more sims. This is a fun game and well worth the money for a vanilla purchase. 

On a side note, what annoys me slightly is EA's blatant money grabbing tactics. Firstly there are 11 full expansions to the game, and each one costs almost as much as the base game. So that's another 190+.....then the rest of the dlc which is more money......and sims points to buy more furniture which is also more money. This all adds up to a pretty penny indeed! Paying 30 or 40 is what I consider a fair price for some decent expansion material, but EA is blatantly trying to shaft the consumer. Needless to say I will not be buying any expansion material whatsoever.

Aside from that, Buy the Base game for some fun, leave all the rest. Recommended.
