As sims player since the first game's release in the beginning of 2000, I loved the first one, a promising game that was overall fun, but it felt like aside from babies growing up, the child OR adult never aged, though the soundtrack is the best out of all the main series of Sims, gotta love that jazzy music~. When the Sims 2 out in 2004, a massive improvement to the first one. I loved it to death and spent hours of playing it (Still playing it with the Ultimate Collection!), from abducting sims for the cute aliens, growing my family tree, helping my sims succeed throughout their life with a Summa Cuum Laude in the University Expansion, to raising their skills before their death, and so much more! When The Sims 3 came out, that was a different story, I didn't like it at first, no matter how much I tried to like it with all the expansions I bought, I couldn't. Right before the failure of a sequel known as The Sims 4 came out, I decided to give The Sims 3 one more chance, and finally, I got hooked!

Sims 3, like the Sims 2, is a massive improvement to the previous 2, regardless of the ridiculous microtransaction. The game is meant to simulate... Well, life! They even added a open-world aspect to the game! Oh, skills now varies from what you learn, it's not just a general thing like Creativity for arts and music, it's now skills like Guitar, Drums, Piano, Painting, so much more! Even exploring the neighborhood collecting items and finding interesting things for your skills. In some expansions, there is a new Life State I taken a liking to, such as Imaginary friends, a great way to build my family tree since you could make a Imaginary friend of the opposite gender of the owner. Even Aliens make a return in Seasons, and oh~ my~, they're even cuter than Sims 2 with that synthesize voice!

Overall, like Sims 2, a massive improvement to the previous Sims. Get it and save your money for the expansions!

This game is quite entertaining and is a great way to pass the time. I've put countless hours into creating sims and the houses they live in. I think it was well made and has a lot of content available for purchase. There is one problem with that, when I originally purchased this game and the ambitions dlc it cost me 70 dollars. I didn't buy any of the other dlc as much as I wanted because I didn't want to go broke. I just assumed as time went on the game and the dlc would lessen in value as most games do. To my surprise the game has dropped significatly in value, especially considering the release of Sims 4, but that's not what gets me. What shocks me is that the dlc is just as much as it was the day it came out for purchase. Don't get me wrong, I love this game and think what I payed for the game itself was resonable. But here we have content for the game, which can not be used without the base game that now is worth the same amount as the base game itself? According to this dlc doesn't depreciate like the game itself does. In other words if I now want to purchase all the dlc for a 6 year old game I have to blow 360 dollars!! I'm sorry EA, your content might be good however little each pack of dlc adds, but I think you've gotten your figures a little mixed up. The max you could get me to pay  for the additive content of game would be ten dollars a piece, tops. So before you go opening your wallets for EA I suggest you definately think about getting The Sims 3, but only choose one or two of the dlc, anymore and you're wasting your money.

This is one of those games that I'm hesitant to recommend--not because it's a bad game (in fact, quite the opposite), but because it's plagued with a few unfortunate setbacks, the likes of which aren't going to be fixed any time soon.

The biggest of these setbacks is the fact that the AI pathing in this game is absolutely horrible. Whenever a Sim gets stuck (and they WILL get stuck), the entire game will freeze as it tries to fix the sim's path. What this means for you is sitting at a frozen screen incessantly for minutes at a time. Luckily, there is a mod that can help mitigate this problem--Nraas's Overwatch--but it won't completely solve the issue, so be aware of this problem before you decide to buy.

With the mod, the game becomes much more bearable, to the point where you can actually enjoy it! The Sims is considered one of the best "life simulators" for a reason. It's a unique game that has carved its own niche out in the gaming world. If you enjoy creating your own stories, constructing a house you've always dreamed of, or simply carrying out your most sadistic desires by killing the sims you create, then The Sims 3 might be the perfect game for you.

As always. The Sims 3 is a fantastic simulation game where you can create your sim, get married, become the president who raises a son who ghost busts on the weekend. Lock the president in a basement to die during a TV repair and then live out your daughter's life as a professional chef.

The Sims has always been a great series and one of EA's staples. But I give it a thumbs down, just like I'll give any Sims game a thumbs down because you are basically paying for 1/20 of the game. The other 19 parts arriving in DLC downloads that cost the same amount as the base game EACH. At the time of this review, the game is $19.99. Round that to 20 and multiply by 20 and if you want the full game... you'll be paying a whopping $400.

I love the Sims. I truly do, but I do not recommend giving money to this company. Not when they expect their consumers to dish out 400 dollars for a single game. It's base is playable, of course... but it's not worth it when all of these $20 DLC's are taunting you along the way.

I'm 21 years old and it's time to make a fresh start. I leave my home town in search of a new life following my dream of becoming a world class culinary artist. I have near enough no money to my name, but with the help of some sort of demi-God I'm suddenly drowning in cash. I buy a beautiful new home and join the local bistro to kick start my career. After just my first week I have plenty of acquaintances and decide to throw a party to deepen my relationships and make some life long friends. The party is going smoothly, and I even get close to a girl and give her the old one-two in my way too big for just me bed. She stays the night and the next day I propose. There's no going slow in this town. Bad news; turns out she's my boss, I gained a step daughter, and she's also pregnant. She soon hits the elderly stages and I end up having to sleep with what looks like a dried up ballsack. I'm still young and have a granny for a wife and a baby who definitely isn't short of being "special". Not to mention my step daughter hates me. Is my life clich? I wouldn't let it end like this. I throw party after party, befriend a highschool girl, and once she hits the ripe age of 18 I snag my first kiss with her; all under the watchful eyes of my wife. Needless to say, we're divorced now, and for some reason the little slut who caused it is no longer interested. That's okay. Time goes by and I bed a tubby tess in my ex-wifes bed, before throwing rejection in her face. My new target is the maid. She has too much to drink and I take her to bed in, you guessed it, my ex-wifes bed. My ex-step daughter walks in on us so I teach her a few choice words on her way out. I decide to marry the maid and have another child with her. A week later I have a little black baby girl, and my first daughter is a teenager now. Although I sleep with my wife and ex-wife in the same room, things are going good. Or so I thought. My new maid wife turns elderly and I've only just hit 30. My life takes a weird turn next, as the ex-step daughter who once hated me is now coming onto me hard. I say fuck it, and bed her. My maid wife catches me and we get divorced, so naturally I marry the step daughter while she's in her prime, and of course we need another baby. My first wife is now my mother-in-law, and my daughter is also my sister-in-law. Not that she cares. No matter how many wives I go through, my two daughters are still my best friends. Because they're the only two people in this world I can't fuck.

Since reading is hard for some of you:
I do not recommend this game because it is a shitty base game, the previous versions of the Sims were much better, the DLCs are way too expensive, and there wasn't anything significant innovative.

Now where do I start. First of all, please ignore the little time I played Sims 3 on Steam. Reason being, I have a copy of Sims 3 (plus all the DLCs, including Ketty Perry Sweet Treats Stuff Pack) on Origin. I played countless hours on the Origin client. I bought the Steam version of Sims 3 because my goal is to own every game and DlCs on Steam. However, when I bought this on Steam, the Ketty Perry Sweet Treats Stuff Pack was already gone.

Having said this, playing Sims 3 is an enjoyable and yet frustrating experience. There are so many things to do with your Sim and this game has a high replayable value. There are countless things to explore and experiment. This game will stretch your creativity skills to the maximum.

However, there is a dark side to this game. If one plays without mods such as the Nraas mods, you will notice that there are many bugs in the game in which the developers failed to fix. For example, if you travel to other worlds like China and did the "unique rocks analyze" and then come back to your world, you will notice a discrepancy in the percentage of rocks your Sim has analyzed. This can be very frustrating if your intention is to create a perfect Sim where all your Sim's stats are being completed. Thus for hardcore Sim gamers, you guys must be prepared for these kinds of major anomalies.

However, for the casual players, (and there are a lot!) I would recommend this game to you. If you just want to have fun and pass time, then this game is for you. As I said this is a very fun game and that is what made the Sims genre a huge success in the history of video gaming. I also feel that women would enjoy this game more than men as there are a lot of opportunities to make your Sims fall in love and create a relationship made in heaven. That is what, most women love and dream about!

In conclusion, if you are looking for a "perfect" game, you would not find it here due to many major bugs. However, I would still recommend this game as these bugs can be fixed by installing the Nraas mods.

The Sims is a "people simulator", which puts you in control of a neighborhood, dictating the personal lives of the residents one household at a time.  It is, I believe, the best-selling game series of all time, despite being a niche market.  It is an awkward game to explain from a gaming standpoint, as design Will Wright found when he pitched the series in the 90's.  

The Sims 3 makes a number of changes that in hindsight seem so obvious and address issues in the previous versions.  Some examples:

*Aging is now optional and adjustable.  You have the option of turning sim aging off (like The Sims 1), or having it on (like The SIms 2), and you can change the length of each age.  

*Story progression, also optional.  Now the neighbors who are not actively being played will carry on their lives without your input.  They will age, marry, have children, get jobs, and other things on their own.  

*Moodlets replace the previous method of tying emotional state directly to needs.  Now situations dictate emotions (and needs are just one trigger of moodlets).  This has a lot of great advantages, because it takes the emphasis off gaming the needs stats and onto the character's interactions.

*Personalities expand on the previous aspiration system, with each sim gaining a number of personality traits that determine moodlets, learning, abilities, and many other aspects of their lives.  

*Interactions between all of these systems make interesting results.  You can watch a lifelong feud between a Good personality-sim and an Evil personality-sim unfold, where their mood drops just be being around each other.  

One strange decision, however, is locking the focus on a single household.  Previously, you could freely switch families during a session, but while this is still possible, the game makes it a little awkward.  Sims 3 is designed for you to focus on a single house for most of the game.  

The worst thing about this game is DLC and microtransation creep.  The Sims 2 had a lot of expansions, and experimented with an online store eventually, but The Sims 3 truly went all out.  There are endless expansions, stuff packs, and an online story for buying clothes and objects.  I am not even sure it is possible to own the complete content of The Sims 3.  On the other hand, the variety of extra content allows you to customize the game to your liking.  You don't have to play Supernatural or get Katy Perry stuff if you would rather have Pets and 80's nostalgia.  

Personally, with the addition of some mods (like Overwatch and Story Progression), I consider this the most interesting version of The Sims, especially if you are interested in the neighborhood story.  Just remember DLC creep is optional...

Sims 3 is a simulation of................ LIFE!!!!!

The game is complex and well designed enough to let the gamers enjoy the possibilities of "life" as we know it.

It is vast enough for the gamers to see every corners of life first hand but it isn't detailed enough to show
every little miniscule details.

Depending on how creative "you" are, the game can get extremely fun or extremely deadbeat-boring if you arn't.

The game offers some intense customisation
Houses, sims, jobs, family, are some aspects that are fully customizable down to every individual faces.

It is a must try and a worthwhile buy(base game) quality wise.

They have their own version of a contents sharing communitites, the gamers are able to download various player made people, buildings, objects from the internet.

Similar to EA's spore, this is one of their trademark franchise that has not failed them, (for a damn good reason.)

The pros are explained above, the cons are:

-The game greeds money, it really WANTS you to make purchases for ingame items, DLCs etc.

-DLCs make the game more fun, THEY ARE INDEED FUN but imagine how much money you'll have to pay for various DLCs
you want.(if the prices have dropped to primal dollar values then reconsider the statement above)

-The game can get addictive, it can seriously chew up some valueable time.

-After you play the game for a long bit, it can start to lag horribley due to cummulated cache and such, so consider ventilating a bit.

- Sims4(or versions above?) would be out. It would be more versatile than the previous sims3 and possibly more fun.

-It is reccomended you use Origin :(

Nothing beats the absolute, undeniable pleasure of creating an extremely obese black man who is life partners with a skinny green skinned alien. The euphoria of sending your disgusting, nature defying couple to work as a scientist and an artist is beyond the comprehension of the human mind. It is with absolute certainty, that I give this game one of the best ratings that has ever been given/recieved in the history of human kind:

It's a solid 7/10, not too shabby, could use some work on the GUI layout, though

Quick Review

Good game. Has a few issues in terms of readability, and generic EA bullcrap like Origin, a billion "Would you like to share this on Facebook?" pop-ups, and more than enough load time than is necessary. It's like my ass-hole, always loading shit.

As for the content, it's well packed with things to do. However, if you want more than that, get your Mastercard ready and prepare your anus, because you are going to get smacked upside the head with outlandish DLC prices. You want a few new items and an extra way to earn money? 20 dollars, please. Need new clothes? 20 dollars, please. Want all 10 DLC packs? 400 dollars, please.

If The Sims wasn't an EA franchise, it would be way better. Too bad, because this series has  A LOT of potential, and The Sims 2 had record breaking sales.

If you don't know what The Sims plays like already, here's a quick run-down. Create a custom character (or 29) called a Sim, bunch them up as single bachelors or families, and build them a house from scratch. Now control every aspect of their lives; fed or famine, rich or poor, children or freedom. You tell them what to do, they do it.... kind of like you are Fox News.

Playability: 200+ Hours
Technical Performance: You practically need an Alienware computer if you want to load within a reasonable time.
Enjoyment: High
Gameplay Quality: Very High
Non-Game Annoyances: 9001
For the Story?: The story is as good as you can make it.

Final Verdict: 7.5/10

Now, I know youve seen the bajillion negative reviews about the amount of dlc. First off, Stuff Packs SUCK. Do not buy them, they are lack luster in content and expansions are the same price and better. That makes buying all of the dlc about $200 including base game if you buy a plus pack (I personally recommend buying a plus oack to strat off). But you dont need all the dlc.  That is still an amazingly high price, but you do not NEED all the expansions. Based on my knowledge of playing sims 3 on origin I know that sims 3 alone is fun since they have updated it with plenty of options by itself. You only need to buy expansions based on what else you WANT with Sims 3. Want to focus on a more singular lifestyle? Late Night adds a big city and plenty of social interactions for that style and ambitions adds plenty of new jobs that require more attention then most jobs. Want to focus on a family? Get Generations, and University Life to make the most of each stage of life. I do hate that you need to buy an expansion to get seasons and weather but its the only problem i have found with the expansions. Sims 3 is a complete game with plenty of free Custom content and you may or may not want more from it. I do hate EA for the excessiveness but I do like that they put out every kind of expansion for any playstyle. There is Into the Future for time travel and Supernatural for gothic horror (although it is tones down for T ratings sadly.) If you are a person you likes a game where stories form from organic gameplay I would highly recommend the Sims 3 to you.

The Sims started out as a fairly simple franchise that rewarded player choice and experimentation, had a distinct air of optimism and innocence, and a far more neutral, natural tone. Most importantly, perhaps, the game was a satire of consumerist mores, which it managed to parody and embrace in equal measure. As time has gone by, the series has become increasingly loud, obnoxious, manipulative, and (ironically) the embodiment of the consumerism it initially played upon. With each iteration, I've found the game more and more hollow. The last significant entry I can recall was likely The Sims 2 on the PS2, which allowed direct player control of your sim, alongside the traditional list based control scheme. This was never implemented again, and I always thought that was a pity since it completely changed up the flow and tone of the game.

The biggest downfall of The Sims is that it's failed to mature with it's initial player base; the teens who once played these games are now hitting thirty, at the very least, and the game in no way reflects the reality of life, or the character of real, living and breathing locales. Everything feels like a forced smile, masking a deeper cynicism that I find, frankly, repugnant and unwelcome in my gaming life. Even if you choose to play the game dark, the aesthetic and soundtrack choices betray a deliberate attempt to keep everything upbeat; even death is treated with levity, and birth is a necessity rather than a philosophical choice. The Sims will never really be more than it currently is, and footage of the fourth major installment unfortunately confirms my belief that the franchise has no desire to do anything new, innovative, or meaningful in it's life cycle. 

This franchise wants your money, and that is all. And it'll be the best fairweather friend you ever had, so long as it has access to your wallet.

TL;DR

Another decent addition, aspirations are a nice touch and the sounds are really top notch but the microtransactions and 'holding back for more money' feel leaves a bad taste in the mouth. Plus, it can be a little glitchy at time.

Would just about recommend to buy. - 7/10

GRAPHICS

Putting into account when the game came out, the graphics are your standard 'good'. You can get a feel for the cartoony graphics and your Sims look like living beings in the create-a-sim. However, when you get to the real world, things start to come apart a little. There are definitely some rendering issues here and there, particulary when your Sim enters and exits taxis which they take around town now. Rather jaring. Buildings sometimes take a while to jump into focus as well but that might just be my PC. The animation hasn't moved on massively either (bar a few pleasent editions), which is dissapointing. Everything does it's job though and the textures look surfice a nothing really spectacular here or wowing, but it does the job - 7/10.

GAMEPLAY

Alot of your staple sim catagories are here: your create-a-sim, create-a-house, create-a-neighbourhood, etc. In these respects, the rule of thumb is we'll give you more, at the expense of less because we want to slap a microtransaction/DLCs ontop to bleed your money. The create-a-sim (where this rule applies the greatest) features a great deal more colour options, with the option to even change the shoulder colours and use ANY texture in the game as part of the costume (can make for some interesting results)... but at the expense of less clothes because we want to charge you for those. Oh and we'll charge you for the breast and chest enhancers to (via it's inclusion in certain DLC). Create-a-neightbourhood? We'll give you the freedom to build any lot you want... on certain spaces (which is a shame really). We'll also charge you for extra maps (which would be fine but the game only includes I believe 2 maps might even be 1) via DLC. Create-a-house, thankfully, isn't as bad. There are microtransactions for extra items, but the game does provide a number of items and item variations although this is not anything particulary groundbreaking. The inclusion of several upper and lower areas for any structure you build is an excellent edition, as well as tools to fill an entire room's wallpaper/floor in a certain way, saving you time.

Real world game play is your standard Sim affair but now with a number of extra parameters to flick on and off like how long you live in 'sim days' which are highly variable and you can even adjust the amount of time your sim spends in each area. There's also a few unique and interesting objects to interact with and you can set people to move in/out in real time, so there's lots of little tweaks to play around with. However, aspirations is the real meat in this game compared to the Sims 2. Filling aspirartions gives your sims boosts to happiness and bonus points to spend on stuff, with a massive boost if you manage to fill their life aspiration (selected at create-a-sim from a limited no. of options). The small micro-managing of what 4 aspirations you want (your sim gets new aspirations at regular times and when you add an aspiration or 'promise' it) adds a nice little dynamic to the game and surprisingly doesn't jar your day-to-day medelling. Some of the aspirations are a little superficial like 'buy a T.V.' but things like kiss such and such or go on an amazing date are always interesting to furfil and give some direction to the game, with the flexibility to ignore if you prefer.

Overall, it's pretty good - same old stuff (nothing too wrong with being puppet master) but the aspirations are a well needed spice. Some more seasoning would have been nice though. - 8/10.

SOUND

The sounds are where this game excels for me. The new build-a-home music tracks are delightfully calming yet inspiring melodies that take their time for you, just like the time it takes to build some of the monstrous projects that can occur. The usual pops and clicks are present and pleasent with the added quior like AHHHHHHHH whenever an aspiration is completed, which is a joviel touch. Even the new sim radio tunes are on the right side of silly. Sometimes, it does all get a bit samey and annoying - perhaps some more variation in tunes between the neighbourhood, create-a-sim and create-a-house thing wouldn't have gone astray, but mostly good news here. - 9/10.

FEELZ

Ah, The Sims. There's alot to like about the Sims franchise in general. The concept of creating this person that you can manipulate at will imbeds the player with a great sense of power. It is something that has been strong amogest all the Sims games. This powerful feeling still lingures, although some of the magic is starting to fade away. Not only is this the 3rd game in a row like this but also what feels like the 1,000,000th edition to this game. It's suffers from a classic (and somewhat severe) case of 'franchise fatigue' as I like to call it whereby the company tries to bleed every last penny out an initially successful game rather than come up with a new idea by tweaking and perfecting. Doesn't mean the game is bad as per se but it feels like it could be so much more and probably would be if the company wasn't to busy trying to hold back on ideas. Here we see DLC varation in it's most hideous form and, worse still microtransactions, which are pretty much the gaming equivilant of a sin in paid games. This is a proper game, I expect proper standards right from when I put the money on the table and it's a great shame when the company holds back. 

Basically, it really does feel like you are being ripped off big time but what you do get fed by the EA machine is pleasent enough to taste... even if it is a little familiar. - 7/10.

ADDITIONAL:

- The initial load time is horrid, especially with all the DLCs. Hell, they even patched it with a mini-game it's that bad. It's as bad as Dues Ex Machina.

- The game glitches out more than it should but nothing that won't stop gameplay all together... it's just a bit much, even for an open-world.

I personally did not expect Sims to travel down the road of Microtransactions, but it's a fantastic game that'll keep you busy for hours, especially if you've played and enjoyed previous Sims games.

Pros:
- Hours of fun, "replayability" is high
- Clever programming, Sim interaction is interesting to watch
- The price of the base game is a lot cheaper than it used to be
- Plenty of building tools to keep you creating awesome things
- Extensive character customization

Cons:
- Microtransactions, Simpoints are terribly overpriced
- Game crashes sometimes, mostly due to a memory error
- Sim interaction can sometimes be glitchy and everything will come to a standstill in-game
- Forced to pay real world money for some necessary items
- Expensive DLC packs that make your wallet cry

TL;DR: If you like Simulation games, you'll like this. The base game is great on its own, but if you want to explore what else this game has to offer, prepare to pay an absolute shitton of money, and expect some lag. Overall, would recommend.

Pros: There's lots of customization available to you as you create your sims, both in looks and personality, so you can easily and creepily recreate your old uncle Frank and live out his life if you really wanted to... Their AI isn't horrible, and they will self-perserve as best as possible without your input (although they're still horrible at it). There are also a lot more interactions with the world and other sims that help flesh out your little community.

Cons: You need the DLCs. Maybe not all of them, but you need at least one of the larger expansions and a few content packs. The base game is okay, but it's obvious that a lot of things that should have been in the base game, such as modifications and extra options for various careers, were not in specifically so EA could sell it to you later. And as always, the more add-ons you have, the worse the game performs, so there's always this balancing act. 

Pro?Con?: You will wonder where the last 8 hours of your day went... frequently.

Verdict: I can only recommend this game earnestly if you are okay with buying some of the DLC. If not, then you're in for maybe 15 hours or so of enjoyment before you get bored of having the same items, doing the same careeers, and generally following the same path over and over again.

A cute and suprisingly fun game. Although it will nag you regularly about it, the game is playable without creating an EA account. If you already have an Origin account with another game, just furnish your Steam product key to link it. Loading times are much longer than I expected, but everything ran fairly smoothly after that. On my first Sim, I noticed a lot of frequent lags as we were waiting for the Grim Reaper to show up. I'm not sure whether it was some background process on my machine or the game itself, but considering that it didn't start until a few days before Death came knocking, I'm tending to believe it's the game. Actions would lag for a second or so a couple or three times per minute. Really annoying. Well worth the price if you can catch it on sale, but definitely not worth the full price tag, especially considering that Sims4 is due out in a couple of months.

(EDIT)Forgot a couple of things. When you register the game, you'll get 1000 Sim Points (worth about $10), but it will take some hunting to find them. They'll be on your store account page and will need to be redeemed before you can use them. EA is still EA, so expect to have additional content (microtransactions) dangled in front of you anytime you try to build/buy stuff in-game. Annoying, but totally in keeping with EA, so not surprising.

The Sims 3 is an awesome game that simulates life in fun and rewarding ways. There are a huge number of expansion packs and other DLC that add a great deal to the game. These range from small gameplay elements, to clothing and furniture, to new careers, worlds, and lifestates.

Although interest in this game is waning because The Sims 4 is due out soon, I'm sure fans will continue to play it for a long time to come. If for no other reason, then it will be a long while before TS4 will have anywhere near the amount of content that is now available for TS3 by means of expansion packs, stuff packs, and multitudes of mods.

If you like designing, building, and furnishing homes, then there is a great deal of fun to be had in this game.

If you like creating a character and making all their dreams come true, and achieving all their goals - romance, marriage, children, career, whatever - then you'll have a blast. If you'd rather choose some poor lost soul to torment, visit misery and an early demise upon ... this, too, can be arranged.

Whether you prefer to play as a family-oriented type whose focus is their family, as an evil mastermind who seeks political leadership of the world, as a 'romance' type whose life goal is to woohoo with as many sims as possible, or as a fire-fighting hero with a bent for community service, you can do it. This, and oh so much more.

Do you wish to play as a witch, a genie, a werewolf or vampire, a fairy, a ghost, or an ordinary sim? All these lifestates - and more - are available if you have the right expansion packs.

There are also multitudes of ingame achievements for those into that kind of thing (like me).

The only real negative, imo, is the cost if you want more than just the base game ... and believe me, you do. Which is why I waited for the Steam sales to purchase them.

Oh, the SIMS. The love we dare not speak its name. 

I remember playing the original and thinking that it was a lot like a game I had played way, way back in DOS land. Then Sims 2 came out and competely blew my mind, giving a whole new spin on the idea of the virtual dollhouse. It was a game you could walk away from, come back to, watch passively or interfere with. So imagine my surprise when Sims 3 said that the entire town was going to run simultaneously. I was shocked, outraged, and said I wouldn't play it.

I take everything back. The Sims 3 is a solid upgrade to the Sims 2 (though it crashes just as much, it seems) and the up-and-coming Sims 4 still appear to have everything that made the franchise great amounts of money for EA... and people are still waiting in the wings to give them more. Yes, EA, you've taken my money again and I gave it with a smile, a prayer, and a pony.

Rating: 9/10

The sims 3 is a very enjoyable game... WIth the DLC... I mean the core game is fun for the first couple of hours or even the first couple of days but it dries out quickly.

There isn't enough to do in the core game and if you want all the DLC you are going to need to pay approximately $400, I recommend getting the game right now during the flash sale or just when the game is on special so you can enjoy the game a little more.

Game elements like playing the Piano and going to university should realy be in the core game but no, you are going to have to pay for the "Late Night" DLC if you want a piano, or the "University Life" DLC if you want your sim to go streaking. With the DLC the game is exceptional but it costs far too much money to play the game without getting bored.

If you bought all the DLC for $400... You could have bought 50 if not more games for that value, cheap-ish ones of course but there are many impressive indie games out there, especially now that the summer sales are going round so you can get over 100 games and still have some change.

But as we all know EA are notorious for DLC so asking for less DLC that is cheaper would be asking too much so only buy this game if you have seen gameplay of the core game and seem interested enough or if you want to play for DLC.

Cons:

There's a lot I want to praise this game for. There's tons of sim customization options here, some very powerful building tools, and some pretty funny situations you can get your sims in. Even the pets have a ton of customization options available to them. In truth, when the mood hits me just right The Sims can feel like an incredibly satisfying game. Why can't I recommend this game then? 

I have probably over 500 hours clocked into this game on Origin. I have almost all the expansions, and a lot of fun memories with this game. In a lot of ways The Sims is like a seperate hobby branching off of your gaming hobby. The problem is that it's a stupidly expensive hobby for a game and, ultimately, feels like a huge waste of time. No matter what houses or community lots I create or fun families I put together, actually playing the game is often a huge head ache thanks to some pretty miserable pathing choices and unrealistic Sim interactions (why can't they just socialize with the people in the room with them while they are all doing different activities?). I often finding most of my time going into creating new lots for the game, but I have yet to ever make it through an entire generation without the game feeling simply too repetative, unimmersive, or just plain buggy as hell. 

There are some fantastic mods that can fix a couple of the issues I've pointed out above, but if you're new to the series bewarned that it is, without a doubt, a huge time sink and a very expensive one at that. Ultimately I think the promises of The Sims 4 has potential to fix many of my peevs with the game, but once again, what an expensive game to get into...

You have been warned.

I love video games, because they let you explore your wildest dreams.

For example, in the sims you can have a house and a good job.

Lets get the negs out of the way first.  1.  It's EA, so official support for it is crap, the tug-o-war for making it available on steam is tiresome, there are bugs in it that have not and will not be fixed, and it's expensive with more DLC/Expansions than any rational person would ever allow into their game.

Now for the positives:
Non-sims players -- this has a gameplay unlike anything else.  Yes, it's a sim, but it's a hybrid of a comedy sim (like surgeon simulator) and a serious sim (like Cities XL or SimCity 4).  There is tons of content in this game--only Skyrim compares to it in sheer scope, and the user-content community is arguably bigger than Skyrim.  Whatever you want your sim to do, chances are there is a way to scratch that itch in the game.  Be what you've always dreamed of being, or what you've never dared to.  
It's fun, it's quirky.  You can drop 20 minutes on it and be fine, or play it in 6 hour stretches.  It has all the good makings of a casual game, but plenty of options in it for more serious gamers.  It's not age-specific, or gender specific.  My daughters and I play it together frequently and enjoy it, and even my wife plays it.  It's kinda odd to say it like this, but it's the Disney of games--fun for families and all ages (and fortunately I haven't had to had the WooHoo talk with my 4 year old yet as a result of her playing)
Veteren sims players -- this isn't anything like The Sims 1 and 2.  You are not bound to lots, it's no longer about sending your sim out to their job in a good mood.  The city you live in is seamless and vibrant.  Everyone in the city is being simulated and living their life in the background while you play.  There are careers that require interaction that are fun, and there are ample ways to make money without even having a career.  The game doesn't end when you're fabulously wealthy either.  Every skill has its own journal with difficult tasks and opportunities that add an interesting new element to the game play.

The Sims is one of those games that really owns its genre. There's nothing to compare it to, which is why I think it does an amazing job at maintaining its position as the leading game in the 'Everyday Simulation' genre.

Positives:

Fun to create and support Sims, and is challenging enough to remain engaging
Fun to build homes

Negatives:

In sum, I reccomend this game only if you like games with no real objective or destination, and are willing to be patient while playing.

[Rating: 92/100]

Twilight begins with an unnamed narrator (whom we later find out is Bella) giving a brief account about how she is about to die at the hands of a hunter. She is dying in the place of someone she loves, and the narrator does not regret any of the choices that brought her to this point. The past few months have been extraordinary, and she cant complain.

Zip! Now were following the life of Isabella Bella Swan, our seventeen-year-old narrator. Bella is moving to Forks, Washington, to live with her dad. We later learn that she volunteered to do this so that she wouldnt hold her mother back from spending more time with her mothers new husband. Forks is isolated, cold, dreary, and wet, and Bellas relationship with her dad is distant, since she was raised by her mother in Phoenix. Bella's new life is dull until she gets a glimpse of the Cullen family  five gorgeous, mesmerizing siblings who attend her high school. She learns they do not socialize with anyone but each other. One of the boys in particular, Edward, pays her close attention and seems to regard her with alarming hostility when she's forced to sit next to him in Biology class. The next day, he is absent from school.

Bella continues to adapt to her new life in Forks. She gets a lot more attention from boys than she was used to in Phoenix. She makes several friends quickly. A few days later, Edward finally is back in school. Now hes friendly to Bella. His mere presence excites her. That afternoon in the school parking lot, a boys truck almost hits Bella after skidding on some black ice, but Edward uses his body as a shield in order to save her. Wait, howd he do that?! Bella is totally baffled by this, but Edward refuses to explain his inhuman strength. She begins to have dreams about Edward, but at school, he gives her the cold shoulder. His behavior is very confusing, indeed.

Bella gets asked to the upcoming school dance by not one, but three boys, all of whom she rejects. The next day, Edward gets Bella to talk to him during lunch  for the first time hes spending lunch apart from his siblings. Knowing that she's trying to make sense of his strength and how he saved her, Edward asks for her theories on him. Next, its lets-figure-out-your-blood-type day in Biology class, and Edwards skipping class. Bella becomes faint at the mere thought of blood, and gets taken to the nurses office (Edward appears outside and intercepts her from Mike, one of the guys who has a crush on Bella). Edward insists that he take her home.

That weekend, during a trip to a beach at La Push Indian reservation, Bella meets Jacob Black, who tells her about the cold ones (vampires). Word around the reservation is that the Cullens are vampires. When Bella gets home, she does some internet research and things start falling into place. Bella decides that shes too in love with Edward to resist him, even if he is a vampire.

Soon after, Bella takes a trip to Port Angeles with a few friends, where she gets lost looking for a bookstore. Some thugs almost attack her in a dark alley, but Edward appears in his shiny Volvo and saves her. They have dinner together, and he drives her home. He reveals that yes, he is a vampire. Edward doesnt want to be a monster, though, and actually only drinks the blood of animals. Bella knows now that he does thirst for her blood, yet she still is in love with him. Edward repeatedly warns Bella that she should be afraid of him and stay away, if shes smart.

Edward and Bella take a mini-field trip together and spend the afternoon in a nearby secluded meadow, where Edward shows Bella that his skin sparkles in the sun (which is why vampires only come out at night or on cloudy days, which are common in Forks). They are completely in love. They kiss for the first time. Bella learns more about Edwards family and their past. Edward struggles with abiding his morals (not tempting himself by getting close to a human) versus what he desires  to be near Bella. 

Edward spends the night in Bella's bedroom, watching over her as she sleeps (without her dad knowing, of course). Bella visits Edwards house, meets his family, and learns more about their kind  vampires who dont feast on humans. They go back to her house where Jacob and his father Billy Black show up to see her dad (Billy and Charlie are friends). Being a Quileute elder from the La Push reservation, Billy knows about the Cullens' secret and is worried for Bella's safety. He warns her to stay away from the Cullens. After the Blacks leave, Edward returns in his brother's jeep to pick up Bella. Theyre going to play baseball. It's a Cullen family bonding ritual, evidently.

While the Cullens are playing their crazy version of baseball (they're all incredibly strong and fast), three other vampires show up. One named James takes a liking to Bella (in the I want to eat you kind of way). Edward and his family get Bella away from James long enough to make a plan. They know that James is trying to track Bella, so Alice and Jasper (Edward's adoptive siblings) whisk her away to a hiding place in Phoenix, but James lures Bella to him by telling her that he has captured her mom. Hes about to kill Bella when the Cullen clan shows up. The only problem is that James has already bitten Bella. If Edward doesn't suck the venom-infected blood out of her, she'll become a vampire. Though it's difficult for Edward to control his urge to suck all of Bella's blood, he manages to cure Bella without killing her. The Cullens kill James and get Bella to a hospital, where she starts to recover from her many injuries. 

Overall Bellas OK, though banged up. She and Edward are more in love than ever. However, they argue because Bella wants him to bite her and make her into a vampire so that they can live together forever; Edward refuses. Regardless of their different species, they are devoted to one another completely.

In the Epilogue, Edward surprises Bella by taking her to the prom  she's horrified because she's uncoordinated and worried about dancing in public. Jacob shows up at the dance and delivers a message  Billy wants Bella to dump Edward. He also wants her to know that they will be watching (Epilogue.118). Anyway, Edward and Bella go outside to have some time alone  its twilight outside. Again, Bella asks Edward to make her into a vampire, and he refuses. Edward says to Bella, I will stay with you  isnt that enough? and she replies, Enough for now (Epilogue.204).

Life sucks sometimes.  We all know that.  Well if your life sucks, the Sims 3 is probably a game you'd love.  You can design Sims, and make their lives glamourus or make their life as sucky as yours.  Or you can be a mass muderer and just kill every Sim you meet. :D  But anyways . . . the Sims 3 is a really great game.  The best feature by far in the game, though, has to be all the possiblilities.  I know this is a huge marketing thing for the game, but it's so true.  You can have a Sim with a green thumb, flirty, and a bookworm who's rich and has a massive house, or you can make an evil, athletic Sim with commitment issues, who's broke and is a criminal.  You can literally do almost anything.  And with all the expansion packs (none of which I have BTW, I'm broke, like I said, life sucks), you can do even more.  Oh, and if your one of those people who think the Sims is boring (I mean, whi wants to order Sims around, it's hard enough to have to get outta my office chair to grab a pop) you just have to try it to know it's not.  I didn't even know what it was about before I played it, and when I did <3 !!!!  There are only a few complaints I have with the game, for one, the Sim creator is a little laggy, (not sure if it's the game of the computer, actually), for two, it takes a loooooooong time to load (once again, not sure if it's the game or the computer), thirdly, I wish controling Sims actions at jobs was part of the game, and not an exansion pack, and lastly, and the biggest complaint . . . THE SIMS 4!!!!!!!!!  It's coming out soon, and it's the sole reason I wouldn't suggest this game.  I've even watched a few videos on it, and it looks like all my complaints (other than the job thing) are being fixed (unless it's my computer, in that case :( ...) it's also a lot more detailed in the Sim creator part.  I would deffinatally recommend this game, it's a great addition to any game collection.  :D
~Poe out

Graphics? 6/10, I've seen better, but it appears they put more into it than they should have, given other areas of the game.
Audio? Yet again, I've seen better. Another 6/10.
Creation freedom? 9/10, I've only seen better in a select number of MMO's.
Fashion freedom? 7/10, I love it, but to get some of the... flashier/faddish pieces, you must pay more.
Building freedom? 9/10, I'm horrible about just playing with the housing and not the sims. A few things that could be improved on, like pathing and such, but good over all.
Furnishing freedom? 8/10, same issue as the fashion bit honestly, but doable if you're willing to custom texture things.
Gameplay? 7/10, it's pretty good. I've only come across one or two gamebreaking glitches, and those never ruin more than one character to my experience.
Overall? 10/10... Why? Because it's addicting. And makes many hours vanish. And also stirs more ideas up just playing around with it than many a game I've seen to date. The world is yours, play with it.

Note: I'll admit the price of addon's is extreme. Do NOT recommend for the funding deprived/limited gamer... outside of 50~60% off Steam sales. Then dive in!

I've put so much money into this game.

When you make characters they end up being the same, because you need them to be practical and functioning - it's boring in that respect. The jobs and career tracks are severely limited, and if you want more careers, you need to pay $40 for the DLC. If you want more than the ugly clothing, $20 DLC. If you want pets, $20 DLC. If you want new towns, they can cost from $20 to $40-50 - and don't come with new careers anyway. If you want new towns and new careers, be prepared to pay $60-$100 extra. I wasn't prepared, nor will I be.

Another installment of The Sims. Even though I skipped Sims 2, it's hard to see where all those years of developing a game have gone into. Most mechanics are a bit more refined and expanded compared to the first installment but I haven't noticed any mayor changes in gameplay or graphics. I felt that earning an income is ridiculously easy, almost any activity can make you some income, from a regular job to selling your fruits harvested in your backyard, even picking up rocks and catching butterflies in the town. It gets hard not to make a ton while playing with any sort of focus.
Of course, Sims comes with a ton of expansions and DLC. So far I haven't felt the need to expand from the core game since there's plenty here to keep you busy. Though the game is stingy in the amount of villages to live in (1) and intersting plots to build on.

I really love this game. It is very addicting, with all of the varied ways of creating Sims and somewhat-limited possibilities for houses. I've never played the DLC, but I'd love to give it a shot. Even though I like this game so much, there are some bugs. It may just be my computer, but sometimes some of the Sims won't even show up; therefore I can't even interact with them. At all. And that really sucks when it's your Sim. Also, I've had a Fireman, and at a different time, a Firewoman glitch and stay in my home for weeks on end after I burned my kitchen down. Other than that, it's an amazing game that is so much fun!

I never seem to get tired of this game... in the beginning, they are learning who to be [I give them full willpower so they become molded individuals] and it is extremely hands-on. After they have mastered skills, you can let them go for a more "video break" day off - I like to let them do what they want all day, here and there, and they remember to feed the fish! Plus, you get to see what they choose to eat, watch, play, etc...even when they want to go to sleep! I like the mini-movies in STO episodes too; so maybe it's me.

I did some hardware work on my computer and am having to install the game again; took a while to figure out what the problem was too! I've missed it...it can be very relaxing after playing battle games. I like to let it play at normal speed while they are at work sometimes - to watch the rest of the map move around. It's the only game I've ever played where you can do that. Usually, you are restricted to your character.

Side note, great for reinforcing "planning" ...if you don't plan, train, work, etc - you just die! It's not a bad game to reinforce responsibility; so it's oddly educational... I started thinking in steps again; like I did during my career climb in real life. I must also mention that your reputation matters; people talk in this game! Do something in public - everyone soon knows. I think it is a great gauge for social skills too...if you are rude, people don't cooperate. But that sounds less fun than it is!!! Sorry for that.

Bottom line: it offers variety. Fast forward thru everything or watch it play out...follow them up close or from a distance... make them lazy or a perfectionist - which does effect their moods! Always remember that you cannot make them lazy then force them to work out all the time; their mood will go south! [I like to do random traits sometimes, it changes the play... the Sim needs to be happy!]

The Sims 2 is my favorite Sims version, hands down. I have sunk in a lot of hours on that clunker on how much IMPROVEMENT it had over the Original Sims and it's console counterparts. It introduces Aging, towns, the Supernatural, 3D archetecture, Floors, and just...so much stuff that it is hard to comphrend how many things it has done.
Sims 3, however...isn't that. It kinda...uhm...isn't really as fun.

Sims 3 looks and runs a LOT better than Sims 2, don't get me wrong. The visual design works in it's favor of making characters look realistic as well as adding a town that doesn't require a long-crack loading screen. But when I bought Sims 3 and started playing it, It felt empty rather than full. 

Not once did I actually play the In-Game families, when in Sims 2 I took a big love of the single mom and her dedicated son, the three dudes and the little alien baby (...Just got that reference) And the Goth Family just being cool again. But with Sims 3, I cannot recollect a single memorable sim that just made me think: "Yeah, that WAS a fun family to play with". But...I GUESS you can play as a custom sim? You know, the one with only a dozen or two default hairstyles?

And let's get it out of the way. The Sims is just a dollhouse simulator for adults and kids, and we just like building our little 'family' to play around with. But with Sims 3, it feels more like a Lego simulator, where you have to buy all the hairparts and 
the brick parts and the clothes parts and the blah blah parts, and all of them are just so god dang expensive! 

Even without the price tag, each DLC actually kind of RUINS the main vanilla flavor of the Sims 3 base game. It use to be where ghosts and the unknown were strange scary things, where the threat of death can come at a moments notice and surviving through to old age means you are a cool dude. Now, there are werewolves running around my town with a full moon every few nights, a dozen deer just running around yukking it up, and FESTIVAL EVENTS ARE COMING UP even though you bought the DLC to just get the hairstyles! It just muddles the main point of where I just want to let my sim live a normal life, not to become a immortal werewolf fairy vampire who has the big bucks and is married to Chuck the plumber.

I would love a Sims game where you can actually customize the length of the hair, the fabric and length of the clothing, the dreams and desires of a Sim where the actions can't be overridden, I just want a Sim game where it just takes place in a house, and you raise a sim from being a baby sim into being a dead ghost sim. Just...please.

Suggestions to Game Devs: Try to focus on making a game where the character's personality actually defines how they dress and how they interact with others. It would be SO MUCH FUN to just have Sims interacting without our guidance.

I must say that I do love the Sims as a franchise. And yes, I will admit that having to pay for multiple little cool things in a game is a horrible idea. But the base game alone is worth adding to your collection of games. It is a unique simulation and can provide some expirimental, time-wasting fun. And it also provides a great base for the modding communtiy to get their creativity on. But without the mods or certain expansion packs, I must admit that it is a very lack-luster and thinly spread game. Comparing the base game to either a modded game or a game with all of the expansions and "stuff packs", it is an overly-simply good idea than anything else. Creativity is at play, yet the microtransactions are strong in this one. I'd make sure to download many mods and to turn off the in-game payment system in the Options to get a very true and personal experience with this fun simulator.

Good, but damned expensive.  Especially considering:
 The game is relatively ancient.
 They're getting set to release a new version of the game.
 As soon as this version was released, they literally turned off support for the last version of the game.

I play the game like an RPG.  Subsequently, I end up working to keep my character "young," even as the world ages around her.

The game allows for an immense amount of freedom, and has very interesting content.

Unfortunately, for a game that costs as much as this one does, they seem to have some pretty big major oversights:
 They have a micro-transaction system that isn't micro and requires buying points.
 Their in-game store does not work with the Steam Wallet.
 Some of the expensive content in their store could well - and probably should - be offered on Steam as DLC instead of from their store.
 The game should have Steam Workshop integration.
 They have a free toolset that will not work with the Steam version - unless  you're willing to edit your registry and perform a wide variety of other advanced tasks in order to trick it.
 The game has some pretty basic bugs, and have always had those bugs, and requires mods just to keep the game playable.

Please note most of the problems I've noted just wouldn't be "problems" if the game wasn't still so expensive.  For example:
 Simply releasing a version of the game with all the content available for it included in the purchase price, even at a cost of around forty dollars, would render my complaints null.
 Either making the base game "free" as in beer, and bringing the costs of the DLC down to no more than a few dollars each.

A fun game, and with the Sims 4 coming out soon you'll most likely be able to catch the DLC on deep sale soon.

Alright, let's get the bad out of the way first:

- Yes, there's a lot of DLC for this game. The total cost is almost $500 to get all the content available on Steam. Even if you don't buy any of the Stuff Packs, which only contain decorative items, you're still spending like $340. There's even more in the online Sims 3 store, most of which is just recolors or redecorations of existing items, but there are at least a dozen premium items that add new functionality to the game...and they cost more than $100 total too!

- The game is VERY buggy and slow. Any time you have to change maps (Create a Sim, Change Outfits, any expansion lot, etc), you have to go through a loading process that can take a while too. Compounding the problem is the "Hidden Objects" Loading Screen game that EA uses to advertise Sims 3 expansions and stuff packs. Once you get in the game, you have to deal with memory leak issues, which means that the game will get slower and slower the longer you play. The problem isn't too bad if you have just the base game, but each additional DLC you add on, the slower it gets. As for the bugs, the list gets too long to mention here. The major ones that I have experienced are that some of the icons don't always load and the Sims will have severe pathfinding issues from time to time. Don't get me started on the minor issues though...

- Make sure you have PLENTY of space. The game itself takes about 32 GB of the hard drive you install it on, which could be rather important if you choose to install Sims 3 on a SSD, which would help with the long loading times I mentioned earlier. In addition to that, the saves and any custom content you download from Sims 3 Store can also add to the bulk. Saves + custom content generally installs itself in your Documents folder, which means anyone who has a small SSD for their OS will have to be careful, since they can take 10+ GB of space as well (my saves + custom content is about 9.7 GB).

Alright, so those are the major bad points I can think of. Do the good points outweigh the bad? Well lets see:

- The game is fairly addictive for me at least. Even though this game is officially a simulation, I treat this game more like a RPG, as you get to customize your characters (Sims), help them train their skills, get better at their jobs, go on adventures (expansion packs required for this part though), and various other things. Even though the game premise (simulating real life) doesn't sound like a particularly exciting thing to do, it actually is quite fun. Your Sims has six basic needs in game: Hunger, Fun, Bladder, Hygiene, Social, and Energy. Trying to satisfy all of those needs while simultaneously trying to get the Sims to get better at various things is a challenge that requires planning and a lot of in-game/real world time. Besides, as you improve your Sims and they get more money, they can buy more stuff...and who doesn't like (pretending) to buy more stuff?

- There's a fairly high degree of customization available in the game. Within the game itself, the number of items available *might* be fewer than in the past, but each item can now have variations, many of which you can customize yourself. In addition, even if you don't get any DLC, there's plenty of free customized content available to download online, and, if you are talented/feeling adventurous, you could always design your own.

Conclusion:

I really wish Steam had a recommendation system ranging from 1-5 stars instead of a simple Yes/No recommendation because getting the game is ultimately a tricky decision. You will definitely have to put up with a lot of various frustrations in the process of playing the game, and patience is certainly required. In addition, even though you can perfectly play the game without any of the DLC, I'm pretty sure that anyone who buys the game without any DLC is constantly going to be either tempted by all the additional features of the expansions or just simply bombarded by the blatant advertisement for the packs that EA sprinkles throughout the game. 

Still, if you are willing to deal with these faults and temptations, the game is certainly very fun to play. As I mentioned earlier, the game is certainly a good simulation game, and it does include good RPG elements as well. If you've played Sims 1 and 2 before, you already know more or less what to expect here, and (excluding bugs) the game is certainly better in every way. 

In summary, if there was a 5 star rating system, I'd probably give this game a 3.5. Great game, but certainly flawed in numerous ways.

I am male and i have played The Sims 3 a tonne. I have also played The Sims 2 a tonne. I gave this game a thumbs up but lets get started with the criticisms. The game mechanics are often clunky. Interactions between two sims require the two sims to be perfectly lined up and in sync in order for the interaction to be executed. This is frustrating when you are waiting for like ten seconds for two sims to interact. In the Sims 2, sims were capable of liking each other a different amount, but in this they always like each other the same. I don't know why they downgraded that aspect. If i made the game i would make the AI a lot better. I always have this beef with games. They never make the AI in games good enough. Good AI creates depth and makes the game a lot more replayable. It doesn't seem to bother people. Let's go through the pluses of the game. The Sims is a very unique concept and no game goes into such depth with social interactions. The game simulates a social society. I am too lazy to think of more positives, and to be honest, if they let me 'direct' the game i would have made it way better.

My review of this game is easily mixed, the game is very fun to play and enjoyable, but much more so with the downloadable content, or only a fraction of it.  Most of it is about half as expensive as the game itself where other content is even more expensive than that, there's plenty of useless add ons that only add a few cosmetic changes and nothing else.  More or less it's devided into two seprate groups.  Actual content and "Stuff" packs, the actual content is viable if it weren't more expensive, where as the "Stuff" packs only add a couple new stuff, ussually stuff that won't affect gameplay in the slightest outside of just being able to buy a couple extra stuff for twenty dollars.  

Essentially the only reason I got this game due to the price was because of a 75% sale that was going on, doing research on every little pack just in case I missed something, I've narrowed down some essentials to get if you purchase this game, but I'd only do so when it's on a 75% sale due to the fact all the DLC is over 250 US$ not including the game itself.
Needs:
Seasons: Adds a couple new traits, a lot of new winter coats plus normal everyday clothes ussually themed with seasons, as well as adds dynamic weather and a threat of dying from weather or getting miserable sun burn.
Pets: Adds a bunch of pets to the game, from cats, dogs, and horses which you can control to birds turtles and other non-controlable characters.  You'll spend a little less time speeding through your day when your sim is taken up at work or asleep this way.
Generations: Adds quite a few new traits and a new theme, scrapbook, which stores your memories, the pictures are taken a bit wonky half the time but it also lets you pick your wish no matter what which is always a plus.

The rest is based on oppinion such as a couple I haven't gotten, supernatual comes to mind on this one.

You should avoid at all costs unless you feel 100% sure it'll add a lot to your experiance is all the stuff packs.  Mostly servering souly for role play aspects (Which the modding community glady contributes as well for free) your packs come with generally a couple new things for males and a handful for females (very lopsided men are less important than females in this game it seems) these packs server only to take your money, in fact my suspicion is that the reasoning behind using your codes on the sims 3 website you get with your games is souly because EA Games is so terrified people will find out it's a bad deal and just hack the stuff into the game, which wouldn't surprise me given their more or less monopolistic aproach.

Verdict is the game is a avoid at all costs as you'll want to get a bunch of map packs, it's saving grace is that the stuff I found contributed to a great game is spending 60 US$ durring a 75% sale going on, but that's about 240 US$ out of a sale just to have a good game and that's only buying less than half the downloadable content.  Don't waste your money, wait for a sale or have been born very rich to not care, but this game so isn't worth the expense out of sale and DO NOT get this game if you don't have high end hardwear, this game will give issues to some better designed computers in its own.

Hmm. I am dissapointed and um... angry actually. This is one of the most dissapointing games I have ever played. Not because of gameplay, that part is great... when and if it happens. This is the most buggy thing I have ever played. I read the online reviews which warned me, but I have a great gaming computer with lots of resources and processing power, what could go wrong? My real issue (as far as I can tell) comes from the paradise island add on which consistently stalls and has a huge bug... I tried setting everything down way low but it was still stalling all the time. I would just go elsewhere (like university) and all would be fine, so I mostly played there. But i went on an 'adventure' and when i 'returned home' i got dumped on a tiny island with no ability to move physically at all and I mean at all,  no home no money no access to the other panels for phone or anything else. I have repeatedly gone back to my save and tried again but its the same thing and I can't go anywhere else... the worst part is that when the 'adventure' times out it just takes me there again and I can do no more. When you invest a fair amount of time building a character, which is what sims is all about, and then it gets destroyed by a glitch it really is annoying, and for a game that is this incredibly expensive it's inexcusable. If you still decide to pour your money down this money grubbing hole, don't get paradise island and really look at the forum for issues others are having before considering any other add-ons.  And hey Maxis, when you make a game this badly perhaps you want to take the time to fix it before putting out another rendition. Just sayin.

What a wonderful game!   It's really fun to play and it's like no other game made ever.   You could easily waste away hours on such a entertaining game.

Why do I not recommend it then you ask?   Easy.   Nothing ever works right.   The developers are more worried about getting the next DLC released so they can get more cash.   They really don't care if all the features in the game or the DLC don't work.  Oh?   You sent our sim to university and then it just vanished making the game unplayable?   Who cares because we already have your money!  Fun stuff.

It's really a shame that we, as consumers, put up with garbage like this.   If a game isn't complete it should not be released as a complete game. Then telling people the new DLC (which cost more money) will fix the problems. Then that DLC causes problems that you have to buy the next DLC to fix.   See what I am getting at?  This game is fun but the people who made it are more worried about coming up with ways to squeeze more money out of you than they are making an enjoyable gaming experience.

When you look at the number of players in the community and the number of DLCs for this game it doesn't take Adam Smith to figure out this title is raking in the cash.  You would think with that kind of money flowing the developers could at least spend a real effort getting rid of the bugs.   After two or three years games should not have bugs that make it totally unplayable.

Ask yourself.   Do I really want to experience the frustration of spending money on something that infuriates me before I get through the registration process?  Am I going to spend money on a game and time creating a sim just to have them vanish when I try to use the extra content?

I wish somebody would file a class action law suite against these guys.  If they had a real threat to their money perhaps then they would start making software that functions as advertised.

I hate this stupid game... yet I can't stop playing it.  There is something highly addictive to just growing people and thier environment.  This Sims has opened up the world.  I felt in the previous Sims that you were constrained to the needs of your Sims to the point where you couldn't actually go anywhere and spend enough time to enjoy it.  All that has changed.  Character needs are lessened a bit and you can now carry most of the needed items with you.  Exploring towns that are full of collectibles  with characters that respond differently to situations turned out to be really fun.  It was the World Adventure DLC and Supernatural DLC that really nailed me into the game.  The Genie race can magically take care of many critical needs while out adventuring which made everything much more fun.  Traveling to china to learn martial arts and then traveling to Eygpt to take on dungeon puzzles and karate chop mummies was fantastic.  If you plan to travel this long time-sucking but enjoyable path, buy the game and the DLC's when they are on sale.  The normal prices for these are ridiculous. Also choose the DLC's wisely, some are little more than costumes and knicknacks.

I think the Sims 3 was okay but compared to the Sims 2 it falls short in MANY ways, Originally the sims 1 was supposed to be all open neighborhoods with no loadscreen between houses,etc and all familys going simultaniously, but computers of the time just couldn't and weren't able to do that sort of processing just yet. The Sims 2 on the other hand allowed players to finally go INSIDE the Sim's places of work and to build it and even run it (to a degree) and you could even visit it with your other sims, etc -> this is one MAJOR thing I feel was left out of the Sims 3. I also don't care for how cartoonish the Sims series has become, The Sims 1 was sophisticated and articulate but the sims 2 got more childish and the sims 3 is just a complete mess, The makers of the game need to appease to all age-groups, I couldn't imagine this game making me feel any younger way into the future one far off day when I am in my 80s vs. some maxis classics like Simcity 2000. I -am- aware that will wright didn't make the Sims 3 and that that may be a HUGE part of it but still, The cartoonish-ness levels need to be brought down heavily. With that being said if I could give this a nutral rating a would, I will do a thumbs up but only because the game itself can still be a lot of fun, but only in limited amounts,

I really enjoyed playing the base game until I started to invest in the expansion packs.  Stability problems, freezing and random quitting were some of the problems I've experienced.  It's a shame because I've always enjoyed the series.  But it seems that the more expansion packs you add, the more problems seem to show up.  It was running OK for a while when I had just installed Night Life...I only noticed some slowdown here and there.  However, I picked up three expansion packs during the Steam Winter sale.  In doing so, my game became unplayable.  My previous towns were all suddenly gone and any game that I created thereafter always became corrupt.  It's rather frustrating and I wish I could get my money back at this point.  Forums don't seem to be of much help either.  I just had my computer built in Spring 2013 with WIndows 8, so my computer is not the issue.

In the end, I DO recommend the base game to loyal fans.  However, just be warned that the expansion packs may completely ruin your ability to play, regardless of how new your computer is.  Since the expansion packs are what previously made this game's replayability so high, overall it's a disappointment and I regret having wasted money on broken expansion packs.

The DLC is fucking annoying (there's always something you have to buy with real money being shoved in your face) and the online stuff can be a bit tedious, but it's still the same old sims with some added bonuses.

This time there's a far more open and refined town system, with one open world which sims can move around in at any time. Sims can now own cars or bikes and head to the shops, the local pool, work, etc. without relying on taxis or carpools. Want to visit your sim's ingame friend or love interest? Hop in the car and head over there right away! Your sim miss the bus to school? No worry, hop on that bike and still get there on time! This new method gives sims more time to do stuff as there's less waiting around and makes the surrounding world seem more like a living, breathing entity than ever before in the series. When playing the sims 2, I always felt like my sims were cut off and confined to their own little bubble, but this game changes all that for the better.

This new system also means there are no more loading times whenever your sims leave their home lot (provided you stay in your current town, that is). Of course the tradeoff is that loading times when starting the game and entering your world seem longer than the previous games. If you're planning to play for extended periods of time, it's not a real issue and may actually have saved you time. However it does make playing for shorter bursts less viable.

Another major bonus in this game? There's an option in the base game to make sure everyone ages up at the same time (It's on by default but can be turned off at any time). This means your sims won't reach elder status while their friends are still children like some freakish simmified version of Jack. This makes working on friendships and first loves for child and teen sims worthwhile for a change. Add to that the improved romance/relationship/socialisation/personality systems, it's a really good deal during any sales.

Just DON'T bankrupt yourself with all the DLC/Expansions. Sure, there are some decent ones like Ambitions, but some of them (like Diesel Stuff) are just there to feed EA's money addiction. I'm sure cynics such as myself might wonder why some of these expansions weren't implemented into the base game, seeing as similar (and sometimes almost exactly the same) expansions were availible for the previous game. I guess it's just a sign of the times.

Instead of giving EA even more dosh that they don't deserve, check out one of the many community content sites for free stuff such as clothes. Sure, a lot of it looks like it was designed by the person who wrote My Immortal, but there are still some decent (free!) clothes and hair items to expand the moderately sized amount availible ingame. There are more you can buy ingame with sim points, but they cost you real money! That being said, you do get a small amount of points for free when you get the game. Make sure to spend them wisely.

In summary, if I'd have bought the game when it first came out, I'd likely not be recommending this game and be warning you of it being a ripoff. But I didn't buy it then. Instead I bought it several years after it came out and got it for cheap in a sale. For the price I got it, it's a really good game and I made a few smart choices with the expansions to get the most for my money. It's got some issues here and there, but I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the previous games and has a decently powered PC.

Did you love Sims 1, Sims 2? You'll love Sims 3. 

...If you want to pay this much for very little... What made the previous Sims so fun? The excessive options in clothing, furniture, etc. With Sims 3, its a little different. You'll pay 40 for the standard, and being a Sims fan you'll spend another additional 20-40 bucks for an expansion. 

What you think you get? A world full of options, diversity and the start of loads of fun. 
What you actually get? A hollowed out game. Lacking content compared to the earlier games. The diversity of clothing, furniture, house options, etc, its been minimized. But, EA, being as lovable as they are will give you a chance to add some of that content back.

You want to use this piece of furniture? Yes? Pay extra money. 
Oh you want to make use of the different towns in your options menu? Well, better pay some more money. 
This particular shirt is featured today, if you want it.. you better pay more money. 

Sims 3 will use any and all means neccesary to make you pay more money for stuff that should've been in the game in the first place. You buy the 'locked' stuff with points. These points can only be purchased with real money and there is no way to earn them. 

You pay for a pedigree dog, and you get an emaciated mutt.

I love Sims 3, but dont bother buying it unless its on one hell of a sale.
