Sims 3 Is an insult not just a shitty game

There are two main points to why Sims 3 is a terrible game. Despite the graphical advancements and optimization that make Sims 3 a much smoother game than previous titles, Sims 3 fails to deliver an actually game experience that is rewarding. This and atrocious advertising by EA/Maxis make the game a flop. Here are the reasons broken down.
 
1) In game advertising. This was such a new low in all my time of playing video games. At every turn, the game is selling you something more. IN THE GAME!!! And if its not useless then its obviously removed from the final product. Selling 20 DLC is one thing (that I object to FYI) but selling you furniture in the game building menu, loading screens that were for DLC, and then asking you to post your screen shots on Facebook... wow that is just putrid. Your playing of the Sims 3 is not a game, but an extended infomercial. 

2) I simply found Sims 3 to be a series of mini-games rolled into one. Career advancement, needs, lifetime aspirations, friendships, it was all just so boring to check off one task after another to satisfy each 'aspect' of the game. None of these things made a difference with each other. 

Dont go to the bathroom and  yourself? no worries, this has no affect with the sim you're talking to. Cheat on your sim significant other? who cares, you'll still get a promotion at work. Achieve the lifetime aspiration? not a bid deal, since you'll get one more pointless talk bubble with another sim that wont mean anything. 

Its just frustrating to see that the game has so many aspects that play like mini-games since they have no bearing on anything else. You'd think a close sim dying would remove options for your playing sim since a traumatic death would scare/encourage certain developments. Nope

Also failure in the game means nothing. Got rejected from WooHoo? Got fired? Got a sim cheating on you? this will not hinder or alter the game for your sims life. How can this be a game mechanic for success?

If you are of the perspective that in game sales arent a big deal, well then this failure of gameplay cant be ignored. What a sad story this franchise has had, going from on eof the most popular games out there (16 million units sold for Sims 1) to a laughing stock example of DLC cash cows.

Save yourself the Simolians and don't buy this game. And if this game is a looking glass into the future, don't buy Sims 4, either. Sims 2  is better for less. Yes, Sims 2 has more limitations than Sims 3, but you have more fun playing it because there are far more items to choose from. Example: Sims 2, you could buy a hot tub or two, or, even a couch that you can find funky things growing in it. The experience was a lot more fullfilling with the cool things you could get, and discover what they do. In Sims 3, if you want something remotely interesting, prepare to dish out more money. That's right! Get only some boring mundane things and no interesting things by purchasing the game! Everything else comes at an added price. Oh! But maybe you could get MORE interesting things if you dish out an extra 30+ dollars for an expansion pack! Oh yeah. They have like, seven expansion packs right now. All with things you should probably have gotten in your full-priced game you already bought.

The Sims is very addictive, but save yourself some money and get Sims 2. Or better yet, don't support EA at all with their cash-cow ways.

This is mostly written to address my concerns with previous reviews. I am assuming that the person reading this knows what the game is about and has read some of the other reviews.

On the game itself:
-Yes, it can get very micromanage-y, but that's what the game is: a life simulator with architecture and interior design thrown in. It's been this way since the development of the first game, when playtesters enjoyed the Sims more than the actual building aspect. 
-There are a mutlitude of bugs, but most can be fixed with patches or mods. 
-The lag can get monstrous at times. These spikes tend to last about 10 seconds for me.

On modding:
-There is a very active modding community that releases a lot of well made content.
-If you are running the game with a lot of user-created content, expect to get more lag than usual.
-Be prepared to sift through all the nude mods and band t-shirts.

On the DLC:
-You can have a lot of fun with just the base game.
-I agree that the content is overpriced, which is why I tend to only buy them during a sale.
-The major DLC packs (Pets, Seasons, Etc.) bring hours of new content, options, and possibilities. Most include bug fixes. While their normal prices are still high, they're not as outrageous as people claim.
-The stuff packs are overpriced no matter how you look at it, in my opinion. I recommend staying away from those.

My rating: 7.2/10

Questions, comments, or concerns? Share them below. If you raise a good point, I'll be happy to modify this review.

The Sims franchise is one of the most profitable franchises in gaming and The Sims 3 shows you why. First off, I am a huge fan of the series even though I haven't played a Sims game since Sims 2 Castaway (which is another great game) I was clearly missing out on this game. Gameplay has not changed hardly at all since the original Sims in terms of day-to-day activities; eating, social, fun level, etc. With all of The Sims 3 DLC you could have literally hundreds of hours of fun. My only real complaint is that there is a vast amount of technical problems (I run this on Windows 8 so that might be the problem) quite a bit of framerate issues, slowdown and at least for me it takes almost 30-45 seconds to save your town/sim. If you can overlook the technical problems, this game truly is worth playing; all the DLC sweetens the pot to an already big game. I highly recommend this to seasoned Sims fans or for newcomers!

After forking over your hard earned simoleons for the base game, you will find you will find you are the subject of constant, ill integrated advertising for mods, new expansion packs, and other EA games. There is literally no point upon starting the game where you are not being sold something. Items available for purchase are at the beginning of all menus, rather than at the end, something I considered an aggressive design flaw, and turned me of any potential purchase.

That said, this game has strong sandbox play and is a significant improvement on previous versions. It is very easy to sink a few enjoyable hours into house, character, or neighbourhood design. Actual live mode gameplay is a little dull after a while, and improved through expansion packs - I recommend Supernatural, University, and Pets. 'Stuff' packs are really not worth purchasing unless on sale.

Overall rating of Sims 3: 6.5/10

I'm a huge fan of the The Sims franchise, so it comes as no surprise that I enjoy this game. However, maybe this review is useful to someone already familiar with the series.

There are several aspects about this iteration of the series that I dislike and which make me continue to view The Sims 2 as my favorite. I absolutely abhor having to see paid content in-game without having any interest whatsoever in ever buying it. I already spent more than $100 dollars on the base game and DLC. Why would I be charged for more and what justifies charging for it? Server maintenance, updates, and the cost of a Community Team (does The Sims even have one?) should be more than covered by that. So, besides the major issues of microtransactions being forced down one's throat, it also appears that getting free community content is much more of a hassle.  For starters, there is no Body Shop that allows you to easily create Sims and package them. There is no denying that the new Create a Sim tools are much more evolved and allow for much more customization, especially the ability to modify a Sim's body type, and the addition of true personality traits and combinations are great. However, there doesn't appear to be an easy way to share and obtain community content outside of EA's platform. I could list various other things that bother me about the game (e.g. Why are younger Sims so ugly? Why add rabbit holes?), but I think the attempts at money-making and sharing limitations are the main downsides to me.

On the bright side, the graphics are beautiful and the exploration options endless, especially with the DLC (which, I am sorry to say, one still has to get for a more complete game experience).

In some ways, this game isn't realistic enough.  I have an Irish wolfhound, and a burglar broke into my house and stole my things, all without a peep out of the dog!  Seriously?!  The dog had already been told to guard the house several times - which let's face it, you wouldn't have to do with a real dog, especially a breed like this, we're not talking chihauha here!  The dog should be programmed to automatically guard, and the burglar should be afraid of it.  Also, your dog runs away if you only feed it for a couple of days or so, and don't hug it, or play with it, or walk it, treat it, brush it ....

In other ways, the game is eerily realistic.  By the time my Sim gets up, showers, brushes her teeth, makes some breakfast, feeds the dog, plays with the dog, hugs/treats/or brushes the dog, takes out the trash, and recycles the newspaper, it's time to go to work.  And my sim only has a part-time job!!  Then she has to come home, make dinner, do the whole dog thing again, maybe find a bit of time to read a skill book, and go to bed.   Way, way, way too much like real life.  Except that I have a full-time job in real life.  Why on earth would I want to play a game that was as filled with mundane tasks and routine as my own life?  People play games to escape from that!  

I know, you can change the time speed.  But shouldn't the devs have already set it up as a default that the routine things don't take so long to do, so you don't have to constantly play with the time settings?  and shouldn't they have set it up so your sim knows what to do after you've done the same routine at roughly the same time on the same days, and your sim just goes and does it superfast, leaving you more time to go off and do other things in the game?  am I supposed to set this up, making routine lists and feeding them to my sim?   If I leave my sim alone to do things, she does stupid, pointless things like reading and re-reading Where's Bella, over and over again.  

Maybe I just don't know how to play this game, I know it's a popular game, and maybe there's a way around these problems that my 20  hours or so of playing hasn't been enough for me to find.   I get bored quick, though, so if a game can't me interested within that 20 hours, forget it.    Sims3 gets a big thumbs down from me.

I've really never written a review for a game before, so I will do my best to make this brief.  Sims 3 expands on a lot of the features from the previous installments, including adding some new features and then Electronic Arts to my surprise removed some features in this edition.  One of the features they removed that was in the Sims 2, was the ability to create new lots.  In the Sims 3 you are basically stuck with the pre-installed lots and then of course like the previous installments you have to buy all the expansions. 

Buying the expansions is not what bothers me. What bothers me is not being able to make my own neighborhoods and customize them to my personal tastes like I could in the second game.  I still wish I had it.  I only have the original content version so that is what my review is based on and not any of the expansions.  So I am not aware if they have changed that rule about you being able to create your own personal neighborhoods in now since later expansions have come out.  As I may or may not have read somewhere, The neighborhood creation feature is really the only thing that bugged me, other than that everything else right down to the increased character personalization options was incredible, not to mention I was rather impressed with the realism in the way the characters looked and acted.
Of courae the Sims is great, who doesn't love the Sims?! Get it while it's hot.

"But why?"  You might ask.  The extremely long rant to follow are *some* (not all, I am just tired of writing) my reasons:

This is a love hate thing with the Sims 3.  I was so addicted to Sims 2 I lost whole days sitting in front of my computer planning out their day to day routines and hoping that they actually did well.  (I know a lot of simmers just want the absolutely worst outcomes and love either killing and/or torturing their poor Sims) 

But this game changed that a little.  I still don't have a bunch of murder, sex or terror mods that make their lives truly miserable, but I don't care near as much for the characters I make or choose to play, I don't have much of a connection to them and sometimes I just stop caring and walk away leaving them to do their own thing until I just save and exit.  Sims 3 lost a lot of charm Sims 2 had and honestly, I blame this entirely on EA's way of thinking which seriously tanked in the customer help department about the same time.  It also began to be called the worst company every year and so on and so on.  The game is pushed more and more for microtransations and not much else now.  Especially with the upcoming Sims 4.  

Microtransactions are a good thing, do not get me wrong please.  These are very small purchases someone can make with real money online to pay for all different types of digital goodies to use in game.  For most things this is a term MMORPGs use and they sell cosmetic things.  Outfits, pets, mounts, hair, etc. etc.  

With games like Team Fortress 2 this has not only kept the game alive, but brought forth an entirely new type of community where artists and creators come together to make outstanding creations which the community can then vote on and the original creators can make real money from their serious effort and hard work; hand in hand with the original game's creators to make something entirely new.  This idea has even started to be embraced by MMORPGs such as EQ2 which now has their own type of workshop where players can now create things for that game.  It goes on and on and on how awesome microtransactions can be for a game, bring it back to life and keep it ticking with new content and eye candy for everyone.   It's even been how some companies now fund the next expansion, start new servers or how they are able to further polish their games.

Sims 3 though went and tore this concept apart (as far as I am concerned) and with Sim Points introduced a new low in this field.  Sim points are nothing new, the way they are handled in Sims 3 though is.  If you want to buy a certain type of object that has new animations and/or has an actual use in the game that would change it at all; then you cannot just buy that item but actually have to spend more money than you would just buying a stuff pack alone.  These things are usually leaning towards harassing the player even in their game to buy the items.  Everything with Sims 3 is an add to buy something else in Sims 3 and it never stops even when the player is playing.  You can turn these options off but let's look at the key point for EA: Sell items to little girls playing.  Mostly these little girls do not understand the value of a dollar, do not understand what EA is about or how little they could care.  I'm not saying a lot of companis are bleeding hearts but it's more than obvious that EA takes the cake when it comes to giving their customers the finger.  

On top of all of this, there are the bug and game stopping glitches.  I want to state first of all, ALL GAMES WILL HAVE BUGS AND GLITCHES ALL OF THE TIME ON ANY CONSOLE OR PC NO MATTER WHAT.  Even Mario still has glitches!  It doesn't matter, games cannot be 100% polished at all times, it is not possible.  But game breaking glitches that either force the player to stop playing, do not allow the player to continue to play or break the game entirely, ruin the save or even break itself; are out of the question!  Especially for such a large company!  Every time a Stuff or Expansion pac has come out, there is always a game breaking glitch that does one or more of these things.  

Late Night is a great example.  Mysteriously players suddenly had a horrible time trying to please or even sometimes control their Sims.  Sims would be unhappy no matter what the players did.  They would stay bright red day and night, become incresibly ticked off at all times, divorce one another without the player being able to stop it, kids would be taken away.  No one knew what was happening or how to stop it.  As it turns out, it was the beds.  For some unknown reason beds weren't working correctly in games.  They would cause the characters to become more and more upset until someone finally made a mod fixing this glitch.  The game breaking glitch was fixed well *after* Christmas, months after the game came out and the glitch was made aware by players on the forums of Sims 3.  Simply because the game wasn't tested enough nor were the customers heard. 

Game breaking glitches and huge annoyances adding to lag and unplayable situations are still in the game today even though Sims 4 has been announced and you can even pre-order it though they only have a handful of screenshots and a video that they have also stated will change.  

They make it so obvious that everything is only about money that they forgot the simple truth.  This is a game for kids and adults alike.  This is a learning machine for everyone and a fun experience to boot.  I would suggest playing the game.  With the right mods (Google NRAA Sims 3) this game is really fun.  It is very time consuming and if you are willing to face a serious challenge, (unless you don't want that you can always mod it too!) at least with your time, than I would suggest this.  It is a LOT easier than Sims 2, make of that what you will (if you played).  You do not need to know anything at all about Sims 2 to play this either which is another plus.  Although the cow plant is brought back and I adored that as well.  Yes it still eats Simmies.  Sims 2 was a huge challenge money and happiness wise, this is more of a "how much time are you willing to sit and grab achievements online, skill up, etc." type of thing.

Vivian Ward has found a way of living by working as a prostitute on Hollywood Boulevard. When she runs into the prince of her dreams, who comes along on his wild horse, she first does not recognize him as her saviour. The prince, a ruthless and wealthy businessman by the name of Edward Lewis, does not know that she could be more than just a girl from the sidewalk, but he changes his decision after the first night with the beautiful stranger. Her being the first person in a long time who could surprise him, Edward can slowly feel the light at the end of the tunnel. He is on his way to become a better person, whereas Vivian has got a new chance to start over again.
dis game is tight
Love being able to create my own quirky world and cause chaos wherever my characters go. Lots of great DLC packages for this game also.

I love this game.

I'm biased, the original Sims was the first normal PC game I'd ever owned and I loved it.

Now that that's out of the way, I never played 2 but everything I wanted from the original is here, you can walk outside of your lot and explore the neighborhood and you can age or go to another neighborhood for college.. You can even make friends with service workers because they're all Sims that exist in the town. It's amazing! If your Sim is a criminal you might see him rob another Sim if you aren't playing as him too!

All the inter-connections they've made are just a lot of fun. You can even eliminate having to micro-manage their needs almost entirely if you so wish to maximize time on progression.

I really can't list all that you can do because there is so much.

So quickly... Lots of job choices including work-at-home, expanded families and trees, option to have aging or not, ability to either micromanage all Sims in a town or let them follow their own will, and you can build basements! Not to mention all the other 'towns' your Sims can go to as vacations, trips, or education.

I do have some negatives about the game though. First, initially loading time is really long, understandable but still they could optimize it instead of the current 2-5 minutes it takes before you even get to play. Second, HUGE push towards their content marketplace. Users can still make their own content but the game pushes their own pay-for content more and it's not cheap (new towns can cost around 20 USD and items are usually 3-5 USD and more for sets of items) so be prepared to spend a lot of you want extra bits and pieces.

Finally, this is The Sims, even with the first series expect a lot of expansions. Thankfully, this game and all its expansions go on sale at least once a quarter so if you exercise patience you can get them all for 40-60% off which will save a tremendous amount of money.

So, don't let that deter you, it might cost a lot to get everything but you can still play fine with the base game and ruling over the lives of little digital people is always entertaining.

One final note, save often because the game can and will crash during long sessions.

8.5/10

Sims 3 includes all the classic fun of The Sims and The Sims 2, plus a lot of swank new tools (like the Basement Tool and the Fountain Tool) that let you build even better houses than ever before.  Individual Sims are still as fun, weird, and entertaining as they've always been, and the "open neighborhoods" introduced with Sims 3 just lets that fun spread.  

My main criticisms of this game are first: it's a resource hog, so it can be very difficult to run on an older computer or one that's been weighed down with a lot of other active applicatoins.  Two: it has a lot, lot, lot of outstanding bugs.  Many of those can be dealt with through the use of third-party mods and scrupulous computer maintenance, but really, I do wish the game developers took bug fixes more seriously.  Despite all that, I come back to Sims 3 time and time again and I have a lot of fun every time I do.

With such an open world, the possibilities are endless, and I don't think I'll ever -- no matter how much I play -- manage to see 100% of this game.
My life would be intensely more productive if this game had not sauntered into it. Also I like whatever the font choice was for this review box.

Sims 3 has two extremes, either you will get bored of it real quickly or you'll end up spending hundreds or thousands of hours playing this game for any reason.

Sims 3 offers really many thing you and your creations can do, design houses or clothing styles for your Sims or see if your Sims can makes hotdogs without killing themselves. Recreate video game characters and start making a horrific slash-fic, design a mental institution for your household of clowns, recreate yourself an make it succeed in whatever you dreamed to be.

If the base game gets boring, expansion packs helps bring new flavor to your game, like Nightlife gives you lounges and bars,  Seasons gives you weather and Pets gives you...you guessed it, pets. If expansion packs aren't your thing, there exist tons of mods for you to play with, in fact there exist several mods that should be essential for everyone to have (Nraas Overwatch and Nraas MasterController).

The only problem with Sims 3 is it often lags and freezes, the expansion packs are too expensive, and the autonomous behavior of other Sims can be very undesirable. Certain mods should fix two of the three problems mentioned here, and you know which one it doesn't fix.

I used to be a huge fan of this series, and I kind of have a love-hate relationship with it. I can even remember watching my mother playing Sims 1 when I was like, three. When I played Sims 2, I owned every EP. I once was able to call this my absolute favorite series, until I came to the realization that the game plus all the expansion packs cost around $400, and as amazing as the game is, I dont think $400 is worth it. Its extremely difficult to play this game and not drool over the expansion packs, so I just kind of stopped playing it. I recommend this game if you have amazing self-control, or have $400 to waste. Dont get me wrong, hours of fun are to be had with this excellent game, but the fact is that the developers and publishers are evil when it comes to the EPs. Even though playing as a vampire fireman who aspires to be a stunt double, living with robots, racists, and poodles, then watching them all try to kill each other is amazing, $400 for the full experience? Fuck you EA.

If you need to burn a few hours and have fun doing it, then this game is perfect for you. While the base game only has the basic game content, you can still spend hours building houses, making your Sims successful in life or hey, even killing them if that's what you're into. Each expansion adds hours of awesome stuff to lose yourself in, whether it be tons of new jobs with Ambitions or new types of characters with Supernatural, each one adds it's own little something.

While the game is incredibly addicting, it also has lots of bugs. Some bugs have been around since the start, like the game crashing (happens mostly when you haven't saved for several hours and you just finished building your dream home), others only turn up when you start installing expansions or custom content, like the strechy babies and the hand-bowl (not actually sure where this comes from).

So, yes, I recommend the game, but just be prepared for glitches, crashes and a slight addiction to new content.

There are very few games quite like The Sims. I would say that it's biggest flaw are the microtransaction advertisements being thrown into your face if you ever dare decide to login to the game. But it's a decent enough game. You could definitely get lost in it for hours and hours.

For example using the Seasons,Ambitions,and Supernatural I would go around setting people on fire during festivals and then after go to work as a fireman just to start even more fires inside the houses :P

I regret nothing except for the fact that I shouldve waited for the Steam Holliday Sales to save a little extra money xD

I played through the Sims 2 and really enjoyed it, so my kids insisted that I get this version, and we love it.  Basically the game is a "person" simulator, where you create a sim from scratch or use one thats pre-made.  You create their appearance and personality for a single sim or an entire family then drop them into a house (which you can create also) in a community of sims.  They then go about their business with you nudging them along.  Sims are generally automnomous but will not be truly happy or miserable unless you intervene.  The plethora of interactive objects, perks, locations, and other Sims make for a very dynamic experience.  Very much recommended, particularly if you have teenage girls.

The Sims 3 will offend long-time gamers with its DLC-overload marketing strategy, inefficient coding that makes the game slog evenly on laptops and powerful machines (especially if you make the mistake of attempting to mod this game). Even when its exploitation and laziness isn't shoving itself in your face, the gameplay contradicts the primary appeal of the game (it's a sandbox game that takes you away from its sandbox to clean your toilet, cook a meal, go to work, and do other "watch a bar fill up" menial chores far too often). If you're a creative type, you'll likely still have fun with this game, as the sandbox elements, while contradicted by the gameplay style, are quite extensive, and impressive if you're willing to put your time and money into them. But I've already sunk too large a portion of my life into this game with inadequate return on the investment.

I was actually disapointed in this game. I felt the sims needed too much micromanaging and were completely incapable of doing anything on their own. In the Sims 2, I was able to leave them alone for quite a significant amount of time while I told one of the other one or two sims in the house what to do and not have to worry. In this game, I leave them alone for 5 seconds and they've cancelled all my old orders and gone to watch TV (while their fun meter is already full) or some other useless activity. This would sometimes get to the point where they would completely ignore needs like going to the bathroom, eating and sleep just to watch TV if left alone.

Tons of microtransactions all over the place, I was constantly clicking on items in buy mode only to find out I would have to pay a couple bucks for them. Save that crap for the expansions or at least give me an option to hide it.

I would definitely reccomend getting the Sims 2 over this if you're considering a Sims game.

Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
---

With regard to accessibility for deaf/hoh gamers, I give The Sims 3 a 10/10.

Gameplay
The Sims talk, but the speech bubbles generally show what they are talking about or what they need. All of the indicators in game have a visual component, such as the need meters, and events in game are visible things.

Subtitles/Text
Because nothing requires subtitles, this section isn't necessary.

Chatting/Communicating
When playing with others, you can communicate by typing, so there are no problems here.

Best simulation game out there! The house-building aspect of the game is the winning factor for the decade long series. Realistic and easy-to-learn building tools, no worries for first-timers. For the hardcore builders or designers, certain tweaks and non-game changing cheats allows for sophisticated ideas of home design. Let your imagination run wild! Not forgetting the simulation aspect, there are countless wicked and crazy ideas for your Sims to engage in their everyday lifes. Tonnes of fun-filled intereractions ranging from your Sims working as an architect in the day, while studying astronomy at night, to being abducted by aliens the very next instance. Join the community, as we wait patiently for the next installment for the Sims 3, Island Paradise, where boat houses are common sight for the Sims living on Isla Paradiso, a new neighbourhood! After playing over 100 hours of the Sims 3 I can finally say that any trace of manhood is now completely gone.
All in all, the Sims 3 is a great addition to the Sims franchise and obviously follows it's predecessors with a huge amount of overpriced DLC/Expansion Packs. What were you expecting, though? It's developed by EA. The game is constantly being updated and patched by the developers, but unfortunately continues to have many glitches. The actual base game is very dull and if you want to have fun for more than 5-10 hours you should purchase expansions. The fact that you need expansions to continue having fun with the game is kind of a big no no, though. I do like the game along with my bundle of expansions but have recently grown tired of it after playing it non-stop for awhile.
The verdict is if you're interested in the game then go ahead in buy it. Just don't buy it blindly, know what you're getting into (Watch youtube videos, read reviews, etc.)

This isn't a game for all types, but given how many hours I've put into it it's safe to say it's addicting to those who enjoy this kind of game. Interior designers will enjoy building homes and businesses, while micromanagers will enjoy running every minute aspect of their Sims' lives. Roleplayers and worldbuilders/writers may enjoy the character building and social immersion (provided they can forgive the often dumb AI and occasional routing issues); it's your story to build. With a robust modding community (non-Steam though) and lots of content in the form of expansions, this game will have a very long shelf life. Just be sure to take advantage of Steam's sales when you're ready to throw money at it!

The freedom of The Sims 3 will inspire you with endless creative possibilities and amuse you with unexpected moments of surprise and mischief! Create over a million unique Sims and control their lives. Customize everything from their appearances, to their personalities and even the home of their dreams. Then, send your Sims out to explore new locations around town and to meet other Sims in the neighborhood. Go online to download exclusive content and show off your own creations to the world. With all-new quick challenges and rewarding game play, The Sims 3 gives you the freedom to choose whether (or not!) to fulfill your Sims destinies and make their wishes come true.

In The Sims 3, you basically create families (or play pre-made families) and live their lives as you would your own. The Sims franchise has improved throughout the years and I'm pretty satisfied with this version. If you have never played before, you can do almost everything you would in real life. Own a house, go to work, go to stores, go to friends houses, host parties, learn to cook, play chess, watch TV, and have relationships. It's a really fun game. The Create-A-Sim is also fantastic because you can customize basically every part of your Sim, including your build, clothes, and personality. It also has a memory book where it saves important parts of your Sim's life, such as you got a promotion or had a baby. It's also customizable. There are websites you can go to where you can download extra clothes and items. Pretty cool.

Create, build, and explore this fun filled adventure were you control the action. You get to create your very own Sim and build a house or a future for yourself. The options to the creativity in this game are endless. There are so many options to what you can do it can be overwhelming at times. You put attributes into your Sim and you can ether dictate every little action your Sim does or let the Sim make its own decisions. The world is massive and you can interact with pretty much everything. You can be what you want to be and do what you want to do. But with every action there is a equal and opposite reaction so remember that when playing this game. Its such an awesome adventure and a very addictive hard game to put down. Just the details that you can put into your home is mind boggling.  I have totally loved playing and creating in this game. If you like a big world were you control a Sim and control the outcomes to an extent then this is a definite do not miss game! I love it!

Well, as always, you either love the Sims, or you hate them. Personally, I played the first Sims on PC about 5-7 years ago, and fell in love with them. It t was such an amazing game to where you literally controlled people living their own lives (except you could really mess things up for your poor sims ;) ). Well, the Sims 3, just improves on the same basic, but addictive concept. Controlling your sims is as simple as ever, with a simple interface. It took me a couple of mins to get used to it, but after those couple of mins, I was living my sims dream of becoming the CEO of a major corporation! There is a lot more to do and explore in the Sims three than other versions, and an incredible amount of other sims to interact with. The only dissapointment in this game so far is the lack of starting items. I know the main money maker is the expansions so you get better loot, and other living options, but I think they are a little too skimpy on the items in the Sims 3 base game.

The Sims 3 has taken everything from the first two games, and then built on it (No pun intended)!

Not only are the graphics largely improved but they have taken into account some of it's previous faults and fixed them (or mostly fixed) which has turned the Sims 3 into, in my honest opinion, the best in the series. Add to this that you can FULLY customise anything in game, place items on angles, improved building mode, aging can be extended or disabled now and multistories and you have yourself an awesome simulation game!

Added bonuses include the exchange, where you can download items other players have created for use in game, as well as upload things you've created. A store to buy new content and a world editor! 

I think it's hard to find a disapointing feature with this game and I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who enjoys any or all of the above!
